title: Great Company
pros: There is no better REIT to work for. Large, sophisticated organization offers loads of professional expertise. Work load is manageable. Data is superb. Everyone in the company takes your call.
cons: They still think of their front line employees as being two notches below where they ought to. Say they promote from store level, but rarely do.

title: Not worth it.
pros: Pros: • The pay is okay for what it is, though it doesn’t feel like enough for everything you deal with • The schedule is predictable, which makes it easy to plan your week • You usually work alone, so there’s some independence
cons: Cons: • There’s a constant push to make sales, but you don’t see any personal reward or commission for it • Motivation from management feels forced — it’s more about driving company profits than genuinely helping customers • Customers are treated like dollar signs, and employees eventually start to feel the same way • It feels less like being a property manager and more like working in a call center • Higher-ups seem to spend more time watching cameras than spending time with their families or supporting their teams • The push to constantly ask customers for 5-star reviews feels fake and unauthentic • If you get hurt or have any issues, it’s brushed off or met with sarcasm instead of care • The work environment feels unprofessional and disconnected, with little real concern for employee well-being • The job can be slow, repetitive, and mentally draining • Overall, it feels like the company cares more about appearances and metrics than the people keeping things running

title: Toxic work environment and lack of respect for employees
pros: They hire quickly and the recruitment process is very fast. The interviews are smooth, and they offer opportunities for people with customer service experience.
cons: The training process was unprofessional and abusive. I was assigned to different properties with no proper guidance and asked to clean entire buildings instead of being trained for customer service tasks. Some managers constantly disrespected me, mocked my English accent, and left me alone without support. I witnessed bullying, unsanitary conditions, and a complete lack of empathy from supervisors. When I reported issues to the district manager, no action was taken — instead, I was blamed. The workload was excessive, the environment toxic, and I was treated like a cleaner, not as a Customer Service Self storage manager in training.

title: Toxic. Deceptive.
pros: Maternity leave. 2 supportive supervisors. Work from home.
cons: Low pay. Low commission. Toxic environment. Angry customers. Working weekends and holidays. No quality of life or work-life balance. Monotonous heavy workload. System issues affect income. Company does not care about its hardest working department, that is sales. Upper management keeps increasing our sales metrics without a pay raise. The Call Center production average used to be 28% back in 2022, now the expectation is 36% with most agents topping 40%. The company has become an evil version of itself by becoming greedier and greedier since Covid. They’ve hired overseas employees who they can pay lower wages but the US customers hate speaking to the overseas workers. Customer care is atrocious, I’ve never seen a company mistreat their customers the way Public Storage does. They raise the rent on customers frequently, and customers can never reach an in-office staff member for any assistance. Sales has to take the heat of all of its angry customers due to the lack of staff at the properties. Upper management is too micro-manage-y with constant fear mongering of termination. 4 supervisors were just terminated and overseas has the majority of managers now. Upper management has been promising the sales department “shift bids” for over 3 years with no intention of ever letting any sales employee have the opportunity to change their shift to better their quality of life. They’re just dangling the carrot as a tactic to lessen their high turnover. Unkept promises. As of July 1st, they only allow 8 call outs per year. Sales employees call out due to strenuous work schedules, and high burn out. Be prepared to call out sick when you need to take a rest from the toxic mental workload.

title: Easy but toxic culture
pros: easy work Self managed Great place to grow and learn about property manegnemt if you see yourself doing this in the future
cons: Starter job Toxic when comes to cliqs and long tenure or housed employees to take this job personal and believe they are indeed the owners of these property’s. Instead of an employee who can be removed in 48 hours

title: Environment good, pay bad
pros: Feeling like a family rather than just coworkers
cons: Low pay and raises are not based on performances

title: Hours are nice but......
pros: Work hours are fine. Team Enviroment Good benefits Great support from District managers
cons: Zero support from senior management Micromanaging from senior management If they want you out of a position, they will set you up for failure. Yet they claim to care about thier employees Metric based High turnover due to senior regional management

title: Great entry level opportunity
pros: Great entry level position. Ability to manager yourself and your own day.
cons: Micro-management, heavy work load and expectations, minimal opportunity for growth.

title: We're growing, and so am I!
pros: Public Storage is a super company with great people. We are the industry leader and way out in front from an innovation standpoint.
cons: Recent move to Frisco added 30 minutes to my drive. But I don't mind.

title: Great place to work for if you are disciplined and able to follow sales scripts and process.
cons: istent hours with plenty of overtime options. *Work remotely from home. *Bonus through sales incentives and competitions. *Uncapped commission. *PTO and paid sick days. *Supportive management.

title: Company doesn’t care
pros: Not a lot of oversight
cons: Company doesn’t care and customers are bad

title: Company overlook
pros: They work with your overall needs for scheduling mainly depending on your DM.
cons: Pay could be better, often short handed, we train ourselves.

title: Stop the insanity
pros: Team mates, 401k with Match. Insurance options Apartments available at select locations. PTO is calculated per pay period, not monthly.
cons: As a long time tenured Property Manager, this job has changed for the worst. With the introduction of MPV(Multiple Property Visits) and 3 before me, the ability to communicate effectively with the DMs has diminished greatly. MPV leaves locations unsupervised and at greater risk for break-ins and mischief. Training needs to be longer than 9 days! WE are not custodians/landscapers! We are supposed to be helping our customers and creating an atmosphere where the customers/tenants feel safe leaving their items in our care. Instead they are met with empty offices and no idea if there is someone onsite for assistance.

title: Horrible
pros: Nothing honestly. Schedule is supposed to be ready atleast 3 weeks in advance but it’ll change days before it starts
cons: DM is a joke. RM is the worst. High turnover

title: a little more than min wage
pros: solidarity - i did hw
cons: people get mad when they can't get into their units for non-payment

title: Awful
pros: There are absolutely no pros at all to this job.
cons: Every single thing. You are overworked, underpaid, and stretched thin doing the job of two people.

title: Best job I've ever had!
pros: Zero housing costs. Set schedule, same days/hours always. 75% of up to 8% 401k employer match. Competitive bonuses. No micro managing.
cons: Unreliable help. Poor training. No actual co-workers during your regular work schedule.

title: Worst company to work
pros: Coworkers are best with works
cons: Low pay! Wants you to work two different locations double jobs same pay Always some issues ( Computers doesn’t work Restroom is not work ) Always management wants you to clean Abandon good never pay extra they don’t want pay vendor Poor management team Company wants from you to much Happy to leave this company and working Extra Space ten times better company then Public Storage less stres

title: Worker bees feeding the queen Joe
pros: It’s not constant face to face interaction with customers like with retail or restaurant. There is SOME downtime. Company housing is super affordable.
cons: It doesn’t matter how much you bend over backwards for your position, for your boss, for your bosses boss. You are still a worker bee at the end of the day, working your tail off for upper management and stockholders to get a fat check. I was commended time and time again by higher management for pulling off the impossible or going above and beyond, but it’s all just their mental manipulation to keep you satisfied at their unethical pay rate. A pay rate that at least guarantees you to qualify for government benefits like Medicaid and foodstamps.

title: too many changes
pros: great coworkers and a good work life balance
cons: too many changes and layoffs in a short period of time

title: Find Better
cons: istent work due to multiple franchise locations. No location micro-managing, it is a Self-managing position. Flexible. Offer housing to those who qualify and the availability.

title: It's good enough
pros: Love my DM, hours are good.
cons: Working multiple properties, having to clean up after co workers, the pay is terrible.

title: Worst job of my life
pros: This job had absolutely nothing going for it. It was the vocational equivalent to a miserable and complete and utter rip-off.
cons: Everything. I would suggest to the reader to think of positions they've held in the past - good or bad - and whatever redeeming qualities such positions may have had - anything - a decent culture, pay, commute, tech - whatever - I guarantee you, you will not find it here: just the polar opposite. Again, this job had utterly nothing going for it. Nothing. Everyday was a bad day and the pay hardly comped for it. Hardly. I could write paragraphs but, trust me, ANY other job will offer a less stress-to-pay ratio than this lemon. I cannot for the life of me understand why anyone would find this position suitable in any regard. The company asks for the moon while giving you next to nothing. I've never seen anything like it and hope not to in the future.

title: It’s fine
pros: * FREE onsite living (if an apartment is available and if your DM approves you living there) * save money on gas when you work at home * the job can be easy certain times of the year when it’s slow * working individually, if that’s a plus to you * not a lot of micromanagement from DM *there is a monthly bonus available if you can get it, but they’ve made it more difficult to earn. it’s $150 a month if you get it. * there is also a regional bonus available which ranges from $100-$2000 but is very difficult to get chosen for it because only a few people are chosen per region * set work hours and opportunity to leave early if you contact management
cons: * they’ve changed our scheduling. A manager used to work 1 property every day for the most part. You had plenty of time to get work done usually and some down time in the office. Now, they schedule us working 2 properties a day multiple times a week. Meaning, you start at 1 store, you’re expected to complete everything by 1:30pm, then drive to the next location and complete everything there. It can be stressful and frustrating at times. You do get mileage reimbursed between stores. * customers can be absolutely insane and rude

title: Not for me
pros: Compensation is on par or above the market
cons: Very little recognition for accomplishments. All districts are different with their own challenges and this seems to be ignored.

title: Beware
pros: Regular business hours workdays/mostly part time
cons: Everything. No set schedule, corporate doesn’t care about anyone and they will fire you for any minor inconvenience to the company.

title: Overworked & Underpaid
pros: Great customer relationship building if you are scheduled reliably at one or two of the same properties, lots of self-management, kind district manager
cons: Split shifts between two properties with all tasks done in 4 hours twice a day and yet the lowest paid property manager role in the market with the least amount of managerial influence to actually run a property. Flawed business model resulting in high stress across the board and horrible retention. DM is kind and good at their job but overwhelmed with work and tasks, minimal middle management positions that are only paid during specific times, poor division of responsibilities, massive lack of actual ability to manage property, role is essentially glorified custodian that makes collection calls and helps people fill out an agreement on an ipad by repeating a script. high-tier customer service expected for lowest-in-industry pay by highest-performing industry leader.

title: Great coworkers
pros: The other property managers were very friendly and the district manager was too
cons: The pay wasn't the best and you have to deal with critters/snakes/etc.

title: None
pros: The company is excellent. Just need to know what you are doing .
cons: Learning to manage the property and learning the ropes of the job

title: Horrible Company all the Managers are Quitting
pros: There are no pros at this company
cons: They've had 4 out of 7 Supervisors quit in the last 6 months. They've let go of most of their U.S. based workforce and instead have decided to outsource all their employees from the Philippines.

title: Thankless
pros: Can't think of any pros
cons:
Toxic workplace 
Low pay
Job description misleading

title: Barely above minimum wage
pros: Only pros most of the coworkers if you are not working alone.
cons: Pay and virtually everything is not worth the time and gas having to be spent to go to other stores which I found I didn't even make enough money at the job.

title: There are pros and cons...
pros: There are some locations with really great employees.
cons: For as much money as they make, its unbelieveable that they cannot simply have a worker in the office during business hours. I spend more time waiting on someone to let me in to get my auction unit, than anything else.

title: The apartment is the only benefit
pros: If you’re lucky you can get an apartment for free. No micromanaging, you’re by yourself at properties and as long as you have good time management skills you’re fine.
cons: However the apartment attaches you to the job and makes it very hard to leave unless you have an alternative living situation, or financially can afford to leave. I used to love my job but recently they started having managers going to two properties in one day, but also mandate you take a lunch so you essentially have 3.5 hours at each property but they want you to still get 8 hours of work done at each property. They have been complaining the properties aren’t up to cleanliness standards but refuse to acknowledge that we don’t have the time to do everything we need. There is no work life balance because you’re expected to be there 8 1/2 hours five days a week… 9:30-6 Monday - Friday and 9:30-5 on weekends. They do not close early for ANY holiday, they close for Thanksgiving, Christmas, and New Years Day that’s it. They have been getting rid of golf carts throughout the company making it harder for managers to get things done. There is no accountability when people don’t do their jobs, it gets pushed under the rug. They don’t want us to tell customers information about why the office is closed, and they keep giving customers ridiculous rent increases, but assume we can keep the customer even tho it’s their business practices driving them to the competition… also since we’re barely interacting with them we never know if they’re vacating to keep them as a customer. As an employee if you need a storage unit you get treated like every other customer, no employee discount, no free unit and no special privileges and they pay us on the day the late fee hits, when this was brought up to management we were told to pay early with the second pay check in the month. There’s so much more I could go on, but honestly his job is not what it used to be… we’re just overworked bees making the queen richer and richer with nothing to show for ourselves.

title: What a joke and a big waste of your time if you're smart.
pros: Not much pros here maybe you might meet a few cool people if you're lucky but company-wise and pay wise culture wise no pros only cons.
cons: For someone such as myself who's had a perfect record with zero write-ups and an overachiever and a circle of excellence winner...... So hear me out and yes I was fired recently for something absolutely absurd that could have easily been solved with a write-up instead but the reason why they fired me is because I kept on pushing and requesting information about pay raises and why after two and a half years and winning awards how come I haven't received one and what is the criteria for a potential raise and how can I improve and why would this be a subject that cannot be answered I had to have blown my mind trying to figure this out for a long time with this company. I've tried and tried and emailed different channels in corporate and everyone ignores you when you ask about money what a damn shame. Let me first start off by saying this, It's all about the shareholders from the top round table and it trickles all the way to the DMs and it stops there. Beware. It's a damn shame but this company loves to boast and brag about how it's one of the best places to work but they don't want to pay their employees nearly what they should be paying them. They damn sure take advantage of you especially if you're a hard worker. . Be ready to be discriminated on and used and abused and taken advantage of while the CEO soaks in 8 to 10 million per year salary. They don't care about their tenants and I have many stories to prove this, long story short it doesn't matter if you're in the ICU on your deathbed they will sell your stuff it doesn't matter if you have cancer and have survived it three times and literally just got out of a hospital from surgery they will sell your stuff it doesn't matter if you have 50 cents left on your balance they will sell your stuff zero morals. This company has come a long way from it's original roots in which were genuine and honest. But over the years, public storage has transformed into a political monopoly ran by money hungry corporate blue collar folks that have designed the framework to load their pockets with so much money they don't know what to do with it . So rich they become greedy and they will probably never take care of their employees and pay them and treat them the way they should be. Lots of favoritism as well, DMs usually only care about one thing...... getting their bonus! As a manager it's sad to say but it doesn't matter how many work orders you put in or how many times you try to get something repaired or fixed on the property they just don't want to spend any money to the point where you end up doing it your damn self and that's pathetic. This company will use you up and then the moment you try to defend yourself or start asking valid questions that deserve valid answers, they will frown upon that avoid it at all costs and then hang you up to dry The very first chance they get whether it's on a technicality or anything just so they don't have to talk about it. I used to say I loved my job but once I uncovered the truth...I realized quickly this company is a scumbag company. Oh yeah and if you're a hard worker and you think that reaching out to a corporate employee will do you any good we'll think again because all they do is ignore you .... They don't give two "you know what's" about property managers as we are the scum of the company and they don't care about our opinions nor do they care about our living situations or our well-being there is no culture here and there is no appreciation and there's no money. I've worked a lot of companies and I've always given it my 110 if not more percent effort and still to this day I do the same because I won't let any company change who I am in the way I perform I do a great job for myself and my self only but I can tell you that this company does not deserve people like me. Sad but true. This company will implode due to its own demoralized actions and for the unfair treatment unfair pay and despicable corporate office decision making. Everybody in the end gets what they deserve and public storage has got another thing coming.

title: Alright, can do better

title: Salary of a Data scientist
pros: Data Volume and Variety: Public Storage likely manages a diverse and large-scale dataset, offering opportunities to work on complex, real-world problems. Industry Stability: The self-storage industry is stable and growing, providing a secure and long-term career environment. Impactful Insights: Your analyses could directly impact customer satisfaction, operational efficiency, and business strategies. Technology Adoption: Opportunities to work with cutting-edge tools and technologies in data analytics, machine learning, and cloud computing. Cross-functional Collaboration: The chance to work with various departments, enhancing business acumen and communication skills.
cons: Limited Innovation Opportunities: The self-storage industry might not have as many cutting-edge AI/ML challenges compared to tech-heavy industries. Data Constraints: Depending on the company's infrastructure, access to high-quality, diverse data may be limited. Narrow Focus: Projects may revolve around operational optimization or customer segmentation, which could feel repetitive over time. Pace of Change: The industry may adopt new technologies or data-driven practices at a slower pace compared to tech startups. Resource Limitations: Smaller teams or budgets might limit experimentation with advanced models or large-scale tools.

title: Pros and cons
pros: and cons
cons: Terrible benefits: 3 holidays, no paid parental leave, relatively poor health insurance. Awful pay for frontline customer-facing employees. Hard to feel much company pride about that. The office space is textbook "soulless corporate '90s", and it's a real drag when you haven't seen the sunshine in 8-9 hours.

title: District Manager
pros: Decent pay, Great Team and Leadership
cons: Lots of "fires" to put out. Not much time to be with your employees and there is a lot of administrative work that you have to do daily

title: It was pretty good
pros: Can’t complain honestly, work is not too bad.
cons: No one to rely on but yourself, but a lot of people would take that as a pro.

pros: it was okie for a first time job
cons: just we had to work on sundays but they were slower days

title: Too many stores, not enough employees
pros: I was lucky enough to have some amazing coworkers who made it easy to learn the little things that make the job that much easier. If it wasn't for them, i don't think i would have stayed as long as i did.
cons: They expected myself and 2 other people (not always together usually by ourself) to run the office, keep the 4 story facility clean, and deal with late payments with barely any oversight from management.

title: Strong company, weak culture
pros: Company is flush with money and will be around for a long time. Comp for DM and up is very competative.
cons: Mindset of favoritism and political games overshadows what could otherwise be a good place to work. Rules and discipline are applied with little consistency ultimately driving to promote yes men and stifle constructive feedback.

title: Good position, good company, awfully quiet most of the time
pros: The coworkers I had were all incredibly supportive, patient, and quick to help when needed. Pay was fair and the job's tasks themselves aren't all that challenging for the avg. person
cons: Working at multiple different locations in your district in the same week. Most of the more tenured staff live on site in apartments on property or have a "home store" so they only work at one location, so if you're new you'll be what's called a "Relief Manager" and cover properties on the days the residential manger is off. That parts not so bad, but in the district in which I worked I could be at a property that was 8-10 minutes away from me, and the next day one that was 45 minutes away.

title: Employees are bottom of the food chain
pros: None this company is not a good company to work for.
cons: Working multiple locations in one day. Can't find other employees to stay long enough to actually get help with each property. DM's don't really care about you only their bonuses. They will go months with fixing the a/c in office and let you suffer. They don't have employees backs just care about lining their pockets...

title: Blah
pros: It's a job. Barely if you like being dehumanized
cons: Too many to cover. Very low wages. No raises.

title: Stop closing stores
pros: A steady but underpaid check
cons: They close stores for half the business day. They think they are saving money when actually they are losing money. They are overworking store staff with unrealistic tasks to be completed in half the time at two locations. They are losing customers because no one is ever in the office or on site. Customers at locations that are now Kiosks are angry. They don't want to use the kiosk, they want to walk in the office and deal with the manages as they always have

title: Over seas outsourcing has taken over
pros: None really. Commission is decent but nowhere near what it used to be.
cons: Decreased commission, firing US employees in favor of Outsourcing to the Philippines, Columbia and India. The company cares about numbers and profits, not people. Keeping their shareholders happy is their main concern. No career advancement opportunities.

title: Not recommended
pros: 1- Diverse Team: My team was quite diverse, consisting of individuals from various backgrounds, including Hispanic, African-American, Asian, and Caucasian.
cons: 1-Limited Paid Holidays: The company offers only three(3) paid holidays, which can be quite restrictive. Chronic Understaffing: As the company continues to expand and add new properties, they fail to hire additional staff or implement procedures to alleviate the workload, leading to increased pressure on employees. Lack of Effective Leadership: My supervisor was under significant stress and had difficulty communicating effectively with the team. He often delegated tasks without proper guidance and struggled to set boundaries, unable to say "No" to requests. Frugality on Compensation and Benefits: The company is very cost-conscious, offering minimal compensation, limited paid holidays, and basic benefits. Expensive and Basic Insurance Packages: Despite being a large company, the insurance options offered are both costly and provide only basic coverage. Minimal Team Building Activities: Due to the company's reluctance to allocate funds, there is almost no budget for team-building events. If managers wish to organize any activities, they are expected to pay out of pocket. Poor Work-Life Balance: Particularly during month-end and quarter-end periods, I often had to work up to 60 hours a week, increasing the likelihood of errors due to fatigue.

title: Not to bad of a job
pros: Easy work and training. Get to choose when you want to go to lunch.
cons: Working on the weekends and holidays

title: Experience
pros: Ability to manage the property without micromanaging and having a set schedule every week makes it easy to know when you will be off.
cons: There were no increase pay when accepting the property manager position.

title: The worst employer
pros: Large company, but that's it
cons: One has to try hard to find a worse company to work for than Public Storage (look no further than other reviews here, CEO approval ratings, or Reddit). I've worked at many large corporation, which all have their pros and cons, but none have been as terrible as an employer as Public Storage. Senior management cares about nothing but shareholder profits, there's zero leadership or concern for employee wellbeing. Archaic practices and zero accountability from all levels of management. I work at corporate, but field employees have it even worse, with the workforce constantly being reduced and managers strained for resources.  The benefits are also sub-par, and there are only 3 paid holidays a year. Do yourself a factor and look for another organization to join if you value both your career and your mental health.

cons: Working weekends no holidays off but Chris new years and thanksgiving

title: Best job I’ve ever had
pros: Public Storage is the most organized and professional company I have ever worked for. The senior leaders to the District level I have only witnessed professionalism and kind interactions. In addition, the role includes a diverse list of responsibilities and you must be able to multi-task relentlessly. If you’re into that I think you would love it. The employees that I work with are passionate about customers and create a welcoming atmosphere for their coworkers and customers. One of my favorite things about working here is how passionate the company is about the brand and what it represents. The facilities are maintained and clean and as a DM I have the ability to impact the business every day. If you care about the customer experience and brand integrity then you will love working here.
cons: Zero cons. Great pto and benefits.

title: Public Storage is a great place to work.
pros: The call center environment was excellent and well-structured until the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic. In response, the company transitioned employees to a remote work setup. This transition was handled seamlessly and efficiently, ensuring minimal disruption. Managers consistently provided constructive feedback, fostering continuous improvement and driving optimal results.
cons: Shift availability tends to favor top-performing employees, making it challenging for others to secure the most desirable schedules. Additionally, achieving top-tier commissions can be difficult without access to the best shifts and strict adherence to the prescribed script.

title: Ok company
pros: Helping customers. Benefits ok. Most district managers are good people.
cons: Rats, and nothing you can tell customers makes it right. Buildings are starting to fall apart and constant leaks when it rains. And you can't forget the high rate increases and they don't just happen once a year, it can happen every three months. You are told to help the customers but you can only put a decrease in once a year and then the easiest way is to make them move units.

title: Terrible
pros: Best and only pro is if you can become a resident property manager. Live rent free in a 2bed apartment. Currently trying to automate the whole system to they might get rid of resident managers all together very soon.
cons: If you are a resident manager you then forfeit raises and get state mandated minimum wage. They are slow to update. Still using tech and programs from 2005. If your area is under staffed then the only way to get time off is to be in the hospital. Even then you have a small window to return or you will be fired. Zero room to grow within the company. If you are hired to work at the office level then you will never move up. Noticed in my entire region all District Managers, Regional Managers were referred from friends who already had the position. They hire people they know like family and friends in those positions. High expectations and demands and your only recognition is a pat on the back and “now try to beat this month next month” They are not picky in who they hire. You will work with people who have serious substance abuse issues.

title: Awful
pros: I used to have an amazing manager but that was about it.
cons: Awful Benefits, pay is sub par, 5 days a week in office, unorganized, don't care about corporate employees, treat you like a child and always keeping tabs

title: Manageable
pros: No weekends are good to have family time.
cons: Higher pay is possible for ALL field employees.

title: Great
pros: Great people to work with.
cons: I do not have bad remarks

title: Unfair Work Environment and High Expectations
pros: You work alone 9 times out of 10. Work is generally easy. Communication amongst team members using emails and phone calls is usually smooth and helpful. They pay per mile you drive with your own car only when you’re clocked in and even potentially insure you if you’re in an accident while clocked in.
cons: tantly get updated with new changes through emails. They use a computer software for all of their work called iChamp/WebChamp, which makes communicating and working as a team, much easier.

title: It's not for everyone..
pros: There is no "boss" hovering over your shoulder all day and a good mix of duties to perform
cons: The pay does not reflect the amount of work you do.

title: Former Employee
pros: It was ok until I left
cons: Dealing with customers that have payment problems

title: Worst ever
pros: None… at first the resident manager role seemed fantastic but it literally a trap.
cons: As a resident manager you forfeit raises. Worked for PS for almost 11 years and was still only making $10/hr because “you have the apartment”… ok that’s fantastic and all but I can’t even afford groceries. The health insurance coverage they offer is overpriced and crappy. The upper management plays favorites. No diversity… was on a mostly female team and there was so much gossip and drama it felt like being in high school. PS was only hiring young girls in their early 20s and it was super annoying. Our KTP was constantly praised but all of her new hires were calling me constantly to answer their questions because they state they were never taught something…wouldn’t surprise me since her kids were always in the office and the DMs didn’t care…

title: Great depending on your supervisor
pros: Autonomy and not strapped in a single location.
cons: You are the point of contact for EVERYTHING

title: Stable company
pros: Storage will always be needed.
cons: Could be higher bonus amount.

title: Interview
pros: Descent pay, stock options work flexibility
cons: Pay not based on experience just on who will take what is offered.

title: Working
pros: Quiet Environment to work in
cons: Sometimes you have to run multiple stores

title: If corporate cared, it would be a great company
pros: Flexible hours, opportunity for Voluntary Time Off. Bonus.
cons: Where do I start? They have minute metrics and oversight on everything a call center agent is supposed to, then hamstring us in the ability to do our job properly when Property Managers are never there to help customers paying cash, to assist customers in finding the right size etc. I've have customers call just to vent about rats, water damage etc to items just to get the run around from corporate. We have "online price matching" which is a joke, because the prices simply don't match. Our systems are down 20% (approximately) of the time allowing us to fail making a transaction...which is how we get our bonus. I hear the pay is $13 an hour for PMs. What kind of quality do you really expect when you can get better pay and benefits at Starbucks. I can go further, but I'll stop right there.

title: Stop Gap
pros: Steady Hours= Steady Pay Management tries to accommodate Daytime Shifts
cons: You WILL be working Weekends Benefits are so-so Vacation accrual is slow Little Advancement opportunities (past a certain point.)

title: Good co workers
pros: I worked with lovely co workers
cons: Job in general, they expect one person to do everything on a property and help the customers, which for smaller locations that was fine but larger locations it was near impossible. Especially when you had to do more than one property a day. To hey kept add responsibility and things we had to do and some of it like the rent by phone was not necessary. They have a call center that is not only no helpful but down right bad at there job as well which constantly made customers upset at the pm. I think the main thing is I could do the work but it wasn't worth only making $13 a hour.

title: It's cool
pros: Not hard. Work alone most of time. Nice training so you know what you're doing if not you just call and some will help. Possibility to live in one of their apartments.
cons: They just don't pay enough. You work alone but your coworker may talk about you behind your back. Weird clique-like vibes sometimes. Not diverse. No team comradery. Not getting 40 hours like I thought. No set schedule. Just random, can't live like that.

title: Toxic Work Environment
pros: Benefits (Healthcare, Vision, Dental, Renters), Employee Connection
cons: No work/life balance (especially for on-site residents), low pay, high expectations, no salary increase under same role, little opportunity for promotion, unorganized upper management, money hungry company (base employees/customers)

title: Decent Company Lots of work
pros: Quick promotions, stipend for uniforms, Full time hours
cons: Low pay, lots of work, lots to learn, a car is necessary to drive between properties and to go to banks

title: predatory management, scapegoating common.
pros: The hours were consistent, and the territory was small.
cons: Limited pay, no compensation for travel, and limited guidance on processes added or antiquated systems at older properties.

title: It is Mutli Unit Management
pros: Company is stable and are very structured in how they want processes completed.
cons: Some decisions are made with the expenses in mind and not looking out for the well being of the employees or customers.

title: Good job for teens but they expect adults to live on the baby pay
pros: get to work alone, learn about property management, and leasing, and can develop customer service skills.
cons: pay typically starts at 16.50 if your lucky, will have to work in the rain, snow, AND HEAT. Pay gets bumped down to 12.00 an hour if you live on the property as if the rent there isn't covered by the revenue they make off a the property each month (over 150,000 monthly).

title: Good company
pros: Manager is really good to employees, work independently, fellow property managers are really nice and helpful anytime you need assistance.
cons: Have to get a required amount of Google reviews which is difficult if you are at properties that are not very busy. Pay is lower than other storage facilities.

title: DM Public Storage
pros: Gain multi unit leadership experience. Company is profitable and will continue to be profitable. If you stay long enough, you will gain shares of Public Storage.
cons: If you are currently a DM, this may not be the job for you. Pay is below market average. Little to no autonomy to fix customer problems. Company spends as little as possible on properties, will wait until you are threatened with citations before violations are fixed. I was personally cited for landscaping issues that the company would not pay for. That was the end for me.

title: P storage
pros: Meet cool people in the job
cons: Lots of work, minimal help, a lot of guesswork, way too much responsibility for 14 an hour

title: Public Storage Review
pros: Good Manager, Good company culture.
cons: If that is a CDD property you are working at, be prepared to work multiple locations within an 8 hour shift doing the job of 2 or more people to the level of burnout. (Managers are not to be blamed, they are nice. The actual culprits (Board of Directors) are the people who decide if you region needs to overwork or not

title: Not terrible, but not great.
pros: Flexible scheduling, potential for housing, good team locally with wealth of experience
cons: On site live in managers take a pay cut to barely over minimum wage to live on property, long term customers leave with egregious price increases, budgets for what should be simple maintenance jobs are allocated to different departments resulting in issues at older properties not getting properly fixed if at all, district manager jobs are hired from external hires rather than internal promotions most of the time, pay rate is not commiserate for the sheer amount of different jobs expected of workers(cleaning, maintenance, security, collections, just to name a few for just above minimum wage), only 30 minutes allotted for lunches

title: Great place to build a career
pros: Good people and lots of upside to career growth and responsibility
cons: Not too much on the cons. Remote work options could be better for those who have a long commute.

title: Need to focus on the employees/ property management
pros: Can meet different people from different backgrounds
cons: Company pays less then any other storage facility and it is one of the largest facility, alot of there properties need remodel ( flatten and rebuild) too many issues, the higher up focus on giving property managers all the work in meetings but don't want to pay the property management proper pay,

title: public storage review
pros: work independently, interacting with customers, software systems
cons: all the daily tasks required, the pay and benefits arent very good.

title: It's great for experience and a long time career
pros: Great experience, healthy and professional work environment. You get raises and that's only about a couple cents. I'm not sure if there's a cap, so if you plan to have a long term job then this could be it.
cons: Pay is not a living wage and crappy customers but what job doesn't?

title: Not great
pros: If you live on property it's great
cons: They can make you feel worthless if you let them

title: Property Manager
pros: Easy job duties Downtime sometimes Flexible work schedule
cons: Low pay No promotional opportunities Management won’t write up or fire bad employees Slowly being replaced by AI Glorified janitor Selling customers items in auction

title: Profit over People
pros: Good benefits, consistent hours, independent work environment
cons: Ridiculous quotas, random policy changes, unfriendly management

title: Work duties excessive
pros: PTO time, Sick days off
cons: Excessive micromanaging, low pay, traveling to work two properties a day, and toxic work environment

title: Do not work here
pros: None. Run far away. Don’t let them fool you.
cons: You work by yourself, you get to be a janitor. This company will recruit you promising you so much but they are lying to you. I worked here for almost 20 years and if I could go back I would never work here. The district managers are on power trips and they will fire you for some dumb things and they will make you work by yourself and expect you to keep a large property clean by yourself. So you will literally be a janitor but will get paid meager wages. Do not work here. No matter what they promise you. They are lying.

title: Pretty great stepping stone, not a career
pros: Great coworkers and stable hours
cons: No internal growth once promoted to a property manager

title: We are being replaced
pros: Days go by fast. That's all I can come up with.
cons: Insurance costs you 40% of your pay. If you live in the apartment you get paid 10- read it- 10 dollars an hour. This leaves many unable to leave bc they cannot afford to. They will also never fix any issues with the apartment, kinda like how they won't pay to fix things on property. Everyone saying there's not much to do, is just not doing what's expected. Not that I blame them, but there is always lots to do. Too much in fact. They will expect you to empty abandoned units so they don't have to pay an outside company. They will ignore all cx complaints, and pm concerns. They won't even let you put presumably items at your desk or use colorful pens or paper. This place sucks. Hard work is rewarded with more work. Dms and above have lots of ideas of how to manage a property, with zero knowledge of how it actually works. I can't wait to quit.

title: HR is a joke
pros: Good people for the most part and a relatively cut and dry job.
cons: The company seems to be promoting the people that cause employees to leave;in particular they like to promote people who misgender people and laugh it off as if its a big joke.

title: Only work if necessary
pros: Most days are pretty easy Decent benefits for part time work
cons: Low pay Bad management You’re just a face to scream at for greedy company decisions No room for advancement

title: Overworked
pros: Working by yourself, and walking.
cons: Being blamed for no security for break ins.

title: Good Company overall
pros: The company is very understanding if an employee has health issues when it comes to attendance. If you work hard the company will acknowledge the effort you put in.
cons: My only suggestion to the CEO and Senior Management in order to keep good employees who have no choice but to look for a better paying job. Keep in mind many of your employees are single living on one income with inflation and the high cost of housing. PS is a large corporation I think management should discuss with the CEO about paying customers service agents who have a lot of experience should be paid minimum of $18.00 an hour. It would be beneficial to the company by keeping good employees plus the budget for training new employees would degrees and lower turnover rate.

title: Do not recommend.
pros: It is relatively easy and simple.
cons: Downgrading, unfulfilling, and inconsistent overall.

title: average job
pros: easy work and money, free apartment for minimum wage
cons: 9:30am-6pm, must work a weekend, most employees barley work, isn’t worth it if you don’t want an apartment

title: Stay Away, Narcissistic Trap
pros: Some of the tenets are very nice. Some overtime. Nothing more
cons: Everything is horrible. I’m not exaggerating!!! You work for lint in your wallet. Corporate’s treatment of It’s employees is that of a domestic abuser, the criminally deranged, like you see on cold case tv shows. Beyond awful. Company culture is false friendship like prison, Bergen-belson, concentration camp. If you are a good worker, stay that way, not here, you get gaslighted, narcissized, abused, lied to, there’s nothing good at all. I’m better off homeless squatting on government land. You loose all dignity and self worth. Your body, mind, emotions go to hades. Everything public storage will twist and distort everything exemplary about stellar employees. Think the regime of Stalin. Dangerous neighborhoods are where the properties are located. Bring your own weapons to protect yourself. You are your only backup. Absolutely calloused, obtuse, management and coworkers. There’s nothing good to be had with this company. Nothing

title: Good work life balance

Work life balance
Supervisor

title: Maybe PT not FT

title: Keep looking…
pros: Autonomy. At least, it used to be.
cons: Almost everything else. Company is allowing the properties to crumble down around their ears, including the newly built properties and the older, acquired properties. PS has eliminated office hours and now requires appointments. PS management is not interested in showing up for these appointments and try to avoid them if possible. Employees are treated with less respect than janitors and at a fraction of the pay. Benefits, if taken, can take up to half of an employee’s pay. Three paid holidays per month and if that day falls on a regular day off, you won’t get paid at all. Reimbursement for travel is almost nonexistent while travel is demanded. I could go on. Keep looking; every other storage company does better by its employees than this one.

title: Good for starting your career
pros: The job is not complicated, flexible hours, and standard benefits.
cons: The job while not complicated is most of the time extensive. The pay definitely does not match the amount of work you will do.

title: worthless dead end job
pros: no vertical mobility, horrible pay, high expectations.
cons: They don't pay enough for anyone working there to care.

pros: Flexible schedule , nice people
cons: Work holidays no Time in a half

title: Pay could be higher
pros: Not difficult to grasp the role. There are many responsibilities, but nothing that will take up your whole day doing. This position is very much you get out what you put into it. If you go above and beyond, it is very easy to climb to a certain point. Then it becomes a matter of having the correct experience.
cons: Pay could be higher. Depending on the location, you will have to deal with difficult or needy customer. I have had to kick homeless people off property before for trying to sleep their overnight.

title: Property Manager

cons: Pay, lazy co-workers. Upper management does not treat employees fair. Favoritism. High turn over. Overworked. You don't get rewarded for doing a good job. You get rewarded if you play the corporate politics game.

title: Property manager

title: Offshore Outsourcing to Save Company $$$
pros: Work from home. Supervisors are there to support you. Fun coworkers.
cons: Only job I've ever had where the longer you work for them, the less you make. Corporate employees may be happy and well paid, but call center employees have seen their bonuses go down month over month, year over year. They have found a way to make you work more for less, and in an effort to save the company even more money and increase their profits, they are now outsourcing most of their sales and CS business to the Philippines and Columbia, South America. Very little sales opportunities for the more expensive US employees. Call volume has dropped tremendously. Sales manager and team supervisors are either planning their exist strategies, or have already moved on. This has definitely become a sinking ship.

title: If you like to be micromanaged about everything this is your company.
pros: Most of the district managers are great and it’s a financially stable company.
cons: The culture is terrible. There was high performing district manager that unfortunately passed away while on company time. He had been with the company over 10 years. There was not one email sent out from the executive team or mention of him in the monthly company newsletter sending condolences or highlighting the person he was. That’s the culture of this company. The conditions of the facilities are just like the culture . I wouldn’t let my friends or family rent from them. Everything is a bandaid fix when it needs surgery.

cons: There is no advancement in this company. You either come from the old boys club as a district manager or not. There is no room for a property manager to do well enough to eventually be promoted to district or regional manager. Dream on.

pros: Great work and life balance

pros: Work from home is great

title: Shady place to work for
pros: Get two days off consecutively most of the time.
cons: Can't move up in the company. Pay is low. Relief manager and property manager get paid the same but the property manager has more responsibility but district managers make their employees think they are getting promoted when really its just a title with no more benefits than what the employee had but now they have more responsibilities. You have to deal with irate customers that are usually upset for a legitimate reason. For example - rats in the units destroyed their property but the insurance public storage tries to offer makes it seem like it's a non negotiable when signing paper work, wont even cover a fraction of what the customer lost or a unit got flooded and again, the insurance wont cover hardly anything. If you want to do the same thing for years on end without moving up or getting decent raises, then this job might be for you.

title: No supplies No Support
pros: The only upside is a paycheck. And that they can't keep new hires long enough so we are always short handed

They won't let us order basic office supplies and cleaning products but still expect things to get done. Barely above minimum wage and I have to buy my own supplies. We are nothing more than janitors.

title: Run away from this company

cons: Toxic/ hostile work environment The company does not value their employees tenants will threaten you and curse you out and they’ll just be given a credit applied to their account for the next month rather than corporate having your back. Communication is horrible never expect your DM to be available to help she can’t be bothered to take a second of her day to help you. You’ll be working alone all the time and if you have any emergencies you have to figure them out on your own the DM won’t help you. They want you to do everything be security a janitor a secretary and maintenance person a baby sitter but won’t pay you more money. They do not value their good employees you are just a number to them and they see you as replaceable. No job security and your personal safety is put at risk daily with the type of tenants they allow to rent there.

title: Choose this job wisely
pros: The team i worked with was absolutely amazing. They were very supported and helped me improve my skills while I worked there and they definitely watched over each other. I loved interacting with some of the customers and I actually learned knew things and had interesting conversations with some of the regulars on the properties.
cons: I started at PS and it was nice at first, but please be careful because they do not care about you. They care about numbers and the way the property needs to look (like an corporation). They are super understaffed and will spread their employees out thin. I've seen people work 8-12 days straight from how understaffed we were. The DM I had made it difficult to have a work life balance because they could not get a set schedule in, Sometimes it would get published a couple days before the next week is about to start. They also would not respect the time off people have submitted whether it was put in weeks or months in advance. Like I said, choose this job wisely. They pay $17/hour and they do not give raises unless the minimum wage goes up. From my experience, the amount of stress and the unrealistic standards higher management hold you too is not worth the pay. Sometimes the physical labor is too much on one's body as well.

title: Best Career Decision
pros: PS is always looking for new innovated ways to move the storage industry forward through improved technology features. Positive culture and environment to work in with a leadership group that truly cares about the field and their opinions. Balanced workload with the independence to cultivate your own structure to be successful. PS believes in development for ALL their employees; not only for them to be successful at PS, but to have improved life, leadership, and business skills. Increased promotional opportunities at all levels makes PS a long term home. By far the best career decision was taking the leap over to PS!
cons: If you struggle with change, PS does have a good amount year over year. However, they do give you the tools, training, and resources to adapt quickly. Because PS is the industry leader, there are very detailed job aids, scripts, and policies to follow. While I love this, some leaders may struggle with the inability to create their own process.

Prepare to give this company everything you have for nothing in return.

Our Executive Leadership Team is supportive, transparent and provides continual feedback. I am proud and grateful to work for Public Storage.

title: Public Storage gives it to the employees again.
pros: Working alone without supervision of the District Manager is good. Pay is O.K., but could be alot better.
cons: the employee's at the properties are the heart of the company, yet they treat us like dirt. The economy is in the toilet and instead of accepting that fact, in order for their bottom line to look better they cut the bulk of our bonus encentive. What we are paid for the most on is no longer in the equation. Baseing it entirely on people through the door now totally removes it out our hands. If our numbers are not up to what they expect, it's always the property managers fault. They want and accept no excuses but rampidly run with theirs. Upper management, all colledge educated, love to make changes to the properties when they never have run one day on a property by themselves. They give no reasoning to any of the changes, we are told that it is now what we must do, and that's it.

title: No advancement from the property manager position, inadequate pay and OK benefits, some job security.
pros: PS operates with minimal labor hours and it continues to add locations so there is some job security from that viewpoint. If you need the secondary job in your family, need to live in a company residence, need a flexible schedule or enjoy the resident manager lifestyle the property manager or relief manager positions would be good for you. There is a 401K and group and other medical paid by the employee.
cons: The job is more than challenging as requirements for how the PM operates including scripts is changing virtually daily from many in management.The property(s) you work can make a huge difference in working conditions. Generally speaking there is no additional pay for working an old no climate control property as oppossed to a modern, climate controlled and therefore much cleaner property. The size of the property and the level of activity can make a huge difference in working conditions.The property is a big influence as to whether or not or how much bonus money you make. Everyone is paid virtually the same no matter which property they work or how long they have worked for PS. There is no consideration for loyalty except additional paid time off after 5 and ten years. The group medical has essentialy a 4k deductible.

title: Rewarding Career and Room For Advancement
pros: Public Storage is a great company from top to bottom. The company is hands down the industry leader and has great systems in place to develop junior leaders. Hourly associates are taught how to run a business and are given real authority to impact customer service and grow the business. District Managers take over established systems for existing and newly created districts that give them the freedom to plan/adjust/react with enough structure to keep them on the right path. Employee development is is a priority at all levels and each individual is given the opportunity to progress. Many District Mangers find the DM role to be 100% fulfilling and there are ample opportunities to promote for high performers. I was able to go from brand new District Manager in training to Regional Vice President in less than four years. Public Storage does a great job of giving its leaders---at all levels-- the flexibility to control calendars, develop their teams and achieve results. I would strongly recommend Public Storage to anyone who is highly motivated and wants to be a part of world wide industry leader with a proven record of success.
cons: Not a lot of Cons caused by the company. The storage industry in general has some strict lien rules/laws and regulations that can cause customer conflict. Public Storage does a great job of providing leaders at all levels with the tools to prevent a customer from falling into this trap and help them recover if they do.

title: No Work/Life Balance. Hostile management.
pros: Pays well. Good peer group.
cons: Expected to work 12 hours a day / seven days a week. Very top down. No collaboration. Do as you’re told environment.

title: Not worth it
pros: Work basically the same days and hours
cons: Low pay Work load of three people Micro managed No room for advancement Can be hostile work environment with no help from upper management

pros: Sick day and paid time off
cons: Run Away Forced to clean up rat poop, toxic materials and get threatened if u question your safety Pay is minimum wage Management plays favorites Company only cares about salary management only Took company six months fix the front door, someone had to get hurt first

title: Poor wages for requirements
pros: You have a job and medical.
cons: It’s minimum wage with no opportunity for promotion. You solely handle 90% of the work and get paid nothing compared to higher ups. The endless tasks never stop, regional managers hassling for improved sales, phone calls, and ask you to clean human feces left on the property. Finally you are required to have a car, again all for minimum wage.

title: District Manager- Great Position!
pros: I really enjoy my position as a District Manager at Public Storage. #1- I love the competitive environment. Everyday I get to motivate, coach and train my team to reach daily and monthly goals. I enjoy being able to see where my performance stacks up against all DMs in the company each month. #2- Work life balance- I can honestly say I enjoy going to work everyday and I NEVER work after 7pm daily. Coming from Enterprise Rent-A-Car, I hated Monday Morning. Now, I enjoy waking up and going to work everyday. #3- Coaching process- I love being able to interact and coach my team one on one 3-4 days per week. Our structured process sets myself and my team up for success and I like the impact I am able to have daily with each team member.
cons: The hours are great! Not opening til 9:30am and closing at 6:00pm daily is definitely great for Work, Like, balance. The only downside is being open 7 days a week and most holidays, so you always need to be available. With that being said, the better you coach, train and improve your team the less you need to be involved daily.

title: Great Company
pros: Great Company to work for.
cons: I couldn't find any areas that need improvement.

title: It’s ok
cons: istent hours, management is helpful.

title: GREAT KEARNING EXOERIENCE
pros: Small slow paced job great customers interesting field
cons: dealing with troubled tenants constantly

title: District Manager - Worst Career Choice I've Made
pros: As a District Manager you will have very few things you will enjoy about working for Public Storage. Since there is a 20 word minimum here I'll just add the items that I dreaded the least. My DM peers. The comical relief on how unethical and unprofessional an organization can be - from the top down. That is basically it. No part of working here is enjoyable.
cons: RUN FROM THIS JOB unless you have no other prospects. You will not have any work life balance. They sell you on banker hours in the interview process, but once hired a 70 hour minimum is required which include nights and ALL weekends. There is consistent change on what the DMs have to focus on which boil down to who can steal from the customers most to achieve an unrealistic goal. You will become a direct customer service agent who handles all customer service calls which normally would be fielded to a corporate office number. As the DM you may have a customer call the customer service number at 3am because they are locked behind a property gate. As a DM you will be expected to go at 3am and let them out! Regardless if it jeopardizes your safety or not. I read across the reviews on here before accepting a position with public storage thinking it can't be that bad. WELL IT IS!!!! RUN!!!! This is the most unethical company I've ever worked for who only cares about their profits not their customers nor their employees.

title: So many mixed feelings.
pros: Lets see... for the pros. My coworkers for the most part were very hard working. They sacrifice so much and cared about their properties. They tried their very best to succeed. The one nice thing was that if you did your job well, they pretty much left you alone. All alone!
cons: So many cons. Lets start with scripts. They come out with a new script ALL of the time. Sometimes we got a new script revised after one day. Locks and insurance. Your bosses all up the line all bonus on them, If you are not good at sales, this job is not for you. Short staffed. Never enough help for the properties that need it. The company put a hold on all repairs at properties. Slowly the properties are getting run down. I was even told to do an unsafe act because the company was not willing to pay a vendor to come out to do a 5 minute repair job. Upper Management is micromanaging every thing. It became confusing as to what our focus should be. There are no career advancement possibilities for property managers. No matter how good you are, you will never move up. They took away our chance to get a bonus and accrue vacation time. That"s okay, being understaffed means never being able to use your vacation time.

title: It sucks
pros: Free housing and meeting some interesting customers or tnts
cons: Omg ...they change things so much u don't know what is going on we have 11 scripts to remember...you do a lot of work and if you don't have help with the people who work at your store ....you will be so stressed and is it really worth it? PS is like a pimp they want you to push their things merch and insurance but ( and insurance is optional) u don't bonus off of that right now! Vacation time is what u work for u accumulate it by the hour u work but in my district now the sm says you can only take a seven day vacation...I used to take a month if I wanted!!! I'm quite sure if upper management went on vacation they take more than 7 days!! They take theory time on fixing problems with tnt and employees!!! I live on site I haven't had any screens since moving in in 2009 and I have a 1 year old son the regional manager has been to do apartment check three times and I yet have received the screens!!! Maybe because no bonus for her was involved! I love my co worker in my district but Ps will drain u stress u and push u away and eventually out the DOOR!

pros: Running the property and meeting knew people
cons: alot of gossip between KTP and Management. No advancement and raises are far and few in between. do not feel appreciated

title: Profitable Company
pros: Very profitable Company. Great group of core employees. Great first impression. Seem to bring in bright, capable people. PTO allows employees to work regular holidays or take them which lends more flexibility in vacation planning. Enjoyable company events. Company has a solid financial future.
cons: There seems to be a great divide between the "have and the "have-nots." Public records display total comp of executives. PS doesn't pay that well at the lower levels and that pay tends to "flat-line" thereafter not keeping pace with the cost of living. Shouldn't the bulk of people creating the company identity enjoy in the financial success too? PS' relentless pursuit of more for less comes at the great personal expense. There seems to be a prevailing 24-7 mentality among many managers. Those who master this "badge of honor" and fall in line - experience longevity.

title: PS Review
pros: Easy job Nice people Easy scheduling
cons: Difficult customers No room for advancement

title: Not Great
pros: You work mostly alone or in small teams. The lowest position can get hired on as is a property manager so it's very easy to get a manager title.
cons: You're basically a janitor that does a little customer service.

title: Bad bad bad
pros: I don’t have anything good to say
cons: Management, corporate. Nasty and old buildings. Crazy customers

title: Where Dinosaurs Go to Die
pros: This job isn't not overly stressful and very repetitive.
cons: Micromanagement, lack of creativity, lack of career growth opportunities, lack of innovation, withholding of information, poor communication

title: Not for the educated
pros: Good customer relations opportunities in the job as I enjoy liasing with customers
cons: No career growth. Poor poor pay at $8.50 an hour. Not one scrap of overtime allowed. Ever. No education required t do job, therefore if you have an education it is not use at all. My previous experience is being wasted away with this job. If I become a Property Manager, I get a 50cent raise.....We are so below poverty level that we can't afford to get to work sometimes! Certainly cannot afford to live on my own. My raise after year one was 13cents. Why don't they just slap me in the face? I am actively looking for a job that I can you my education and experience and not waste my time. You work EVERY SINGLE WEEKEND....even if you have to sit there from 9:30 to 5 doing absolutely nothing because there is absolutely no business. I have wasted many many Sundays doing nothing cuz no one comes in. As a matter of fact, I didn't even unlock the front door on one Sunday cuz I knew no one would even show up. And I was right. I am so glad I can use my skills in this company.........waste of time. 10 to 2 on Sundays was at least a small glimmer of hope to enjoy life with your family who work normal times. But they took that away too.

title: "A" Property Manager
pros: No night, two days off at a time, DM usually is willing to work with days off. Busy season during the summer, the rest of the time is pretty slow. Apartments on property isn't bad but the age of the facility makes a difference for how nice it is. For most getting fired is a challenge. Team work is mostly dependable. OT- Overtime is almost always available.
cons: Retaliated against if sales of merchandise , locks and mostly insurance isn't at they're ridiculous expectations. High turnover rate. Cannot get promoted any higher than Property Manager if you start in the field. Almost impossible to use vacation. The pay isn't great compared to the amount of work that has to be done. Property Managers have no authority at all. Took away incentives program but expects the same incentive with no rewards for upselling or going out of the way for the team and customer. Call center usually gets store employees yelled at contantly for making reservations customers dont want. Sometimes takes months to get work orders approved and fixed by vendors. Borderline false advertisment company.

title: Terrible
pros: Working alone. Customer relationships. On site apartment is rent free.
cons: The pay is to low for what we do. There is zero security including properly lit properties, surveillance systems, alarm systems. If you are a woman working alone you still have to go outside with potential new customers onto the severely under lit property. Working alone is not a great example of security either. The sales goals are ridiculous considering nobody is walking in off the street to rent. Locks and merchandise is insanely overpriced. If you don't meet your monthly goals you are basically humiliated in front of all your peers. Google and yelp continuously remove reviews that are written by legit customers and yet we get in trouble anyway. I've been threatened on numerous occasions by angry customers. I fear for my safety everytime I walk through the door. Winter is the worst because responsibilities that are not in the job code magically come up. Shoveling through 4 ft of snow and uce for customers because they can't get into their units. The maintenance responsibilities are crazy. Property managers never get weekends off. Forget trying to take a vacation. All property lebel personnel are under paid and even more under appreciated. Sales Scripts that don't even work and just get customers more angry.

title: Rotating HR managers do not honor loyalty
pros: Variety of assignments and able to move around.
cons: After 9 years one of the rotating HR managers termed a DM for a unproven accusation. No loyalty whatsoever. If you are over 50 they will find a way to get rid of you.

title: Great!!!!
pros: Great place to pad up your customer service and collections skills
cons: No internal growth above property management position

title: Not enough pay
pros: No micro management Clear objective
cons: Too much responsibility and duty in comparison to wage

title: Not as promised
pros: Properties are only open from 9 AM to 6 PM.
cons: Tenants call at all hours day or night. Company does not appreciate your input nor results,"in appreciation for all your hard work, we are going to be giving all the district managers a Polo shirt at the sales conference" Your immediate supervisor, a RM or SDM, can make a bad job worse. For a company that made 1.8B in profit last year, fixing anything at the properties is next to impossible. All PS cares about is money, how to make it and they will pay as little as possible to keep it. Everyone in the company refers every complaint to the DM, but we are not empowered to make any adjustments to rent increases, delinquency, pricing, etc.

title: Zero Integrety
pros: Steady hours, face to face contact with your customers, no two days are the same. That's about it
cons: 1.This company swears they value their employees yet several employees in my same district including myself fear for our safety on a regular basis. We practically beg upper management for more help and safer options at our stores as in security or cameras and are constantly looked over or totally ignored. 2. We are constantly forced to perform jobs that are completely out of our job description and if we refuse our position is threatened. I've been told flat out "If you don't do it, I'll just fire you and hire someone who will." 3. Our property's are constantly being broken into and vandalized and absolutely nothing is done about it. Hundreds of customers are losing their belongings monthly and upper management says there is nothing they can do about it. 4. We all have personal lives and understandably should leave them at home when coming to work, but when we express and extreme sadness to our district and Sr district managers because of some type of personal tragedy they show no compassion at all. You are told that your emotions are not their problem so leave them at the door or don't come in at all. 5. If you get hurt anyway at all, you will be fired! 6. There is no incentive for becoming a property manager and that is literally as far as you will ever be able to advance in this company!

title: Decent place to work, just need a little more pay
pros: Flexible, set hours, full time, easy to do, laid back
cons: nothing really, if you enjoy working alone. this is the place for you.

title: Relief manager
pros: The hours are nice. If you're not a morning person, not having to wake up super early is a nice. Your coworkers are pretty cool too.
cons: They do not value their employees. The pay is not worth it! You do a lot for very little money. Also they base promotions on tenure alone, not based on skills or qualifications. You are also forced to "go for the no". Keep offering product to customers knowing they don't want it. Ridiculous! You are also not allowed to sell yourself product but if you're the only one working that facility what are you supposed to do? If you try to add the item you want to someone else's rental knowing it's already been paid for, you get fired. You also have to drive around town to work at different properties each day. The property managers don't always have the proper tools needed to run the facility so you are forced to try and function within dysfunction. They also do very little maintenance to their facilities unless they are forced to do something. All in all, do not work for this company. I am shocked they are still in business.

title: There should be a Negative option for Stars to describe my opinion of this employer....
pros: I worked with the company for nearly a decade. There was a time when I enjoyed this job. I always enjoyed my clients, and enjoyed my coworkers. It was good to work both inside and outside daily.
cons: I see many results that say not bad pay for an easy job. Those reviews come from the obscene number of employees who have been hired as body's, that don't work. At ALL. Upper management will hire anybody, you need only apply and show up. For that matter, once hired, if you don't feel like showing up its OK, someone who's more dedicated than you, will cover for you, and you will not be reprimanded, despite how overworked the teammate was who covered for you. THE DEDICATED STAFF ARE TAKEN FOR GRANTED, & OFTEN SKIPPED IN REWARDS. They blatantly disregard unscrupulous behaviors and in fact encourage them. Nothing matters but the metrics. Pay is to low for the heavy workload both physical and mentally. Favoritism is used to disperse bonuses and awards. While fear is used to push employees to preform and remain loyal.... So much truth stands to what I've stated that the name Public Storage alone being sited on my resume often sparked negative conversation in interviews and frequently added to the reason for my not being hired.

title: Join Us!
pros: This company is such a hidden gem. From a retail perspective, it doesn't get much better than this.
cons: istent shop hours keep my work-life balance stable, and I get major holidays and weekends back. Like any other job, you get out what you put in. So I work hard when I'm supposed to so that I can enjoy off hours. My team of managers is fantastic. They're bought in and do their best to take care of our customers. My own leaders are phenomenal. There is no doubt that they're invested in my own development and career progression. There are no secrets here, we are candid about our feedback. This company is a God-send for anyone that wants to get get/do better and doesn't like complacency. The company has rolled out a new operating system and its FANTASTIC. It's taken a lot of our feedback over the years and is really making our jobs easier. The best thing is that it has the ability to continue to refine itself to support the demands of the business. Lastly, this is a PEOPLE FIRST culture.

title: Terrible
pros: Its a job Steady schedule
cons: The company does not care about their employees or customers Benefits are not even the bare minimum Poor communication all throughout this company

pros: Being able to work from home
cons: They do not tell you about the weeeks of mandatory over time until you have been through training

title: Prop manager
pros: Good schedule Good benefits Good work life balance
cons: Not many cons at this location

title: Never Again at this call center in Gilbert, AZ
pros: Pay was decent.... health benefits were good... At time of interview, they made it sound really good as far as sick time; vacation time; etc...
cons: Personal Growth.... there is none !!! For the most part, this company does NOT promote from within.... there are no raises AT ALL no matter how long you have been there. They continue to set you up for failure.... there is no winning at this place.... you leave every single day feeling beat up and a failure. They have no values... there is no work/life balance here. You get 2 paid holidays a year.... those would be Thanksgiving and Christmas. The call center is closed. The ONLY holiday you receive time and a half for is New Years Day.... all the rest if you are scheduled you work for straight time. They will change your schedule on you, most of the time without notice. They don't care if you have previous plans or day care issues.... you better be in that chair taking their calls no matter what.

title: Do not accept the offer.
pros: - Peers were supportive and helpful of one another even though they were extremely overworked, overwhelmed and overly stressed.
cons: I have never worked for a company that lacked so much in integrity, ethics and respect. - Micromanagement occurs at all levels. District Managers are trained to micromanage their teams. I was told by my Regional to assume that when I walk into a property, to assume that everyone is lying, stealing or doing both so that I can dig into everything and catch their mistake.
