It is the worst possible way to engage, motivate and coach your team. - Lack of support for field team. Everything is escalated to the District Managers. From customer calls to IT issues to Facilities. - Monday through Friday does not exist as promised during the interviews. You are on call 24/7. I was harassed by text and email on the weekends upper management, for non-urgent issues. - Does not care for its people. Our CEO stated that we were puking cash as a company. Not too far away where property managers that are making minumum wage and have yet to receive their bonus that is several months overdue. -District Managers are held accountable for everything, even items outside of their control (like a new storage business opening near by with newer facilities and lower pricing but the pricing team would not lower pricing to be competitive as our facility is significantly older. DM would be held accountable for occupancy and revenue still.

title: Not the worst job I had
pros: Set schedule, off everyday by 6 pm. Meet great customers at times and ok co- workers
cons: Public storage is a company that is number driven. If you don't mind aggressive coaching to obtain monthly goals while cleaning and moving furniture and doing everything else on the property while working alone perfect job for you. This company focuses more on how much money they can make then actually employee concerns and safety on property. I worked here for a number of years and several times customers has walked in and said "you here by your self right". Long story short, if you are in between jobs and are looking for something now apply, if you want a job that care about you and want to work for a company where you matter move on this is not the job for you

title: It's ok
pros: Being alone, not having to come in early
cons: Push for Google reviews is ridiculous

title: Unsafe Environment
pros: Can work alone if desired Lots of down time
cons: Forced to push unwanted products Forced to read script Will be blamed if you cannot make sales using the script and accused of going off script Will be harassed by customers because the deals offered are misleading May be attacked or harassed as a woman working alone on a large property

title: Would never recommend anyone to work here!
pros: Set schedule, work at your own pace.
cons: Pressure to sell, lack of security on property, maintenance issues take a long time to be resolved.

title: Great job for anyone looking to gain "manager" experience
pros: DM was personal with employees and worked with you to the best of his abilities. Some of the workers I encountered were genuinely good people. The job helped me get comfortable with handling customer issues or irate customers. A few skills that I developed while I was here; property management, cash handling, scheduling and selling merchandise. Dealing with the various amounts of characters that come through helped develop personal growth, whether it's increasing your situational awareness or networking.
cons: People can be cliquey, and some just don't want to work. Sometimes hard to get a response on customer service issues from DM sometimes (being as the DM is being ran very thing between multiple locations and dealing with the Customer Service issues). Customers LOVE to play stupid and will play word games with you to try and catch you up, DO NOT AVOID THE SCRIPT AND YOU WILL BE FINE. Avoid working at any property with an apartment.

title: Amazing company to work for, great benefits, and tons of opportunity for advancement!
pros: It is difficult to start over after working for the same company for 20 years. I had a tough decision to make three and a half years ago when I chose Public Storage, but after the interview process I knew this was the place for me! I was given the opportunity to interview with several layers of management, each interview giving me more reasons why I wanted to be a part of this exceptional team. The culture here is one of endless support that I had never experienced until I joined the Public Storage team. I love the fact that there is room at the top for everyone with tons of opportunity for advancement. This company takes great pride in the development of its employees and because of this I have enjoyed two promotions within the last three and a half years. The work-life balance here is a breath of fresh air. The restaurant business didn't allow me to experience this wonderful convenience. The benefits don't stop there; medical, dental, generous vacation package, rewarding incentive plan, 401k with company match, just to name a few. I'm very happy to work for a company that values integrity and trust. This is a company with a solid business model that understands how to treat its employees.
cons: I would like to see us continue to improve our technology. At times the field experiences added obstacles due to out dated equipment/software. The company has recently upgraded phone lines and seems committed to making technology advancements a priority.

title: Mismanaged to the MAX
pros: There are no pros to this company. Hasn't been in years
cons: Everything! Upper management are at home. Store employees at risk.

title: Garbage
pros: relatively stable schedule with a 9-6 work day.
cons: bad benefits, pay, and treatment

title: Good team environment
pros: Good support from management, company does listen to feedback, good benefits, advancement is available
cons: Some micromanagement can occur at times.

title: Job is a bit above average.
pros: Lunch and breaks whenever you want. Plenty of down time. You oversee entire office and property. Good district manager. Good job to start of your close to the job and not needing to pay rent.
cons: Worried about getting held up at gunpoint depending on location. Short 30 minute lunch break. The person you work after may completely NOT do a single thing and make you look bad if a district manager or regional manager come in and blame you. Sales are forced. If you don't make your sales goal they will make you feel uneasy, lower than the others - even if you run places that make lower revenue. They have reduced our bonus to 0% unless you make them a lot of money. You're expected to force customers to buy insurance illegally. You'll have to pick up dead rats and birds, change lightbulbs, fix gates and doors and pay is nlt worth the work. On our conference calls they say we need to sell better but they disguise it as we are helping the customer. The upper management are wealthy and boast about their possessions and vacations while we all have cars that are running on empty and can hardly pay our rent.

title: Job Security!!!
pros: When my friends and family were unfortunately getting laid off or furloughed during the pandemic I had job security. Public storage is a financially strong company that never skipped a beat during 2020. We still received yearly raises, quarterly bonuses, and additional stock. I also felt very safe working the day to day since we had to follow very detailed safety protocols. I am very proud of how Public storage handled the pandemic. I would also have to say another pro about public storage is upper management leaves their titles at the door. Everyone I’ve met and worked with have been very friendly, welcoming, and genuinely wants feedback from you on how we can make things stronger. Not only do they want the feedback they actually implement it! The day to day job is very fast paced, there is always something to do, and you are given the flexibility to run your district how you see fit.
cons: You have to be okay with knowing the job will never be done. This is something I took some getting used to. If you are one of those people who need to mark everything off your to do list for the day just know there will be a couple things that will pop up and they will go straight to the top of your priority list. Non- priority items will have to get moved around. You can still feel accomplished in your day it just might not be what you originally had planned.

pros: Always overtime Flexable Pto Pti
cons: Sometimes its too much over time horrible pay Phones never stop Hard to move up

title: Unsafe and Poor pay
pros: Possibility of being able to live where you work for free. Work outside and inside, good mix of both. Able to manage your sight within reason the way you like. Independence. Get exercise.
cons: Constantly working alone with little security at some sights and no security at others. Management uses apartments as pawns and does not follow through with giving apartments. Gave up previous home with promise of apartment and then was not given a place. Management is rude and uncaring and gives no concern to the safety of staff and customers. Management bends rules for their benefit and does not follow through or stand behind their employees.

title: Customer
pros: Got good benefits of the company
cons: The pay is Terri fkjeuik3

title: Greedy Corporation with very little care about employee safety and loyalty.
pros: Rude customers, Greedy Corporation, workers are drove like a sales commision job without the commision. 15 cent raises, yes I repeat 15 cent raises. So I guess the real answer is nothing good about this job. Do not invest in camera system for workers safety.
cons: Too many to count but I will try to be brief. If you mess up your fired. An "audit" is always coming. Property manager salary is decreased to $8 per hour if you live on site. People will bother if you decide to live on site. Regular pay is $10 per hour plus a bonus that works out to be $1 more an hour. You cannot live in California or anywhere else in America on this pay. No the work is not hard all the time, but the company cares only about stock price and not about creating a great, safe job for loyal workers. 15 cent raises after one year and each year going forward says that there will always be a revolving door for workers looking to make real money to support a family or pay basic bills. Greedy CEO and C level management. This company represents everything wrong with corporation in America today.

pros: Pay, bonus, that's about it.
cons: Hours, stress, workload, work life balance, constant threat of termination.

title: Success is not certain until you are obsessed by your goal!
pros: One of the greatest reasons to work for Public Storage is that your hard-work is always be recognized by all. The company is driven to succeed and therefore it enables and provides all employees to strive for the best. They provide you with the needed resources, as well as a field of upper management personnel that is available to always lend out a helping hand. They provide their employees with great benefits plans and as well as opportunity for growth within the company. They teach you never settle for anything unless it is your best!
cons: We all wish sometimes we had more time in the day. Time management is very important because sometimes when we plan our days out accordingly, but not always do they work in our favor. Some days you may be faced with things that come up through the day and that interfere with the tasks you have planned. Always space out your tasks accordingly and make sure to complete them right the first time.

title: Great career move to a strong, stable and expanding publicly traded company. Top management team, talented colleagues.
pros: Super smart and good-humored people at the top and throughout all levels of the organization. Employees are diverse, talented, dedicated and have a fun spirit. There are many long-term employees, some "bleed orange." Work is always interesting with new challenges every day. The company is forward-thinking and serioulsy plans for the future, striking a balance of high growth without high-risk. Fiscal policies are conservative with very little debt. The company culture is "be respectful to others" and feel free to laugh at yourself and make others laugh along the way. The company is very careful in the hiring process to make sure new hires are a good fit. The company spends a lot of money to hire and retain top talent. Corporate offices are at good location for easy commute from many directions. I work on a great team with a great boss and definitely recommend the company to others!
cons: No challenges or gripes you wouldn't find in any organization. Some employees feel that communication needs to be improved. This probably varies from department to department, and between corporate and the field. It's a rapidly growing environment and hard to keep up with it all. Need to pursue your own path to success and personal growth. Slackers need not apply.

title: Run away as fast as you can
pros: Stepping stone to learn the Storage business if that's what you want to do. Good way to see how employees should not be treated.
cons: From reading posted reviews seems that those who are in the Glendale corporate office are treated like humans. Can't say the same for the rest of us in the actual storage facilities. District mangers are basically puppets who are not allowed to make decisions. Pay, bonus, time off, benefits, are all below industry standards. Company places unrealistic demands on field personal. Only a few ever make bonus. In the years I was with the company I had time off, benefits, and bonus taken away. The merchandise they sell is sub par and grossly over priced. They think customers are idiots. Employee safety is a big issue for field personal. I have heard of some employees fixing locks and doors with their own money because management would not. That's pretty bad. I have no idea what people are talking about in regards to advancement. Basically you can become a trainer which gets you peanuts as compensation. That's it. You go no further. District mangers are recruited from outside of the company. Takes them a year to learn the business. By then they are either fired or they are running fast to another job. Turnover at this company is astounding. HR is a joke. I saw employees report district managers for egregious behavior. HR did nothing. On the contrary, within six months some one above fired the employees. Trust me. This company borders on evil.

title: Just don't. You'll thank me later.
pros: Full time to start out with, and decent benefits. That's about it.
cons: They don't support people with disabilities I have a service animal protected under the American Disability Act (ADA) and they refused to allow me to keep her with me. Which is illegal. If a unit is mislocked in an open position or no lock, they advise you to open it to see what is inside which again, is illegal. They don't back up their employees, you can be held hostage and the customer isn't wrong. They don't properly train you, there are stupid scripts you have to follow. They make you tell the customer they HAVE to have insurance through us (Public Storage) which they DON'T. The lazy workers who do nothing are praised. Those who work their butts off continue to be taken advantage of. The District Managers don't even know how to do the basics! (Rentals, print certain reports, etc) they advertise free rent for their vacant apartments- not the case. They take the funds out of your paycheck sure it only comes to $300/mo which is cheap but they advertise as free and that is NOT the case. Upper management (DM's) are extremely UNprofessional they talk about other employees (your coworkers) to you and they talk about private matters that shouldn't be talked about that should be left confidential. I was a property manager and after that there is NO room for advancement they do NOT promote within. For the amount of work they have you do, pay isn't good.

title: The District Manager position is not what it seems- stay away!
pros: Public Storage hires from retail so the work life balance is definitely better.
cons: You’re essentially a glorified General Manager who oversees multiple properties. Compensation is low at both the DM and property manager level. The company pays their property teams minimum wage and expects way too much for the pay. If you get promoted out of the DM position, don’t expect extra compensation for your new role. Turnover is very high and it’s because the competition is paying much more. You’ll spend a bulk of your month cutting locks and selling auction units. The company does not provide you with protective clothing for the lock cuts either...if you want something more than gloves and goggles you have to pay for it out of pocket; which I’m sure goes against OSHA standards. Benefits are very expensive for not the best coverage. Also, as a district manager you are responsible for working with vendors to get repairs done in your buildings. This takes up a ton of your time and doesn’t allow you to coach and develop your team.

title: I feel the need to answer some of the remarks I have just read about the company.
pros: I enjoy working with the public, have made many friends within the company. Most times I am sent to properties close to my home. My DM can be a stinker but a very likeable stinker. He tries to take care of his staff as well as his bosses allow him.
cons: They expect us to not only collect rents, rent the unit only after trecking out to show the unit, sell sell sell. The lock check has to be done twice a day rain or shine, traffic on the property or not. And the pay is just so low it is almost unheard of. The manditory monthly meetings are ruled over like a storm trooper is in charge. IF you don't know all the paper work word by word you will be told you are going to be fired. I also read in one of the letters, the manager was to make bank deposits after hours on their own time, NEVER in all my years. Deposits need to be made by noon unless you are tending to someone then the time is 2p.m.

title: It not a job - more like and indentured servent or slave.
pros: The compensation is good for the industry. However expect a 60-70 hour work week. Including all weekends and holidays. Do not expect any monetary rewards or comp time.
cons: 1. Unreasonable workloads. 2. Unreasonable time frames for completion of reports, surveys and analysis of reports. 3 Unreasonable travel requirements. 4. Employees have to pay for all travel expenses and wait weeks for reimbursment. 5. Unrealistic meal allowance when traveling ($40.00 a day max.) 6. No recognition for doing exemplary work and exceeding expectations. Only criticism if you miss something minor. 7. There is no comp time ever in this organization. 8. You must be able to carry thousands of dollars on your personal credit cards to work at this company -while waiting for reimbursments. 9. The turnover of employees at this company is huge. 10. DM's are so low valued that they pay a $5k bonus to anyone who recruites a friend that lasts 60 days. If you don't like someone- recommend them for this job. Even in this time of high unemployment. Just read between the lines. 11. Employees are paid on a base salary + Bonus -Beware - They fire huge groups of employees just prior to reaching the pay out date annually.

title: Stay away.
pros: This will be a very short list. You would think that me being with a company for over six years I would only have good things to say, wrong. It started off great. First year we made bonuses off sales. Following few years we qualified for a yearly bonus. This last year we got nothing, not even the .15 cent raise that we typically got. Now the only way you can make more money is to participate in their YouTube challenges. The only good thing about this job is you get your 40hours a week and they are flexible if you need time off.
cons: Where to start? They eliminated bonuses and raises. Now they sent a memo out that they will start it again but it’s not worth sticking around for an extra 15 cents. They don’t promote from within even though the property managers know more than the dm. Property managers do all the work for no recognition. It Takes months for vendors to get approval to fix anything. Angry customers because they keep getting raises for “upkeep” on the property but there have been no improvements to warrant the raises.

title: Any 5 star reviews on here have to be bogusly done by PS to improve there online reputation!!!!
pros: Working alone and having office/steady hours are about it.
cons: Scripts....... I'm not a robot and I know how to deal with the public. They expect you to sell 8.5 locks per every 10 rentals or the regional/DM manager will come to your property and hassle you. They expect a %20 increase across the board every year which is ridiculous in this economy. They make us tell the customer that some sort of insurance is required to rent a unit when they don't have to have insurance at all (were lying to the public to make more money). Bonus's are disappearing every year and this year my PTO was cut in half... If your on unemployment, do yourself a favor, and stay on it. I would NOT recommend renting a unit there either because of lack of security, Thefts, and they will sell your stuff if you don't pay. Corporate Greed is a BIG PROBLEM with this company. Employees are struggling to survive and PS corporate is spending extra money on building a useless float for the new years day parade... Their ethics are really screwed up bad here.

title: Semi okay experience
pros: Nice hours, flexible time off, not too hands on
cons: Micro managing , no set breaks

title: Lowest pay in storage
pros: No working nights, independent work, work inside and out
cons: Lowest pay in storage, people do not come to work nor held responsible for it

title: Don't do it...
pros: Benefits are decent for the work you do
cons: Sales quota, up sales, properties in low income areas not maintained.

title: Key Training Professional and Property Manager for 11 years
pros: This is an awesome company to work for! I have been here nearly 11 years and love what I do. You can create your own agenda and do not constantly have a supervisor hoovering over you. I like that my day is mine and I can chose how to complete my tasks. The company in many cases will provide on site apartments allowing you to live rent and utility free. The benefits are fantastic and upper management are wonderful! Scripts are used. They do not have to be word for word but instead take you through a detailed sales process that will HELP you be the best seller you can. Scripts are great when you are new and make sure we cover all of our customer's needs.
cons: I do wish that KTP and PMs made more than relief. The job has more expectations and typically those managers have more to complete each day. The incentive program could be better but I am grateful that it even exsists.

title: An Awful Place to Work!
pros: At Public Storage, they have some good stock incentives for Regional Managers and above, but even they are being reduced significantly.
cons: The top down culture here makes this an awful place to work. The company manages by fear and expects to terminate a big percentage of it's employees every year. One DVP actually stated, "All your employees are stealing from you, it's your job to find out how and then fire them." One of the CEO's favorite sayings is "Only the paranoid survive!" Even the paranoid can't stand this place. Nearly all employees are consistently looking for another job to find a way out. He also has a short-term view of the business and does not believe in customer service, he only wants decisions made that affect the quarterly results he has to present to Wall Street. Read the customer reviews on Google and you will see what I mean. Even the positive reviews were received through a forced solicitation. In the CEO's own words, "We puke cash", yet even though they had record breaking YOY improvement, salaries and hourly wages are the lowest in the industry and increases are often put off for several months. My best advice to you is to stay as far away as you can get, both as a customer and an employee.

title: Property Manager
pros: Set Schedule work 5 days a week with two days off Full 40 hours a week with some overtime opportunities Very through with training and after training support Bonus opportunities
cons: Its considered a retail position so Saturdays are mandatory Its sales driven and if you can't up-sale expect to have a lot of "coaching" with your DM Highly micro-managed, including daily conference calls Turn around is high so there is always a shortage of workers and hard to request time off Unless you call in Only closed 3 days of out the year so expect to work most holidays Not a very caring environment from the company all they want is for you to show up and do your job Property Manager is the highest you can go in the company, they do not prmote from within after property manager.

title: Better work-life balance!
pros: I had been in retail management for many years when I decided to step out of my comfort zone and take a chance on Public Storage. I'm so grateful that I did and I've never looked back! I was welcomed in with open arms by an amazing and caring leadership team. My peers and supervisors were so supportive and helpful, and really made me feel valued as I learned my role. The work life balance is excellent compared to your typical big box retail and I think it's one of the best things about this position. We are in a booming industry and the company growth has been incredible, even throughout the pandemic. The company is constantly coming up with newer and better innovations to grow the business and I love being a part of that creative energy. With all that growth, comes plenty of opportunity at the DM level, especially if you are willing to relocate.
cons: Managing all the change can be challenging and keeping your hourly staff motivated and engaged takes a lot of work. The hourly staff have very few opportunities for upward mobility, so selecting the right candidate is key. Delinquency management can also create some very difficult customer interactions for the property managers and DMs on a monthly basis.

title: Demanding but can be relaxing depending on your personality type
pros: Able to work alone and at your own pace. Dedicated workers with tenure can sometimes secure free housing through public storage (depends on the exact PS location if its available though). Full benefits. Easy to get into a rhythm/routine each day. Being in charge of an entire property can be rewarding. The company has a nice training program.
cons: - You are expected to hard sell certain items, with at least a 90% success rate. - The company prioritizes new customers over old ones which lead to awkward situations where a customer has a valid complaint and you just kind of need to placate them till they go away out of frustration, (not exactly something you will take pride in). - Certain selling techniques are not the most honest... there is an optional item that PS wants you to sell but they don't want the customer to know that it's optional, so you are trained to tell them certain details as you are closing the storage unit door so they don't hear it. Again not something that you will take pride in. - As a property manager, you will repeatedly find yourself in situations that make you wonder why you aren't paid more. - Depending on the property you oversee, and your relief managers it can feel overwhelming at times. - In my opinion, you are not paid enough for the sheer breadth of work that you have to stay on top of.

title: Stressful
pros: Independence. Manage your own day. Close friendships develop for me.
cons: Bad pay No support from company Bad customers Unachievable goals Short staff all the time Being put in uncomfortable situations No work/life balance if you live on property

title: Corporate Greed
pros: It's full time, and the health benefits are decent
cons: First of all, P.S. pays below the market average for a similar position. (9.50 to start, which is ridiculous) I was told during my interview ,"Good luck finding a better opportunity with your skill set." I should have seen that as a red flag, but was desperate for work at the time. This company is all about the money, and it's business practices are downright despicable. I was expected to lie to meet unobtainable sales goals, and beg customers to give me five star reviews on yelp/google. And if one didn't get enough reviews, you bet you're going to get a talkin' to. (I'm pretty sure most of the five star reviews on G.D. for this company are lies) Eventually employees just started faking these reviews online to get the DM's/RM's off our backs. I felt unsafe working alone, and have been threatened on multiple occasions by intoxicated customers. One guy threatened to kill me. If you want to work here you better be comfortable using scripts for every potential customer encounter, which made me personally feel like some corporate stooge, idiot robot. Working there was very stressful, and not worth the near poverty wages the company deems as sufficient compensation. I could go on and on about the unethical practices I witnessed everyday, but I won't. I'm just glad I'm out over there and this chapter of my life is closed.

title: Great to learn storage
pros: Great Company to learn the storage business from!
cons: They pay towards the bottom of the scale compared to other storage companies

title: Good money - horrible life style
pros: Pay is good, bonus for first year is guaranteed
cons: DMs are required to work and be available 7 days a week and at a moments notice. We were told several times that we needed to manage our families better so they would understand the needs of PS. Company structure micro-manages every last detail and the administrative requirements are unnecessarily exhaustive, and are mostly high level busy work that no one even reads or reacts to. Even when on vacation or on holidays, your supervisors will contact you constantly from the early morning to the middle of the night, meanwhile never themselves being available during their time off. There is more than 50% turnover in DM's every year. That is a fact. The company is only concerned with stock holders dividends and frequently denies reasonable requests from customers as well as basic maintenance and upkeep of the buildings. Property Managers are not paid anywhere near their value (and are actually paid less than the industry standard), and they are constantly pushed to achieve unattainable goals and are treated with hostility, they are often questioned and reprimanded just because they are not well liked, and are treated like the obstacle to the company's success rather than trained and developed and incentivized. There is no opportunity for upward mobility for Property Managers which also hurts their performance.

title: Started great.. Ended horribly.
pros: As a relief manager, I travel around a lot. Was offered a PM job several times but declined because I like going to different properties. At first I liked it. I was able to get the numbers but as time went on I realized this company is very unethical..
cons: Where do I even start?! Let's start with the buildings I guess. Horrible. Constantly leaking, nothing ever gets fixed, I had to always lie to customers and tell them "oh it'll get fixed soon" and send out an email to the DM who would never reply anyway. I was forced into selling locks and insurance, which everyone agrees is uncomfortable and I always get customers who always denied/argued about it. Google reviews.. If I hear those words one more time I'll lose it. The rent raises so much, how is that even morally okay?! And guess who gets to deal with it? Us. The managers. While upper management sits on their butts in their comfy chairs, I get things thrown at me, threatened and verbally abused by entitled customers. Even if they're loyal and always pay on time, corporate won't lower their rate and just tells them to "move units". Ohhhh and the cameras don't even work! None of the properties I've ever worked at has working cameras. It's sad, really. There's black mold in some of the offices and it makes me sick. No one cleans it even though I've reported it many times. It's in the AC unit as well which blows on me all day. It's a good temporary job I suppose.

title: Overall a good place of employment
pros: The hours are great, no night or early mornings. We work together as a team to be the best district. Employee retention is good(however has been better in the past). They offer an incentive plan which is a bonus for doing your job well. Pto starts immediately and accrued by hours worked. Upper management is easy to work with. No boss over your shoulder. Computer system easy to use. Paid training and trained to where everyone in the company is on the same page with every process with customers. They provide the tools needed for this and to be successful. Versatile as far as moving around while at work ie some office work or outside work. Annual evaluations. 401k and benefits are available. Provide uniform tops and give an allowance for the care of your uniform. Paid mileage for use of personal vehicle. Guess I've said enough but I could go on since I feel, it's an overall good company to work for.
cons: No upper management advancement. Need more than 3 holidays off a year. Would prefer to have Sunday's less hours if not closed completely.

title: Worn thin with low pay, districts fail
pros: Some inside and outside work, other managers are your community, good hours. Build a relationship with your DM and you will be able to rely on them (and vice versa).
cons: Low pay leading to massive turnover, deaf corporate side, yearly bonus system gutted and not helping maintain employees because a whole year of working hard at $10 for one payoff feels like climbing a mountain for people who see Walmart hiring for $11-11.50, cost of living seemingly ignored when considering pay so that new hires quit within a week or two, managers working overtime for weeks on end get stressed out and leave or transfer that stress to new hires (who quit), secret shops touted as a way to keep workers honest (but no pay difference, only fear), district managers with their hands tied trying to keep employees when they have no incentives to keep anyone (firmly a corporate problem)

title: Corporate
pros: Title and opportunity to put your experience in action
cons: Worse benefits (very expensive), only 3 paid holidays, 20 PTO days but that includes sick time and of course all other holidays you don’t get but your family does. Closed minded on changes for improvements, very old culture mentality. If you are in a group age of 40 less don’t come here... forget it! Most people have been here for a long time and it is a constant struggle for them to adapt to change, they even feel it is ok to treat you without respect and your future way to move up is just staggered by the fact that most people that have been there for long have the high titles/pay/ and want to work forever! Amazingly you do 10 times more than they do, faster and better but all you get is constant opposition! Also, if you don’t have kids stay even further away! They will make you work even during National Emergency! The whole culture and vibe doesn’t feel fluid and good, they might offer you a higher title and even salary because that’s the only way they can make people from other more “modern” industries to go there or most importantly younger people, but at the end of the day you deal with people that deep to their core won’t change.

title: Don’t work for public storage
pros: I don’t have to work there anymore
cons: Terrible management and extremely underpaid for the job requirements even with an all paid for apartment

title: Job Stability!
pros: In an ever changing environment my job still being here tomorrow is not something I have to worry about, we have been here and are not going anywhere! We SAFELY stayed open during a Pandemic and continued to pay our employees at a higher rate during the transition! Public Storage consistently looks for new and innovating ways to better our business not just for the Guest but for our internal guest (our employees!) As well! One of my favorite parts of my job in the last two years has been travel, it has allowed me to learn from Leaders throughout the company at multiple levels and experience new cities at the same time. I have been able to travel to multiple States and Districts to support transitions and new acquisitions while continuing to prep for my current role. In a Management position I expect Leadership, Honesty, and Accountability, the team I work for strives for these values daily and is not afraid to push me to be a better Manager and Team Player each day.
cons: In a environment such as ours you have to be able to stay on your toes, we DRIVE innovation, we DRIVE positive results, we DRIVE change this job requires flexibility on all fronts this job is for Leaders who are actively involved and can pivot in a moments notice.

pros: I loved it, everyone was helpful
cons: No cons honestly, I loved it

title: Low pay vs competition
pros: Reasonable work loads Independent work
cons: Pay is $2 less then current competition

title: High Expectations With No Reward
pros: There are not late shifts to work. You have the opportunity to be an onsite manager with an apartment fro a lower payrate.
cons: The company created scripts for every interaction with a customer that you must follow and are tested regularly by the District Manager on your knowledge of these scripts. They want you to sell their overpriced boxes and moving supplies to every customer that walks in the door to rent a space with a lousy bonus program that only rewards the top few employees. Public Storage does not care about line level employees nor their customers. I watched them sell off a terminally ill man's unit who was waiting on a government check to make a payment. You also get put in a really bad spot as an employee when a tenant's unit gets broken into. Even if they buy the insurance (from a the insurance company Public Storage owns) the tenant will 9 times out of 10 NOT get a payout. Even after 30 plus units got broken into over a month's time the company did literally nothing to make the property more secure. Also there is no opportunity for advancement. Line level employees will never do better than being an onsite property manager.

title: Wear good boots
pros: There is a relaxed atmosphere, the co-workers are often helpful, and there is direct communication on a regular basis with management to check in, communicate anything new, etc. Checking on the units is a regular scheduled thing, which can take time and require a lot of walking, I would not call it labor-intensive. My own manager was very uplifting to people's efforts, and provided a supportive atmosphere and praised achievements. The computer system is fair to use and learn, and a lot of it is linear in use during tasks. Another pro is that some workers get to live in near or an attached apartment to storage offices. They provide snow-tread shoe covers, jackets, shirts, most of which have the company logo.
cons: Lots of sales pitching required to use with customers, down to a specific script, and one of the tasks is to call customers who have not paid for their unit and push for payment, which for some workers without some marketing skillets, this could be challenging. Management does have certain numbers to achieve, some of the facilities could use more resources or upgrades to tech or physical items. It can be tough to man the office and the grounds in inclement weather, such as heavy snow or ice, since checking each unit is locked is still required. As which most retail and retail-adjacent jobs, there is some risk of burglaries or other misdemeanors, but this risk alters depending on the area.

title: Choose your attitude when you come to work
pros: The opportunity with this company is what you make of it. If you are driven, competitive, able to motivate a team, hold them to a high level of performance and celebrate your victories, you can do very well at Public Storage. I have been here for three years and have enjoyed the opportunity to control my own destiny in the ways of my career path and earnings through competing for higher bonuses. Shame on current employees who are willing to accept a paycheck and turn around and blast the company (this or any) with negative reviews while still working there. If you're not happy, you should look somewhere else.
cons: It's difficult to see people at tough transitions in their lives. Death, divorce, lost a job or home are common reasons why people need storage. As far as the company culture, I would like to see more incentives and/or contests for our property level teams. They will drive whatever you want driven with incentives attached to them.

title: Great choice for the talented multi-unit manager
pros: From my first day of training to present day, Public Storage has provided me the support and development to grow into the best leader I can be. This is a continuous journey that never stagnates because all businesses grow through change and opportunity. I have had 2 supervisors while in position. Both were promoted from my current role. Both are still with the company. Both are highly successful. Both chosen for their role to support me in mine. I have a A+ team operating my properties due to the incredible hiring support the organization provides coupled with the continuous focus on training and development. My performance is graded on my ability to improve my business from the prior year and whether I achieved success using the right behaviors and processes. I'm now putting my children through college with the help of stocks grants I earn every year. If given the chance to chose all over again, I'd definitely give a resounding YES.
cons: District complexity varies widely. There is no way to avoid this. Manager competency is consistently well matched with district complexity. Adjusting the pay, bonus or stock grant scale would be a suggestion.

pros: Loved working with my co workers. After being with the company for over 2 years you form relationships with the customers and that’s what I loved as well! The job is pretty easy and you will gain some new customer service skills as well as learning new things like be able to fix light fixtures.
cons: Pay wage is horrible. There is no pay increase between a relief manager (assistant manager) and being a Property manager. When you become a property manager, you receive a lot more responsibilities but no pay increase. When a relief manager doesn’t do their job, you’re left with having to pick up after them and no matter what everything always falls back on you. There is also no upward mobility with this company, KTP (Which is someone who trains the new hirers) is the highest you can go. They do not hire DMs within. If you’re a relief manager be prepared to travel to different properties at any time during the day. I’ve also gone through 4 DMs within 2 years, I guess that says a lot.

title: Horrible management & job duties
pros: Decent schedule for work and life balance
cons: Working here was the worst, they tried to slave there employees, scrubbing floors clean to diamond shine instead of hiring professionals

title: Worst company
pros: Remote work from your own home
cons: Treat their employees and customers like crap

title: I have worked many stores in the district and I love it due to many tasks in a day.
pros: Very diverse clientele. Competitive work environment great work flow.
cons: istent work schedules; I've had 2 District managers and BOTH were very positive. Andrew Ton is the newest and youngest but has THE BEST MOTIVATION SKILLS! Another great shoutout Rob Fragoso who understands each of his managers very well. They both care about family.I have learned so much regarding the dynamics of not just this company, but any company. This corporation is located all over the states so u are never "stuck" . You want Hawaii, you want New York... They have them EVERYWHERE. Great resume builder as this company's reputation and name are known and respected. Most but not all facilities have an apartment on site which is a bonus for single parents , small families,retired couples or students. You live rent, water and electricity bill free!!

title: Brace yourself for a different lifestyle.
pros: You have the opportunity to live in a free on-site apartment. The jobs allows flexibility to manage your own day. You don't have a boss leaning over your shoulder all day. You can leave for your lunch break, you don't have to stay at the job. Anytime you travel, you get mileage which is nice.
cons: You will get verbally abused by tenants beyond belief. You will be threatened, screamed at, cussed at, and you will be outside in the most unbearable weather. You will encounter problems that are out of your control yet the tenants will expect you to have a solution and FAST. You will get little to no help from management. You will be expected to lift heavy items that people leave behind. You will be expected to drive anywhere from 20 minutes to one hour to work at another property with literally no notice. Depending on who your DM is, your life COULD be hell.

title: Good place to work
pros: Locations and experiences different daily
cons: Low pay for the amount of work expected.

title: All of these positive employee reviews are false
pros: Public storage requires all employees to produce positive reviews online, whether they be from “customers” posting on Google, or employees posting on Glassdoor about what a great company this is to work for. Don’t believe these reviews from these happy employees; the reviews are fraudulent. Happy employees don’t exist, and Public Storage is actually a terrible company to work for.
cons: High turnover due to unfair practices from corporate demands of meeting revenue, insurance, and merchandise quotas. Disciplinary actions taken if aforementioned upsells aren’t met. No raises for hourly employees. No monetary commissions or bonuses for hard work. A manager that was hired 8 years ago is currently making that same hourly wage-barring any federal legislation requiring a pay difference. So there are no yearly performance reviews at Public Storage. No incentive to work harder and earn more. You simply have to keep making the company money to avoid being on the radar of management. No ability at PS for advancement. If you start out as a relief(assistant) manager, the highest you can go is property manager. If you are reading this and desire to one day oversee a district, you never will with Public Storage. They do NOT promote any talent from within. They hire senior management from outside companies that frequently have nothing to do with the storage industry....so they are usually incompetent.

title: Lots of work
pros: Never board, mental and physical.
cons: Understaffed in property management positions.

title: My time at Public Storage
pros: If you like to multi-task this would be a good fit. Good learning environment for a young person who still lives with his parents and going to school.
cons: Over my six years with PS I have seen many tactics that are not consumer friendly. Trying to get people to buy two locks if the door has that type of hasp and of course insurance. The employees have a lot of pressure put on them to sell the insurance, including management. The insurance PS offers has the lowest claim pay out in the industry. PS does have a bonus-incentive plan that has changed over the past few years to the degree that only 60% of the property people are eligible and of course the performance levels are raised every year so if you can't get 85% insurance sales how are you going to get 87%. The vacation time has also changed, many companies have a limit to the hours you can accrue, but PS come November will cash out your hours in excess of 40 hours with the fraise "Just In Time For The Holiday's". No kidding. The pay is low for the demands of the job and their is no opportunity for advancement from the property level. That would be the definition of a dead end job.

title: biggest mistake you'll ever make
pros: Pto get and you get off at 6pm that's about it
cons: Low pay high expectations for pm and rm. This company moral is low dms are catty they have the behavior of a 16 old girl , my Dm ask me plenty of times to add merchandise to rental without customers knowing .so she can get her merchandise sales . I was also told to come to a district meeting that started 1 hour before my scheduled shift and was not paid I ask dm about it twice and she never responded . You will have to clean up poop do collection calls, sweep Long hallways in the summer,rent spaces ,clean toilets etc all for 9 an hour if you don't sale insurance or merchandise you will explain to dms every day over and over .you will also have to stalk customer for Google reviews or make them up.

title: Easy job, terrible company
pros: Easy job. Renting spaces, cleaning, delinquency control. Day to day it's routine and easy. Good benefits and vacation time. Great schedule. Stable company, expanding.
cons: Terrible upper management. In 8 years we went through 5 district managers. Crazy high pressure to meet goals but you get no power to work with customers or implement any new ideas to achieve the goals. Minimum wage pay if you're a property manager. I got "promoted" from a Relief manager and got money taken from me for a "free" apartment that isn't free if they took money from me to get it. The corporation never gives positive feedback. It's totally $ centered. And while most corporations are at least they attempt to make you feel like you matter. Not so at PS. There is zero room for growth, they do not promote from with in at all.

title: You’re just a number
pros: District Manager was pretty nice.
cons: Pay is poverty wage. Customers are ruthless, and management does nothing to help you. They lie customers and then you get verbally abused for management’s actions. You are just a number.

title: Thanks for the job, but..
pros: It's a job to take in a bad economy or if your in school. Other co-workers are hard working people who try very hard to play by Public Storage's ever changing rules.
cons: Very low pay in regards to the work expected of you. Low budget benefits after 6 months of work?Relief manager must have reliable transportation and travel to 5-7 different sites roughly 10-25 miles away. So after paying for gas it's pretty much a min wage job with maximum stress. District Manager are basically the "real store manager", as manager don't have much power. Dealing with sketchy people in a unsafe work environment. Public Storage is all about covering their own, you know what's, they regular have all employees sign of on working safe at work. But seem to provide nothing towards a safe work environment for those same employees. No security onsite, they don't care about customer break ins because it just forces more customer to buy the overpriced locks out of fear. Bad Corporation, with sub standard wages for it's hard working employees out in the stores. To add insult to injury, they pay the call center employees $2-$4 an hour more to do basically 1/10th of what a Store Manager do. Greedy and dumb Corporation.

title: Don’t appreciate the people just want to make money
pros: Independent, create your own day
cons: Micromanage, hard sells, and no direction

title: Worst Company Ever
pros: I literally can't think of one single reason to recommend working for this company. Of all like ten jobs I've had in my life, this one was worse than all the rest combined!
cons: Where do I start? They start off in the interview process by selling you on the job the same way they train you to sell to customers. You are told there will be "light" cleaning... That's a severe understatement. Then if you're in a district with many properties they tell you they will keep you in one location closest to your home when they really just toss you wherever they want and you're working three different locations in one week. You're also told you'll be working in a specific location but 5 minutes before you leave your house they say to go somewhere else. When you give your two weeks notice, the distric manager goes around like a 12 year old girl and tells all of your co-workers that you quit. I will NEVER return to this company or recommend working for them OR renting storage space with them.

title: Stay Away
pros: Quiet at times you work alone 99 / of the time
cons: Work you to death force and threaten you job if you don’t sell merchandise to every customer the remember all the bosses get a bonus on everything you sell you get nothing forced to sell insurance which is not worth the paper it written on if you don’t meet there numbers the senior DM will come and sit in your office for at least 5 hours he watches and then will find something fire you for but it’s because it is you didn’t get them there bonus this company has got to be investigated the mental abuse they put on there employees is is out of control there is no room to advance you could be there for 10 years and they would rather hire someone for a DM that has no experience you figure it out safety issues are off the chart osha needs to check everyone of these stores I have seen so much in the years I really don’t know how they are still open I guess money can buy anything they have no respect for the real people who make them their money you do work of 3 people no lie Well just had to tell everyone Also they lie to you when you have an interview promise thing that will never happen.

title: Relief Manager
pros: It is a full-time job, so there is no lack in hours. The work is mostly independent, so one can can dictate what gets done and in which order. Most of the work is done within an office with no need for difficult labor. Things such as making calls for reservations, e-mailing the district manager, and completing as well as filing leases are all done in an office setting.
cons: There is no opportunity for promotion from the Relief Manager/ Property Manager position. Though the company and your District Manager will encourage sales and constantly remind you of performance reviews of sales, there is no commission at all. There's is no opportunity to receive a raise either. Once you have been with the company for 6 months you receive a .50 cent raise. After that it is a plateau, and there will be no other pay raises at all. Weekends will most likely be worked as the locations are all open 7 days a week. Physical labor is required while cleaning the property, and unfortunately you may come across very many filthy things. One may have to discard old abandoned furniture, sweep pests such as bugs, and rodents, and may even have to clean feces.

title: Great
pros: Option for an apartment on site
cons: For the amount of work pay could be lots better

title: Property Manager with the best "numbers" and customer reviews in the district .
pros: you get a paycheck...albeit, a smaller one than you deserve. If you aren't willing to do all the work on the property yourself, you are considered less than worthy.
cons: where do I start? Total lack of appreciation for "human beings", so not to mention their employees. They do rotate District Managers and Senior Manager positions so often your head spins, not knowing who your immediate supervisors are; they have been caught in sexual harrassment, dismissing employees to keep them from reporting all the mismanagement and sex liasons, especially betweeen property assistant managers and managers, with senior district and even COO positions...You would not believe what I went through with this company! But I was an "older" employee so hung on for 5 years. They still fired me, although I had held them off for all the previous time. Unwarranted. Even unemployment agreed. How often does that happen? Terrible place to get entangle with; do not promote from within; and if you don't play the game, you never get promoted to even property manager. Which is as far as you can go unless you come from outside the company. Sound odd? It is! It's because you "know too much" about all the employment laws they break, and how little respect this company has for anything or anyone that doesn't have "increased profit" attached.

title: The money grab continues
pros: Steady employment helps to stave off hunger and/or a homeless lifestyle. If you can sell locks and insurance, you can basically get away with being lazy in all other areas..
cons: Many examples. One from last year: No more end of year performance bonuses for the HOURLY employees/Property Managers...never mind they do the most important job in the company. And today, we took another hit: No more cash outs on Paid Time Off. They couched it as a caring, "take time off..work/life balance" thing. It is nothing more than another corporate money grab. I can't imagine what they'll come up with next.

title: Good job
pros: Locations, pay , management,benefits, flexibility
cons: Hours, paper work, rude customers

title: Relief manager. Ocala, Fl
pros: Working alone. Half down time and half busy. Meet lots of new people. Mainly janitorial work. Great job for returning to retail sales. Offers benefits. Builds management experience. Simple cash, checks, and credit card payments.
cons: Forced to sell locks and insurance (company makes employees tell customers insurance is a requirement when it really isn't) Employees are liable to have to explain to district manager why they haven't sold locks, insurance or merchandise. Job is highly based on retail experience. Set scripts to follow and if not learned fluently termination is decided. District managers hardly ever reply to property managers wants and needs for property's issues. Relief and property managers have very low power as far as issues and complaints. Company is very cheap and does not like to spend to fix necessary things around the property. (Roof leaks, gutters, door hasps, lights). Human resource department is very slow and inaccurate when returning paperwork. Depending on district manager, schedules are set and not alternated. (Some managers work every Sat and Sun away from their families; not able to call off because of low staffing). Depending on district manager: can be stuck working extremely busy days with no help. (Lines out of door).

title: Its okay
pros: Can be easy and laid back at times
cons: not paid enough for all you have to do.

title: Greedy, careless company!
pros: -little supervision -if you're lucky, a large apartment for free -wide array of tenants
cons: Most of the properties are worn down but the company is too greedy to fix things. They're too busy buying out all the competition. When my tenants would have items ruined from snow or rain management would say, "just offer them plastic sheeting to cover their things. We're not replacing anything." They could care less about their customers let alone the employees. Each tenant is just a number and is easily replaceable. The company is ALL ABOUT the share holders, not employees or tenants. Not to mention there's no room for growth. You start as a relief manager and you can become a property manager next but that's as high as you go. They tell you in the interview, "we only higher upper management positions from outside the company. Why you ask? Because while we struggle to make ends meet at minimum wage they pay their upper management close to, if not over, six figures a year. Complete garbage!

title: Taught me a lot
pros: -they taught me how to SELL -they have scrips you memorize for everything you do so you feel so confident doing your job. -you learn ALOT about storing items, how to maximize the space in the unit. Very useful life tips I didn’t know I needed. -live onsite, or don’t you don’t have to. -you really do manage the everyday responsibilities of the store(s). I could go on for a while with the pros of this job.
cons: -I would have liked to have more holidays off -you’re by yourself mostly so that comes with it’s difficulties -your DM could make or break your district, I had a good one luckily. -they put emphasis on sales and numbers but it’s not commission based (which I loved because I sucked at selling sometimes) -you have to deal with vendors, unloading a lot of merch by myself (I had a really big property) -you could not “move up” in the company at all really. They don’t promote within for the cooperate positions.

title: 9 year employee read this!
pros: Hours are 9:30 to 6pm 2 days off
cons: *You play many roles in that company. *Property manager is just a label because you have no say on anything in the company. *when you get interviewed they tell you all the goods and always mention the apartment, but don’t mention you have to wait for years for it. (If available) *when you do get apartment nothing gets repaired. * reduce your rate by $2.75 hr to get an apartment * no where in paystub shows how much you pay for the apartment nor that they reduced your rate for it. *you work alone most the time, and that includes office work, attending customer’s, cleaning, collection calls and so much more. *no bonuses *nothing gets repaired at the facility or they expect you to be a handy man and fix it your self. *after 9 years to a job I only got $1 raise just because you live in the apartment. *you can’t grow in the company, I was told I would have to leave my position as KTP and re apply for district manager.

title: An Incredible Company
pros: I have worked here for 5 years, and couldn't be happier. The company is rock solid, with a business model that produces amazing results year after year. Our culture is centered around coaching, executed at all levels of the organization following a model of "We Care". With this, we openly talk about opportunities in our business and partner for success. We are expected to run our business as if we were the CEO of our markets and have the ability to impact results with solid operational execution and coaching for performance. I look forward to the next 5 years of growth and expanded opportunities for success.
cons: We are results oriented, which required a high level of dedication. If you are not willing to work hard, then this may not be company for you. Although "thinking out of the box" is encouraged, we are a highly structured company and we have less flexibility to implement innovative ideas.

title: Good company
pros: Care for employees and environment
cons: Could have better pay and benefits

title: Low pay with high demands - not worth it.
pros: Usually work by yourself or with one other person. If you're bored in the office you can walk the grounds for lock check to break up the day. Usually not a lot of foot traffic.
cons: Pay is poor for what they expect you to accomplish. Demand for sales, sales, sales, and do not want to hear excuses for not being able to sell merchandise, insurance, or a lock. Must check in with DM when you complete sales to explain what you could have done better and how you're going to improve and what goals you are setting for yourself. Must use your own car for bank trips and runs on the property to show units if golf cart is down. Nothing seems to be fixed right away. Lots of sales pressure, no commission. Scams for half the items you have to "sell". Scripts you must follow exact and at times they request.

title: Okay
pros: -Most properties you work are not super busy so you have free time to yourself throughout the day -you can become property manager and get free onsite living but your pay goes down -As long as you get your work done then you don’t have to worry about someone supervising you closely in person -not too much walking or too much physical stress besides when someone leaves something big on property you may have to move or ask for help -opportunity for a monthly $150 if your store(s) do well
cons: -there isn’t much opportunity to move up the company at all and there’s mot much room for promotions as well -long days -not all offices have a break room, fridge or microwave which is annoying for lunch -you’re usually by yourself in the office so it can beget boring and you have to call someone for help if you’re confused or need back up -they underpay!!! -rude and crazy customers who freak out over small things and people who try to live in units, etc -I reported an employee for being overtly racist and nothing happened. Certain employees get away with anything if they do their job or work their long enough

title: Worst Ever
pros: The hours are fantastic, and your coworkers will likely be decent. If you do the job right, you will meet and befriend a number of your tenants, especially if you are a Resident Manager.
cons: This has to be the worst company I have ever worked for. The pay is horrid, about half what the industry median industry wages are. Also, they refuse to pay for upkeep on their buildings. I had to call OSHA after 2.5 years of complaining about the dangers of having NO LIGHTS at the Property when it is dark. I actually went and bought my own light meter and found over 75% of the property, including RIGHT in front of my Apartment Door, registered absolutely ZERO foot candles. A month after I anonymously filed a complaint with OSHA, all the lighting was repaired. What a sad reflection on a company that safety and security concerns are not enough to warrant repairs, only when they face fines for blatant violations of the law do they spend the money. Also, it takes a Manager actually filing a complaint to have this done. Most managers will not, especially in this Economic Environment, because Public Storage can fire you and have you evicted from your home on 72 hours notice. DO NOT WORK HERE!! I left them to go work for another Storage Company that actually pays a percentage of revenue as a bonus in ADDITION to the Residence and HIGHER PAY RATE.

title: empty promises that lead to bad work environment
pros: the only pros are the people are really nice and you can work alot of OT during busy season.
cons: was told during my interview I will most likely get sat or sun off and then another day during the week but I had to have good numbers during training, I tried really hard during training and was top of my class and got stuck with working all weekend anyway. Also we were told that top performers would get 9-5 shifts, now they're adding mandatory OT to my schedule and have me scheduled at 7am. no one asked me if I can work these hours or told me during the hiring process. For a 50 billion dollar company they need to get their act together. When you hire people tell them they won't have weekends off instead of creating some false hope. Also everything is micro managed, can't step away from your desk unless it's your break.

title: District Manager
pros: Public Storage is a good company with a solid foundation and established track record. As a District Manager you will run a multi-unit district and gain valuable experience in a company with a clear promotion structure that provides room for a future. The support structure is clear and if you ask you will receive assistance or guidance when needed. Public Storage recruits high performing leaders to serve in the District Manager role. If you are detail oriented, have the ability to drive behaviors within your team, poses a high degree of organization skills, and the ability to multi task you will be successful in this role. The salary and bonus structure is good and allows reward for your districts performance, the work life balance is better than most normal retailers.
cons: With any new role it will take some time to acclimate to the speed in which you have to operate to be effective and build your efficiency. This will be dependent on your ability to identify, adapt and overcome obstacles.

title: Run Away
pros: Day shift, no nights, that's it.
cons: Too many to list...start with unsafe

title: Going Downhill
pros: It is a great job for those people who like working alone and enjoy having the freedom to be inside/outside. Must be self motivated.
cons: I would say the cons (as of late) is the low pay, all of the scripts, never having holidays off (except for the 3 that corp. finds acceptable) and having to wait so long for anything to be fixed. It is also becoming increasingly evident that Public Storage hates families. A couple of examples would be that 1. You can't give a special to someone who has been listed on someone else' paperwork as a contact (family member) and 2. even though the hours of operation seem to be reasonable, if you have young, active children, you are probably not going to be able to go to anything they have going on because you are the only place open. Also, the constant rent raises are ridiculous, for our customers who are not seeing any reason why they should be getting one since they are being told it's due to upkeep of the properties< yet nothing is being done to them anymore.

title: Profits first, people last
pros: As a district manager, you are in the field very few weekends, with nothing after 6pm.
cons: Extreme micro-management of district managers. Daily conference calls intended to humiliate employees in front of each other. The executive team doesn't think that the buildings should be maintained or cleaned. Most of the customer related issue are avoidable if PS would just loosen the purse strings and let the DM fix the buildings as needed. The hourly employees have no chance of getting promoted and are payed a very low wage. This adds to the difficulty since there is nothing to motivate them to work. Extremely overpriced merchandise and forced to enforce used car salesman pushy sales approach or get fired. The last thing PS thinks about when making a decision is how it effects people. Won't even clean an apartment for an employee before they move in. This could be a great job if they would give two thoughts about people and not make every decision based on what's cheapest today.

title: Public Storagr
pros: Stay away from this company they use and abuse their employees
cons: No cons at all for this job

title: Horrible
pros: Meet new people and ok hours
cons: Long weeks. I have worked 7 and 8 days straight. Never get a Saturday off and very lucky if you get a Sunday off. You never know what you will be working from week to week. Lots of work and no consideration for a family. The buildings are falling apart and camera don't work. Never get recognized for anything you do. They always want more and more. They don't care about there employees because you can be replaced. If your a big boss like DM etc. Then you get great pay and weekends off. Always getting harassed by the customers. I personally have been threatened at least once a week. They don't care. In the end everything falls on your plate. I have never worked for a company that is so heartless. This is a temporary job. Don't get trapped. They make it sound good but everyone is a manager and there higher ups are from outside never within the company. So no chance to move up. If you love your family and don't want to get treated like crap on there shoe don't work here. Lots and lots of work for little pay. You must sale merchandise and push it on customers or get in trouble. They are all about money not customer service. Just a horrible company.

title: Not a career
pros: Office Hours are reasonable. Do not have a manager in your office all the time. Great job for college students and kids living at home with their parents.
cons: Certain DM's are rude and disrespectful. The workload to pay ratio is absurd. Managers are more and more expected to do what DM's used to do. Yet there is not compensation for this. PM's are not able to reprimand RF's when they are not doing there job. Manager's are constantly bickering and gossiping creating an unpleasant work environment. DM's need to be #1 clouds their judgement and causes them to stress out managers even when managers do meet the numbers it is never enough. Young managers come to work with the expectation they will just sit in the office on their phones all day. Managers get their friends hired and tell them its a chill job you don't have to do anything all day.

title: When I first went to work years ago it made its employes feel appriciated, now it treats you like a slave.
pros: The hours are good, and you don't have anyone micro managing you. Most of the people I work with in my district are geat people. I've never had a problem getting time off when I needed it.
cons: Public Storage wants little robots in their offices to speak their scripts and sell the over priced merchandise. Apparently the corporate office doesn't believe that there is a recession. You must sell a lock and insurance and set people up with Auto Pay when they rent whether they want it or not. We have a new contest running right now where the district manager and the regional manager get a trip to Hawai and the property managers who do all the work get a $100.00. Just think about that, you do all the work and get $100.00 bucks and your boss and his boss go to Hawai! Their pay raises are also a joke, their idea of a raise is a whole .25 or less, yes I said less.

title: Think twice before taking a position with this company
pros: Being able to get time off when needed.
cons: Advertisement stated that I would be working 40 hours a week - in reality it was 35 hours a week. I only worked for the company for 2 months but it became very clear that there was a great deal of disrespect amongst the employees. District meetings were thick with tension and the gossip that occurred on a daily basis was amazing. My property manager would actually have 2 phones on speaker (2 different stores) so they could sit and gossip. There truly is no "team" within this company. It is all about the money and no concern for the employees. Throwing one another "under the bus" seems to be a very active sport at this company. Also the inability to take responsiblity for one's behavior is very prevelant. There is nowhere to eat lunch - maybe a broom closet with a microwave if you are lucky. Other than that, one must eat in his/her vehicle or go to a restaurant. During the summer months, the air conditioner stopped working - the district manager decided not to fix it because of cost and that he considered it the employees' fault that it was not working. at times the office was close to 90 degrees!!

title: Property manager
pros: There are no pros for this company
cons: Worked here for 7 years. This is the worst company you could ever work for. Don't do it, and if you do, do not take an apartment. That's how the get you to stay. I'm going to be honest. I was contacted by HR to write a positive review on this site so "we can hire employees at your level" bull!!! I feel so bad for DM's They are expected to be on the clock 24/7. The pay is terrible and anyone with a positive review on here is either higher management or were told to write a good review by HR. You will be unhappy and ruin your life here. You will have to learn 10 scripts and get written up if you're not selling enough locks or insurance. They expect 85% locks and insurance but again we do not get any bonus or incentive on it. You will deal will customers complaining about things being broken and things will never get fixed because it will not help the stock. No one cares about low level employees even though we are the ones lining their pockets with money.

title: Not a family orientated job.
pros: Hours the stores are open.
cons: Some of the DM's alone will bring this company down. They have no experience working for the company and yet they are hired. More then half the time they do not know What they are to do or How to do it and push it off on those who do know. Micro management is the only way this gets done in our district. And good luck trying to file that complaint about them or anyone for that matter cause they never do anything about it anyways. The pay for this job is WAY under What it should be, and vacation time is never going to happen, between black out dates and having to have it manitary that you are here the last day of the month and the 1st day! Weekends, going to work those also cause you have to have time in your "pto" to get those days. So, if you have no life, no kids and like working for Nothing, and have upper management treat you poorly this is job for you! Oh and good luck getting any type of bonus...

title: A positive outlook
pros: Working at Public Storage has helped me in great ways that other companies can’t do for you. As a college student it is important for me to have a full time job that will work with your schedule and Public Storage has done that for me. Not only that but we are offered great benefits like 401k, medical insurance, paid vacation time, & more. The company also has an awesome referral program because they want to hire excellent employees. As a property manager, I work mostly independently and often times with my district manager to make sure my property meets expectations.
cons: Like any job there are some cons to working here. For example there are times when you have to deal with disrespectful tenants or rude customers so it is important to stay calm and try to fix the situation. Another con is that there is not much room to advance in the company. You are either a relief manager or a property manager. Some property managers will have the opportunity to become trainers but that’s about it.

title: Public Storage is a great place to work, IMO.
pros: Ive been working for public storage for some time now, and i cant say i relate to the reviews im seeing on here. From the beginning, the SDM who hired me has been very confident in my abilities. He has shown me much encouragement & continously gives me props for what i do. My DM is absolutely phenomenal. He listens to my every need and responds to every text message and call almost immediately. He also gives me a sense of security, he lets me know hes here for me and hes got my back. I dont know if its the region im in, but in my district we work as a team. I couldnt be happier. For those complaining about numbers and scripts, we are SALES people. Of course theyre going to expect good numbers from us!
cons: Having to work every weekend lol , but of course you know this will be required from the moment you are interviewed. If youre going to complain about it, just dont take the job.

title: This the place to be!
pros: This is a great company to work for! The pros of the company are countless and I could spend hours going through them. They have an excellent training program with many opportunities for growth. If you are looking to move forward in your career, this is the company to help you get there. The team environment is like no other. District Managers work well together; supporting each other and sharing best practices. The compensation is more than fair and the earning potential with bonus can be over $100K annually. The reason I came to Public Storage is for upward mobility. From day one, my supervisors have made my development their priority. With the right drive, results, work ethic and commitment, you will be recognized quickly and this will result in advancement. The company is growing at a fast pace, the opportunities continue to become available. If you love challenges, driving results, leading a team and working for a great team; this is the job for you!
cons: There are no cons at this time. Any time that an issue arises, it is discussed and resolved in an efficient manner.

title: Changing Culture
pros: -Flexible schedule at times -Building life long friendships with peers is common here because we were able to share some of the same terrible experiences we had with daily tasks and irate customers.
cons: Compensation may seem fair until you realize just how much your having to work.
