You have to make sure your properties are open 7 days a week, take phone calls and check emails 7 days a week, spend 7 days a week catching up on what you couldn’t get to during the week because you are consumed with countless tasks. Throw in physically cutting locks and recently the DMs have had to manage large facility projects with all the spare time they have and you have one burned out employee. Over the last year the DM position has become a maintenance manager and glorified adult babysitter role with little room for decision making and developing strong employees.

title: Low Pay
pros: Good time off, benefits and set schedules
cons: Low paying job, had to be on food stamps

title: Best Career Decision: Life Changing!!! (Former Store Manager @Walmart)
pros: Work Life Flexible, Generous PTO balance, Generous Stock Plan, Great People: As a district manager at Public Storage, I got my happy back. I am assigned to a complex district(that I love) and I still have the flexibility to enjoy my loved ones. I have nights and weekends off. I work from home on Thursdays. I have the ability manage my district the way I see fit. The success of my district is up to me. The best part is that I have a Regional Manager who has my back through it all. She is supportive , inspires confidence and accountability. And to top it off, we have fun reaching company goals. Stress level is minimal. I love it here and looking forward to the next steps! Overall great company that continues to acquire new portfolios across the country. A company that's here to stay.
cons: Yes. I took a pay cut when measured against my Store Manager salary @ Walmart. The biggest difference is the annual bonus. Annual Bonus is given in the form of unvested stock awards. Not necessarily a con but an adjustment for sure.

title: Working for one of the best companies out there!
pros: Some of the greatest things about working for Public Storage really fall into feeling that the work that you do day in and day out really matter. Your contributions really can steer the business in the right direction. Work life balance is also very good. Public Storage really allows me to unplug whenever I have PTO. Lastly, the leadership from our peers and managers really make all the difference. I always feel valued and the feedback I receive is always geared to help me be a better manager.
cons: There are very few downsides. The only downside that I could see bother some, is the distance that it would take to get to your assigned district. Once you're in the district. Properties are very close. but some may not like the amount of travel that they have to do to get there. For me, I don't mind driving, but I can see where others may not like it.

title: Started Great
pros: No one is physically standing over you while you work, You can balance your duties over the day how you see fit. Pays decent. You get to work with some great people. And the majority of the customers are wonderful. You can earn PTO for every hour you work. If available you can be lucky enough to get an almost free apartment. ( some strings attached ). Benefit package is decent. If your a multitasker and very flexable, and great at sales with no commission its a great place!
cons: If your looking to advance in the company you have to be hired at a District Manager level or higher. Turnover is often in most areas. Expectations are to treat the business as it's your own, but the pay doesn't reflect this. If your lucky, you can get a District Manager that knows how to mold you to the goals needed. Sadly they are stretched over an area that entails them to limit the amount of time they have to work with individual employees. Lots of changes and often. You can be praised on the inhale, and demeaned on the exhale. If your looking for a job for a year maybe two it might be the job for you.

title: THE place to work!
pros: After 10 years as a DM in retail, I knew I needed out but had no idea where to go. Luckily, I found my savior in Public Storage. Great work/life balance. People are amazing. Compensation and benefits match the position perfectly. And the additional incentive of the bonus program make all the hard work worth it. PS provides a solid training and development program along with an abundant supply of resources to help every employee be successful in their position.
cons: Small property staffs on single coverage can make it difficult to staff in emergency situations. DMs are responsible for getting handyman work completed on their properties which takes up valuable time and can be challenging to get vendors to complete the work.

title: NO Upward movement
pros: In my case, I have the most amazing District Manager. My District Manager empowers the Property Managers that show passion for wanting more from their career. My pay is decent and the apartment is not a bad perk if you can get into a nice area.
cons: The BIGGEST con when working for Public Store is the lack of culture for upward movement. "A" Property manager and or Training Manager is the end of the road. No matter how well you perform or rank in the company there is no opportunity for advancement.

title: 7 Great Years and Counting!
pros: After 7 years I’ve seen industry innovations, improvements to processes and then more tweaks to make the already great culture even better! PS and our management teams absolutely listen to our customers, our employees and we use feedback for the purpose of bettering our customer experience, solidifying our place as the leader in the industry and improving the work life of our employees. Supervisory support, check! Work life balance, check! Recognition for a job well done, check! A place to grow your career, check! Best of all, the people! As a DM we are able to drive results through coaching diverse teams of people, all coming together with a common goal, solve our customers storage problem, with the right storage solution, at the best price and with the best customer service! Like I said, 7 years down and excited for many more!
cons: With our growth strategy, constantly acquiring more square footage, and dominance in the industry you could be left behind if you’re not up for the challenge of keeping pace and keeping your team engaged. If your the type that engages your team daily, builds a culture within your team of support and growth then you’re golden.

title: Learn the exciting Day-to-Day Operations of managing any retail business!
pros: Public Storage offers a very generous benefits package which includes Medical/Vision/Dental/Legal & 401k contributions with matching deposits & Profit sharing opportunities. Public Storage provides paid training, as well as detailed and specifically tailored ongoing training to learn the day-to-day operations of running a retail business and management truly cares about ensuring your success: from Customer Service, Sales, Accounting, Exceeding Goal expectations & customer issue resolution. You also have a vast amount of autonomy in running a location. And as the largest, Fortune 500 personal storage company with over 2,600 locations nationwide, opportunities exist for advancement and relocation throughout the United States. Public Storage also believes employees need to have a well-balanced mix of work and family life. As far as retail goes, Public Storage's business hours are VERY family friendly! Typical business hours weekdays are only from 9:30am -6pm, and slightly less on weekends Overtime is NEVER mandatory, but available if desired.
cons: You MUST enjoy working with the public, and be outgoing with the ability to LISTEN to all customers, and be empathetic to their individual situations. Also, most properties are single covered, so need to be reliable in showing up to scheduled shifts on time.

title: They are not all bad
pros: PS is a great opportunity to learn management and propfessional skills that will be valuable assetts in future career ventures.
cons: They tend to hire people that are able to be "pressured" into shady methods. Ethics amongst this company are comparable to those of the credit collection industry; way below average. Pressure to push merchandise on customers is high; we are hounded to sell things, even to customers that obviously don't need it. PS is not a criminal organization. PS provides a good service to the community that is valuable, but they are shady in their merchandise sales.

title: Supportive Company
pros: Public Storage gives their employees a platform to learn, grow and gain experience in many different areas from customer service to sales. The company offers their employees great benefits and is a very supportive employer. A big plus is the possibility of an apartment which frequently goes with becoming a Property Manager. What I like best about the job is the friendships made along the way. My boss, co-workers and my customers are the reason why I love going to work each day. I’m very grateful that the company took a chance on me with my spotty resume. Great for young adults, students and young retirees. I would definitely recommend this job. All local upper management are great people to work for. My co-workers are all hard working great people. I absolutely love working for Public Storage.
cons: Pay could definitely be better and should not be basically the same for every Property Manager. Not all properties and workload is the same. No ladder to climb, but it is a steady income in unsure times.

title: Whatever public storage
pros: Company not fair to employees or customers,
cons: Prices are outrageous,rude employees,nasty stores,no security cameras if so they don't work

title: Great Career Path
pros: I never thought I would work for a Storage Company. I came from a fast pace and high stress environment that was not supportive and I used to work almost 60 hours a week.Public Storage is a great company to work for. There is a nice work/life balance here. I've heard from my supervisors at many levels to not spend so much time working after hours, which I chose to do. They only hire District Managers from outside with previous experience. The employees and management here are great. There are many oppurtunity to move up after the District Manager level. The workload is manageable. I enjoy having my own team and creating a positive and friendly sales culture. It is great to see how your leadership and coaching can affact behavior and change. If you want to develop your leadership and management skills and build a career with management, this is a great company to work for. They are evolving their sales culture and continue to be the industry leader and I am proud to be part of it!
cons: No company car but I can expense my miles

title: Behind the Orange Doors
pros: Guaranteed 38 to 39 hours. If your a property manager you are at a set location which is good to get to know your area and customers demographics wise. Also, its a pretty laid back job once you do what you have to get done and is repetitive so every month on select days you pretty much know your work load.
cons: The PAY! For such a big company with over 2,300+ locations the employees who do all the hard work renting spaces and keeping the facilities cleaned deserve better than $9. The competitors pay more but we are leading in real estate something is definately wrong with that. Also bonuses and incentives....they can do better. It doesnt make me feel as an employee that the company cares how we live day to day with so little.

title: Relief manager
pros: Worked here for about a year . Guaranteed 38 hours full time .. Depeanding on your DM you might have a less tougher time having a really flexible schedule.. very nice for a temporary job to pay at least the majority of your bills.
cons: The pay is just not enough for what they demand you to do . They expect you to clean windows , walls , floors , sweep all theirs units and emptied units .. There also is no bonuses or room for growth ! The only growth u can get is from relief to property manager .. which is not even a raise in pay . Property and relief managers do the same things and get the same pay.. the only difference is that property managers get blamed for everything and more pressure .. so I’m not sure if that would even be considered growth ! .. also the pressure for selling merchandise is rediculous !! They set these high goal expectations just so that the DM and upper managements can get their bonuses , u get absolutely nothing expect them finding something else to complain about !

title: District Manager
pros: Coming from a big box retail background I find this position a breath of fresh air. The work life balance is a huge plus for me. Being able to have most weekends off and not having to work late nights or early mornings is a big plus. Compensation is good along with a performance based bonus structure and annual stock options make it a financially great place to work. Benefits are good and the vacation accrual is very generous. It is a great place to develop talented teams to drive results through regular teaching and coaching interactions. You will work with talented leaders and peers. Public Storage recruits the best talent for the DM position and promotes within. It is a very team oriented place to work that fosters healthy competition among peers. It is a place where everyone is willing to help and share ideas to drive success not just for individuals but for the company.
cons: No real cons. You will engage with customers as needed to solve elevated issues. The job certainly has its challenges but the rewards are beneficial.

title: Disappointing 2 years
pros: Good Pay the first year with guaranteed bonus
cons: As a District Manager you are working 7 days a week with no work life balance (even on vacation), micromanaged to the point of not running your own area. The upper management believes that learning and memorizing scripts will bring in sales. There is no real training department. There is even a script for DM's to use when coaching employees. No advancement for Property managers and the bonus and pay is pathetic and there is no advancement opportunity so there is no incentive for them to improve. Leadership leads with hostile tactics. Lock cuts are not safe and when the injuries are reported, the details are pushed under the rug. Regional sets up employees for failure so he can look better. This job is stressful and not worth the money.

title: Public Storage provides a lot of opportunities to advance your career.
pros: Public Storage is a winning Company with approachable employees at all levels of the organization. Strong bonus programs provide opportunities for all employees in the Company. As a DM, you are able to create and develop your Team. With smaller Teams compared to other District Manager positions with other Companies, you are able to spend more time with each employee to coach, recognize great performances and follow up. DM's get to increase leadership skills, facilitating skills and mentoring skills by working closely with other District Managers and Regional Managers.
cons: Company provides a lot of perks to the field personnel including full time positions, benefits, annual bonuses and provide apartments to live in as well. Even with these perks, I would like to see more incentives for the employees in the properties at a monthly or quarterly timeframes.

title: Not a Career
pros: Work schedule - 9:30am-6:00pm. Independent environment.
cons: -No promotions. -No pay negotiation. -Bonuses are awarded to property managers only once a year and are gutted by the time they make it through division/region/district/property. Bonuses are not based on whether or not you hit metric goals but are based on how well you stack up with fellow employees. Some properties have a clear advantage when it comes to sales based on location. -Hard work often goes unrecognized and unrewarded. -Company doesn't care about turnover which creates a stressful environment for other employees. -High pressure sales environment with daily sales calls without the benefit of making commission or monthly/quarterly bonuses.

title: District Manager
pros: The properties are only open during the day, so there is no second or third shift issues. The technology is always leading edge and the ability to pull reports to check current status is amazing.
cons: You are completely micro-managed. The number of assigned tasks continues to grow and become more and more difficult to accomplish and takes you away from developing your people. When certain goals are not achieved the management style shifts to a bully style management approach and is very uncomfortable.

title: Minimal Pay, A lot of Job Duties
pros: Usually pretty easy work, ability to work independently and autonomously, no boss breathing down your neck, other co-workers are helpful, good facilities.
cons: Too many different tasks to complete throughout the day. Although easy work, there is just too much work for one person to complete for this amount of pay. Very minimal pay. Hard to get time off. Other cons include dealing with bad customers who break rules and live out of units. Having to be the bad guy and evict homeless drug addicts who aren't happy with you. Have to meet sales quotas and push un-needed insurance and packing supplies on customers. Also having to push customers for Internet Reviews when most just want to get their unit and be done with the process. Very little help from management with billing discrencies. Too large of a company takes to long for disputes to get handled, meanwhile you're the sounding board for angry customers while they wait to get resolution to problems. TOo many calls to make per week. Repetitive work. Minimal pay. Very little room for advancment.

title: Not fun...
pros: It's nice not working nights.
cons: The company doesn't car about it's employees. Raises are a joke or non existant. Bonuses get cut smaller every year. Pushing for google reviews is out of control. Pushing for Insurance and locks and being judged on that is unfair. The properties in winter do not get cleared and we are the ones having to handle irate customers, but they still want reviews anyway. People who work hard are not rewarded and people who slack off get away with it all the time. I would not recommend this job to anyone. If you live onsite you take a pay cut, and it would be great as the apt and all utilities are included, but when it comes to raises they do it as a percentage so even if you work like crazy, you get a smaller raise because your pay is less to begin with. You are not paid based on your performance at all.

title: Your Experience is Based on Your Location, Lifestyle, Transportation and Ability to Cope
pros: Please note that my three-star rating can go up to a four, or even a five based on your personal experience. This can be a great job if you want to work for a stable company. If you are a two-income family, this may also be a good job. There are options to work full-time or part-time. Vision and dental insurance coverages are good. The variety of job responsibilities keeps the work interesting. Physical work helps keep you in shape. Opportunities open from time to time to apply to work at a location that comes with an apartment. Helping customers can be rewarding.
cons: While the insurance coverage is good, you pay 50% of the cost of your benefits. You may need a car depending on the district you work for. National management has strict expectations regarding specific quotas you're supposed to meet or exceed that have nothing to do with renting storage. This changes over time so I won't be specific. Dealing and coping with difficult renters (those who defy regulations or refuse to follow rules stated on their contract) can be very stressful. Your pay is minimum wage.

title: Super easy job
pros: Very easy job, no prior skills or education required. All goals/benchmark numbers are easily obtained if you do things the way they script. i am in top 15 in my region, and it is not difficult at all. follow the scripts, follow the policy, follow the rules, and you will exceed. I get max bonus every year. very easy job. not for lazy.
cons: Your district is your "team". too many people here that just 'punch a clock'. Pay is too low to reel in quality field employees. PMs, need more power in dealing with big picture stuff happening on properties. DMs become too overwhelmed and things like customer service and property maintaining gets neglected. If your hired anything lower than DM, you have no chance to move up in the company. thats a poor policy

title: Great company to work for!
pros: This company is a hidden gem. Who knew storage can create fantastic careers in management? Public Storage is a great place to work at all levels. The senior management team is extremely supportive and personable. This is an very stable and successful corporation with great values. It is great to see our President and VPs in the field building rapport and getting feedback from the team to create a supportive and positive working environment. You can feel the pride and energy from people who work here at all levels. The company is growing and there are a lot of opportunities to move up to the next level. I'm glad I found Public Storage where I can continue to grow and be part of a successful and profitable team.
cons: The only downside is that very few people know about the positives of working for this company! The industry might have a bad rep but it's about the people and the team who supports you. Public Storage does it right when it comes to employee development and training.

title: Kind of shady
pros: Rent free apartments if you can get one Daytime hours
cons: Minimum wage Too much work for the pay you get Shady practices Unethical No way to advance

title: $$ Grubbing Corporation!!!!!
pros: You get to work alone and have a rent & utilities free place to live.
cons: PS is not family-friendly nor are they good to their employees. 1. They raise the rent on customers telling them it is due to repairs needed on the property, but don't fix anything in a timely manner. Also, they take the cheapest route possible. 2. The pay is horrible. 3. They say security is important. My gate has been broken several times this year and has stood open 24/7 for over a week. The gate vendor told me that PS could have paid to overnight the part, but refused. Yea, that's real secure, huh? Also, half the lights don't work on my property. 4. You only get 3 paid holidays off a year. 5. They make it harder and harder to get bonuses every year. 6. Sick? Don't even think about calling in. There's no one to cover your store. I could go on and on. If it weren't for me living here(I have a really nice apt) I would have walked along time ago!!!!

title: District Manager
pros: If one comes from a retail background, the majority of weekends off and the ability to take time off around Thanksgiving and Christmas are nice perks.
cons: One will perpetually be yelled at by customers, since the District Manager becomes the first line of defense for every upset customer in the district. You will have to work in the elements, as cutting locks in the heat of the summer/cold of the winter and running auctions in the torrential downpours is a regular portion of the job. There is nearly zero ability to innovate or think critically, as every aspect of the job is process oriented and one, therefore, merely becomes focused on endless tasks. If I had to guess, the company advertises the salary on each job posting because they would not get any applications for the position otherwise, and certainly wouldn't be able to retain good people if it did not pay better than many from the retail background - from which they recruit - are used to being compensated. There is simply not any satisfying aspects of the job itself.

title: Stepping stone job
pros: Hours are 930 til 6 monday thru friday and til 5 on weekends. Coworkers for the most part are good to work with.
cons: Starting pay is 9.50. Dont expect much more as bonuses went away and no raises in 2018. If you take on a property as property manager there is NO extra pay for doing so, just more responsibility and accountability. They do have some properties with on site managers apartme t. Watch out, if you arent good at saving or have particular circumstances you will be VERY hard pressed to be able to leave as apartments outside of this are costly to move in. Empty promises, pressure for sales and you get the 3rd degree if any of your metrics are low. Never worked someplace where management works so hard to find you doing something wrong or dwell on your faults.

title: Treat people the way you want to be treated!
pros: Lived on site. Had job when needing a job and was able to exist.
cons: Where to start? No living wage. Took away all holidays, longer hours on Sundays, chipped away at benefits, treated employees like they were idiots, made employees kowtow to their wishes, micromanaged, reviews never would allow a 5 on a 1-5 scale stating a 5 was impossible for "anyone" to achieve, blamed employee if people came in with their own locks, based bonuses on differing criteria each month, making it impossible to know which criteria was important. Life as a live on manager was 24.7 with people knocking on the door of ones apt and screaming and yelling at being locked out, or being locked in because they did not get out on time, dealing with policemen being called and alarms going off all the time and people urinating and defecating on the property.

title: Best company I have ever worked for!
pros: I love the working hours and that it is a full time job. The job is very easy and rewarding! I love that your success with the company is always recognized and the company even picks an elite divisional circle of excellence winner and flys them on an all expense paid trip for the manager and a guest to California every year to attend the annual sales conference where the manager is presented their award and recognized for their achievements. This is one company that you will never have to worry about going out of business, so there is job security.
cons: I can only think of one. They do not promote within the company to district manager or higher. The furthest you can be promoted is to a KTP which is the person that trains all new hires and assists the district manager while still having the role of a property manager.

title: Lots of opportunity for growth as a DM!
pros: This company has a great culture that is really focused on people development at every level of the business. As a DM I was given continually feedback on development opportunities and stretch assignments to hone my abilities. I have grown in a leader more here in 4 years than I did in my past several positions. Additionally, the work life balance is fantastic in comparison to normal retail. No late hours or night shifts and weekend working hours are minimal for a management position. The ability to grow and create your promotional opportunity through hard work and performance is at your fingertips! All promotions after the DM level are internal and the next step, Senior District Manager, is yet another opportunity to grow!
cons: The biggest con is that some DMs don’t see their own potential. There is so much opportunity here so one should never sell themselves short. I did not enjoy doing auction ads as an admin task but overall the admin was manageable with proper organization and time management.

title: I love my job!
pros: I value my career here even more than ever due to the fact that during Covid, alot of my friends and family were getting laid off from their positions and companies were downsizing and closing down and we didn't miss a beat. The company is stable and recession proof and stability is very important to me. I love that this position gives me such a great work life balance- I am a full-time working mom with 2 young kids and I love that my mornings and evenings can be dedicated to them without work distractions. This is not your typical retail position of opening super early and closing super late and being slammed and busy during holidays. We are open from 9:30 am to 6pm on weekdays and 9:30am to 5pm on Weekends and holidays are our slower times so we have more family time. Upper management is very hands on and involved and I always feel supported and heard.
cons: I would love to be closed on Sundays completely but we cant have it all, right? I would love to see a wage increase for store level employees.

title: Great Team Environment!
pros: Especially in the last few years we've added more pros to this list. We are focused on the development of our teams, we are committed to evolving our business and trying new things, we understand how to drive our results, the total pay package is competitive, and it would be difficult to find an organization that is as stable or supportive as Public Storage.
cons: In a previous review I highlighted employee development as our biggest opportunity but I'm excited to see that we identified it and are making progress. I believe that this area is still our current con as we haven't created that clear path of development for our teams.

title: Relief for 4 months
pros: Their are not really many pros except if you get the health insurance, their health insurance is pretty good for the cost.
cons: The hours are in the middle of the day, no flexibility as far as days off, they rarely give 40 hours a week. You are constantly dealing with pissy customer because they have either had a rent increase, late fees, or they were told it was only going to be $23 and then we have to sell them lock and insurance (which has gone up). The amount of responsibility and stress for the pay is not worth it. Plus they've been putting me at properties that are not even close to where I live, I can think of at least 5 properties that are closer to me than the one I'm working at now. My DM just got fired for being so much of a jerk to his employees and not listening, which is the norm for PS DMs. The pay and bonuses (which change and get less every year) are just completely not worth it. If you become a property manager (more responsibility) there is no pay raise. After 6 months there's a .50 pay raise and that's pretty much it. They do not hire up within, so no room for growth.

title: Great company; even greater people.
pros: First, the company is solid. It’s the undisputed leader in the industry with a good business model and a strong balance sheet – it’s not going anywhere but up. The compensation is more than fair and there are the usual vacation and insurance benefits many companies offer these days. But it’s the intangibles that really make a difference. There’s a genuine passion to help employees develop and grow as professionals. And with the breadth of knowledge available in this office, you are limited only by your own ambition. The environment is friendly and casual, with no ivory towers or executive washrooms. Even the highest-level executives are approachable and willing to listen to new ideas from anyone. It’s a refreshingly open-minded culture for a company this large – and probably one of the greatest reasons for our continued success.
cons: There’s a lack of system redundancies in some areas that can cause pinch-points if a process fails. This is especially true with IT and the various software programs that that are inter-reliant. We need more diligent monitoring and better recovery planning – even if it’s just improved notification.

title: constant turnover
pros: good benefits if you can afford them
cons: No promoting from with in, scripts that mislead customers, heavy physical work cleaning abandoned goods with no help, egotistical upper management, low wages, yearly 2% pay increase, unattainable bonus structure and lack of injury reporting. Minimal and drawn out repairs to facilities, required to rent units with known issues like water intrusion, mold, falling insulation ect. Inexperienced DM's that are given freedom to implement changes to policies and procedures with no concern or understanding of long term goals. Requiring meeting a growing number of metrics including selling locks insurance, merchandise, collections, attaining social reviews, customer email addresses, setting up auto pay,ect. Constant changes with lack of additional training. I could go on but after reading other reviews I think viewers to avoid this company.

title: Great place to invest your career
pros: First and foremost, we have a Chairman of the Board that truly cares about every individual in the organization. Additionally, we have all been held to a very high standard of integrity, so our company won't stand for unethical members on the team. If you want to be developed, and grow both professionally and personally then this is the place to be. We do set the bar high, because we believe that in order to be the best, we must have the best people. We all work very hard at Public Storage, but the rewards far outweigh the hard work. I look forward to starting my day, because I know that I work for one of the best ran corporations in the world. Lastly, with all of the businesses shuttering their doors, laying off people or being taken over...I can sleep well at night knowing that my company has solid balance sheet and a bright future.
cons: If you are not performance driven and results oriented, then you won't like working here.

title: Solid Company That Develops Leaders
pros: • The company is a market leader and very intelligent in the way that they spend their finances. Public Storage is a very financially stable company. • If you're looking for a company to grow your career and advance, Public Storage has leaders in place at every level to get you to where you want to go. Employee development is the company's number one priority.
cons: A Need to Know for Prospective Candidates: • A candidate needs to be able to develop a sales focused field staff and drive the business under a very limited payroll structure. • Candidates have to be a very organized individually and able to manage their time efficiently as the position requires you to wear multiple hats to be successful at the position managing operations to customer service to repair and maintenance issues.

title: Dead End Job
pros: Great training for the Self Storage Industry, less of a "RAT RACE" when you live onsite, no supervisor hanging over your shoulder trying to micro manage you. Great bonuses IF you run a large property (more stress) AND can reach the ever changing goals that are set for you.
cons: Pay is not in line with the amount of work and responsibility you are given. While you are allowed PTO (paid time off) there is usually not enough employees working for the company to cover you for an unscheduled day off such as you or your child getting ill, and so you are pressured to work anyway. While you are told you have benefits the package is expensive with poor coverage, a single mother would have a hard time insuring herself and her children and still have enough money for necessities.

title: CEO who only thinks about bottom line
pros: Very financially stable company whose stock is doing well. Leader in the self-service storage market and is rapidly expanding operations. Employees are very smart and hard working.
cons: CEO only thinks of the bottom line to the detriment of Public Storage's employees and customers. For instance, starting 2014, corporate employees' 10 days of sick time was effectively eliminated and, for some employees, their vacation time reduced. We now have a reduced pool of "paid time off" so if you take a sick day, you take what was previously your vacation time. Raises are rarely and minimally granted, even though the company is doing very well. CEO's mantra for the customer is "no pay, no stay" putting the field in a very difficult position when dealing with their customers. The field has very little flexibility to work with customers, which makes it hard for them to deliver any real customer service. Though the CEO surrounds himself with some extremely smart senior management, he doesn't listen to them and will make decisions against their advice. His management style is to impose fear and intimidate.

title: Worst ever
pros: The only pro is that if you like working alone you do this alot here.
cons: Management makes your life hell if you question them, call HR, or assert your rights. They pay is horrible. They use your PTO without telling you. Paid holidays are only 3. There are no incentives for selling. And they want you to lie to customers so they will buy locks and insurance. And There is only one position you cant move up from which is property manager, the very people who make the money for this greedy company with their greedy DM's who never have anything on the properties fixed because it comes out of their bonuses.

title: Former Employee
pros: As an employee, you work independently at your own pace. This is a bonus for an individual that needs NO SUPERVISION. A skill to have is time management because you are your own relief for lunch and property checks
cons: The downside to working independently is that you are working alone, for the most part, if you have an issue with multitasking or time management, this is not the job for you.

title: Island of Misfit Toys
pros: I LOVED 20% of my customers, and the Resident Manager at a couple of places. I liked my District Manager.
cons: Public Storage is a publicly held company and their #1, #2, & #3 goals are PROFIT. Their employees are a means to that end. I made $12 per hour with virtually no overtime. At large facilities if you have to work by yourself, it is overwhelming. At small facilities if you have to work by yourself it can be mind-numbingly boring. The Resident Managers can be obnoxious with their own "territory". The company allows NO variation from their structured rules. I was told if I followed the rules , it would be a job for as long as I wanted it (not get fired). Raises are small and almost a slap in the face. There is a bonus program and if you win, it works out to about an extra $0.75/hr for that month. Relief Managers are scheduled to go anywhere they are needed and sometimes that location changes at the last minute.

title: Corporate Office - Accountant
pros: I have been working for Public Storage for almost a year now and I have to say it's a big step up from the public accounting world. Work hours are 8AM-5PM with minimal overtime required. Great work environment with people who actually love their jobs. Most of the people that I work with have been here for 20+ years. I think the reason Public Storage has such a low turn-over rate is because they really focus on the little things. They provide us with bagels every Friday and even have raffles with cash prizes at our monthly meetings. Although these things seem really simple they help keep up the morale in the office.
cons: The pay is good but could be more competitive. They only give you 3 paid holidays so you have to use PTO if you want other holidays off. People tend to stay with the company for 20+ years so it could be hard to move up within the company.

title: Company Review
pros: Company listens to employee suggestions, works around your hours, easy work for the pay and benefits you receive from the company.
cons: The downside of working with Public Storage is that property managers have no authority over anyone working their property, you have no way to make sure the work is done other than do it yourself. Also, ANY complaint submitted by renters is accepted by management as true, there is NO loyalty to the employee.

title: Great place..if youre looking to gain storage skills...and leave...
pros: A set numbers of hours each week, as a relief your locations may change,however you will have a set amount of hours each week.
cons: *Scripts: PS has come up with several scripts that they want you to memorize to use in daily interactions with the customers,they insist on "role-playing" during visits and have you sign that you will learn these scripts..... *Google: PS has stepped away from providing customer service,and is now pushing the employees to have customers write reviews on Google. As an associate,you are expected to pass out a card asking for a review, and keep track of how many you gave out with how many you expect to receive a review from.... *Bonus: What bonus?? When I first started,we received bonuses every quarter....then it went to monthly...now its ONCE a year...and that is ONLY if you are within the high ranking.... This company is not geared towards the customers or the employees. As an employee you are expected to produce numbers which boosts the upper management pockets.

title: A Stable Company Focused on Its People
pros: Hands down the best company I have ever worked for. There is a huge emphasis on people development and naturally, along the way, some won't make it. You are expected to work and work hard, but with all of the growth opportunities here, you are recognized and rewarded for your hard work. I honestly feel like my supervisors care about me and my continued growth and development in my career. I definitely did not feel that in my previous job. Coming from a retail background, having the holidays be your slowest time period of the year is a nice change as well!
cons: None that I can really think of. This is really a great company to work for if you're not afraid to push yourself and work hard.

title: Not worth the stress and games
pros: Most co workers are friendly and helpful. The set schedules are nice too, not much else to say though. Helping customers one on one isnt bad either.
cons: The sales culture being shoved down employees throats is depressing and demotivating. The constant need to sell merchandise drives a lot of employees to just flat out cheat and charge customers without telling them. Even worse the DM's are aware of this practice but if youre a favorite if theirs theyll look the other way, even promote you in cases I've seen. It's very corrupt, immoral, and probably illegal. If youre a kiss up youll do fine, you can get away with almost anything (calling out at least once a week etc) if youre not on the "pet list" though, watch out.

title: Stressful, Dangerous, But Okay Sometimes
pros: Decent pay. Sometimes it is so dead you can read or catch up on shows. Working alone. My District Manager was respectful, helpful, and understanding. Work-life balance. The hours are good, and you are able to request time off and earn decent PTO.
cons: In general, you are running an entire property and managing the accounts of potentially hundreds of tenants. As a relief, you rotate around your district and some properties are really gross and terrible. Rowdy homeless people, dead cats, prostitutes, and overall crazy tenants are just some of the things you will be dealing with. Also, you are basically holding people's stuff ransom and tenants get crazy, like threatening and screaming crazy. You also auction peoples stuff. That is just the people side. On the property side, if the property is old be ready to fix broken things often, deal with rats, deal with break ins (which happen constantly), and deal with stuff not working. It is fine if you are mentally tough and physically capable. Otherwise, its a ridiculous job.

title: A company that his highly successful and profitable, at the total expense of it's employees.
pros: Decent pay, good benefits. (as a DM) Very good bonus's, and preferred stock, but Don't get lulled in by the golden fish hook.
cons: Complete disregard for one's work life balance. really a 7 day a week job. very common for the customer service department in California to call your home at 8pm to 9pm sending you back out on the job for ridiculous problems. They pay their reliefs and property manager very poorly, which makes it difficult to recruit and retain good people. I was called at 10pm on Christmas eve to go to work, because a fire alarm was going off. The stories could go on and on and on. 50% district manager turnover from year to year. 8 years for stock to vest, they count on you leaving before you own it.

title: Relief Manager
pros: The hours were consistent. You always worked about 40 hours a week. You definitely get a workout walking the length of the properties at least twice on slow days. 200+ units.
cons: Like most companies, they frown on overtime. You need to finish all closing paperwork before closing and clock out exactly at that time. Which is nerve racking with a customer in the store. You will get dirty and sticky working here. Cleaning everything from dusty hallways to human excrement in the stairways. There is a chance that you will be working at multiple locations in your region. The property managers are the only ones that don't move around, usually. You will be learning script after script, word for word, so there is NO room for error.

title: Deceptive and sneaky DM's.
pros: The only pro to this job was when you were left to do your job. In other words, when a DM, who has no clue about the day to day running of the facility because they do not do but maybe 1 rental every few months, (by their own admission), leaves you to do the job that you do day in and day out and lets you help the customers, it's not that bad.
cons: A DM over your shoulder who changes policies according to her whims, despite that there is a policy site called PS central which outlines all of the procedures that she goes against. Being told that you have to constantly sell merchandise to customers who refuse and penalized for not selling. Being penalized when customer's refuse to use the facility's insurance program and provide the own locks to save money. Being very ill and needing to call in sick but told by the DM you HAVE to go to work only to discover the reason is because, although you no longer receive a bonus for your performance, they do based on your attendance. I could keep going but you get the idea.

title: A Great Place to Move Your Career Forward
pros: There is a lot of opportunity at this company. Sustained growth for PS is secure and there is a strong need to develop people into the upper levels of management. This is a place where you can break through to VP level in 3-5 years if you enter the company and perform. You are rewarded and recognized for how well your team executes their job functions, not just metric performance. As a result those managing challenging markets are essentially on an equal playing field with those in less challenging areas. The operating hours also limit the amount of urgent situations that arise after hours, making strong work life balance very possible.
cons: The responsibility and workload is manageable but significant. You can get buried quickly if you fall behind or run into unforeseen challenges. Strong time management is required.

title: Micro-management at its finest
pros: Being able to build a team.
cons: The company has one focus... stock price. Everyone that contributes to the success of the PS is looked at as replaceable. If you are creative, your ideas are disregarded and you are told to fall in line because “they can find others that will do what you do”. The issue comes from the CEO/COO and trickles down into the field. To save money the company turns its back on issues at properties (lights out, mold in units, security issues, the list goes on) and forces the property and management team to deal with the issues while sweeping the issue under the rug. The lack of intelligence to run a company the right way instead of the most profitable way will always hold Public Storage back. That why the market share in big demographic areas like South Florida will continue to go in the wrong direction.

title: Okay job
pros: The ability to work independently without a boss standing over you all the time. When you do bonus they can be good.
cons: You are expected go out and rent a unit in horrible conditions When the company does contest they mostly benefit the district managers and not the relief and property managers who do the work They only care about sales such as selling locks, insurance, and merchandise . You can be an amazing employee but if your sales are not good they will treat you like crap

title: Great Career Opportunities
pros: Since joining Public Storage a few years ago, I can say I have grown tremendously in many areas. When considering a new company and position, the most important thing for me was growth opportunity and work- life balance. It was always very difficult to find this but Public Storage has shown me it is possible, and provides the tools to make it happen. PS has invested in my development and truly cares about my growth within the organization. This keeps me here and invested in PS! Kudos to the Executive management team for developing and providing a culture that is so invested in their people and futures.
cons: With anything, you have to take the good with the bad. There are a lot of task items that can get a bit heavy at times which can be time-sucks if you let it, but with any successful organization it's about getting it right and doing the things that need to be done. Strong time management and prioritization is a must!

title: Not worth it
pros: Working for public storage gives you the opportunity to add management onto your resume and you have a decent amount of downtime
cons: This company doesn't pay you nearly enough for the job they ask you to do. They expect you to clean the outside property in all weather conditions even in the freezing rain. Wow trying their best to pay you as little as possible. During your interview they will tell you that you could become a property manager in as little as six months But what they don't tell you is that you can only become one if a property manager quits and most managers have been there for at least five years. And if you don't like to deal with negative customer interactions this is not the job for you. Public storage does everything they can to get money out of their customers while doing as little as they can to provide quality service

title: Great Company, Great Career Path, Great Leadership
pros: Great company with thoughtful decisions on growth, development and advancement opportunities. If you are driven for success and the ability to develop others and see results from your daily activities, this is the place for you. Senior leadership is driven by success at the property level, providing the tools needed to drive performance and give customers a first rate experience in our industry. I have been willing to dedicate the time and resources to build a great team. With a great team beside me, we continue to drive success. The company recognizes these success' and rewards us for the hard work and dedication.
cons: Task oriented job management can be a struggle to complete at times, but continued focus on process improvements and technology enhancements will allow improvements to work/life balance.

title: Disillusioned and disappointed
pros: 401k is amazing, no working nights, pto accumulation is faster than most companies, flexible schedule depending upon staffing. Bonus potential for top numbers.
cons: No holidays (company is closed 3 days per year, trying to get holidays such as Easter or the 4th of July are difficult unless you request them months before), travel. There is serious problems with scheduling and micro management.

title: Don't work here!
pros: There are none. The positive reviews are probably posted by the corporate office to offset the truth.....they don't value tenure, don't care about the field employees at all.....and we're the ones driving the success of the company! I've been around a long time and have seen a lot. Any incentives are gone, short staffing , horrible pay, now we pay for medical. They pay more for KTPs to press the button to watch videos while they pay less to the rest of the field employees that actually train them! And the DMs get paid more to read trend reports that tell them what we need to do to improve THEIR bonuses, then cry about having to DEAL WITH customers. Really?! They are paid 3x more than what a field employee makes!
cons: Everything. I've watch this company go from caring to oblivious and as long as the rent keeps coming in, they dont care who is on the frontline.

title: One of the Better Employers
pros: Solid organization and great HR department that is concerned about employees, all the way from the top. Energetic management. They still provide employees with weekly treats, a yearly In-and-Out Burger festival and have many office activities such as birthdays. When other companies have cut back, they still do some of the nice things that have gone by the wayside in other companies. Hard works is rewarded, raises, although not huge, are fair and at least still give in spite of the economic times. Long term and new employees and a mix of all ages makes it a very integrated company. They make money, even in the bad economy (perhaps more in the bad economy). Executive goup is smart and friendly
cons: Sometimes a bit too conservative. The business model is a classic American top-down, command style (but it works for them), and for creative people, that may be difficult at times.

title: Great Company To Work For
pros: Public Storage is a great company to work for and has allowed me to start reaching my career potential. A key factor to being successful with the company is your ability to train and develop your team. The senior managers & executives are very supportive, transparent and provide continually feedback. Public Storage is not afraid of change. If they find something is not working, they'll adapt and change with the times in order to grow. The career advancement is predicated based on hard work and performance, not tenure.
cons: Like any other job, when your new your learning the business and growing into the role. It's important not to lose focus on work / life balance in a very fast paced environment. The speed in which your successful, is dependent on your ability to adapt quickly, be proactive and maintain a high level of organization.

title: unappreciated
pros: No one breathing down your neck all day.
cons: We are pushed and pushed and pushed to sell. We are reprimanded when we don't get a lock sale with a rental. They think we are lying to them when the customer won't buy boxes with a rental. WE are the ONLY ones who bring in ANY revenue, yet we are treated like second-class citizens and the company keeps reducing our bonus program. Upper management lives like kings while we struggle to make ends meet. The new bonus programs says the company expects "40%" of "eligible managers" to earn a bonus. Wowee! That means they expect 60% WON'T??? How encouraging! The DMs and higher get four times the bonus money we get, and we do all of the work bringing in the $$. Disgusting!

title: District manager preview
pros: Great profits for shareholders knows how to get big dollars in sales from non commissioned sales people. Very profitable company
cons: Dm role is 5 different jobs at least no support from leaders or field support. The facilities support is not available. There is no work life balance

title: District Sales Manager
pros: -Great Pay -Great Bonus program paid every 3 months -Growth and development opportunities -no nights limited weekends -Good work life balance -opportunities to relocate -Structured company -stock options -autonomy -ongoing training
cons: -long days -heavy workload of operational duties -you have to use power tools to cut off locks of tenants that do not pay quite frequently -point person for all tenant/customer issues which can distract from your regular bonus activities -collections, which is not fun

title: Great Company!
pros: Public Storage is a great stable company to work for. Having been here for over 11 years I am happy to have found a company that values it's employees and their contributions. I love the fact that there are so many employees here who have been with the company for a long time. I know many who have been here over 15 years and several who have been here 20+ years. That is a sign of a good company to work for!
cons: Sure compensation could be better or benefits could be greater, but it is competitive with other companies. You get what you put in to the company and your job. Do well and be rewarded. Doing your job and doing it well is expected. If you take pride in what you do then this is the place for you.

title: A good solid company to work for
pros: First of all, Public Storage is a very solid company that is well run and in great financial shape. So, you don't have to worry about layoffs and accross the board cost cuts. The management is very smart and knows how to run a company smoothly. It is not a disfunctional company at all. Beyond that, the people here are very nice and treat each other very good. I have been here 25+ years and am very lucky to have found this company. We stay busy, but we I don't work any overtime for the most part. So, we can all live with that. Work at Public Storage if you want to be part of an S&P 500 company that feels kinda like a neighborhood real estate company. Good atmosphere.
cons: I really don't have any. Maybe a little more contribution to our 401K would be nice.

title: Fun & Stable
pros: I really enjoyed the people I worked with. The hours were extremely flexible. We worked a 7.5 hour shift with great benefits. Free bagels every Friday and free Krispy Kreme donuts once a month. Ongoing training to help you succeed.
cons: There is no advancement. Some agents who have been in the same position as me are making the old wage of $18/hr, while the newer agents can only make $15/hr. We are competing with our own website pricing. We get penalized for taking misdirected calls (non-sales).

title: District Manager Review
pros: Public Storage is a great company to work for and has allowed me to start reaching my career potential. A key factor to being successful with the company is your ability to train and develop your team. The senior managers are very supportive, transparent and provide continually feedback. Public Storage is not afraid of change. If they find something is not working, they'll adapt and change with the times in order to continue to grow. The career advancement is predicated based on hard work and performance, not tenure.
cons: Like any other job, when your new you're learning the business and growing into the role. As a new District Manager it's important not to lose focus on work / life balance in a very fast paced environment. The speed in which your successful, is dependent on your ability to adapt quickly, be proactive and maintain a high level of organization.

title: Waste of Time
pros: Good starter job might look good on a resume but no hope for a promising career. If you believe the lies and ignore the warnings.
cons: Where to begin. This is retail so it's just selling and making profit for the capitalist company mongrels. In my first few days I realized I can't be a part of this culture and look myself in the mirror. I refuse to force a single mother or a guy falling on bad luck to purchase an insanely priced lock or lying to them about how its required by law to buy our insurance. Forced selling with no price lock I was shocked how they can raise rents and how often they do raise the rent. The worst is realizing public storage doesn't pay my wages they hide it in the contract. The very customer I am trained to screw over is realistically the signer of my paycheck. Sorry but you will, unfortunately, not pass my 90 day probation period. I would bet money that job fairs will be an ongoing thing so....

title: Great Place to Work
pros: I have been working here for 8 years and it has been one of the best companies i have worked for. The Job security here is great. Most employees have been working here many years. The pay is is competitive. The management is great. Any time i needed help or advice for any level of management, they have been very helpful. All my coworkers are a joy to work with. in my opinion Public Storage treats it's employees very well. Once a month they have a birthday celebration and give prizes and cake to feed the whole corporate office. they also give holiday bonus' and a holiday party.
cons: I don't have much cons. Maybe they can send more memos let us know how much they appreciate us. Of course even though the pay is competitive, I wouldn't mind receiving better annual increases.

title: Public Storage, the Walmart of the Storage industry.
pros: If you own PS stock, they are doing great. As a field employee though the best I can say is that working for Public Storage is no more than a transitional job until a better once comes along.
cons: Below average pay for the job requirements. Field employee benefits are constantly changing and not always for the better. Weekend and many holidays are considered mandatory work days for employees. No overtime, even if you work more than 8 hours, the Regional Manager will tell the District Manager to have the employee take off early or come in late on a day they are double covered. No back up from management against iiate customers who are angry with company policy, than they are with the employees for following policy.

title: Do not work here
pros: The have paid sick time and benefits
cons: No room for growth, the upper management only cares about getting their bonus... Btw store level employees do not get commission not bonuses or even raises as of 2018. Oh but you beat believe the district manager get a big enough bonus every year to but a brand new vehicle out right...The hound you in selling merch insurance and locks.. however it is a catch 22 they tell you no one walks... But don't you dare not get that merch lock and insurance!! Therir management does not give a damn about their employees, or customers .everyday you have to sit and listen to a conference call and it always the same subject... You are failing as a district and it's not acceptable... Their is no positivity in this job... Only negative. They are shady as hell and manipulative to their customers. They use bait and switch tactics. This company will suck the soul and will to live right out of you!!!

title: This has been an amazing experience as I transitioned out of the Army.
pros: I was worried about transferring of skills into the civilian world but I couldn't be happier. Public Storage is centered around its people and customers. This company has shown me that a leader is a leader, and that anyone can do well with the right motivation. They've provided me with the tools and mentorship to confidently and effectively lead my team. This company is fast paced and has a lot of room for career growth. One of the best parts- the leaders in this company are genuinely interested in your growth. For such a large company, we are such a family of purple and orange.
cons: This company is filled with motivated individuals who want, no need, to succeed. Those that want to work will succeed and grow. Unfortunately this means that there is little to no room for slacking. If you want a desk job that's 9-5 PS may not be the place for you.

title: Profit above all
pros: Compensation is decent, and stability is very good. Quite a lot of people with 20+ years on board.
cons: Lack up upward mobility. Lack of cohesion among mid-level management. Department heads seem to be working to expand their legacies, not improve the business. Benefits are there, but you'll pay a hefty premium. Perks? Not really. Only three company holidays per year. Bottom line, CEO is an accountant, and it shows. Anything and everything to drive shareholder value.

title: Great place to work if you are a hard worker
pros: One of the best things about working for Public Storage is the work and independence. You are allowed to make decisions that affect the company in positive way and earn the respect of management. If you are a good, ethical, and hard worker management will show confidence in yours skills and allow you to grow and earn a good living. I have been with Public Storage for over 20 years and have enjoiyed the business challenges and the opportunities for growth professionally and intellectually.
cons: Public Storage is a publicly traded company and as such must continue to grow and change in order to be competitive in the real estate market. Some people are not good at adapting to change in the business world and may find it difficult to understand business decisions a company makes to keep it successful.

title: District Manager
pros: I just started work and so far I am having a great time. The interview process was long, but I appreciated the time they took to get to know me and make sure I was the right fit for the job. They asked me to do a job shadow and that experience is what made me select Public Storage. That experience showed me the day in the life of a DM and gave me an honest outlook of the job and the company. The training has been thorough and everyone has been so sincere and kind to make sure I will be successful.
cons: None to date. So far my new career is awesome.

title: It's not worth it.
pros: 40 hours a week. Nothing else.
cons: Pay is horrible. They expect everything from you. But give NOTHING in return. They'll let the property go. You put work orders in. They get cancelled or pushed back. But expect you to clean everything. The property, office, bathrooms,units,hallways and clean windows. Dust unit doors. They don't offer promotion. Best you'll get is property manager. So added stress because if something goes wrong. It's on you. But you make the same amount you started with. They give you zero incentive for sales. But if your metrics for locks, insurance or merch isn't good. They will make your life absolutely miserable. Do well and they always find something to complain about. Only good things I had left. Was a little extra money around the holidays. And getting paid for pti not used. Both things got taken away. I only right this because I wish someone did before I took the job. The stress isn't worth the pay.

title: Good for first job
pros: Can get an apartment if you get promoted. Easy work. Not too physical but definitely a lot of walking, some cleaning, and some merch carrying. Easy laid back job most days.
cons: Lots of phone calls. Lots of scripts to memorize. People can be people so need to be a patient person and someone who wont fly off the handle when people are being jerks. Gotta sling merch but eh its retail. Honestly good first job just lots of hours and can be pretty tiring. Also homeless folks and drug addicts may be on your property so be careful. Don't be surprised if someone commits su*cide on the property. It happens. other than that pretty good job. You wear many many hats. you are a janitor, a therapist sometimes, a debt collector, a deescalator, a lock smith, an exterminator, a salesman, a cashier, a security guard, etc etc etc. good luck be safe and just enjoy it.

title: These reviews are inaccurate...
pros: They worked with my school schedule and allowed me to work part-time. And they transferred my higher pay from the bay area when I moved.
cons: This company is cheap, they don't fix anything yet they build more properties with 4,000+ units. Their technology is outdated. They do not care about their employees when they need to take a leave of absence or have a death in the family. They do not care about their customers and put property managers an a place that requires them to break the rules in order to make their customers happy. No one is paid enough compared to other storage companies and we are just robots to them spitting out scripts that don't work. No company advancement. You can only go from relief to property manager and can never advance to a district manager no matter how good of an employee you are. Way too much stress for such a low paying job.

title: Public Storage expects you to dedicate your life to the company expectations.
pros: Entry level salary and gauranteed first year bonus is a plus. Initial stock offerring and 3 year vesting is beneficial.
cons: There is no balance between work and life. You are on call 24 hours a day and expected to look at your phone every 30 minutes to make sure you did not miss a call, text or an e-mail(even Saturday and Sunday). Management continues to add to the workload with no consideration for family or time off. Management promotes and demotes with no rhyme or reason behind their decisions. Their motto is "We Care", but unfortunately it is only about the bottom line. The new motto should be "Do Not Care" for employees or customers.

title: Great Position for Balance and Growth
pros: Public Storage is an awesome company to work for. There is a great sense of development with the company because leaders are home grown. There is an immense involvement in your development at all levels and feedback is ever present, but not over powering. The company has continued to grow and adapt with the times which, obviously is more important now than ever before. The company has made great decisions for customers, for their employees and the business. Public Storage is a consistent performer financially and a stable company to work for. Public Storage is not afraid to change quickly to make sure that they continue to make the right decisions for everyone! Coming from a retail background where the pressure is high, the feedback is never ending and the hours are long, Public Storage is a breath of fresh air!
cons: Because the company is successful at growth, development and consistency, I can't say there is anything that is a con.

title: Not Worth It
pros: Banking like hours and one shift insures you have a great ability to perform life activities outside of work. If you choose, you can be lazy and the job will essentially be a cakewalk. They don't tend to fire lazy relief managers
cons: Because they don't fire lazy relief managers, Property Managers like me feel a lot more pressure to keep up with the property. The pay is complete joke for the amount of regulations, scripts, procedures, and policies they want you to follow and excel at. The true travesty is they treat the job as if it is really a sales job but there are no monthly or quarterly bonus(s) and there is no commission. Motivation to keep working harder to make this billion dollar company more money is offset by the very low pay

title: Great company!
pros: Company is 100% clear and realistic with expectations. Generous bonus packages. Overall, a great job to experience managing multi-unit functions without working late nights/weekends.
cons: Some domains of the business have shared responsibilities between Operations and Facilities that are not effectively handled. The back and forth does not consistently permit the quickest resolution(s). Note - there have been great improvements in this area and I'm confident the recent changes will continue to help reduce DM workload in this area.

title: Unfriendly!
pros: Conveniently located to a train station. Benefits and salary for corp. employees are pretty good.
cons: The CEO has his fingers all over this company. No decisions are made without him knowing the situation. Executives feel their skills are not utilized as a result. For any employee, beware of politics. Within my first week there, a mid-level manager came to my office and warned me himself to be careful; I learned from The Godfather, and stayed away from him too. But he was right; the corp. employees are not very friendly nor are they very nice. If you can just do your job and go home, you'll be fine. Be ware too, that to take a holiday day off (e.g. 4th of July), you have to accumulate time like you would for a sick day or vacation day.

title: It was great at first
pros: The health benefits were pretty decent Being able to incorporate exercise with work was great, meeting new people daily and being able to put smiles on faces that walked in scared, sad, and upset was the best part of the job
cons: Working from 930-6 was a downer especially, traveling about an hour for work everyday when there was a location up the street from my home. They took away getting a yearly bonus because some employees where not getting them (but it was based on a number of things). I went out on medical for about a week and they posted that my office was hiring while I was out. When i came back they had me train my replacement for twos day then walked in on a Tuesday, saying your fired. My direct district manager tried to explain why but her boss (standing there) told her no need too explain she needs to go.

title: District Manager is really a manager
pros: Stock when I was hired with a three year vestment. Other than that, as I look back at my two years there I see no pros.
cons: Although they only hire experienced DMs I found the DMs who had been there the longest where ones who had never worked for a decent company in the past. This job is really a management job where you manage hourly employees who have no authority to make any decisions. The Senior DM is really the DM managing you, the manager. Work life balance is the absolute worst and a complete joke. You aRe expected to log in every day to make sure you employees made it to work. This means forget church, workouts, camping with no wifi, etc. God forbid one of your lame hourly employees call in sick at the last minute, show up late for work, or quit and you don't get your property opened up on time. The. An email goes out to every level of mgmt and if you didn't prereport it you are screwed. Summers you are expected to work six days a week for about three months with no other compensated day off. You literally have to send in reports several times a day on Saturdays and sometimes Sundays during this time reporting units rented, locks sold, etc. What a joke and another way for them to make your life miserable. Car mileage is a joke. I know it is the law but if you don't live near your territory you will be screwed. Management--- I don't know where to start. This is the most micro managed company you will ever work for. The CEO and upper management have their hand in everything from approvals to pay repairs on dilapidated storage units to 24/ 7 tabs on all their employees. They have huge egos And treat their employees poorly The regional meetings are unbelievable. The regional and seniors will literally practice their DM meeting presentations for hours so when the CEO and whoever else decides to attend their meeting, don't chastise them for having a bad meeting. We had a DM once who got fired because the CEO reported her to the rvp that she took her shoes off under the table during the meeting. True story ! The annual reviews are a complete joke. The RVPs have to spend a week in California presenting their dm reviews to the CEO. What CEO has the time to manage every DM in the company! It is a complete dog and pony show. I don't know where to stop so I'll stop here. Don't take a job here. It was a complete waste of my time. I was not fired or forced out by any means just got tired of working for such a crappy company

title: Horrible!! Run away!
pros: Retail hours are ok, no over time. You only see your boss a few times a month. The company ain't going out of business any time.
cons: So many! To start they expect for one person to run the office and all the facility, from customer service to collections,sales,janitor, security. greedy greedy upper management, while we make them tons of money $30-40 thousand a month, they pay property managers about &20 thousand a year yes a year! They focus on SALES but we get nothing as an incentive. Tons of scrips, they have scripts for everything. They do secret shops to make sure we're doing the scripts. You are expected to force customers to buy a $20 lock and $11 Ins and very expensive packing supply's to customers that can barely afford $23 for the first month or you will get fired. You have to clean ficus. and deal with irate customers on daily basis.

title: Why Did I stay as long as I did?
pros: Apartment, decent insurance, met some nice people.
cons: I busted my hump for this company. 4 years of "Top Tier" numbers and in those 4 years a 60 cent wage increase. I was ranked in the top 100 managers in the country 3 of the 4 years. The 4th year I was screwed out of my bonus... Most of the DM's I worked for were ok, but ever one would throw you under the bus if need be. You get "stuck" in there apartment and they know this. You don't make enough money to save up and move out. I was fortunate enough to pursue other options. In the 4 months I've been with my new company I have already made more than I did in 12 months with PS. Also the DMs that PS hires usually have no background in storage, there usually from somewhere like Payless Shoes or Ultra Foods and they come in and tell someone with years more experience in self storage how to do there job...

title: Absolutely Love The Job!
pros: There are so many things that I love about this job. Me and my District Manager have an amazing relationship, the leniency of the job is great, we have an amazing team of people that we work with and the teamwork that everyone shares is outstanding!! All in all I love my job so much and the people that I work with are amazing! Were like one big family! Incentive bonuses for properties too :) who doesnt want an extra $150 bonus!
cons: The office can definitely get a little hectic and time management is definitely a huge factor. Personally i think the pay is a little low for what we go through being on the front lines but you cant win them all.

title: Unethical, greedy
pros: No pros that outweigh the cons
cons: Where do I start? This company is horrible, and I'm not just saying this because I have a chip on my shoulder. For near poverty wages (9.50 to start) employees are expected to be a retail sales expert, a leasing consultant, a collections agent, a janitor and put up with micromanaging abusive DM's that have no idea what it takes to run a property. My life has been personally threatened on multiple occasions, and have been expected to clean up human excrement. Roach\rat infestations are a common occurance, and the security is laughable. I have run into units that have been broken into on a weekly basis, the company does nothing to improve the situation. No work/life balance. Required to work every weekend. only one week of pto in your first year that is accrued. Im also pretty sure the company owns the insurance company that employees are forced to make customers buy. TRUST ME, YOU DONT WANT TO WORK HERE.

title: Could be better
pros: you don't really have to do much once you figure out how to organize your day, the schedule is always sent out in advance so you can make plans. Good work life balance.
cons: no security.....I always feel unsafe coming to work at certain locations because anybody and everybody (including bums that rent there) can come in and they always make me and other tenants feel uncomfortable. bad pay....they pay you 9/hr and you work full time.....you work a lot to get a bad check that you can get at a part time job. dishonest company......let's just say this company will leave you always looking like the bad guy to renting tenants because you're the only one they can see and complain to about rent rising and other horrible things they act like they can't fix. upper management is pretty much a bunch of inexperienced rich people who just want you to do things the PS way (which is not the right way)

title: No opportunity for lateral movement past the Trainer position.
