pros: Limited supervision- most times you are working alone. Customer interaction- you can build great relationships/rapport. Trainer- train newly hired District Managers; compensation for training veteran and new hires. District Manager- respected and encouraged to do my best and learn.
cons: New employees are hired in at a higher compensation than the tenured employees. Not able to waive a late fee without giving a full explanation and getting approval from upper management.

title: Great place to further your career
pros: As a newer employee I can say that the training program is fantastic. This is not a company that will throw you into a position and tell you "good luck". The training is 2-3 months with full pay. The people I have been working with are great trainers, but also really enjoy coming to work. It's definitely not a miserable place to be. As far as the actual position, you are given a lot of autonomy to run your own District, but you will never be sitting around looking at your watch. There is a lot of variety of work, and if you are the type of person who likes to get outside then you will be thankful that you aren't stuck in a cubicle 24/7. There is also a lot of untapped potential talent to work with at the property level. I really enjoy the coaching with employees and helping them learn life-long skills that will help them be their best. Coaching and developing people at the property level will help you set your team apart from other Districts. You also work as a team with other Districts and the attitude is helpful and competitive, but not when it's at detriment to the company. The best part about the company is that people from Regional to "Corporate" are all very welcoming and happy to have a conversation with you. There is no "better than you" upper managers that I have met. I can walk over to someone in real-estate and they are happy to talk about how they help make the business run. All the Regional Managers are invested into employee well-being, even with people that don't work for them. I don't think I've seen that anywhere else I've worked. If you are on the fence about applying, you should go in for the interview. Between the ride along "day in the life of" and interview process, you will know it's the right place for you.
cons: The company restricted stock program is a great incentive to further your career. 8 years is a long horizon for full vestment of stock.

title: Great Line of Business
pros: Company has strong financial and continue healthy expansion; leadership position industry in conventional, but Great Line of Business. Manager willing and welcome new idea to improve work efficiency. Under a progressive manager, one can work often independently and can seek advice when needed. Work load can be heavy at time for being a public company. Good work life balance for well informed and willing to adopt technology. Great and competent colleagues who will to provide answer and help.
cons: Promotion opportunity. There is good path for field management, but not for property managers and corporate employee. Corporate employee is usually a choice; one select company primary for work life balance or to build specific skill. Field employee has no defined track for management advancement. A lot of long tenure, the con side: inefficient processes for lack of technology adoption, myopic to intra departments process, and lack a centralized knowledge base.

title: A career mistake-district manager
pros: Will make you appreciate former companies and future companies more. Really there are no pros.
cons: No respect, no support, micromanagement and business model that should be simple is made complicated. Upper management believes in pain management they inflict pain to change behaviors. They want you to inflict pain on the property managers to the change behavior. Upper management sees no value in property managers and will not promote them. District managers are seen as a means to an end and turnover so quickly. No work life balance, total lack of ethics, corporate HR pushes new employees to write reviews to increase glassdoor average. DMs don't get fired we quit in droves. Don't work for Public Storage if you do you will regret it within 90 days.

title: Property Manager
pros: When I started the use of the apartment was a great perk. It presented me with my first opportunity to live on my own and I found the independence very satisfying. I had a great district manager and good co-workers which made the job enjoyable. For the most part you work alone and are able to plan your day around helping your customers. There was a focus on sales (more on that in a minute) of their packing supplies which were over priced but still sold at a decent rate due to the convenience. Stores close by 6pm so no late nights. For a retail type environment this was a big plus.
cons: While the apartment started off great it later became a shackle that I felt kept me tied to the job longer than I would have liked. Once I met my girlfriend and we started a family the apartment no longer worked for us. The pay increase without the apartment wasn't substantial enough to move out while still working there. If you quite you have something like 3 days to move out of the apartment. So I felt trapped that in a matter of 2 weeks (2 weeks notice) not only would I have had to start a new job but pack my entire home and find a new place to move as well. Ultimately I was able to figure it out and get out of there and I'm glad I did. I've changed companies two times since leaving Public Storage a little over a year ago and I've been able to double my income from changing companies. Another "Con" is the sales scripts that they constantly make you role play and secret shop to make sure you are in compliance. Even if you have fantastic sales numbers at your location they expect you to use this robotic, annoying approach to sales which ultimately ends up just irritating the majority of customers. Final "Con" and this was the biggest for me. THEY DO NOT PROMOTE FROM WITHIN AT THE STORE LEVEL. This was the main reason I chose to leave the company.

title: To Whom much is given....Much is required.
pros: Corporate Housing a blessing and can find stability for the time needed.
cons: Raises are medieval and not up to standard based on what is brought to the table and also the impressive financial stability that WE the Property and Relief Managers bring to table for the Company as a whole. Our competitors pay a lot more! Bonus program elminated but asked to stay tuned on on possible compensation for a performance driven environment. Meanwhile the companies stocks are rock solid.

title: Good job for independent workers
pros: The pay is pretty competitive. With offices open 7 days a week, schedules can be flexible and 9:30am-6pm allows you to get home at a reasonable time. This is a good job for someone who can work independently with a daily and monthly routine. There is some room for growth within the company as well. Incentive programs have been created to meet monthly goals and managers can be contacted directly for any issues that may come up.
cons: Sometimes, multiple "small" tasks can get time consuming, which may lead to a busy day if you're by yourself. This is a customer service based job with customers often in a low point in their lives, this can require a strong sense of patience.

title: Lies that you have to tell the customer in order to make your goals.
pros: Can be just the work scheduled.
cons: That you have to tell the customer that Insurance is Required, when is up to customer if wants or not the Insurance. Can be because Public Storage is Co-owner of the Insurance Company. The Locks that they are very bad quality ( made in Chine)) and $7.00 dollars more expensive than Wal-Mart or Home Depot. Boxes 70% more expensive that Home Depot and they are made by the same CO. You make the money and deal with the customer and you are the lower pay in the Company. You are a janitor, a Handyman and office manager for low pay and if they increase a few pennies they take away in the Bonus. For this Multi Billion Dollar company is a shame.

title: Great place to work - Strong job security
pros: When working for Public Storage you truly get the feel that you matter as an individual. Coming from a retail environment where all that was talked about was getting the "result", here we focus on all correct behaviors. Even during a pandemic Public Storage found a way to not only thrive but is constantly changing and adapting to current situations. This is a great place to grow your career.
cons: You have to be skilled with time management. This job requires attention to detail and time sensitive. If you are self sufficient and able to manage your time this job is perfect job for you.

title: Customer Service Representative
pros: Very laid back company, no real customer service/people skills required- rudeness and giving customers the run around is the norm and quite expected. Bagel Fridays Free coffee Casual dress Not many rules - cell phones are fine on the floor
cons: Hours are cut drastically, with mandantory time off to the extreme - I was hired for fulltime and would work an average of 18 hours per week. always potentially losing benefits, If ethics are important to you - this isn't the place for you, Also if you are looking to truly provide customer care, you won't have that opportunity at this company. It's hard to give a customer the impression that you care or build any kind of company cofidence/rapport while advising them of a $20 phone pay convenience fee (just one example). I saw no advancement opportunity, at all. Poor queue volume control - either way too busy or no calls for up to 35 minutes - no middle ground

title: It use to be an ok place to work. Not a career!
pros: - Hours - Decent benefits - Good co-workers
cons: Public storage profits 48% of it's total income, yet none of the people who draw in the business see any of it. (Property Managers/Relief Managers) They constantly change the bonus structure every year and the majority of people do not receive a bonus despite the hard work they put in. District managers and above receive a very generous quarterly bonus all built on the back of our hard work. They want you to sell, sell and sell, yet give you no incentive to. I use to have faith in this company when I first started, but it has all gone downhill. The stockholder ALWAYS comes first. The employees will get shafted by not receiving any bonus and the customers will get ridiculous rent increases. Stay as far away from this company as possible. They will draw you in with false hope and promises. Side note: Paid time off and holiday has been reduced each year.

title: This is a great company to work for, a industry leader with really great people
pros: Long term stability and a positive working environment. A senior leadership team that has grown revenue while developing a dynamic business model that is extremely responsive to its customer base. Great people, I am a long term employee and have enjoyed the worth ethic and passion of my work colleagues across the whole organization. This is a company with world class operational processes and high standards, it has a culture that is willing to explore and generate new ideas within the industry while remaining laser-focused on the key drivers of the business every day. You need to bring your ‘A’ game but it is truly worth it.
cons: There are no real cons in truth. It is a high performing environment so commitment is big but it’s been very positive in my experience.

title: It’s alright as long as managers care and have a good team
pros: *Great team *Outside and inside work so always something to do * pretty good benefits for property manager since they get a free apartment and utilities to live onsite. * Holiday pay and closed on holidays
cons: *definitely need thick skin since you will get angry or upset customer * company cheap on pay and other things such as security. * Not worth the pay for relief managers

title: Run, run away!
pros: You have a set schedule. Full time. A lot of down time. Independent work.
cons: The managers dont care about your well being or opinions. The training lacks to the point of setting you up for failure. Only reason I survived was due to my past knowledge with other jobs. They under pay their associates, and make rediculous demands that can't be met. They make it a requirement to sell merchandise with their leases or you are written up then later fired. They lie to their customers, I am too honest to ever work for a company like this ever again. You not only have to deal with awful hostile customers each day, you have management breathing down your neck making you afraid to lose your job. If you have any sense, keep looking don't accept this job. Wish someone had warned me.

title: Good product - Good people - Great opportunity
pros: I have worked here for 7 years. The company has a solid runway and room for advancement for those willing to work hard. It is positive and fast-paced; always challenging you to be nothing less than the best! Phenomenal, world-class training provided for all aspects of leadership and people development. Good product, good people, GREAT opportunity. We are encouraged to run our business like we are the CEO. We do the ordinary (renting space), extraordinarily well and are the leaders in the industry.
cons: No cons to mention here. Management is great about recognizing high performance and rewards hard work. This requires an oath of allegiance and devotion. Public Storage harbors an awesome culture that is inspiring and infectious!

title: Would not recommend this company.
pros: Vacation time builds quickly(good luck taking it though)
cons: Poor traning procedures, work alone, no security systems, long hours, no support from upper management, practically impossible to take vacation days or sick days, policies and procedures change constantly without any training and at times no one in the company even knows what the new procedure is but we're required to push it on customers ( right size, right price), employees are required to sell customers insurance but customers aren't required to purchase it , property managers have no power to deal with customer issues, we must contact the district managers, who are unavailable 99% of the time, too many upper management positions all of whom do nothing productive, employees are required to memorize scripts on how to deal with customers, the scripts are non-sense and do not apply to real life situations, absolutely no room for growth in the company, $1000.00 insurance coverage for the year, so don't have a major illness or accident, employees are treated asif they are simple minded.

title: AWFUL-WORST JOB I EVER HAD.DEAD END WORK-MUNDANE-
pros: A way to get PM experience to move on wards if you can get out.
cons: Old Shurgard properties have more issues than newer PS properties. Large facilities have security issues after hours. Lack of cameras make it virtually impossible to always find those responsible. No more monthly bonus- PTO paid out after many diligently saved hours.Either use it or loose it to annual payouts.. DM's far to pushy on requirement to sell with every rental vs employee trans reports & goal sheets. Some dist have 2 PS on same street making competition & occupancy all that much more difficult. DM's only stay a year.reviews from prev DM no matter how good are re-written with very new DM. Nothing you did in prev years reflects with current review.. High expectations- Vendors junk & hauls almost impossible to get approvals for abandon goods. Over weighted position vs pay for performance metrics. Inability to take phone payments & delinquent customers not coming in for EOM payments. Always loosing occupancy to Auctions! DM's don't care about employees just about numbers.

title: Has its positives and negatives but the negatives very much outweigh the positives
pros: The job is full time, no late shifts, job security, paid time off and benefits.
cons: It pays very little for the amount of work that is required. There is a large amount of pressure to sell merchandise and get positive customer reviews for a job that does not offer commission or bonuses for those sales(or any incentive other than management will back off for a bit). They frequently (every 6 months) raise customer rent and leave you to explain to the customer why the increases are so high and so frequent. Their reasoning for the increases is for the upkeep of the facility yet very little is ever fixed on the property. Most days you are scheduled alone at a property that has over 500 customers leaving you to handle all existing issues and new customers that need assistance.

title: Not recommended for any long period of time
pros: Customers are a pretty decent bunch. Decent work hours Benefits are a lot better than what they were and pay....eh....it's slim pickins these days. You can do a lot worse else where.
cons: Bonus program changes on an annual basis to make it harder to obtain a decent payout. Job is touted as a customer service/management job but is actually sales. Upper management rules by intimidation. Because this is a publically traded company properties are falling apart and PM's can't do much about it other than field complaints. You have the title of manager but you are pretty much bottom rung of the food chain. District managers and regional managers get their bonus based on YOUR work and it's way more money than anything you will ever get for a bonus (which went from quarterly to monthly to annually). Also they do not promote from within so it's a pretty dead end job.

title: District Manager
pros: The Stock Option was a great incentive to accept the postion.
cons: The job title of District Manager is just a fancy word for "baby-sitting" low-minded employees. Public Storage is NOT open to creativity or new ideas. Upper mgmt is quick to say: "it's not how we do it at Public Storage". Promotion is not based on your performance but whether or not upper mgmt likes you. Granted this company is a billion $ industry, however front-end employees are treated more like "slaves" rather than "assets". Whenever I met with my Senior District Manager or Regional VP, I had to discuss the ranking of front-end employees that I wanted to terminate. Imagine dealing with employees that are always in defensive mode and see you as an enemy when you try to coach them. I take pride in developing employees rather than getting rid of them the moment they face a challenge.

title: World-Class Team and Operation!
pros: Public Storage has been the best environment and culture for learning, training, and development I could ever imagine. It's not all talk at this company. This leadership group truly devotes their time to developing their employees, and trying to make life easier and more fulfilling for all employees as well as customers. The only thing holding you back at this company is yourself!
cons: It's all about your attitude and how you are able to take direct feedback on learning opportunities. The environment is overall a positive place to be. It may take some people more time to develop, and it takes great patience and self-awareness to realize that we always have room for improvement!

title: Property manager
pros: Bring back bonuses and treat employees with respect and give them a raise and how more employees and security
cons: Safety of the employees start scripting the employees who don’t work and stop bothering the employees that really work the turn over is high upper management don’t care about the employees they only care about internal revenue merchandise sales and that fraud insurance they sell to the customers they don’t fix nothing and if they do it take along time public storage dont care about they employees are customers all they care about is delinquency and insurance so they can get there bonus that took from us they need to provide break rooms so we can stop eating lunch in the car

title: My time here has been character building.
pros: as far as company wide, medical benefits and opportunity to have on-site housing is wonderful. you can work individually or as a team depending on support staff. the managers directly above are extremely supportive and helpful. I’ve never once felt uncomfortable asking a question when needing more guidance.
cons: as part of this job is customer service, just like any CS job, customers can be difficult (again, upper management in general will help in this situation if needed). one thing that could be improved is the timeframe in which we get responses on different requests.

title: Interesting job. Interesting customers. Management squishes you.
pros: Fun job. Interesting customers. Every day different.
cons: Only one person per week can take a vacation. There are more weeks of vacation than there are weeks in a year. Those who don't get (use) vacation get the money in November, and have no time off. Cannot take an individual day off....have to take a whole week off. If your parents are celebrating their 50th wedding anniversary on a Saturday, you must ask off for the whole week. Not everyone gets paid for Thanksgiving, Christmas, or New Years. About 80% do, about 20% do not. Different persons every year. Want to feel worthless? Work here and watch your co-workers get paid, but you don't.

title: The Ordinary Done Extraordinarily Well
pros: I have worked here for 9 years. The company has a solid runway and room for advancement for those willing to work hard. It is positive and fast-paced; always challenging you to be nothing less than the best! Phenomenal, world-class training provided for all aspects of leadership and people development. Good product, good people, GREAT opportunity. We are encouraged to run our business like we are the CEO. We do the ordinary (renting space), extraordinarily well and are the leaders in the industry.
cons: No cons to mention here. Management is great about recognizing high performance and rewards hard work. This requires an oath of allegiance and devotion. Public Storage harbors an awesome culture that is inspiring and infectious!

title: Growth and Advancement
pros: Public Storage is a great company to work for. I started as a District Manager and in less than 5 years I was promoted to Regional Vice President. The company is growing quickly which allows for advancement opportunities. Public Storage is an industry leader that provides competitive compensation and job security. The executive team is supportive and listens to operations feedback and suggestions. I have a great work life balance and truly enjoy everyone I work with.
cons: The company is task oriented and a lot of reporting is necessary. The con is that this takes leaders out of the field and away from coaching and developing their team at times.

title: Property Manager
pros: Flexible days off, 40 hours PTO and PTI every year. Company offers insurance for health, dental, ect. Some districts offer apartments to senior employees. Hours are easy, 930-6 weekdays and 930-5 weekends. We get Thanksgiving, Christmas and new years off as well.
cons: You have to be okay with being the maintenance tech for a lot of things as well as handling large abandoned goods and other items. Company will only pay for outside vendors if it is absolutely necessary even if you don't have experience with related fields. Also, once you have hit property manager of an A property and have position of a trainer that is as high as you can get within the company as they do not hire from within. If you would like to work for corporate level you would need to leave the company for at least a year to be considered when applying for such a position.

title: Good Management, no advancement
pros: Management is understanding and works with you. Benefits are pretty good and the overall job is pretty standard with, depending on store location, alot of downtime. Good for an inbetween job, maybe work for a year or two.
cons: Pay. No advancement or upward movement on the field level. Just three positions, Relief Manager, Property Manager and KTP. The only differencr in pay is 1.50 when you become KTP. The only benefit of becoming a Property Manager is you don't have to travel to different locations in the district. They have an incentive program that requires hitting different standards and the reward is only 150.00 extra on your check that month, before taxes, and thats IF your property hits every metric. No raises like at all on the field level. A good job but not a career if you aren't corporate side.

title: No Upward Mobility
pros: If you're able to land a property manager position then you MIGHT get an apartment, and getting an apartment that's basically rent and utility free in NYC is nothing to scoff at.
cons: The work load is not equal to the amount of money you make. There is an unnecessary amount of stress that is placed on you from the beginning and there is no stable structure to help teach you everything you need to know. You cannot move from property manager to district manager, you have to leave the company for a year to be considered.

title: Great for what it is
pros: The company hires really good District managers, there is a lot of freedom to move about and working for a recession proof company really gives you stability. For field employees there is rapid advancement and the possibility to live on site. Bonuses are pretty fair for the field employees, I cannot speak to the call center or corporate employees.
cons: They then strangle their district managers and with too many layers of micro management. The pay is not what it could be to keep great property managers and trainers wanting to work for the company. Public Storage also does a flat raise for all employees, at least they have for the last two years. There are no merit increases.

title: The only reason why I would spend time typing this review is to get full site access :)
pros: ZERO!!!! and I mean absolutely none whatsoever other than its a job.
cons: Upper management is awful. Our DM once told a woman on a conference call he was going to plant his seed in her. And then followed it up moments later by telling her she should strap one on. To be a District manager all you need is a high school degree.....In actuality a DM in this company is the equivalent to an assistant manager at a convenience store with a pair of bolt cutters. I'd like to say something positive about the customer interaction. But honestly they are all liars and scum bags with a seldom encounter with a pleasant individual. Apologies for poor sentence structure or grammar, just buzzed this out to get access. This company should be avoided. Should have known when on my interview the manager asked me are you sure you want this job.

title: Great place to work
pros: This is a very consistent position - all of the expectations are laid out clearly even before you start, and especially in the Bay Area, there is a lot of team work and involvement from your peers. The schedule is quite flexible as well. It is a great company, and is continuously growing. There are many people that have worked here for 5, 10, 15, 20 years plus and that is an indication of the type of company it is.
cons: Sometimes it feels like a 24/7 job from emergency phone calls, but these can be managed after time. There is a lot of admin work that is not expected when you begin this position, some of the tasks take a lot of time that do not feel like they yield much result.

title: Horrible Company
pros: Some of the best reasons to work at Public Storage is if you like to work alone you got to do that a lot. Also getting to know the customers is also a nice part of the job. And I think that's about it.
cons: So the bad parts to working at Public Storage are the upper management wants you to bust your behind to sell merchandise sell locks and sell insurance to put money in their pockets not ours because they went and took our bonuses away. Also there's no room for growth where you are is basically where you stay. It doesn't matter if you've been there for 20 years or 1 month there's no seniority rules in that place. They do not give raises and if they do it's $0.05 to $0.25 and you have to wait years for that.

title: Public Storage
pros: Work Independently, Caring Supervisors, steady work, 401 K matching plan.
cons: Very low pay and no acknowledgement of seniority. I receive the same hourly rate as a new hire and I have been working here 4 1/2 years.

title: Long Term District Manager
pros: We get to work in a unique retail environment everyday without the crazy retail hours. We have the support of an amazing corporate office with top notch training tools at our disposal for learning, coaching and training our teams in the field. We have the best management team in place that is dedicated to the successes of all employees. You can feel the passion for our properties / business from many employees at all levels who take pride in what we do every day. You can say “we bleed orange” … I know I do. After 15+ years, I still love Public Storage hope to contribute for many more years.
cons: I can't think of any negatives. We work hard everyday but that come natural to people driven for results.

title: Great Place to be home away from home
pros: I have worked for PS for over 12 years. I enjoy coming into work with kind coworkers, fair bosses, and overall a home away from home. I recommend to all potential hires to come in to hone your sales experience, growth, and become comfortable. A typical day at work is a slight grind, but manageable. I love the management here. I trust them to be fair, and have knowledge to depend on. The culture here is a bit serious, with a splash of fun during the tough days of overtime. Hardest part of the job is the clientele to deal with day in and day out. I enjoy the schedule I have earned over time, & family aspect around the office with laughs being the wonderful bonus.
cons: Lack of pay raise, clientele you deal with daily, change of policies

title: Public Storage is the worse place I ever worked
pros: A paycheck is the only good reason to work at Public Storage...(while looking for a better job with competition and also get experience)
cons: Bad or next to nothing medical...poor raises....poor working condition....they dont care if you have a life outside the company...lies...they tell you when hired you will work one weekend a month......after 5 years working for this company I worked every weekend...!!! micro management to the max...DM's dont give you credit (after working for the company as a property manager) for 5 years you know how to do the job....they hire DM" that know nothing about the job...when you ask a question the DM calls another employee???????? Come on the DM should know how do do his or her job.........very low pay.compared to other storage companies....very low..............also they dont call customers back that have a complaint

title: Not a great place to work.....anymore
pros: Decent Bonus structure and stock options
cons: There is no balance between work and life. You are on call 24 hours a day and expected to look at your phone every 30 minutes to make sure you did not miss a call, text or an e-mail. Regional Managers expect responses to emails even on Saturday & Sunday or else you get a terse call about staying in contact. Regional Manager continues to add to the workload with no consideration for family or time off. Micro Managing and overriding DM decisions only to them hold DM accountable for the outcomes of their choices. Management promotes and demotes with no rhyme or reason behind their decisions, so much for open communication

title: The horrible position as a "Relief Manager" at Public Storage.
pros: You work independently. You receive healthcare benefits after 3 months.
cons: Your overly worked for a position that seems like 5 in 1. You are expected to meet outrageous sales goals, which sometimes you don't even get incentives for. The managers do not care about your schedule and do not make considerations (the schedules are not consistent you rotate every week); all you know is the time frame in which you will work not the specific weekdays after 2 week intervals ( and sometimes they change your schedule last minute).

title: Easy job
pros: Very easy entry-level job. Fair pay and you are able to see raises happen. You start off with manager title so the places you can go from hear increases. Many different skills are taught from selling storage and merchandise to all office duties (calls, paperwork, fax, collections)
cons: Each district has there own gossip and drama. You must learn or atleast try to upsell merchandise with every transaction. Also all cons that just come from working at a corporate job.

title: Great Company to work for!!!!
pros: Several things make this a great company to work for. It really is a team environment. Unlike many positions where you view your peers as competition everyone really does pull in the same direction. Bonuses and Promotions are based on hard work and merit not on favoritism. Expectations are clearly laid out and feedback is given clearly and candidly by supervisors. Overall this is a very fair place to work where effort is rewarded.
cons: Much like any other retail position you can expect to work most holidays though the company is generous with their paid time off.

title: If I could give 0 stars I would
pros: The hours are good 9:30am to 6:00pm They have apartments on site that you can live in.
cons: They expect you to sell an over priced lock and overpriced insurance with every move in. No bonuses, and pretty much all you can ever be is a property manager. They are just starting to hire people who can pass backround checks, and they end up hiring people who just sit and do nothing all day long and you come back from your 2 days off having to play catch up.

title: No integrity
pros: Work from home, you can save money and avoid traffic
cons: They took away Christmas bonus ($$$) during covid even though they made record sales and didn't pay for a banquet room for a holiday party. They change the bonus structure to act like their care about our concerns but they manipulate it in a way that you actually make less money or the same. You are forced to work 10 hour days at the beginning and end of the month. You have to race to submit a PTO 3 months in advance and at midnight to get a fighting chance. Co Stanly receive combines from customers about propert managers not being available at the property to help with move ins.

title: A Warning. Go in with your eyes open.
pros: Stepping stone. Independent work. On site housing. Goal Oriented. Simple work. Resume and contact building. An ideal place to learn the basics of the self storage industry.
cons: The company has decreased real income to field employees for the last 5 years. The company culture is "WASTY" (We are smarter than you!) Employees are unable to take initiative to address customer needs and then reprimanded when customers complain. Facilities are not maintained because these expenditures are a part of the compensation plan for District and Regional Mgt. ergo the routine items that should be addressed are put off until they become major problems. There is no program for promotions or development from within.

title: Great place to grow and develop
pros: Joining Public Storage has been a rewarding experience for me. The “team” environment that exists at every level of the organization has made this an easy transition for me from my prior job. The initial training I received and the support of Senior Management has helped prepare me for whatever challenges may lie ahead. The freedom to try new ideas within my district as well as coach and develop my property managers into solid performers has been a very rewarding experience for me. I also see there is great potential for advancement based on me and my abilities and because of these possibilities I look forward to learning and teaching something new every day. I look forward to continuing my career with Public Storage and would recommend this Company to everyone.
cons: The technology used is a little behind the times and would like to see an improvement in this area.

title: Ok if you're fine with not going anywhere
pros: Set schedule Set daily activities You work alone Not much micro-managing depending on your DM In the office majority of the time
cons: Dealing with the irate customers Having to make harassing phone calls to collect payments You are responsible for the entire property, grounds and all If you are a relief manager be prepared to behave a certain with with all the property managers, each property manager does their own thing differently Training doesn't really stop, as 2 weeks is not enough time to learn all the processes They expect you to use scripts that corporate makes, but corporate probably has never dealt with an irate customer who is being evicted/kicked out of their home High pressure sales tactics to sell merchandise

title: Relief manager
pros: The best part of working for Public Storage are the benefits that you receive. Public Storage offers health care, eye care, dental, 401 K and much more. The hours are also great, 9:30- 6pm monday through Friday and 9:30- 5pm on Saturdays and Sundays.
cons: The company is very tight with their money. If you are a property manager with an apartment, they will drop your pay to minimum wage and you won't receive anymore than that. Also if there is an issue with your apartment they will take forever to send someone over to fix it. One of my co workers has mold in her apartment and they have not taken care of it for her. We used to also have bonuses but we no longer do.

title: Set up to fail
cons: istent 38 -40 hours depending on their needs.

title: Property mansger
pros: Benefits to the company are great start after 60 days of employment.
cons: The company may say they are with you but when you are having issues with either property customers or other employees. They take there sweet time to get things fixed. Especially if your property isnt one of the big income ones or meeting metrics. Numbers seems to be all the corporate side cares about. Those who are local with you will help best to what corporate will allow. Tland they do not hire within so if you apply as a field employee then you are stuck there. If you try and go corporate side good luck to you.

title: Slavery
pros: There are no pros to this company
cons: You are micro managed, You have to lie to coperate if they ask a question about how you are treated,if there is anything wrong on the property, You have to lie to customers on locks and insurance or lose your job, The DM in my district tells your personal business to other peers and always tries to get you to say something about your co workers, He makes comments on your size or if you are classy enough. He likes to keep arguments going on between coworkers.

title: District Manager
pros: Stable company is all I can say for this section
cons: Stable company that does not care about the customers or employees. For having over 1B in the bank they sure don't pay the hourly associates well. They continue to pull back bonuses and perks. DM has no personal life. Expectations are that the office phone rolls to the cell so calls are coming in at all hours. Especially before auctions as you get the last minute tenants wanting to play Let's Make A Deal instead of just paying what they owe Upper management truly does not care about the DMs and hourly associates. It is all about one more lock and one more insurance sale so the stock price will continue to go up...no matter what. There is a reason there is so much turnover. And those that have not left yet just have not found another position. It's is sad that a company his big can be so uncaring Just stay away

title: Public Storage
pros: Forward thinking company which has experienced lots of growth since I joined. Senior Management is very aggressive and smart when making their business decisions. That is why the Company is #1 in the Storage world. Stable company with high demands and expectations of their employees. So if you work hard you will thrive here. There are busy times, but Management will work with you to help with work life balance. The people here are great. Most of the newer employees comment on the people here being very helpful in assisting you when you need help. Very good company to work for.
cons: In comparison to prior employers, benefits are a little softer and less sick days and holidays. They try to make it up to you with increased PTO days off.

title: Best Career Decision I Could have Made!
pros: Great work/life balance, career advancement opportunities, fantastic leadership, strong company portfolio, and great opportunity to build wealth
cons: I've been with the company for just over a year and I have not found many cons yet. Coming from my previous employer, everything about Public Storage has been an upgrade. If I had to select one thing, I would say that the vetting process for selecting a District Manager can be tedious to progress through. I do think that we miss out on some very talented candidates at times, but on the other hand, I also believe it helps us ensure that we are getting a strong, qualified candidate every time as well.

title: An opportunity to pass by
pros: The company offers a good base,opportunity for bonuses, PTO and benefits. There is some freedom to set your own daily schedule.
cons: No ability to make managerial decisions, you become a corporate robot. There is an expectation to work from 7 am to 6 pm and 2 hours of computer work after hours. The company does not value it's employees and has a retention rate of 40%. The company cuts corners in every aspect of the business in order to drive the stock price no matter what the impact is to the employee or the customer

title: Great, stable company that is well-managed fiscally with many long-term and loyal employees.
pros: Everyone I work with at Public Storage is enthusiastic and bright. Many employees have been here for 15 to 20 years and still love their jobs! The employees believe in the product, the customers and the company. Time-off and benefits are good. Pay is good. I definitely recommend this company.
cons: Company is very agressive and detailed about execution and results. If you're going to present results, make sure you know exactly what you're talking about and own it. Although I prefer this and it's a sign of a health, I can see how this could be an issue for some people.

title: Public Storage is a great and solid company to work for
pros: PS has financially strong balance sheet and it is the leader in the industry. The benefits and compensation are in line with other companies of its size. I believe that there is always room for growth if you want to challenge yourself in your job. It is very stable and one can see themselves retiring here. If you work hard and contribute to your department you will be be recognized and compensated accordingly.
cons: Maybe the company can provide more perks like Thanksgiving turkeys and company picnics for employees and their families. Maybe they can give out more cash prizes at the company holiday party. Maybe PS can absorb more of the employee's health insurance premiums.

title: I have worked for PS for over 7 years and am very happy with the company.
pros: Company is committed to my development and provides me with the tools I need to succeed. They challenge me to grow every day! PS relocated my family and I across the country as part of their commitment to my success as I transitioned from the DM to Senior DM role. They care about my development and give me feedback on ways to be more effective in my role.
cons: I can't think of any. This is a great company to work for if you have high standards for development and professional growth.

title: not the best
pros: At times you work alone and at your own phase. District manager was very understating when it came to personal issues
cons: Take forever to repair. They pressure you to sell their products and will get written up if you do not sell. Collection calls (they should have their own department) !

title: Anywhere But Here!
pros: -Pay at 75K -Guaranteed bonus if you dont get fired first.
cons: -You're NOT really a DM...every decision has to be approved by your boss. -Your employees (relief & property managers) have no company growth so if you are taking the job because you are interested in developing a dynamic team...RUN. -Benefits cost way more than average $175-$320 with co-pays and $2500 deductibles per person ...for "A Million" company, they should be able to provide atleast a 50-50 plan instead of 20-80(employee) -MICRO-MANAGEMENT kills -Saturday/Sunday off does not exist. -On call 24-7 and we're not saving lives....Work-life balance is a joke. -No culture, no recognition, no team building, no community engagement, no holiday parties and THANK YOU is foreign to much of upper management. -Turn over is way too high...been here 6 months and saw 4 people go...3 quit! Bottom line PS sucks!

title: Want to work for a stressful place and forget that you have family and kids then Join this company
pros: Fair compensation, if you do a good job they give you year end bonuses and recognition for your work
cons: They expect you to work more than 8 hours a day, 7 days a week. I understand there were time when a fire drill happened like the network was down, the phone system was not able to receive calls then you must be all hands on deck. But come on you were called on holiday because your manager had a stupid question and can't wait until Monday. I have no personal life.

title: Become a storage expert today!
pros: Public storage is definately an Industry leader, very stable! Very customer service focus company ! Work a minimum of 38-40 hrs a week, independent work setting with opportunity to complete task and goals as a team! Gain great managerial experience Excellent benefits to include dental, vision + medical insurance. 401K plan is awesome. flexibl and paid vacation time... you will get a increase in pay after 6 months and opportunity to earn additional money through referral program and the annual bonus program that is in place. Rotating off days to give you flexibly with your personal life
cons: Little to no opportunity for career advancement..only starts off with $9.50 .. bonus program is annually

title: "I'M NOT AN ACTOR"
pros: Good hours because you don't have to work nights. Thats the only good thing i have to say about this place
cons: No advancement at all. DM has his fav's that can do whatever including not coming to work and he'll clock them in, and RM fav's don't have to move around at all. Having to roleplay 8 scripts word for word with Sr DM and DM like your getting paid to be a actor. "Beneifits" lets just say don't get sick!!They have money to pay shopper but can't give the RM's and PM's that make this company desent pay. I have work for this company 3yr and it'sgetting worse and worse every year. Let just say eveything that is said on this website is true. Can't wait until this recession is over!!!!!!

title: Its a Job
pros: Mainly work by yourself on a daily basis. If you do your job you will see the district manager no more than three times a month. A lot of down time at most properties. Job stability.
cons: Lower level employees from Property manager and relief start out making $9.50. Bonus incentives have changed each year and the company has made it harder for employees to get a bonus. Company went from quarterly bonuses to yearly bonuses. Bonuses decreased each year during my 4 1/2 years at the company. Managers are only focused on numbers not employees. There is no opportunity for advancement. Property Manager is as far as you can grow. The company rather bring in outsiders to manage the district who has no clue how to manage the stores.

title: Reality vs. Fantasy
pros: This company has some great benefits. The hours are not too bad.
cons: We are actively engaged in deceiving our customers. No customer is ever told that they will have to buy an expensive lock. Or, that their rent will be raised every 6 months. Also, they do not value their workers. They pay VERY poorly, yet expect perfection at all times. All workers are expected to memorize and use stilted, poorly worded scripts. Lastly there is no room for advancement. This company does not ever advance from within. If you are a store manager that is all that you will ever be!

title: Public Storage is an Outstanding Company to Work For!
pros: Full time hours, benefits, set schedule, days off are consecutive, autonomy, professional environment, outstanding leadership, great training. I've read many reviews from employees that speak negatively about the scripts and I don't feel that way at all. They've helped me become a better salesperson. Besides, there is only one script they ask you to learn word for word. I can be somewhat creative on the rest, even rewarded when my techniques become adopted by others! I enjoy focusing on a select few items to sell, rather than previous retail jobs I've had, where I had to learn an entire store! It's been a great experience!
cons: Most of your interactions with co-workers are over the phone, so it can get lonely, especially when customer traffic is slow.

title: A lot of work for little pay
pros: Getting an apartment on a property for rent free only if you bust your butt to get there and throw people under and suck up to management
cons: In the interview they don't go over at all that you will be required to sell packing supplies. If you don't sell, you get a red mark on the excel spread sheet which the entire region can see! Co workers will throw you under the bus so you fail and the managers will believe anything they say if they have good sales. It's hard to get any days off and you don't work at one specific location. The employees who have apartments with free rent and utilities do the exact same work as a relief manager. You get crazy customers who are scary in the office who threaten you if Public Storage sells their unit in auction. It;s a mad house!

title: Under paid
pros: Free apartment, Laid back environment, you get to meet new people and no late working hours.
cons: Require to much work for very little pay, you're good enough to train a District Manager but not good enough to be promoted to one. Everything is scripted which sucks, no real benefits, the lowest paying storage company.

title: District Manager
pros: Schedule flexibility, support from fellow DM's, good salary, and coaching employees.
cons: Sadly as soon as we got a new Regional targeted for termination. Zero support or development from supervisor who only spent time with you when his supervisors were in town. Terminated with no explanation or previous documentation. They constantly have req's open and try to sell you that they're looking to get people on the bench for support but as soon as done with training someone is getting let go. Conference calls are relentless, repetitive and are just punishment for underperformance. People regurgitate the same thing weekly. Complete waste of time and takes away from being in field. Stock option but was terminated a week before I was eligible to get my 100 shares so I got nothing after being there for three years.

title: Excellent Company to work for
pros: Public Storage provides you with Top Notch training and helps build your resume to progress your career. They allow for you to provide feedback and help make decisions within not only your market, but also throughout the whole company. You receive recognition from the highest level when you excel which is always nice to hear when you do a great job. I would 100% recommend Public Storage to anyone looking for a career move.
cons: At times making sure you stay connected to the daily workload can be challenging as things come up, for me I enjoy this, but depending on previous work environment this can be something that holds someone back. There is a learning curve for everyone, but if you like fast pace and working with people this is the place to be.

title: inventory control coordinator
pros: working for almost 10 years at this company I have become part of a family. i love my job, my boss, the people i work alongside with, and others who became my friends. it really is a great 500 fortune company to work for. we have a very pleasant workplace atmosphere. Coming to work everyday with the right attitude and being grateful for being hired made a big difference.
cons: just like other companies we also have some challenges to face especially with our current economy. but fortunately we are thriving even during this time. since inflation has outpaced our wages i am hoping that salary will also increase, and that sick hours and floating hours will be considered again. oh yes also healthier snacks available at the break room.

title: District Manager Position
pros: You get to create your own schedule. Benefit plans are good.
cons: Constantly working even when you are "suppose" to be off the clock. They say it is a Monday-Friday 9am-6pm position; instead you receive calls at all hours of the day and night from your team and customers. A lot of travel; may not be placed in a district near to where you live. Also have not received a compensation raise the last 3+ years. --- wish I listened to this advice when I read the same reviews before taking the position.

title: I dont recommend.
pros: You get a set schedule, you work independently. Get reimbursed for travel. Coworkers are nice and assist you with any questions. If you don't have "major" responsibilities, this job is good for you because there's hardly any work-life balance.
cons: Training for 9 days, after that you're sent to a location by yourself. Notify DM for a day off at least 4 weeks in advance. Lots of calls, rude customers. You have to be a janitor, sales rep, security, make calls, collect payments, bank deposits, etc. It pays too little for all the work one person has to do. Understaffed. Expected to reach a goal of selling merch. Follow scripts.

title: We work too hard for our small money..
pros: It's a Job... Advancement can be good if your in the right place at the time.
cons: All communication begins and ends with what the District Manager says. There is no communication beyond that unless you get a visit that great once in awhile from upper management. Of course your going to have disgruntled employees when you have the CEO of the company proudly announcing what the company made in profits for the year and the employees knowing who it was that made that money for them, with the poor wages they were paid.

title: Relief Manager
pros: Bankers Hours. Steady Pay. The rest is just horrible.
cons: The company does not recognize your talents or skill you bring. All they care about is finding people to the job. They want people to do the job and not think just follow. No creativity, lack of motivation. It's all about sell, sell & sell at any means necessary. The scripts are junk, Written by people who have never worked the shift. It's a numbers game. No real way to grow with this company unless you are a DM. Which I think is very wrong. We don't get paid enough. Hourly is a joke. They are taking advantage of the current economic situation to squeeze more work out of you. We do rentals, building maintenance. Even janitorial service. Also no ability to take a decent vacation.

title: Think twice
pros: You are generally your own boss, Apartments can very nice
cons: You never get to leave your work and customers swill knock on your door at all hours and expect you to take care of them even on your day off. I have been followed by customers when I was walking. My life has been threatened numerous times due to auctions. You need to know verbatim presentation to customers. Once you move in they are very cheap at apartment repairs and some apartments are NOT NICE

title: Wouldn't recommend
pros: If you get an apartment the low pay is not as hard to live on. Your pay is cut to minimum wage when you sign the lease but at least your bills are paid. Benefits are good but if you are regularly scheduled on a day that is one of the only 3 holidays that you will get, you don't get paid for it or offered another day off with pay.
cons: Overuse of scripts. Management that doesn't have a clue as to what it is like to work at the properties. You will get chewed out on a regular basis for things that you have no control over. Sometimes irate customers threaten you. Forced to beg for google reviews. You work alone for the most part and are expected to do all the work at the property while at the same time be in the office and call reservations for your property and your buddy property within 5-10 minutes. There are tons of collection calls that you have to make and if your delinquency isn't where they want it to be it is your fault because, I don't know, you didn't kame enough calls. They want you to do high pressure sales of overpriced merchandise but do not give you any incentive to sell.

title: Non resident manager
pros: Calm environment, low foot traffic, generally work alone
cons: Held to performance sales numbers without the sales pay. Management hassles over issues, but won't handle the problems when they're identified. Unless you find the errors in your pay, it's not managements problem. You can never advance to become a district manager. They only hire from outside the company. Never expect to make more than $20000 a year to $25000. Ever. Expected to hit sales goals, but relief manager work at the property on day off and can drive down your numbers badly but still is your fault.

title: Can be OK for some, but not for me...
pros: You always get a manager title, ragardless, so it does look good on resume. I was able to get a few interviews for solid positions after being able to put "relief manager" on there. The pay was $12 in my area, and 10 in most others around my are. It's decent pay for an extra level position. The DM was cool, although company expectations were ridiculous for a non commission job. You could tell he was just doing what he was told and wanted to simply do his part and get his check--I respect that because he did his part well, and I understood where he was coming from when he pushed sales non-stop, or came in in a bad mood.
cons: Well, I'm not entitled person, or someone who expects jobs like these to offer a whole lot; however there were things that even I was very disappointed with. If you are not familiar with what the job entails then you may not understand some of my complaints until you are working there. Firstly, the job is very sales oriented, so much so that you may start to wonder why you aren't getting commission. They do offer bonus's once a year based on performance, but it is tiered, and it does not compensate for lack of a commission structure. The GM will spend his day bugging you about each transaction, and begging you to sell more box's or locks until you feel compelled to cheat customers by charging them without them knowing. All the while you are not being compensated at all for this. There are scripts that they expect you to follow with no room for improvisation. These are some of the most robotic scripts you will ever see, and rely on customers being idiots in order to properly work. Any mistake you make, such as missing an empty unit on your lock check, is dingged and appears as an alert on the company software system, and you are expected to give a full written explanation. Furthermore, the software alert system(and company as a whole) is not employee friendly, it is very customer first type of business, which is fine except for when it is 100% their fault. If a customer leaves a unit without checking out, and they continue to to be charged, it falls on us, and we get an alert, the managers get frustrated and you feel like crap. While I understand we were supposed to do lock checks and catch things like that, it wasn't always so simple on our end. It's too much details to go in a full explanation, but can you just move out of your apartment without telling your landlord? Then get mad because he charges you? On another note, there isn't much room for growth. You can become a property manager, and that comes with a free apartment, but it's on the property, and accepting that position will essentially keep you dependent on the company for more than just work, thus keeping you stuck there, since, how can you beat free housing? overall it is a stressful job and the compensation does not match it. There is a lot of paperwork, you are expected to also make appointment calls, late rent calls, lien calls, and calls to tell people your are selling their belongings because they haven't paid. You will be dealing with a lot of emotional people because, well, YOU'RE SELLING THEIR STUFF! I could go on and on about the position. As A young guy with high aspirations, and wants to move up in this world, I was not excited to wake up for this job. If you're not worried about too much and just need a decent job while in school, then you may not mind it. Or if you're older and just want to make some decent money then may be ok. Just know it's a tedious job.

title: Relief Manager
pros: Set Hours, Work Independently, Decent Insurance Plans, Easy Work.
cons: Low Pay, Work in different store each day a lot of times further a drive than its worth, Untrustworthy Coworkers that either don't show up or "borrow" from petty cash or both, Have to pick up other employees slack and everyone blames whoever isn't there, Help line shoves any customer issues back to store managers or relief managers who can't fix the problems at hand or they just transfer calls back to the office so the customers can't get through to help line, repairs don't get fixed in reasonable amount of time and customers get mad at relief/store manager who are unable to do anything about issues.

title: Fantastic, stable company, and a leader in the industry
pros: I have been working at PS for some time now (close to 15 years), and can truly say that I have been given the opportunity to chart my own course here. I truly enjoy my role, and have the opportunity to work with multiple levels of management in the corporate office. From the CEO to VP's to Operations - all are easy to work with, and are approachable . Work-life balance is very important to me, as is the opportunity for continued growth and learning - and I have both! My co-workers are fantastic, and are committed to the growth and success of the company.
cons: Benefits are a bit on the expensive side.

title: Love love love my job
pros: The district that I work in is like having another family. The higher up people as well are the most down to earth people I have ever had the plessure of working with. They do there very best to make you feel like an asset. I will retire from this company. Pros you get the best of both worlds working outside as well as working inside. That is always an amazing thing. Here you are not micro managed. The layout of your day is always at your finger tips. Public Storage does not set you up to fail. They set you up for success.
cons: Really don't know of any cons other than you have to adapt to getting paid semi monthly. Once you get that together then it is truly smooth sailing

title: New DM to Pulic Storage
pros: Love the leadership! Regional and Divisional leadership is engaged not only in my personal development but also with that of the property managers which is key in inspiring loyalty. Training for new DM's is an extensive 3 month process ensuring that you are set up for success once in role, loved my training mentor and my training made me confident in the transition to taking over my current district. Seems like there is a lot of energy put in to succession planning and promoting within!
cons: You have your hands in a lot more aspects of the business than I have ever experienced in similar roles, however the 3 month training ensures you are comfortable with all of this before going live.

title: Relief Manager
pros: Full time hours, great property management experience. Some of the district managers are really amazing. There's a lot to learn in property management and this is an excellent starting place.
cons: Minimum wage, no pay significant increases, overload in responsibilities in comparison to the pay. The company makes over a hundred thousand dollars at one of my locations and refuses to update the building or give any form of true customer service (corporate as a whole). They honestly prey on people in hard situations and then run them into the ground. If you are able to get an apartment, they move your pay to minimum wage and fight tooth and nail for any raises even when minimum wage increases.

title: District Manager
pros: The day to day is interesting- you touch many aspects of the business. Weekends off and no calls after 6 pm. You create your own schedule. There's a lot of opportunity to grow and the company is genuinely invested in your success.
cons: You've got to be organized and stay on top of your tasks or you will drown. Customers get angry about many things and you need to deal with it if it escalates.

title: Public Storage as great company to work for and be a member of a great team
pros: I am a full time District Manager for almost 27 years for Public Storage. #1 reason to be a long term employee is the team of employees who work for Public Storage from our CEO to our Property Managers, a great team of people who care of each other and support our goal to provide a great storage experience for our customers. Our culture is very supporting from all levels of my company. I will always recommend Public Storage for your career and personal growth to be a better person and leader.
cons: Every company has opportunities however Public Storage is 100% transparent to listen and show support for all employees.

title: Although my incentive compensation was good, the stress of the job was not worth it.
pros: Good stock incentive program. The potential bonus incentive helps offset the relatively low base pay. I had a good mentor who was in a similar position. Mentoring is a company best practice.
cons: Poor working conditions, especially for the hourly Property Managers & Assistant Property Managers. Many times they do not get the opportunity to take 10-minute breaks. The company looks the other way in enforcing that employees get to take their breaks. Many of the self-storage properties do not have breakrooms for the employees. In those situations, the employees may have to eat in their cars, or in the office, which can lead to interuptions when a customer knocks on a locked office door. For the salaried multi-unit positions, there is absolutely no work-life balance. They have to work 6-7 days a week and even then, find it difficult to stay caught up. Calls are fielded from customers at all hours (evenings & weekends). The company has a practice of eliminating the bottom 25% of employees at each level in the organization chart. It does not matter if you had a good prior year. Your area could have one bad quarter, and your job is at risk. I had employees threatened by customers and had to work with legal counsel in getting restraining orders. My life was threatened as well by two customers. The self-storage industry is a tough one. As far as Leadership at the company goes, they do maximize the return of the shareholder., but that comes at a cost. Customer service is poor, customers' rate increases are abundant, repairs at the properties are put off and the working conditions are poor. My employees and I never saw any communication from Corporate Human Resources. It's the most silent department in the Company.

title: Not a career
pros: If you don't like working with people, then working a property by yourself is going to be perfect for you
cons: constantly changing how the metrics you are rated on, refuse to take into account your location when reviewed (so if you work in an area with a high number of low income apartments, you'll have bad numbers and they won't care.) Company raises rent often on spaces, then expects you to lie to customers that complain. They will tell you to say it is for improvement to the property, but it never happens. You'll be forced to make phone calls that border on harassment. Pay is not much better than fast food places. Was told many times that even if I was on my lunch break, they expected me to clock in and help someone if they showed up despite this being a very unethical practice. Put a focus on Google Reviews, and encouraged staff to take customers phone and fill out survey for them.

title: Relief Manager Review
pros: Pay, vacation, sick time, paid time off and mileage as well. Friendly management personnel. Very personal job. Overtime available and Sunday time and a half.
cons: No room for growth in moving up with the company. Rumors of not following through with promises dealing with pay and threats of taking away bonus and mileage. Seems like the company management will hire anyone when in a bind, but completely opposite when not hurting for employees.

title: Lots of room for growth
pros: This company has a lot of room to grow and promote. I have been with the company for just over 3 years and have been promoted twice already. You will receive a lot of time working with your manager in order to develop your leadership! Also, because it is a smaller company, you are exposed to the Executive Team. They love spending time out in the field to see what needs improvement and to get feedback from the property team. It means a lot to me that they are willing to listen to the team.
cons: The laptop provided to complete your work is a bit antiquated and slow. I wish I could have a tablet so that I can get more accomplished!

title: District Manager Caleb Galat
pros: I have been with the company for more than 3 years and love to be able to do what is expected of me in my own pace and get what needs to be done in a timely manner. And if I ever have issues that need to be addressed to my District Manager he will take the time to get it taken care of in a quick and timely manner. I cannot say enough about his work ethics and awesome attitude.
cons: Is that when I retire in a couple of years that they do not have part time work .

title: Toxic
pros: It's not a difficult job.
cons: The working People like to spread rumors about other people. Stab each other in the back.. It's a toxic work environment. Good luck getting ahold of your district manager she doesn't care about anyone but herself. Our particular district manager is always on vacation and never available. Should rather allow you to get so frustrated that you quit your job instead of reaching out to you and returning your calls. It's sad it's a shame. I like the job like the job but the people couldn't be my couldn't be more toxic.

title: Corporate culture of fear
pros: Compensation. There is no other reason. Those who remain give a pound of flesh to remain and are compensated for it.
cons: At the corporate level, employees have to subvert themselves to the culture and remain vigilant in being on guard from one another. VERY political without cause. Not a place for development personally, professionally, or otherwise. You endure this place versus being enhanced by it. If you take a position there, then remain low profile at all times. Observe the behavior of your peers and try to understand how and why they have become as such. Model them as long as you have to while you search for a better place. Better place DO exist.

title: Potential Lost
pros: My time at Public Storage was with mixed feelings. I loved the customers and about half of the employees. A lot of back stabbing and lies from co workers to get an apartment. I had a wonderful Manager when I was hired and due to lies and betrayal he was let go. After that it was all manipulation and throwing others under the bus. Very sad.
cons: Here say and contradictions. I would of stayed a long time if it wasn't as bad as it was in my district.

title: It's just a job
pros: Work schedule is great off by 6pm usually no manager there breathing down your back 401k is good
cons: No support if you have an issue no feedback on good job all about the numbers and not enough focus on customer service. Raising rent on long time tenants is just wrong.

pros: I love the people I get to work along side. Getting to work independently and as a part of a larger team. Paid time off. Health benefits. 401K. A variety of tasks through out a given day/month. Opportunity to travel to other stores. Develop skills in the area of sales and over all people skills. Thorough training by excellent trainers. Help people during times of need.
cons: Required work on weekends and at the end of the month. Lack of communication from the top to the bottom. Less than desired pay. Clocking in and out.

title: Learned a lot. Met and networked with some really wonderful people
pros: Great base pay at $15/hr. for Sales Reps. You can work a lot of O.T. if you like extra money. Giant corporation has good benes, 2-3 weeks paid vacation, med, den, vision, fsa, short & long-term disability. You can earn bonus'. Great managers who care about you and talk to you. Great comraderie amongst employees. Lots of Reps have been there over 5years. Job security.
cons: They keep tweaking the bonus structure to take away from the Sales Reps. Live in fear of losing your job every summer (busy season, mandatory OT). Must have thick skin. Must be able to take 35-65calls/7.5hr shifts and keep your cool when you can't make the sale.

title: Don't work here
pros: There really are no pros other then it's a job.
cons: A lot of favoritism the pay sucks. DM follows his own rules. He doesn't call customers back he will leave you to handle customers when he is the one that is supposed to be the one handling the customers . You have people sleeping on the job while on the clock. Others leaving the property for long periods of time and along running a side business while on the clock. To much to name . The DM knows about what is going and so does the Regional. It all gets swept under the rug like nothing is going on. They don't promote within. If you come in at Property level that is as far as you will go.

title: My PS Experience
pros: The things I enjoy most about working for Public Storage is that I feel valued as an employee. The schedule is amazing, I love that I don’t have to be up too early, or stay at work too late. Any last minute changes, such as unexpected doctor appointments, can be accommodated if need be. I truly appreciate the support from upper management.
cons: I feel that every day we face new challenges, whether it be with the customer experience, trying to earn a positive review, or simply just fulfilling the job duties in a day, it can at times be stressful. However, I always feel that with public storage I can clock out and leave feeling stress free and relieved at the end of the day.

title: The treatment of your employees and customers.
pros: I am sorry to say but as far as I am concern I thought there was only one good reasons for working for public and that is when the executives visits , we thought we could voice our opinion but then we were told by the DM and SDM when they ask us what can they do to improve your job, that we were to say everything was fine even though it was not.. I would suggest when you do plan a visit do not let anyone know when you are going to show up, just surprise them and then you will see how they are treating your customers and your employees.
cons: Some of the changelings of working for working for Public Storage is getting better services for the customers and the employees.

title: GREAT COMPANY!
pros: I have been with this Company for 2 years. I came to work her because of the growth potential and to invest myself in a stable Company. It was a great choice. I can work in a business that has great job security and in my time, I have personally experienced the growth potential. I was able to get promoted to the next level. It is a great feeling, to work hard and focus on the right things, and reap the benefits of advancing my career.
cons: Multi-unit positions require a lot of dedication and hard-work. However, you find that in any company. If you are not afraid of hard work and holding high expectations for your own performance, then this is the Company you can grow with.

title: Property Manager
pros: The district managers at this company are hands-on and always there to help. The apartment that is offered is great incentive to become property manager.
cons: Very pushy sales practices. Dealing with irate customers can be very unsafe at times. If I was unable to have a home security system, I would not live on the property. Pay is 9/hr when you are a property manager. If you were to get an off-site apartment and get paid regular, you would even out pretty much the same. Relief Managers rarely work at same location in the district, so there is quite a bit of travel to different locations. The company doesn't like to shell out too much money for maintenance.

title: On site managers
pros: On site properties, set your own pace, great people, and getting to help people. That is all the pros I can think of
cons: On site managers should get higher pay. They are the ones responsible and held accountable for property performance. As the years have gone by upper management demanding more and more but the pay has stayed pretty much the same. Actually worse since the bonuses are terrible now.

title: All 5 star reviews are totally bogus!!!! Great customers but the DMs and above are slave drivers
pros: None.... Even though you pretty much work unsupervised the threat of upper management popping up and drilling you on every script possible exists. They want robots not people. They also force you to sell extremely overpriced moving supplies and a 20 dollar lock (17.99) . They keep track of the number of locks and insurance you sale and if you're logged members and insurance numbers are bad you're in trouble.
cons: Extremely overpriced merchandise and management refuses to factor in the fact that customer don't want to pay for overpriced goods.

title: This company asked me to write a good review to raise their approval rating.
pros: Great Salary for DM's and above Some of the people you work with are very nice, but only some. I cannot come up with any more Pros.
cons: Property managers are paid poverty wages Around 20 scripts that have to be memorized word for word HR asked several new DM's to write reviews to raise the approval rating. That in itself is just poor. Leadership is just awful and they lie, cheat and steal and yet you cannot say a thing or you will lose your job. Gossip is out of control. This company lacks integrity all the way through the CEO

title: District Manager
pros: If you really need a job this may be a fit for you. As a district manager you will have limited flexibility in your schedule. The bonus program can be up to 32K per year although it's highly unlikely you will do well for consecutive years in the same market.
cons: Most companies view their people as the largest asset, not this one. Turnover at the District Manager level and Property Manager position is very high. As a district manager, you will have zero work life balance. You will be micromanaged as if you didn't know the meaning of the word prior. You will have almost no authority to make decisions on behalf of your employees or customers.
