Goal setting is based on beating the previous year, it's extremely difficult to succeed multiple years in the same territory. District Managers conduct lock cuts, auctions, coordinate repair and maintenance, conduct a large portion of the HR hiring process, handle the majority of customer service issues. You're always on call and your phone can and will be ringing 7 days a week at all hours. The issue being is your compensation and review is tied to sales management in which you have no time for. Probably the worst aspect is the treatment and pay of the property managers. The expectations put forth on them is well above the pay scale.

title: Run far away!!!
pros: The hours, no nights...a lot of down time for reading, you work independently with no boss hanging over your shoulder all day long
cons: Corporate office took away the bonus plan, saying that some employees don't understand it so we decided to take it away, but you're all great employees so get people to apply, so ridiculous!! Took away some vacation time Low pay, a lot of sales pressure with no compensation. No advancement from within the company. Scripts scripts and more scripts, you're the banker the janitor the rental agent and everything else they can throw at you...we sound like idiots when we meet and greet a customer. Beg for google reviews and if you don't get 2 a month here comes the disciplinary action!! Camera systems are a joke..stay away if you can!!

title: Degrading
pros: If you like being made to feel like you're nothing than PS is the place for you.
cons: Making less money then when you were a teenager. NO sick time, you have to use 5 vacation days then on the 6th day your sick time well kick in. 2% or less yearly raise. Medical insurance costs have literally doubled. Vacation time has been cut. Managers treat you like you like the garbage stored in their facilities. Managers make it known that hourly employees are clearly beneath them. Managers are proud to take credit for the hard work of others. Employee turn over is huge due to the horrible lack of respect.

title: good until you see through the dog and pony show
pros: Stores are physically not open past 6pm. That helps with less issues with customers past office hours. If you get a great Regional, then you will get more out of this position. Peers 8 out of 10 are good people. Pay is competitive for a big box store salary.
cons: this company has analysis paralysis. There are literally 17 reports to run daily. To send to someone. You need to do things so you don't show up on someone's report somewhere. They will work on your pay plan the year of the pay plan. they work on objectives the year those objectives are for. There is no planning from regional manager and above. They overload you on pencil pushing thing to do instead of value time spent with your people to develop them. Each of the systems are built to take 5 extra steps to do one thing. You cannot approve repairs past 100 dollars. They also coddle veterans that are chronic underperformers. Corporate employees and some regional and above are there to catch what you're doing wrong yet not offer solutions to fix it. There is no real "time off" on the weekends . They have so many unwritten rules on how to answer an email or a question or a phone call. Have more transparency with your people!

title: Great Company to work for! Join Us!
pros: I have been working with Public Storage for a little over a year now and I have nothing but great things to say about the company and upper management. Public Storage provides a great work/life balance, benefits, and growth opportunities. The extensive training and coaching program will set you up for success and continue to develop your management career. Are you ready to join this great company?
cons: No negatives to mention here. Like I mentioned earlier management is always there for you ensuring that you don't fail in your position and rewarding your hard work. Our staff is also second to none.

title: Good job for compensation only - NO CULTURE!
pros: Good compensation! Good people to work with.
cons: No culture so be prepared to build your own. All about shareholders and the stock price not employee. Low pay for property staff leads to constant turnover. Upper management is out of touch with the realities of the business.

title: Family & Friends
pros: Number 1 leading company in storage. Been with company about 3 years and have made some great friends in customers and co-workers. I am very fortunate to have a Awesome DM that goes that extra mile for each and every property manager and relief manger. Just with a simple thank you goes a long way. It's amazing when the little things we do everyday and you think goes un noticed you are rewarded with a all expense trip to California, for a week and a award ceremony were you are presented with the Circle of Excellence. So just when you think you are not noticed, you are.
cons: When items need fixed to have them taken care of in a timely manner.

title: Great Company... Even Better People
pros: I have been at the corporate office of Public Storage for only a few years - which makes me the exception as most seem to have been here for 10/20+. This experience creates a great working environment full of camaraderie and experience. The corporate structure is flat which provides much opportunity to grow and expand. Titles do not mean a lot inside the walls, it's really a team effort. The work/life balance is excellent and the office environment is very quiet.
cons: Public Storage is by far the most successful company in the self-storage industry. However, being in that industry is the only downside I can think of as self-storage is not the most exciting industry to be part of here in Los Angeles.

title: Building Teams
pros: Great team environment. The company offers a very competitive salary, a very real opportunity to advance, a healthy bonus plan, and stock in the company. We are all owners in the company stock program that has quadrupled since I started. There is also a real opportunity to experience work-life balance. We work hard & support each other at all levels. Everyone is committed to their customers & team mates.
cons: The challenges are welcomed because they are a product of our explosive growth. There is a lot of change as we add in hundreds of locations. Although the change is always for the better, success requires an eagerness to try, fail, learn, and grow. The pace is both challenging and exciting.

title: Great Compny
pros: Great independence . There is a great team of DMs and SDMs who help support you along the way. The company is very well run and recently has started to make quick work to improve technology and employees jobs. The caliber of DMs and above is impressive and makes you want to succeed here.
cons: Audits are stressful and lock cuts and managing plowing expectations in the winter can be difficult. It is hard to take an unexpected day off of work because tasks will still be due and if no one is watching your district things still need to be completed on time. There is a salary cap, although it takes a few years to reach it is a little disheartening.

title: Very Poor work/life balance
pros: Meeting and getting to know interesting people
cons: Raises aren’t given very often to property & relief managers. If they are given it’s very low, around 16 cents. Don’t expect a raise if you live on property, not only do they reduce your hourly pay to live in one, but your wage is frozen.The apartments are in bad shape & trying to get something fixed is a lost cause. Only 3 holidays a year & if your regular day off falls on that day, you don’t get paid for the holiday. I could list several other cons but will stop before I run out of space to type.

title: Relief Manager
pros: Meet new people and off by 6pm.
cons: I have worked here for the past 8 months and I been looking for a new job since my 2 week of working. The people at the call center make more money than field employees and 80% of the time they give customers the WRONG information. Only the PM's (well at least in my district) are off on Sunday and Monday. If you want request a Sunday or Monday off, you will work the next 8 days. I don't know about anyone else, but I HATE those stupid scripts. They are impersonal and not realistic in a conversation. There is no security what so ever. So if somene wants to rob you they can. The place is infested with roaches its disgusing. They are so unfair to long time customers.

title: If you are looking for a culture based company you have found it! Success is about commitment to excellence
pros: The management team is dedicated to helping you grow as a leader. You run a business within a business and can see results with effort. Very rewarding personally and financially.
cons: This is not for the faint of heart. It a marathon job that is about relentless execution. If that is you it will pay off. If you are looking for the dream of overnight success, keep looking.

title: Good company if you have initiative and are a long term contributer
pros: Fellow employees in the corporate office are easy work with and the enviorment is gennerally low key. If you show initiative, a good work ethic and common sense the company can be very rewarding both financially as well as in terms of job/career satisfaction.
cons: Depending on your position the balance between work and personal time can get a bit lopsided. However in the context of what can be expected in any company these days, its probably just normal.

title: Ive wasted 4 years for this?
pros: Hours are from 9:30-6pm m-f, 9:30-5pm on weekends so that could be a benefit depending on your personal preference. Most managers, under the district manager are all generally nice from my experience. Apartments are available to employees that need a place to stay. Will have to take a pay cut.
cons: The management style. Upper management sucks-- all the way to the CEO. They constantly change policies and scripts used to rent units to customers You feel pressured into forcing customer to buy overpriced merchandise. And then you are "called out" by management when a customer doesn't purchase anything from you. Inconsistency within the company. For example, The call center will tell the customer it is $23 to rent a space and that is all the customer will need, then the customer will come in with only $23 and we are expected to sell the customer an overpriced lock and then insurance and then sell merchandise to them,.Which makes no sense. No growth. The highest position a relief/property manager can go is KTP, which is a management trainer and they only get paid $1 extra to do that task, So a relief manager can not move up and become a district manager. You would have to quit and then get rehired as a District manager. Finally, the bonus. The bonus plan changes every year and they add more and more variables to make it difficult for managers to get a bonus.

title: A soul crushing corporate environment - DON'T TAKE THE JOB.
pros: If you are C-list executive or major shareholder, this company works for you.
cons: Everything. If you like working in a draconian, institutional, dreary corporate office, this is the place for you. The irrational CEO rules by intimidation and fear and creates policy to "keep the masses down", while creating inflated stock prices to boost bonuses for the very few. Anyone who can leave will or those who have hung on from the glory days before the CEO took over and are waiting for retirement to cash their stock (no longer offered to employees). No investment is made in the infrastructure so employees work with deficient systems in a high stress environment. Avoid the real estate department at all costs. Toxic.

title: Horrible company that doesn't care about customers or employees.
pros: They were flexible with my school schedule and even allowed me to only work weekends. They kept my pay when I transferred from the Bay Area.
cons: Lowest pay in the storage industry, constant pressure from management (including illegally selling insurance and doing whatever it takes to make the customer purchase it), no promotions unless it's to a property manager (you get a free apartment on site, but your pay drops to minimum wage), very small pay increases (I was there for four years in the Bay Area and went from $10.00 to $11.47 other parts of the country make much less.

title: Steady hours but...
pros: Steady hours, good for starters. Everything is scripted, so anybody can do it. Basic knowledge on real state and regulations.
cons: No flexibility, the pay is not enough for the workload. The customers treat you like trash. There's no room for growth. The manager spends most of the time alone and don't think about getting sick, because hardly will get somebody to cover you, but if somebody calls in, hold on tight because toy will have to cover the shift.

title: Loving My Job
pros: Public Storage offers skill sets that can be used anywhere in life. They make sure you know your job inside and out before you get out of training, and offer many educational outlets once you are out. The work atmosphere is comfortable and I know that I can count on my teammates! You are told upfront what is expected of you prior to hiring. Integrity and hard work are rewarded. Public Storage seeks out 'A players' to provide SuperSTAR service skills.
cons: It is extremely hard to move up past KTP in the company. Public Storage hires outside of the company.

title: Sr. Tax Analyst
pros: Public Storage is a solid financially secure company. The financial decisions Sr. Management have made to invest in acquiring and developing properties insures growth of the company and stability for employees. Public Storage values its subject matter experts and the contributions these individuals bring to the organization to help the company maintain its financial position in the market place. Additionally, the company does well in promoting from within. This is evident through the advancement of many District Managers to Sr and Regional DM positions.
cons: The company could offer better benefit packages to employees that include long term care. There are no company or corporate events to increase team building and company unity.

title: Property manager
pros: You get to work alone without having someone over your shoulder all day
cons: Where to begin. They over charge for on-site apartments. The hourly pay starts at 10 but it's not worth the amount of work you have to do. Issues with apartments and properties take FOREVER to get fixed and I hope you don't need your manager to help you with anything cause that won't happen. If you get a bonus it won't be worth a crap and raises very rarely if ever happen.

title: If you care about yourself, do not work here.
pros: There are no pros to working here. I guess if you are desperate for cash they will pay you twice a month. The benefits are so-so at best for a company of this size.
cons: Horrible middle/upper management. Company scams customers and treats employees like scum. If they offer you an on site apartment, run. You will never get a maintenance issue fixed including emergencies (they left me without heating for over a month in the middle of the winter.) You will be required to wear a million hats but get paid less than a mcdonalds employee. Enjoy being the butt end of every heated customer complaint because this company loves to bait and switch. No room for upward mobility. This company does not hire from within. CEO takes home 15 million a year yet you will be lucky if you get a yearly raise worth more than a quarter.

title: I have no bad words..this company has been good to me
pros: I have had a few different DM's and each one has different personalities but I was treated with respect. This is a sales position and that is what should be focused on. When your hired to do a job if you don't like it then you should find something else no matter where you are working. It's nice to be out at 6 and 5 on the weekends. No long retail nights!!
cons: Sometimes it may be difficult when you are working by yourself, that's when it seems the most people come in. The only other thing is that we should be off a few more holidays

title: Great company to work for
pros: I’ve been a ktp at public storage for a year but have been working for the company for about 8 years. The company offers great benefits and the pay is reasonable. The work hours are very accommodating. The district managers work together with the staff and offer a great deal of support. It is a safe environment and the staff works together to provide great customer service. Property managers are able to live onsite in an apartment for a small pay cut. I am very happy to be part of the public storage family.
cons: There is no difference in what a property manager and a relief manager are able to do is basically the same job just different title.

title: Work Life Balance & More
pros: Great company to work for with solid compensation package and incredible work life balance. The companies leadership team is one of the strongest that I've worked for, they are focused on developing employees and helping them achieve their career goals. Job provides many opportunities for time in the field coaching and developing your team and in order to be successful that's your main priority. Additionally, the company does a great job of focusing on and driving the core aspects of its business and doesn't allow outside factors to detract from that goal.
cons: Occasionally admin requirements challenge leaderships ability to spend time in the field coaching and developing team.

title: My Second Home
pros: Being a part of a dynamic company who is the leader in the industry gives me an incentive to want to contribute my best effort and do my share to tackle the chalenges to not only become number one in the industry but to stay number one. Been with the company over 22 years and created friendships that are dear to me which I would not replace for anything else. This is my second home and its leadership inspires me to perform at work the same way I would perform for my own business.
cons: Field employees often change and when turnover occurs and you are dependant on information support, you'll have to find a way to obtain it regardless.

title: Live on Site Property Manager
pros: Didn't have to drive to work Apartments were nice Free Apartment
cons: Scripts made you feel pressured and didn't matter if you rented space without the use of the scripted. Customers will rent cause they need storage. Living on site you were always available since you lived there.

title: Storage Leader
pros: Public Storage is a solid company with a proven track record of stability and plenty of room for growth potential. The one constant at Public Storage is change, we are always willing to change in an effort to get better. This business is all about people and process, find the right person and train them to work the process. A great place to work and further your career.
cons: At times this position can be a bit stressful as people are storing their personal belongings. Don't be surprised by how much a customer loves their belongings.

title: Approachable Stepping Stone
pros: Some of the best reasons to work for Public Storage are the people, the pay, the hours, and the job security. The people that I work with are like family to me, they are very open and honest and caring. I have never worked for a company where management was so approachable. The pay is really good for a person with no college degree. I have worked in call centers for a long time and my hourly rate here is significantly higher that my last job plus you earn commission on reservations and show ups. The earning potential for a driven sales agent is limitless here. The hours...It is a call center that services the whole nation so of course they need to schedule staff for the majority of the day but if you talk to your sales manager about what you need and you are honest with them they will help you. Job security. Storage is a necessity in the USA and it is amazing how many people need it so Public Storage is NOT going anywhere! With that said, the main reason the job feels and IS more secure than other call centers I have worked for is because of management. This is a multi-billion dollar company but working here, with the people, you would never guess that it is so big because my coworkers have become my 2nd family and with communication I know my job will be here for as long as I want to do it.
cons: There really isn't a downside for me. My last job was so stressful for $4 less an hour that being here is better than any job at this skill level I can imagine.

title: This is a job for someone that hasn’t had a job before
pros: They give you a place to stay. You work by yourself majority of the time or with one other person.
cons: Even though they give you a place to stay they only give you 48 hours to move out & the apartment is really just to trap you so that you’ll stay longer. Horrible pay, no raises or very little, they hound you about selling merchandise and locks and insurance, absolutely no advancement unless you’re a district manager .

title: Public Storage is a awesome company to work for
pros: I like to help people in any way i can so working here helps me do that. Most customers are going through a trying time and its nice when I can make it easier for them. The company has a competive pay and hours are great. I can spend time with my children in the mornings before school and evenings when i get off. Working by myself most of the time, I can manage my time to complete task that need to be done throughout the day so I can enjoy customers.
cons: I been here for over 10 yrs and I have no complaints about my position or co-workers

title: Flexing your interpersonal muscles.
pros: The people I meet from all walks of life. People in transition I get to celebrate with customers when they buy new homes or when children are off to college. There are difficult moments as well, I like that we can offer comfort through difficult times . Storing not only our customers goods but also showing compassion through life changes and providing great prices with awesome promotions, clean facilities and exceptional customer service. I love people so this is perfect for me.
cons: For me working weekends is not much ofca problem working in customer service that comes with territory but that would be the one thing that I hear that would make some excited.

title: Relief Property Manger
pros: Working at your own pace, taking control of a lot of difficult situations. Learning a lot of management skills. Customer service has improved a lot more. I also felt I learned a lot more about business management inside the office. being in direct contact with District manager is great.
cons: Only closed on 3 days of the year. No Holiday pay for Labor day, Memorial Day, 4th of July, veterans day, and other similar holidays. Company only cares for their profits. Only growth opportunity is to become a property manger, but they deduct $2 from you pay when you live in the apartment. No pets allowed in the apartment. Dealing with drug addict customers, hobos, and cleaning up after hoarders.

title: World-Class organization
pros: Public Storage exemplifies a well run, growing company; with significant opportunity for growth. Leadership is highly focused on developing people to be the very best. If you want to be rewarded for top performance and further your career, Public Storage is the place to be.
cons: If you don't like to be held accountable, and people development is not your strong suit; this may not be for you.

title: Great job if you like sitting at a desk
pros: You get a great boss who's willing to listen to you and help you out through issues, he's pretty much the only reason that anyone stays there, the work is pretty much the same every month, so no big surprises usually
cons: the work is boring, keeps you at a desk the entire day, bonuses are small, and you'll almost never get a raise

title: Manager
pros: Company has alot of assets and plenty of cash to spend. Its the largest self storage company in the world and one of the largest land holders as well.
cons: The company will work you till you either quit from burn out or will fire you because you either can't keep up with the demands of the job or you don't want to continue with amount of hrs, emails, inter-department BS and overall stress of the position.

title: Stable but little to no advancement opportunities
pros: If you like a stable environment and the ability to clock out at 5pm then this is the place for you. The culture is casual and friendly.
cons: The trade off for job stability is the unclear, if not nonexistent chances for advancement. For everyone but the most senior executives, there is no clear track for career growth. The same can be said for salaries, which are typically below market. For anyone who cares about career advancement, Public Storage is at best a stop-gap employment option.

title: Long-term employee
pros: I've worked at Public Storage for over 30 years. The integrity of the Company as well as the people who work here is outstanding. I've been fortunate to have a job that has been filled with great challenges and opportunities for growth. I've loved the variety and the depth of what I have learned over the years. The employees at Public Storage are hard working, friendly and care deeply about doing the best job possible. There is personal respect at every level and people work well together to accomplish end goals.
cons: Work can be intense at times but that can be very challenging and once the work is completed, there is a great sense of satisfaction.

title: A transforming model Enterprise
pros: Strong and knowledgeable workforce with low turnaround in HQ. Excellent work environment and team Great vision, strategy backed by excellent growth and stability Ever encouraging / empowering strong leadership Personally, love the opportunity I've to build next generation technical architecture to help management make right decisions and drive business in right direction
cons: Not fully paperless yet! Needs technology related restructuring Don't see frequent Company news / Management updates Need to cultivate modern culture of building team/personnel networking

title: For the salary not sure if it's worth it
pros: Some offer onsite apartments, which they will deduct 2/hr from your pay to live. All utilities included. Hours are 9:30-6 weekdays, and 9:30-5 weekends Little supervision
cons: Hourly rate Underpaid for what is expected Micromanaging Company is greedy and can careless for property employees.

title: Good for the young & dumb
pros: The bonus used to be a pro until they took it
cons: You're never an actual manager they are required by law to name a manager for properties but you have no say so with other employees, "your" property, or anything at all. They will work you until you can't take anymore and want to get rid of anyone who asks that they be fair. With the schedule you never have time for anything either.

title: Solid REIT with excellent future potential
pros: Maybe the most solvent REIT in the USA. Prudent company who does not take chances but has grown handsomely over the last few years. Properties located in virtually every major U.S. city so re-location is an option if a work Associate chooses and has proven themselves worthy.
cons: Transition for positions within the company is limited, especially if you are not living in Southern California (corporate headquarters). Business is not glamorous, but profitability is amazing.

title: Solid Fundamentals and Great Culture
pros: Public Storage is an organization built on solid business fundamentals that pays close attention to every aspect of the company. As a result they have fostered a culture that is very supportive and provides ample opportunity for growth. The organization actively encourages employees to challenge the status quo to continue to improve and optimize operations. While not immediately recognizable for its digital excellence, Public Storage is a digital leader in its category. I enjoy coming to work everyday.
cons: While very close to beautiful parks and hiking trails, you must drive for lunch. Parking is also limited.

title: Run away quick
pros: you get to work with some very interesting people and not all of the customers are bad
cons: No pay raises that are worth mentioning after working for the company for 11 years I got a total of $3 in raises. not sure why I stayed in for the exception of loyalty to my one of many many district managers that came through while I was there. Always promising something better anytime you raise concern but nothing ever happens to back it up or confirm it. Company is very concerned with taking over other businesses and being bigger and bigger but they really need to focus on making the stores they own better first.

title: Property manager
pros: Great Hours!!9:30 to 6:00 Mon-Fri,and 9:30 -5:00 Sat-Sun.Paid training,paid vacations and paid sick time. You are supplied training along with training materials.If you enjoy meeting new people as well as providing individuals with storage space, This is the job for you. Daily task involve checking on units, mild cleaning allows you to get your daily exercise in.Pay is Great!! You are recognized for performance daily and if you are having difficulties, the staff along with the upper management are readily available to assist in your job requirements.
cons: I am still waiting to find one!!

title: I love helping people and making them feel comfortable and confident with their storage needs.
pros: Full time work, Great Benefits, 401k plan, nice and friendly staff, very flexible hours, paid mileage. I enjoy the work environment, the staff and Management Team that I work with is amazing. I couldn’t ask to be part of a better team.
cons: The pay is not commensurate with the requirements of the job. Feeling pressured on a daily basis to meet certain sales goals when there is no actual incentive for the regular Property/Relief Managers.

title: I love my job as Assistant Manager at Public Storage
pros: "A good place to work for if you're looking for stability. The company itself is stable and has a lot of capital to keep itself afloat. The pay is Ok but there is a good work-life balance and upper management is great. DM is awesome, cares about team members . Great training program. I learned great professional communication skills and sales techniques. Lots of fun learning new things as an Assistant Manager. Great teamwork, helping each other. Everyone is helpful and friendly. Renting units and cash handling. Paying overtime and mileage.”
cons: If you do not mind sometimes working at different locations and also always on Sundays, then this is your place.

title: great company
pros: potential free apartment if your sales numbers are good. steady reliable income, full time with benefits, relaxed environment with friendly customers, slow paced and great job for people who have ptsd
cons: dont be late, dont call out, dont post pictures of yourself on the internet with your public storage shirt on and you wont get fired, so dont be a bad employee and you dont really have much to worry about, stay off of social media while working and you wont have to worry

title: No future
pros: Expense tolls and $70 of cell phone? I think that's about it, honestly I wish I could type more. But there really is nothing else and glassdoor makes you have to type more than just a sentence.
cons: Micromanagement on every level. They make you use your personal cell phone as your office number and make it public. Anything you need to get done needs so many levels of approval it makes you feel useless. Upper management is not going anywhere and make sure that by only promoting people that they can control.

title: V.P. Operations
pros: The organization is number one in the industry for solid reasons. This is an ambitious, driven and intelligent organization.
cons: As a female there are no opportunities for breaking out of of middle management unless you are HR, legal and/or corporate headquarters staff. Like many organizatiions, it is an issue of popularity not performance that determines success.

title: Public Storage- Great Company to Work For!
pros: Working for a self-storage industry leader that is constantly growing! Great opportunity for advancement within a diverse market, where you can wear several different hats. Great support from your superiors and colleagues! GREAT COMPENSATION!
cons: The unfortunate task of having to sell customers goods at auction due to non-payment. Despite all the checks and balances, and best efforts to collect payments, you find yourself forced to let items go for public sale.

title: Been here 20 yrs
pros: Public Storage supports work/life balance. I have great benefits and don’t work nights. If you get the opportunity to take one of the company apartments, do it! You do get a small decrease in hourly pay but the value of the apartment and utilities far outweighs that. I have been incredibly impressed with the company and their response to the whole Covid 19 craziness. I was just happy to have a job that was not furloughing or laying off but then the company stepped up with childcare/elder care assistance for those who might need it as well as bonus pay. They also went a step further and compiled a list of resources that were available through other sources for parents who suddenly found themselves homeschooling. It wasn’t any thing that cost them money per se but I thought it was nice that they had someone take the time to put all the information in one place just to make life a little easier and less daunting right now.
cons: The cons would be the same as any job where you deal with the public in a customer service capacity. Sometimes tenants want things you can’t do and somehow they blame you. The only con as far as what the company could actually change is there is no way to grow with the company past a certain point. Once you are a full property manager/key training professional, there is no where left to advance. All district managers and above are hired from outside the company

title: Will always be grateful to Public Storage
pros: Inclusive hiring Company Apartments - (although these are limited) --with paid utilities! I needed somewhere to literally start my life over and Public Storage gave me that opportunity. I worked for them for about nine years. Great District Managers and Supervisors (almost all of them, anyway)... Pay should be higher--but they would allow overtime in most cases, when you needed it. A lot of times, they needed it, too!
cons: This job is physically demanding--that is, IF you are actually doing your job! Some days I would go home absolutely filthy, dirty--but that was the job! If you are not willing to run/manage the store as well as clean a bunch of very dirty units in the heat or cold--please don't try to work there! Get a job at a bookstore or something. This job is a challenge--if you are actually doing the job. When I was there, some employees were not and the hard-workers had to 'carry' them--which is not cool! Facilities were not maintained well after some years. The company got so large that they took the actual 'management' duties and authority away from the Property Managers--and even District Managers! Things ran a lot smoother when we were given a maintenance budget to stay within and would be trusted to prioritize and keep things in good repair. This also created excellent relationships with vendors (who would do extras for us--just for being loyal to them). Keeping things maintained is MUCH cheaper than having to make huge repairs due to negligence. For the higher managers/supervisors, they company actually incentivized NOT spending money on maintenance and needed repairs! So a lot of times, things just did not get fixed or maintained. After some years, the only person who could actually approve over $100-$200 in repairs knew absolutely nothing about the property or what it needed. This greatly affected customer relations and employee morale. A lot of the needed information about the repair got lost in the translation--which would end up in a wasted vendor trip, etc. ($$). Many repairs did not get done and money was wasted from miscommunication (putting everything into a corporate billing system for someone else to approve--someone who had maybe never even set foot on that property!) This is typical of a lot companies that become very large, though. I call this 'growing pains' and I think a lot of large corporations go through this. This is a great job for those who like to WORK and do their jobs!! If you don't like to 'hustle'...this is not the place for you! The pay could be much better, but the overtime opportunities made it doable.

title: It was always stressful, but I was still loyal to them
pros: Working with 98% of the customers were great they are the reason I stayed there to be a positive for the customers
cons: Public Storage cares nothing about the employees or the customers, it's about the all mighty dollar, very poor leadership the DM's not (not all) but most don't want you to bother them at all benefits steadily decreased over the years instead of increasing. Time off was given out not by seniority but by favoritism new people were coming in getting time off when the vet time was due to expire.

title: terrible company
pros: all pros to this job have changed and no longer exist
cons: NO chance for advancement , horrible pay, 10+ scripts to memorize by heart, whole days spent on phone calling same customers over and over. dishonest policies like trying to force locks and insurance on everyone, dishonest policies regarding google reviews - trying to make customers do a review right in ofice-BEFORE they even finished renting. and being coached to not get a review if you think it will be bad, just shady all around. AND, notice almost all postive reviews are from managers & not store level employees?

title: ALL ABOUT SALES
pros: I loved the job cause I could read and write at my leisure when I didn't have any customers and all my work was done. Its a very secure job if u just make sure u do whats expected of u. Nothing more nothing less. If u sell merchandise you'll have a much easier time there.
cons: All they care about is their sales. Even if you're on time every single day, build a rapport with customers and manage the property the best it can be managed, they will get rid of u if your numbers arent where they want them.

title: District Manager
pros: Decent work/life balance compared to retail jobs. District Managers and above own company stock, which continues to gain value.
cons: Appearance and perception are more valuable than productivity, meaning as long as you appear to be engaged and productive you are considered to be doing well. While there are many very intelligent executives with this company, there are also many "pretend" managers who don't have a clue how to manage anyone.

title: Public storage wasn’t for me!
pros: Easy to get hired on
cons: Company doesn’t care about the employees, you almost die cleaning out those hot units in this Texas summer, no raises or bonus, you get secret shoppers to see if your saying this terrible script to each new customer that checks out a unit, it’s heartbreaking to see people in awful situations lose their whole life at a auction, they will hire just about anyone and don’t do anything about the bad employees that should be let go,

title: Great Company To Work For!
pros: The hours are great, great benefits, You can work at your own pace, laid back environment, you can live on the property, no one micromanages your work, District managers are very supportive and genuinely want to see you succeed, your hard work gets recognition
cons: I would like to have more administrative work, there is no difference between a relief manager and a property manager, not a lot of room for growth because they hire DM’s from outside the company.

title: Growing Company that doesn’t invest in their people or their customers.
pros: +Stock Options +Ability to schedule personal appts during the day +Job security as they are growing and are an essential business. +Enjoyed my direct report and the relationship that we had.
cons: -No work/life balance -There’s a difference between being frugal and cheap. As long as occupancy is there they don’t care about the customers or the employees. -lack of investment in their employees. There have been no upper management promotions in Public Storage in the last four years. -Horrible culture. I had one senior leader tell me it’s a great thing if an employee can stay for two years. -They won’t fix maintenance issues on properties if it’s not affecting occupancy. -They are very reactive in their decision making and not proactive. This comes down to being financially cheap and ultimately not investing in their people. Turnover is horrendous!

title: Don't trust anyone.. they don't care about you.
pros: Some but not many good coworkers.. Most of the time customers were great. If you make it a thing for sure 2 days off a week . All right benefits.
cons: The whole company.. Regional managers senior district managers and district managers don't really care like they say... watch out for established property managers they will back stab you and not even bat an eye. And for some reason your superiors meddle into your personal when it's unnecessary and unprofessional AND unasked for.

title: Long Hours, Overworked, Low Pay, No Respect
pros: If you are a property manager, you get to spend time in the office alone for the most part. This should be an asset for someone who is more or less an introvert.
cons: Much too much work to do in the office and outside on the property. Policies are always changing and more and more work (paper work and physical work) is demanded. It's hard to get time off even when you have accrued vacation time because people are always quitting making it necessary for schedules to change. Not unusual to work 7-10 days in a row before getting a day off and the management schedules time so that time off pay is minimal despite hours put in.

title: My experience at Public Storage
pros: The hours that you work are morning and daytime hours. So you have a good work/life balance if you have things to get taken care of after 6pm.
cons: Some challenges i encountered were , when i was hired i was told that there was room for advancement, but there really was not. A Relief Manager and Property Manager makes the same thing and neither position can never ascend to District Manager. Also in my city employees are paid less than other storage facilities that are smaller in company size.

title: Everyday is different, exicitng and rewarding. Love it. If you are passionate about what you do, this place is for you
pros: The hours are great, you create your monthly schedule, who you will work with and who is on your team. Team work is very fluid, no district boundaries. Team I work with is awesome, fun to work with and great environment. "I LOVE LA"
cons: Work is constant, ability to multi-task and understand ABC priorities is a must. Never a dull moment. Customer concerns and calls come in any time of the day.

title: Public Storage Review
pros: Public Storage is a wonderful company to work for. I have been with Public Storage for 13 years and am thankful to be with a stable company that values it's employees and their contributions. There are so many people that have been with the company 20+ years, that is a great compliment to the company.
cons: You get what you put in to the company and your job. Compensation and benefits could be better, but I do feel they are competitive with other companies and definitely not a con.

title: It is all about the company and not about the people who make the company work.
pros: It is a great place to learn the business. The front line people are amazing to work with during the hard customer days.
cons: No advancement in the field above property manager. Anyone above a District Manager becomes a company robot. While they say the right things they often forget compassion when talking with other associates.

title: Company has the ability to increase salaries of employees.
pros: Supportive to employees, great training process and easy to access, great insurances, housing program
cons: Once hired its very difficult to advance with the company, they out source for regional managers instead of hiring property managers employed well over many years with the company, the company is known for making new positions without pay out increase of pay, Very demanding for the salary ranges the property manager and assistant property manager. Managers should be paid nearly as much commercial managers giving PM are managing over an average of 150 plus units.

title: Okay job
pros: Easy job. Mostly office work. Great boss. Phone work. This job is pretty laid back for the most part. Nothing too terribly hard that we have to do.
cons: There is a lot of scripts we have to memorize and use and our jobs are threatened if we don't follow them. We have to dispose of abandoned goods. The pay is not any good.

title: A Great Company
pros: The company has a proven formula for success. By following the processes, having the right behaviors, you will get results. We are a company that embraces coaching, and our primary goal is to develop talent at all levels in the organization.
cons: This is a company with extremely high expectations. We strive for perfection in a fast paced environment. As a result, having a good work / life balance in field management is tough unless you are proactive, efficient, and organized.

title: District Manager Review
pros: Meritocracy - very impressive bonus structure based solely on your metrics and how well you lead your district. Autonomy - As a leader, i can motivate, hire, terminate and manage my team that best way i see fit within the boundaries of our region's structure and guidance. Flexible work schedule - i start my day early in the morning because i am an early riser but i have the flexibility to work remotely in the morning before going out to the properties. Candid/Honest Conversation with supervisors Advancement - all upper management roles are all internal hires
cons: Hourly employees sometimes have high turnover in areas with low unemployment %

title: Poor customer service & Price gouging
pros: So far have had no damage to my property although there is no heat
cons: They raise their rates every 6 mths to a year and swear they told you that when you signed on. When I told them that was untrue. The response was, well it's in your contract. I have had my unit since 2/28/2015. It started out at 69.99. It went up to 94.00 09/2017. That's outrageous! It you don't have your own lock, they charge you an outrageous amount to purchase their lock There is no heat in the unit, which is in a Midwestern State. Actual location staff rarely answers the phone or return phone calls.

title: Supervisors Work for Bonuses
pros: Some properties don't install cameras behind the desk so you can watch Netflix while waiting for the next customer to come yell at you.
cons: Required sales pitches for insurance, merchandise. Insurance is an absolute scam and you are a punching bag for customer anger. Property managers will clean both human and animal feces on a near daily basis. Supervisors are spread thin dishing out punishment for not meeting sales quotas, are typically unable to provide you support. Most offices have cameras so you will be on camera almost all the time. Rarely are there functioning cameras on property, so break-ins are difficult to explain to customers.

title: Great company, great opportunities
pros: Never before have I worked for a company that places such a high value in fostering a positive work/life balance. Teamwork plays a big part in the success of this company. It's nice to know that when you need a little help, your peers will always be there to assist you. There are endless opportunities for advancement. I have been with Public Storage for five years. During that time I have worked hard and have been promoted twice. Hard work and dedication are valued and rewarded.
cons: You have to possess strong time management skills to keep up with the work-load and fast pace of this industry. Flexibility and adaptability are essential in this company.

title: Great place to work!
pros: Well managed company that has consistently been successful over the years. One reason for this is that management generally treats its employees very, very well. Working here does not really, that I know of, present any annoyances that are not present within almost every organization.
cons: Nothing alarming to bring up; but it would likely be beneficial to corporate employees to spend a couple of days per year (or even every other year) to learn more about, and be reminded of, how the stores operate and to establish more effective communication between the corporate office and the field.

title: Missed Opportunities
pros: Strong, generally well run company. Fairly safe business during economic downturns. Little debt. Has some of the smartest real estate and business minds in the industry.
cons: Very little communication or respect for employees. Company doesn't get the full advantage of what employees are capable of giving. No partnership. Little respect. Rank and file have no idea of what's going on and consequently have little motivation to perform.

title: Don't work here.
pros: None that I can think of. They actually have some good and decent people working for them, but they are trapped in the horrible Public Storage culture.
cons: Lousy pay compared to the competition. Benefits are a joke. Management tells us to lie to our customers and in the same sentence tell us if confronted they will deny it. Some of their business practices are unethical and probably border on illegal. They cut corners which at times compromises our safety. I find it hard to believe that upper management is not aware of these and many other issues.

title: We don't store like its ours.
pros: It is a somewhat "laid back" job depending on what locations you are sent to. There are set hours to work, you know what time you come in and what time you go home. No late night or early morning shifts.
cons: You are left alone at busy locations. You are required to memorize over 20 scripts. District managers are hardly ever useful, so as a Relief manager you must problem solve to your best ability. Transients and "riff raff" who are unhinged, it is a scary job when alone.

title: Best company I have ever worked for
pros: In my experience at PS - the financial payouts are fantastic but that's based on a forced ranking. This allows competitive, solid performers to make very high incomes, average performers to make competitive incomes and poor performers find themselves with lower incomes. The compensation plan we use is the fairest I have ever experienced as an employee and personally - I love it. I have always been impressed how seriously PS takes the hiring process. We're very particular about who we hire; we are looking for future leaders and the potential for upward mobility is fantastic for employees that understand how to build high performance teams. A core expectation within the company is to develop people, create a positive working environment and to treat others with respect. I will never forget hearing my former Divisional Vice President talking to another DM while I was a DM trainee about the fundamental importance of building people up and not cutting them down when coaching their performance or behaviors. That always stuck with me and I just knew at that moment that I would love this company. 4 years later ....
cons: Working some Saturdays and Sundays during our busy season. If a person isn't willing to work 1 Saturday and Sunday a month during our peak busy season - they're not a good fit for our company. We are a very structured company. After years of trial and error - the company has determined a key set of behaviors that work for our business and it's the expectation that everyone in the company embraces that structure. I was always a very entrepreneurial leader in past careers and that approach does not work here; knowing that going into the position made it very easy for me to accept and to embrace that culture. We take leadership seriously. If a person isn't good at hiring or developing people - they're probably not a good fit. If a person isn't serious about managing their business and creating an environment where employees can flourish - they're probably not going to be a good fit.

title: Great Company!
pros: • Brilliant Leadership Team •
cons: istent execution of strategy • Opportunity for advancement • All levels of management are committed to people development • Financially stable company • Great work-life balance • Structured environment and support system (with the perfect level of autonomy) • Integrity is a precept

title: Senior Management Needs Help
pros: The work life balance is great; weekends off, holidays off. The people in your market are always willing to help each other. Benefits are decent.
cons: The pay is not favorable at any level in the company. Hourly employees and salary employees make little money in comparison to similar jobs within the area. Pay is the same rather you live in the east, west, north, south. (no consideration for the cost of living) The company pays newer district managers more than the current, tenured district managers. Promotions- yes they happen offen, but little to no increase in pay for promotions. Turnover is high for senior level positions; higher turnover the further up the chain one goes. There is very little autonomy to “think like an owner”. The President makes all decisions with minimal if any feedback from the field. A regional manager can’t even hire a district manager, the senior level executives are the one to approve all hires. The senior HR team is more involved in day to day operations instead of building relationships like a normal HR person would be in other company’s. HR hasn’t been the same since recent retirements.

title: Just not enough...
pros: Job is straight forward for the most part, all repetition with the occasional new issue you may encounter. Flexible. Ability to meet new people from all walks of life. You can live on site at facility apartment.
cons: Low pay for property management, they have "increased" a couple times but does not meet the value of tenured employees. Not a livable wage. In tight situations where there is limited staff they will have you run around like a chicken with its head cut off to different properties. So you are managing your store and others... with same pay. Make it make sense!

title: Over Worked
pros: This is a good company to learn storage business from the bottom up. I have been with the company for 2 years.
cons: PM & RM's do all the property work, make all the money for the company and see none of the rewards. The DM's and higher up's who motivate are the one's who get the money and the trips. And poor benefits! Only PTO days and 3 paid holidays a year, no paid vacation time. I'm over the Google!

title: Relief manager
pros: A minimum wage check, comfortable shoes, free water (if you're lucky), lots of free time, fun co workers and tenants (if you're lucky).
cons: There are far too many to list. Just know that this entire company is rotted from the core. They want to portray a great place to the public and ignorant consumers. Trust me, they couldn't care less about you as a customer or an employee at any level. Sad sad place to be.

title: Property manager
pros: Full time work, develop relationships with customers, benefits are ok, personal time and vacation time are accrued.
cons: Everything is scripted, no room for advancement as this company hires Districe management and above outside the company, pressure to sell, pay is deplorable (9.00 hr), even when promoted to property manager, no extra money, VERY hard to satisfy customers when rates are raised every 6 months, and cant get lighting, gate or door repairs made. Buffalo NY market is the WORST, most properties in this area are falling apart!

title: Public Storage Culture
pros: Basic job, with some downtime so you can study or? Lots of walking makes it easy to hit 10,000 steps daily.
cons: Only 2 paid holidays a year, you have to work weekends no flexibility in shifts. Pay is low, with little or no room for advancement. They offer an apartment to live on site with a huge pay cut which is insulting, that they justify by comparing rents in the neighborhood..as if! The health insurance is basically paying out of pocket for the first $3000 or more..

title: Great company
pros: Some independence in the role. Great fellow Co workers to work with. Challenges you. Great to watch your hard work pay off and pay you with the bonus program. Great benefits and stock. I miss the companys transparency.
cons: Can be a hybrid role but there is a lot of travel to sites. Call off almost every day leave DMs constantly on call 7 days a week. Visits can be intimidating to staff employees. Some offices have been updated but a lot still need updated.

title: We all deserve a well balanced work week and fair reimbursement
pros: The salary and bonus are decent
cons: DM's DO NOT get a day off. 365 divided by annual salary sometimes makes the job too much of a headache

title: Little growth opportunity, insulting annual raises, crap bonus and cheap district managers
pros: I genuinely like the work, but am only surviving because I own my home. The compensation (compared to the high level of performance they require and continued mental abuse received from supervisors) is insulting. Pride prevents me from delivering anything less than my best, and that must be what they're counting on. I enjoy dealing with my customers, although corporate continues to lose long term patrons because of regular rent increases (with no ceiling) and skimpy property maintenance. It's all about shareholder profits and executive bonuses, apparently. They couldn't care less about the customers (or employees). We at one time had bonuses for keeping property above goals. Now they have made it that only 40% or less employees can qualify to receive any incentives, plus our PTO is designed to stay at under 40 hours.
cons: My experience is that DM's are spread too thinly between multiple locations and can't handle the work load. It's been far too long since they ran their own facility, if they ever did, and all they see now are numbers and how to line their own purses. Mine has extremely poor people handling skills, and will quickly throw a devoted employee under the bus to make them look good and fulfill their own self-serving agenda. They show very little respect, and belittle and talk down to employees regularly. They rarely praise you for a job well done, but regularly offer harsh criticisms based on ever changing 'policies' and mistrust through scathing emails, unrealistic audits, secret shoppers, spy cams, and recorded phone calls.

title: Winning Team
pros: PS is fortunate to have brilliant leadership. That leadership has fostered responsible growth, a robust bottom line and a promising future. Like any venture, one gets from the company what one puts in. Hard work is expected and rewarded. There are some opportunities to fill needs and create your own, unique contributions to the company and that can be very rewarding.
cons: As with any large company, things can change quickly so one must be flexible and adaptive. That's not a negative unless your personality requires absolute structure.

title: Caution!!!!!!
pros: Close to freeway if you have to commute
cons: I noticed a lot of positive reviews but it is for the call center not IT. Regarding IT the CTO is new and trigger happy to fire. All Business Analysts, QA people are new and express their concern regarding job loss due to unrealistic deadline. It is not a healthy environment to work in. They do not have license for common programs and expect that you purchase your own. This included self support for MAC users which includes installation of network computers and internet. It continues to the treatment of employees such as not providing forks, knives or cup for drinking in breakrooms which is common in all other companies I've worked for. This shows a lack of concern or care for their employees.

title: What's with all the scripts??
pros: 9 to 6 during the week. 9 to 5 on the weekend.
cons: Everything else. Management that doesn't care nor implement employee suggestions. Poorly trained district managers. 18 scripts to learn which do not help in generating sales or getting customers to pay their bill on time. Expected to clean units, show units, mop the hallways, chase vagrants off the property, sell extremely over priced merchandise. (When a person can get cheaper boxes at Home Depot you know something's wrong) Call delinquent customers and try to convince them to pay their bill, book reservations, be a handyman, don't take sick days, And lastly because I know I forgot some things also get the customer to sign the lease. All for 9 bucks an hour with no commission.

title: Key Traing Professional
pros: Hours are great! District manager is a pleasure to work with. A nice mix of inside and outside work.
cons: The pay! For what is expected of you, the pay is laughable. This is not so much of an opinion as it is a fact. The bonus program in place is not exciting. There is no advancement opportunity. The job is stagnant.

title: unprofessional/poor pay/depressing
pros: Colleagues. this company has a lot of great people and they all look out for each other. You do get the CEO and COO box seats tickets
cons: poor pay for a lot of work. It ranges from a 11hr to 12hr work day, 45 min lunch break nothing more or nothing less. Upper management is awful, i remember on my 1st day i say a 12 year manager get yelled at and cried . She cried so much she had to take sometime to start my training. NO RAISES IN OVER 5 YEARS FOR MOST EMPLOYEES.......NONE

title: Not a bad place to be... as a District Manager and above
pros: +compensation relative to similar roles (RSU grants) +worklife balance +upper management +financial health of company +paid hourly employees $3/hr more for 2 months during the pandemic; no layoffs +#1 in their industry
cons: -low pay for hourly employees makes it hard to attract and sustain retention at this level (the company is happy to keep someone for a year and then is prepared to look for a replacement) -limited ability for hourly employees to advance their career -mileage reimbursement only after miles it takes to get to District mid-point -micromanagement -the company is BEYOND frugal: only reimburse $35 for District a meeting for 20 employees, they literally count paper and expect answers and plans for higher usage, do not perform regular maintenance and instead wait for things to break -DM's have to spend out of their pocket to engage team (company won't reimburse for work lunches or contests) -any spend over $100 needs layers of approvals -DM can make limited decisions in an individual capacity -say they are customer oriented but are not with high rent increases and an unwillingness to decrease unless it escalates to past the RVP -DM's can't even credit $0.01 on a customer's ledger if the system doesn't approve it (everything is routed to another layer of approval) -no employee discounts on a storage unit or merchandise -company is growing however opportunities beyond DM level are not

title: Very successful company that provides stability for a long term career.
pros: There is an open line of communication between management and employees. This is a stable organization that will provide you with long-term career stability. The compensation plan is very competitive within the retail industry. The management team operates with a high level of integrity and personal accountability. They value family time and a good work life balance.
cons: In order to maintain the competitive edge and company growth, hard work is required. Some may view this as taking away from personal life. If you struggle with time mgmt., and/or personal accountability, then this may not be the company for you. The company hires only "A" players

title: Was great at first but this company needs improvement
pros: It's guaranteed full time hours. If you like to work alone this is the job for you. You pretty much run the store.
cons: In the summer you have to deal with wasp, bees, and spiders. You have to work overtime to get a decent pay check. You cannot move up in the company being a relief or property manager. You only get one 50 cent raise after your first 6 months.

title: Decent job, definitely not worth the pay though.
pros: Independent work environment, you get to manage your own property. Well at least for a day or two if you are a relief manager.
cons: No room to grow, they do not promote from within. The pay is not worth it. They expect you to hit certain goals and numbers but do not reward you for it. Even if you do a lot better than the person that doesn't use still get paid the exact same and only get verbal recognition.

title: Not bad if you understand the corporate model
pros: Hours are great, and my District Managers have been very flexible for vacations/time-off, etc. Depending on your locale, the bonus structure is pretty good. Apartments are decent, and the total compensation package is acceptable if you have another earner in the family. For the most part, it's a low-stress job, with the occasional flare-up of craziness here and there. I get along great here with my bosses and they make me feel like I'm doing a good job. It does not necessarily result in higher pay, but it's nice to be told that you're appreciated, too.
cons: Once you understand the corporate model, it's not so bad. You have to understand that the top level of the corporate chain makes the most money. The bottom, well, doesn't. And yes, they are also very out of touch with our everyday tasks and customer interactions. As most of the other reviews state, once you hit the top PM position, there is little if no chance for promotion. Goals are based on things that are out of the managers' control, such as customer behavior, payment history, etc. It's not a job I will be keeping for much longer, but I have been here a few years and I can honestly say that it is the easiest job I've ever had. That being said, the laziness and lack of drive of fellow managers make it difficult to feel like you're better than they are. I would like to move up in this company and ultimately the lack of advancement is what will cause me to leave. DMs have the closest relationship with property staff, but have so very little flexibility in rewarding them.

title: Teamwork Environment
pros: I have had a great experience working at the Corporate offices for Public Storage. It's a good stable company to work for, with awesome benefits and a great work environment. I feel truly appreciated by all of my colleagues and I enjoy being part of a teamwork atmosphere.
cons: The only con I could think of is the location of the Corporate offices. Due to the location, I deal with a tough commute everyday. Depending on where in LA you live, you might deal with some traffic. For me it's worth it even though.

title: Long Term Happy Employee
pros: Financially stable company run extremely well by CEO & Chairman Ron Havner and CFO John Reyes. I've been with the company over 20 years and never had to worry about whether the company could weather economic storms. The company has done well when the economy is up as well as when it's down. And besides the stability of the company, the people are what keep me here. Just an amazing group of bright talented people who make it enjoyable to come to work every day. I can't imagine working anywhere else.
cons: Health care costs keep going up but they are everywhere else.

title: If youre optimistic, it can help you grow
pros: the pay isn't horrible. But at times the demand of the job makes you wish you got more. If you're a people person...your customers will make your day. If youre competitive...its the job for you.
cons: the scripts are ridiculous, people really dont talk that way. "raises" are a joke little to no advancement upper management can make this job heaven or hell. Alot of paperwork

title: Don't Trust the 5 Star Reviews
pros: None (read the employee reviews)
cons: If you you look at the source of the 4 & 5 star reviews, almost all coming from an employee in the corporate office in Glendale, CA. Some bright-minded VP saw how the negative reviews were affecting recruiting, and is clearly trying to increase the average review score by posting a bunch of false-positive reviews. They aren't even competent enough to hide it ("10 years with the company"). Any company desperate enough to try and counter well-known and well-documented "churn and burn" employment practices by posting false-positive reviews is not a company worthy of your talents. Trust the negative reviews. They are your salvation.

title: Property Manager
pros: Love the 9:30am-6:00pm hours and the accumulated paid vacation. Also full benefits.
cons: Company puts its budget over the safety of its employees. You are expected to aggressively sell product. You are put at property's alone, that are too much for for one person to handle and are left alone to fail. You must be a collections agent. Customer are angry and aggressive and take it out on you.

title: All Things are Possible
pros: There is so many pros about working for such a great company. Since day one I was greeted by all management with a smile and open arms to feel at home while I am at work. The atmosphere is positive and encouraging. There is room for internal advancement and growth. I began as a sales agent and now I am a Call Center Supervisor. Public Storage is my second family, and its an honor to work with so many great people.
cons: There is no cons to be said.

title: Public Storage is a great place to work!
pros: I work at the Public Storage call center and it is one of the best places I have ever worked for. The culture here is very positive and empowering. Working here I found a good mix of liking the work that I do as well as the people that I work with. This is an environment promoting opportunity, growth and recognition.
cons: No more shift bids. Even though agents can still submit requests to have their shifts changed (which are granted often) and performance is weighed into that equation, I found shift bids very motivational, gratifying and fun.

title: Don't bother
pros: None there absolutely nothing good about this company
cons: They are the worse paying company in the business . All profits and bonus is given to the district managers and above. They have no morals about this only greed. They use their employees and have no respect for them. The upper management is overpaid scum that run the company like underworld thugs that laugh at the "replaceable employees." The employee overturn is so bad that at three years I was considered the old man in my district and I had seen four district managers. The last best DM I had left because he couldn't stand the moral dilemma that he was placed in. Then Add a glass ceiling and you have zero morale.

title: Empowerment and Career Growth
pros: I started with Public Storage three years ago, and with no previous knowledge about storage or property management. I was welcomed, trained, and supported by a wonderful team who provided me with the resources, tools, dedicated time, and freedom to grow quickly and achieve three promotions within Property Field Management and now my FOURTH PROMOTION into Corporate! Public Storage provides more than job, it's a solid career filled with opportunity!
cons: The scope of work duties/tasks cover many separate areas which require a variety of different skill sets; but the tools and resources are available to help you adopt and develop those skills.

title: I love my job but benefits are terrible
pros: If your a full time on site manager you get a apartment and utilities are paid. You run the property by your self, the boss is only there a couple times a month, so you don't have someone looking over your shoulders all the time. You can work at your own pace. We can make a quarterly bonus, based on performance from the previous year, you have to do better. But they take all properties in the district and average them together, I don't think that is right. I believe each property should get a bonus based on their performance.
cons: The pay, since they consider the apartment and utilities part of your salary, they don't give raises very often. and when they do it's only a few cents. I haven't had a raise in 4 years. They don't promote property manager to District Managers. So there's no job advancement.

title: Apply with a goal in mind. Get it and get out.
pros: The training is remarkable. The thought and money put into the training video/program production really successfully simplifies the otherwise complex and stressful job requirements into something palatable and doable. There are things that the training doesn't necessarily cover, certainly, but a website has been produced to answer every question a manager could ask and prepares you for anything that could possibly go wrong. Public storage values the self motivated, the level headed, and the socially creative. You will do well if you can shake off problems and focus on the solution. There are many ways that one can take on more responsibility for increased pay if you are willing to work hard. Signing up to be a trainer or patiently waiting for an "A" property manager position to open up are two. Competitive personalities will find a home here as your performance is ranked among your peers and bragging rights abound. The hiring process is rigorous and their expectations for your resume are set on a high bar, but there are also a multitude of reasons to push through and stay optimistic through the phone interviews. There are so many things to learn on job because there is so much responsibility placed on your shoulders behind the orange desk. Far from being a downside, this is an exciting opportunity. You will be expected to open and close. Make delinquent/welcoming calls and prove consistent performance in sales. The job of property/relief manager is a strange mix of janitorial, security, and receptionist. Whenever you are ready to move on to bigger and better things, you will be well equipped for almost any change in career or promotion that you set your sights on.
cons: The key phrase is "move on". Someday, you will want to and you should not be afraid to give into this urge. The opportunity to learn new things and see yourself ranked in performance among your peers is indeed an exciting one, but don't expect to be well compensated for your efforts. You will be expected to maintain sales quota despite bonus AND commission both having been removed in the last five years, and this year there was no raise at all. Meanwhile, more opportunities for PTO/sick leave were given....In short, Public storage offers more incentives to be absent, than to do the job you are scheduled for. Public storage is obviously not willing to pay a competitive rate for Relief/Property managers OR a sales teammember. Public storage does not allow advancement within the company. They will claim that one only qualifies for the District Manager position if they have District Manager experience--which sounds fair on the surface...the truth is that even if a Property Manager has work or education experience that matches the higher position, they will only be eligible if they first quit and reapply without guarantee that they will have employment at all once they do. Talk about a locked and bolted glass door. Public storage has a lot of issues, the first of which being that property managers within the company make on average $24,000 a year despite the fact that median annual Property Manager salary in USA is $91,114, as of June 28, 2017. This compared to the salary of the most immediate level up--that of district manager---who makes six figures plus bonus. It's a huge gap that represents a serious problem in the company. A problem that keeps the face of the company poor.

title: Property Manager
pros: Not a difficult job, you’re mainly taking care of customers, payments and doing rentals. Most days are slow, depending on location so you get a lot of down time. Pretty laid back and you can work at your own pace
cons: Management pushes selling merchandise, insurance, and locks but you don’t get commission from it. There’s no room for growth and this is highest level you can get promoted to. It pays the exact same as a relief manager , yet you have more responsibilities.

title: Working for Public Storage
pros: Working 9:30am-6pm during the week and 9:30am-5pm on the weekend ensures that you have the time to maintain your life outside of work! If you are worried about benefits there is no need working for this company, whether it be Life insurance, 401k, Health insurance, you name it PS offers it. Amongst that there are also many discounts offered as well, if you'd like to save a little on your cell phone bill, get a great discount on car insurance or get fit and join the gym you can find a savings with PS. Besides the great Benefits working with PS you will get to work with great people, either your finding your new best friend in a co-worker or your making lasting relationships with customer because of the exceptional customer service that we provide, no matter what your people skills will improve.
cons: I know that every place of employment tends to have its CONS but in my time with the company I can most definitely say that there is nothing negative to say. Okay we have a few situations that we normally would rather avoid but as long as we continue to provide our customers with TOP OF THE LINE SERVICE there isn't any situation that cant be resolved!

title: Forward Thinking Company with Room for Growth
pros: Public Storage is an amazing company to work for with a solid team to back it. Coming from a retail background, it is so refreshing to work for a company that has a forward thinking perspective on growth and development and makes this happen in a positive culture. From the ground up, Public Storage invests in their employees' continued success and development and it shows! There is a reason Public Storage is number one in the industry and a big part of that is because they empower their team to be business owners. One of my favorite things about the District Manager role is the amount of autonomy I have to run my market and make decisions that I can see directly impact the business. Additionally, you will get to work with an awesome support system through your peers and managers who take a vested interest in your success as well. Outside of job functions, the compensation is very competitive with a comprehensive performance based bonus structure where bonus related goals are clearly outlined and attainable. Additionally, the potential for annual stock awards make Public Storage a very favorable place to financially grow. Public Storage is truly a place where you can create your own success. Highly recommended to anyone who is motivated to make a positive impact with a world class team. Oh, and I have to say the nights and weekends off are definitely a win too!
