cons: Not a lot of cons. Due to the nature of the industry, there can be some challenging situations with customers, but Public Storage does a great job of providing Property Managers and District Managers with the tools needed to resolve these issues.

title: Be careful
pros: Regular hours, Good pay, Health benefits, & PTO
cons: Management Doesn’t promote ethical sales Terrible for customers

title: Dangerous working conditions
pros: If you ever want to be a telemarketer, you'll get the skills here.
cons: There are many reasons to stay away.#1.Not enough money to pay for even a modest living. #2.Dangerous working conditions. You work alone and when evening falls ,you have to walk perfect strangers down dark aisleways to look at units. #3. Nothing gets fixed in a timely manner. Golf carts are inoperable for months even years. #4.Your Bonus is based on ridiculous, unreachable numbers, that change whenever you start getting close to meeting them. #5. Every year the benefits are worse than the year before. #6. My last yearly raise was. 21 cents. I could say a lot more but, I hope I painted you a pretty clear picture.

title: Trash Company with Trash Politics
pros: - The down time. That's about it.
cons: - The DM's and up show fake concern for property issues (but to be fair, they look overworked too) - Unrealistic expectations. People will make reservations and never answer the phone to set appointments, but apparently that's your fault. - No more bonuses, expensive coverage, crappy pay with way too many responsibilities. - No room for growth. You have to quit and re-apply. - Blatant racist treatment by upper management. - So much more...

title: Good Starter Job
pros: This position is good for someone who wants a job that isn't fast food or retail. This job has a lot of downtime where you can read a book or play around on your phone. There are benefits like PTO and health insurance. The job is pretty easy and gives you office experience. It looks good on your resume to put that you have experience managing a store, managing accounts, performing rental contracts, maintaining an organized filing system, making collection calls and reservation calls. The biggest perk about the job is, if you are lucky and/or work there long enough, you can get an apartment through them. You don't have to pay rent or utilities, just internet and cable. There are usually only a few in each district, so usually someone has to quit for one to become available, and then it goes by seniority on who gets it next.
cons: There really is no room for growth. From a relief manager, you can move into a property manager role which is the same thing except you work at the same location 5 days a week instead of different locations. They are paid the same and are both thought of as 'managers' of the store. You can move into a trainer position where you make an extra $1.50/hr, and that's it. You will not be promoted in a district manager role, no matter how long you work there. There is no pathway for upward mobility. It really speaks a lot about a company that they would rather take someone new and train them all about the company rather than take someone who has been working there for years and train them on being a district manager. The pay is a joke. Honestly, they want you to perform a bunch of different roles (front desk, janitor, security guard, collections agent) and you get paid about $1 over min wage. If you are lucky enough to get an apartment, it is then really hard to move out. You start to rely on not having to pay rent, and even with the money you save every month, it is still barely enough to live on so it is hard to save up enough money to be able to quit and move out. I know of a lot of people who hated working at PS but weren't able to move out due to the cost of rent and the money they were currently making. Customer service- pretty much enough said. You deal with a lot of difficult people in this position. From making collection calls, to handling people going into auction who are about to lose their stuff, to dealing with homeless people who are illegally sleeping in their unit and having to evict them. You will be cursed out, maybe even threatened (I was). PS also has a no hold policy where even if you make a reservation, you are really only making an appointment, not actually holding the space. We rent on a "first come first serve" basis, and I can tell you it really upsets people off when you tell them that they have no guarantee that they will have a space next week when they drive half way across the country.

title: Public Storage Does Not Appreciate Their Employees
pros: On site Living for a hr wage cut . 8.50$ for an apt
cons: Public Storage pays very Low wages with no opportunity for advancement within the company . Property managers are basically janitors who deal with front line issues with very little guidance from supervisors. There is favoritism in the company , on all levels . District managers are paid very well for very little work. District managers work is typically delegated to Property managers . For such a huge company , the properties are poor up kept. Corporate is very cheap and expect property managers to do majority of maintenance work. They offer apts that is a tool of entrapment . They pay 8.50 to live in their low maintenance apartments. Unless you’re desperate, I would not suggest working for this company.

title: Take another job
pros: None! I honestly can’t think of except the pay check doesn’t bounce
cons: You will clean human feces and work for management that has never done or understands the reality of this job. There are no raises and you will be expected to take care of a property with literally hundreds of customers all by yourself. People quite all the time, you will be threatened by customers, you will be concerned for your safety and the safety of your property, company makes billions of dollars yet can’t invest in its employees, you will work with people who sit on there phone or find another way to do nothing and management will do nothing to correct the behavior, you will be forced into job positions you don’t want and had refused

title: After their profits
pros: This company provides excellent trading although it’s mostly on the job, trail and error.
cons: Relief property managers are required to move to 3 properties in a week. Not so bad, but late notice or no notice. District Manager a great personality but induces competition rather than cooperation. Good training if the dm wants to show up. We have trainers available 7 days a eeek and they carry a heavy load. We don’t get increases except in order to hire.

title: Change and turnover are a few of there favorite things
pros: You can make good money if you know how to work the metrics they have for your bonus
cons: Its an old boys network. If they don't like you, you will go nowhere

title: I worked in District 0998 and they were very unprofessional and lacked team spirit.
pros: The customers... which really doesn't compliment Public Storage because if you enjoy working with the public you can find a much better place to work
cons: The management team are made up of a group of individuals that are related with unscrup[ulous behavoir at work...for example drinking on job, borrowing lunch money from cash register. I found it very hard to fit in. They are avery disrespectful bunch, but have been with co. a very long time. I made complaints through normal management channels without any resolve after 6-7 months I resigned. Pay Sucks!!! $9.50/hr with a MBA and 12yrs sales and customer service go figure

title: Career that has been incredibly rewarding personally and professionally
pros: Grew career from entry level DM. Able to create, build and develop teams, while developing more and more responsibility and skills.. Excellent business model, almost no debt, and consistently growing stock. I wish more companies were as financially astute as PS, and wish I would have held onto more of the stock. Performance driven company, that has extremely high business integrity. Always trying to get better, and stay ahead of the competition. Low turnover of employees at all levels, even at the property level.
cons: IS Systems can always be better. Little room for advancement for the property employees.

title: Reservation Sales Agent
pros: *Decent hourly wage *Great co-workers and supervisors *Time-off is in abundance, especially during the slow season (Winter)
cons: *Bonus structure was changed multiple times and did not favor the employee *High turn-over, people would often quit or be fired for performance that did not meet expectations. *There are no raises, it is the same hourly regardless of how long you work there. *No room for growth, PS will look outside of the business for management positions and rarely inside.

title: District Manager
pros: Pay and bonus was very good
cons: Treatment of employees was poor at best. The marketing dollars spent drives customers in. Company attitude is it is easy to replace the people with new employees. Required scripts take personality out of presentations. It makes you feel like a robot. Internal audit is used as a scare tactic versus a learning and growth opportunity.

title: District Manager Review
pros: There are a lot of pros to working at Public Storage including: work live balance, advancement opportunities, competitive pay/ bonus program, excellent peer support and most importantly a District Manager at Public Storage is home every night because of minimal travel requirements.
cons: The cons are similar to any retail environment. Hiring top talent and retaining top talent is often a challenge. Public Storage does a great job of training their Property Managers to be excellent in sales and customer service, which often leads them to finding a higher paying sales position within the retail environment.

title: "Great Company to grow a career with"
pros: Career opportunities! Steady growth and market penetration is what impresses me the most about working for Public Storage. I formerly worked for a retail company for many of years. The difference in working as a District Manager for Public Storage is, "you really feel like a business owner". Stock, compensation and health benefits are above expectation and the Executive Management Team really has a laser-beam focus on sustaining our position as the industry leader!
cons: Nothing really to add here. It's a very rewarding company!

title: Not Just Filling Space.
pros: The work environment originally had an entreprenurial spirit, that changed as time moved on. The field operations was confident and provided feedback to provide you with ways to be successful with your job and its support for the field.
cons: The home office was not connected to the field in many ways, this alienated the field and did not make it a collaborative environment. Many decisions were made that were not practical for good operations and execution.

title: I really want to enjoy my job.
pros: My DMs have been very competent, most of my coworkers are amazing people. I've met a lot of new friends, the work is inside and outside, and there's usually some downtime. I live on-site as well, so commute is awesome. It's a nice place.
cons: See the plural up there? I've had three district managers in just over three years. Upper management has become overbearing and callous towards it's employees, DM and property people alike. Low pay, like everyone else has said. Since I live on site, I make 3$ less than my relief managers. Initially my pay was 1.50$ less but then they gave ALL reliefs an extra dollar in hopes it would 'encourage them to do the same amount of work as the property managers'. Add on the .50$ raise for them compared to my .27$ because it was based on a percent rather than work done... there you go. Even then, if something bad happens, it's the property managers fault. For 3$ less - 9.97$ an hour, even. Slow repairs to properties. Lock and insurance! We get written up if our numbers don't go up. I think our locks are pretty heavy duty (I've cut padlocks myself, at my old job) but not for 18$. Insurance IS a requirement but if people lie, we can't refuse to let them rent... even though our numbers go down. Then we get written up. So on and so forth. It murders morale. They've done away with the bonus system entirely save for the 'once a year' thing. I don't consider that a bonus. They word it to sound as if 40% of the company getting bonus is a lot much like in 1984 when they cut rations but made it sound super awesome. It's not. In a company where the smallest property makes in a month what I do in a YEAR... they can afford to give us a bonus, or raise the pay for property managers at least. The scripts aren't so bad. I've been in sales for almost a decade, every place has their scripts. It's a pain to memorize them, yes, but this is the first time I've had eight to twelve different scripts or the requirement to never vary them even if to built a proper rapport. My regular customers have learned that if they come in with other people behind the counter not in uniform that they shouldn't expect me to act myself but rather spout scripts at them. Not learning them earns you a very aggressive talk from the RM and a write up. Also, three write ups in the course of your ENTIRE career there gets you fired without question. If you've been there fifteen years, received one every five... and you're fired. The only reason I'm with the company is because of the apartment and genuinely enjoy my customers - save for the ones I've called the police on. Or the skeevy ones who hit on me and won't let up because 'those security cameras catch everything?' wink wink. I miss feeling respected and valued as an employee.

title: $91000 Doesn't Even Begin to Compensate
pros: It seems great. Good pay, hours that are bankers hours with only a Monday-Friday work week. Business casual dress and 2 weeks of PTO your first year. Too bad that's not really all accurate.
cons: Let's be honest. You have multi-unit management experience, you are thinking you want to work for a massive company with growth potential and $75,000 the first year plus a guaranteed $16,000 bonus doesn't sound too bad, right? Wrong. The District Manager position is more like a store manager position anywhere else. You are managing $10 an hour employees and it's 16-25 of them. Most store managers have more direct reports. For this compensation, you are expected to be on call essentially 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. Every morning you need to be up and calling each one of your properties to ensure that each of your $10 an hour "managers" has shown up for work in a timely manner. If they haven't, you need to notify your Vice President boss and find a way to cover that shift or go to the store and open it yourself. A report comes out daily and goes to everyone from the CEO to the District Manager about what property didn't open on time. If a gate goes down at 9:30 pm and someone is stuck behind, guess who goes? The District Manager. Customer needs in on an emergency after office hours? District Manager. Lock gets stuck on a weekend and it's urgent? Again, District Manager. Someone wants to finally pay their bill before an auction at 6 am? District Manager. During the summers, it's a mandatory 6 day work week, no compensation or additional time off during the week and no option as to which days those will be. You're expected in the field from 8 am to 6 pm and to still find time to accomplish all your own work of doing mindless reports, reviewing numbers that expectations change daily on and managing your team of under-motivated, poorly paid, high school educated employees. The good news? There is no personal growth in this company. The leadership is continuously changing and turnover has become so bad it's now part of the bonus metric. Any District Manager worth his weight can find a better job - the ones that tend to stay have come from companies that are sub-par and aren't able to move forward and advance with another company. Public Storage is where they die. District Managers are only hired from the outside and are never promoted from within - great succession planning right? District Managers are expected to be professional but be on the same comfort level with their hourly managers. Dress code is business casual and is expected even when you are repairing a rolling door, changing a hasp or cutting a lock in 100 plus temperatures or sub-zero ones. There is no quality of life outside this job. If you don't eat, live and breathe Public Storage, you won't make it. It's about basic greed and corporate manipulation. There is no ethical room to even help anyone. it's a bitter end for anyone who can't pay as an auction is conducted regardless of situation. Your job is to say no, I don't care that you have cancer, don't care that you're getting divorced, don't care that you're dying or that you lost your mother - can't pay today, too bad - it's sold. Public Storage likes to say "We're a compassionate company" but frankly, we aren't. We are a cut throat, money hungry organization that simply is out to make a buck. We raise your rent - pay or get out. There is no flexibility. My bottom line is that I took this position with another offer on the table. I made the wrong decision. I'm looking now as I'm miserable here and it's a limited market. I've been with 2 big box retailers as a District Manager and never been this micromanaged or abused.

title: Manager everyones a manager
pros: you do not have to deal with many customers. And you get to ride a golf cart a lot.
cons: you get paid 9.50 an hour and never get raises. People go crazy some times on you yelling about there stuff getting ruined or sold at actions. Once a week you have to make over a hundred calls to tell people there rent is due. also no room for upper movement in the company.

title: Don't get trapped
pros: I like working alone for the most part. If you're taking night classes slow days are great to get some studying done. Position offers benefits if you can hack it.
cons: As a Property Manager you have to deal with everything: cleaning, maintenance, customer service; which wouldn't be terrible if the pay was better. Safety is a concern, especially as I had someone who came in repeatedly and threatened me, basically saying she was going to keep coming back until she, "get[s] what she want[s]." My DM's position on this was a, "Sucks for you" attitude. Same thing goes for when the DM screws up. I had no running water for 2 weeks because someone did not get my backflow inspection done. He ignored notices from the water company for 6 months. Once again, it was a "Sucks for you" attitude. I never had 'drinking water' per say to begin with, but then I was without a sink or a toilet. I had to drive to a shopping center to use the restroom. In the meantime my DM called me constantly on the store phone to make sure I was still there and didn't decide to leave without telling him. The company refuses to pay to repair and maintain their properties. I have NO light at my location at night. This has been reported for months, but the company did not like the estimate given by various contractors to repair/replace my lighting. I get to deal with the customer complaints on no lights, holes in buildings, rate increases (which are extreme), and now I'm having health problems (so I'm trapped because this is where I get my benefits) The sales requirements are ridiculous. It is assumed you are not executing the script properly if you fail to sell a $20 lock to every customer. Most of these people rent their trucks from Uhaul. Same locks for $13. It would be nice to get a weekend off every once in awhile without having to fight for it. Only certain employees get all of the days off they want, including 3- and 4-day weekends. I cannot remember the last time I had a Friday, Saturday, or Sunday off.

title: Over The Years..
pros: Longevity is the best way I can start this review as a 12 year vet at this Company. If you are looking to work for a great Company and have the skills, for-sight to work hard and flexibility to change at any given notice. This would be a great work place for anyone who applies these abilities to their work ethic. Starting out at the property level was my introduction to how the PS family operates. I had a large work load and gave my all to provide the best customer service and complete all work duties assigned. As I grew to master these tasks on a daily bases, I also grew stagnant to the limitations I was feeling towards my strengths and abilities. So I decided to put in my two weeks after 2 years of service. Once I advised my GM at the time, she then advised our VP at the time. To my surprise, they both scheduled a meeting a few days later to convenience me not to leave the company. I thought to myself why? They both expressed how much I was an asset to the company with great work ethic and provided such great CS, they could not loose me. So they suggested I try a corporate sales job for 3 days, the following week. If I did not like it, they would honor my resignation, but if I felt the sales position would be a better fit position, I could take the job and extra pay ($) . I tried it for the 3 days and took it! After 4.5 years of sales. I was enjoying the sales and learning development training and of course the pay. But not the complacency took its tool on spirit. My manager at the time put a recommendation in for another positon within the company, as an Assistant Buyer. I applied myself again and took the position to further my PS education. I say education because there is so much to learn and teach in all the fields I have grown in. My years at PS have been awesome and rewarding. The PS family has a special place in my heart and I would recommend anyone to apply themselves to become a part of this family. It’s not easy to go above and beyond for some people, but doing better and thinking ,then re-thinking any positive ways to push yourself forward, will have great rewards. Not just for the company you work for, but to prove to yourself, it’s my responsibility to create your own goals and achievements. They just get to reap the benefits for your hard work 
cons: As much money as they make, they should be better raises and stock options for non-ex employee's as well.

title: Dont know
pros: You get paid time off, you are working by yourself most of the time, plenty of time to be on your phone, coworkers are pretty well connected
cons: District managers, regional managers, and coorporate make all the money while the underpaid hourly workers do all the work and many properties have roaches

title: One year in!
pros: - Established structure - Company growth - Supportitive organization - Development opportunities - Independent environment -
cons: tant feedback on performance - Work life balance - Company is continually evolving the processes to improve results

title: It was a very good job lot of fun met amazing people great benefits and pay but.. See cons
pros: Stable pay somewhat benefits and bonus once a year progessing is simple work is dilengent and easy lot of paper work and customer service to keep you busy and lot of maintenance
cons: Constant travel unstable schdueling hire anybody of the street and you got to pick up the slack for someone else mistakes and the improper communication with upper management and again the favoritism i had a better experi ce with the seniors of the company then the new hires

title: Definite pros and cons..
pros: The hours are nice if you’re not into waking up super early, 9:30-6 Monday through Saturday and you close an hour early on Sundays. 9/10 you work alone which a lot of people prefer. Most properties have an apartment which the property manager normally lives in which definitely has pros and cons but it’s nice if you’re just starting out.
cons: Pay is terrible. You work outside… A-LOT, in any type of weather conditions. You’re constantly told to sell locks/insurance & get 5 star google reviews and if you don't, you can get written up. No room for growth, they don’t promote within.

title: Shady business practices, lack of communication
pros: On-site apartments for property managers
cons: Lack of communication from superiors, which in turn leads them to not know what’s going on merely because they do not care to know what is going on. They are only sales driven and not customer service oriented. They sweep customer complaints under the rug and even go as far as to make employees report low customer Google reviews to make them go away or bury them with positive ones, which doesn’t make the overall issue go away. Make you cover up mold growth and rat infestations on the property. Constant price gouging. No upward mobility.

title: Like to spend your paycheck on supplies
pros: Fellow employees are easy to get along with
cons: Work alone 99% of the time, constant moving around, there are several different properties in each district and you are expected to go to them all at one time or another, no matter how far it is to travel. They NEVER want to fix anything, constatnly say we will get to it and never do, they use an unlicensed company for matinence, and the workers that they use for matinence cannot communicate with employees unless you speak spanish.

title: Property Manager.
pros: It's a job, if your goal is to live at your job this is a job for you.
cons: Working 9-6 daily, Always short staff, Drills sales down your throat,NO RAISES!!, you actually get paid least as a property manager.. No room for growth, Does not support employees in school. Bonus program is a no go!

title: Get The Experience and Leave
pros: A great place to learn about the storage industry. You will learn all about the storage procedures,lien laws and gain experience regarding sizes.
cons: Once you become a property manager,theres really no growth afterwards. The bonus incentives no longer exist and more and more is being added to your job detail...which includes tooooo many scripts and pressure to sale over priced merchandise. I worked for the company for 6 years,and I saw the company change for the worse....

title: Regional Vice President
pros: The people that I work with are my favorite thing about the company. We have great people at every level- Property Managers, District Managers, Senior DM's, Regional Managers, Divisional Managers, Corporate employees, and the Executive Team. Everyone is there to help support every level. In addition, every level above the level you are at is spending the time to help develop you and further your career. The hours of operation are incredible as you can be home for dinner with the family every night. Top performers are recognized at all levels.
cons: I have no cons about the company.

title: Great Career Opportunity!
pros: There is great opportunity for advancement for a multi-unit manager. Starting as a District Manager, you can advance into a Senior DM role and Regional Manager role in a realistic amount of time. The company is growing year over year, so the opportunity is steadily available. The position also comes with flexibility. A District or Regional Manager has flexibility in scheduling his/her time to best drive the business.
cons: The company is highly focused on a system of checks and balances. A manager will have to get used to a detailed approval process when attempting to make decisions concerning his/her business.

title: Stagnant organization
pros: Limited flexibility in setting your own daily agenda and how you want to accomplish it. Small team focus on someproperties with 2 person team.
cons: extremely MICROMANAGED to the point where it effects operations and a personal selling approach (I am under the impression that this is more under regional discretion than the company at whole). Management out of touch with operations. Incentive offerings are near unnatainable and very undercompensated. PMs bring in all the $$$ and yet bonus DMs receive a bonus metric almost 5x this amount. Not very encouraging to say the least.

title: Secretive Greatly Compensated Upper Management, resulting in Confused, Disappointed, Exhausted Field Employees
pros: I adore the hands on aspect, enjoying time outdoors and then I also appreciate my office time. It's a unique combination here, you constantly utilize your management skills, customer service, administrative, sales abilities, and all while keeping fit while maintaining the property you run. Your customers witness you in all of these roles and it is near impossible not to build a good rapport when the same people who keep you employed see you consistently active in your role as their Property Manager/Handyman-woman. ♡My Clients and Peers♡ You encounter such a wide variety of customers and associates in this industry. People from all walks of life, all in different places and experiencing different circumstances that have brought them into your storage facility. I haven't met a customer yet that just felt like they wanted a storage space and came out to get one. In the same sense, I haven't trained an associate that set out in search of a position with a storage company. All of the people I have connected with here have enriched my life in many valuable ways.
cons: I was hired in and told if I could stand out, proving my abilities to be outstanding, promotions were possible. It didn't take long before I learned that being as I was hired as a Relief Manager in Field Management, no matter what I did I could only advance to a Property Manager, then an A Property Manager, and then finally I could become a Key Training Professional. (Not necessarily in that order) This knowledge didn't stop upper management from misleading me, recommending that I return to school to complete at least my 4 year degree to become eligible for the District Management position, where my career potential would have no boundaries within the company and my salary would more than triple, and the incentive package would put my years salary to shame. Two years into juggling a very chaotic life...promoting all the way through field management, enjoying marriage, raising young adults, accumulating student loans, and constant exhaustion, but maintaining energy through adrenaline, I experienced a new regional who told me flat out that I had reached the top...No matter what I did, I would not be promoted outside of field management. Since that time I've continued to stay. I've been comfortable at times and I do enjoy the job. However, maddeningly every year they find a way to take more away. They took away sick pay, then yearly they reduce Paid Time Off. Now they argue on allowing us to use our earned PTO, and if it isn't used by a certain deadline, they cut us a check instead of allowing us our earned rest/family time. Our bonuses went from monthly to quarterly, then quarterly to yearly. Merit increases are now mass increases, in tiny percentages, provided to all, no matter what your performance level is. Upper management constantly changes now, without ever sharing any of their strategies. The field moral is now nonexistent, they want robots, they demand results, high pressure sales, so we can pad the pockets of our CEO, while our properties run in need of more maintenance and upgrades for our clients who consistently receive rate increases leaving them upset with the office staff who have zero control. Those upset customers then leave, and upper management expects us to explain why we can't retain their business.

title: A great place to work, Hard work and commitment to employees and customers create opportunity for advancement
pros: As with anything in life, you only get back what you are willing to give. The culture and environment rewards high performers as demonstrated through the various bonus and incentive programs. People throughout the organization, at all levels, are dedicated, conscientious and an absolute pleasuse to work with
cons: The nature of the business is challenging at times when dealing with customers that are facing severe hardship, especially when it comes to managing expectations or providing" acceptable" solutions in the view of the customer.

title: You Can't Grow
pros: Store hours are consistent (certain) property apartments gas reimbersement laid back environment
cons: no room for growth district managers and above benefit from your hard work internal drama between workers at other properties pay is horrible

title: Relief Manager
pros: Great people, love helping customers when they need it the most. Working at different locations and meeting new people.
cons: Taking away almost all benefits, low pay, selling high priced packing supplies if they need it or not. And SCRIPTS... Like the customer doesn't know it's a script, they hate it too. But it's all about the money, they even bragged at company party about the obscene amout of money they make DAILY...But only give 2% raises. They won't spend money on repairs like gutters, lets just take them down???

title: District Manager
pros: This is a well-run company with growth, and opportunity for advancement. Public Storage focuses on developing its employees and taking them to the next level. There are different and exciting challenges each day. which keeps the position fun and interesting. Everyone is competitive, but there is still a great team atmosphere. If you build a great team you can accomplish great things. Overall, Public Storage is an excellent company to work for.
cons: None, this company is doing very well.

title: Not worth it!!
pros: Steady hours and that's about it. The ad says we work independently but that isn't true either. We are babysat constantly.
cons: No regard for our safety. Employees are forced to work on dark properties in unsafe working conditions. Employees are expected to remove vagrants alone in the dark instead of paying for an eviction. We work almost every day because we have so much turnaround. The schedule changes daily so you cannot make plans. They will not fix anything so you are the customer's punching bag all day long while THEY make the money. The employees risking their lives and sanity get 2% a year. Extensive manual labor and sales required or you will get fired.

title: It's all about the people.
pros: Number one PRO - the people and culture. From the Key Training Property Managers who have been with us for 10 years to the Senior Executives of the company- I have not met a leader here who did not show enthusiasm and dedication for both our customers and our fellow employees. From day one, I felt totally supported. My regional once told me- "I work for you. You work for your field employees. Your employees work for your customers." I truly feel that my managers want me to succeed. I previously came from a company that didn't have this culture- and it is amazing what a difference it makes to your overall success and happiness not only with the company but personally as well. That being said- here is a list: 1) Progressive culture- you have a voice, upper management is open minded, and changes are made if it makes sense. 2) Invests in your success- your personal development is looked at every month. It is encouraging to know your manager is rooting for you. 3) Work life balance- no phone calls after 6pm, weekends off, everyone respects your off time. 4) Excellent compensation and benefits- generous paid time off, great pay and benefits, company stock. 5) Team work- this company might be big but it's unified. I haven't come across a department that wasn't willing to go out of their way to help you. 6) Company is picky on who they hire so you end up working with awesome people. 5k bonus for referring other district managers who on-board with the company.
cons: When I think about the challenges that I've faced in this position, I'm reminded more of my supervisors and coworkers who've either gone out of their way to help me or make me laugh, and usually both! One con that I can think of is that because it is a large company, certain items must go through multiple approvals and back and forth communication between departments before taking course- which can make maintenance projects last longer than anticipated.

title: Wouldn't go back
pros: Can't really think of any. Decent hours/decent pay that's about it. Liked the people I was around in the district.
cons: Constantly by yourself. Told to constantly meet metrics even though it is not said to be a sell/commission job. Being a PM you can't do anything more than anyone else. Company does not treat customers well. Management team is good and listens but nothing changes. Constant driving. Late meetings. Bad overall experience. Constantly understaffed and working overtime. Can not advance past a PM.

title: Love it- They're Stuck With Me
pros: Since the cost of housing in the Portland Metro is extremely high, the free apartment (with all utilities) is a great deal. No, Public Storage doesn't pay much-- but those smaller checks go a long way when you don't have to pay rent or utilities. I love the fact that I can walk out my front door two minutes before clock-in time and still be EARLY! Not every Public Storage has an on-site manager's apartment (nor does every manager cares to live where they work), but if a manager desire an on-site position, Public Storage is pretty good about working you into one. 27 days out of each month, Public Storage is, hands-down, the easiest job I've ever had. The remaining three days definitely keep you moving, but the WORST stress-level you experience here is on par with the AVERAGE day in most other retail-ish, dealing-with-the-public type of jobs. I used to manage a convenience store and vividly remember being so busy most days that you have to carefully strategize your bathroom breaks. That never happens at Public Storage. This is an outstanding job for self-motivated, self-starters who enjoy working independently. But if you require somebody standing over you and directing you all the time, or if you require the company of and interactions with co-workers, managing ANY storage facility would not be a good fit for you. Every day here is a little bit different, and Property Managers are often find themselves in the position of making judgment calls with customers and circumstances. But as long as your following company policies, management always has your back. The company's commitment to their employees shown during the COVID-19 situation was quite impressive and made me feel quite good about choosing to work here.
cons: Sure would be nice if they were more pro-active about maintaining their properties, but maybe I'm just being picky. I LIVE here, after all! While the company health insurance is quite good, it carries a steep deductible.

title: Lost in the sea of Quantity over Quality.
pros: Free rent- as the resident manager I didn't pay rent. Because of the size of the company (total sites + head quarters) you never had to worry about them going under, which means not worrying about losing your housing as well which was a bonus during covid. I had a fixed schedule so I always knew it'd be off Sunday and Monday.
cons: Theres so much to unpack here. We will start with the size. PS is doing do well they are able to aquire so many smaller companies, and build more locations, but while they are so focused on expanding, they are allowing other facilities to deteriorate. Gates broken for weeks, mold growing throughout buildings, damaged doors, cracked floors, deciding to cancel/forgo preventitive professional pest control, etc. Maintenance tickets get put in that sometimes go unnoticed, or gone about the cheapest way possible (I won't even start that rant). I understand needing to scale a buisness and they are such a huge company they will never change that but everything is always focused on quantity not quality. That goes for the employees too. Operations managers MIA, spoke to them maybe once? Very hierarchy, follow the chain of command. He meets most people, then anything else goes through your DM. Giving my DM the benefit of the doubt that she took on a big acquisition with poor communication, and she was probably over worked, but her lack of organization and poor time management was only matched by her unphased demeanor of everything. Unphased because at some point I'm pretty sure everyone dyes a little inside from being with this company. I had worked for 4 storage companies in 8 years, PS having acquired my previous company 4 months before I left the company. The sad part is people get sucked into PS because its easy money, free housing opportunities, etc but then have to work in these "dumpster fires" as everyone in my district would call the facilities, and not realize not all companies are that bad. Having gotten to work for great companies before, I can't say I wasn't biased going in, from hearing nothing but horror stories from previous employees from many levels from storage consultants to corporate (OMs/DMs/HRs). But there is a reason I left after 4 months. I can't speak on all the districts/markets, but mine only solidified those biases.

title: Over the past seven years this company has been a great place for me to grow personally and professionally.
pros: The benefits of working here are that you get to work with the public and meet lots of different people In the community, the company offers onsite management for property managers , and offers up to date training in customer service and retail sales.
cons: Some of the challenges to working here are the different customer service issues you may encounter. Though they can present a challenge they can also help you grow professionally and you are never left without help to solve them.

title: Intergrity, Stability, Well-Managed, Hard-working Executive Staff including Managment and Great EMPLOYEES at PS
pros: During the many years of employment, I have appreciated the stability, growth and integrity of the company. The shareholders, employees and public can count on the LEADERS to make sure the company is heading in the right direction
cons: If you're not the type who likes to roll up their sleeves and get busy...then this may not be the place for you. We operate under a culture of being effective and efficient.

title: Solid company with a bright future
pros: Industry leader with a strong balance sheet. The executive team is accessible and the working environment is casual and friendly. A generally conservative management style ensures long-term stability, yet new ideas are encouraged and given thoughtful consideration. If you are willing to work hard, you can go far.
cons: IT systems haven't always kept pace with the latest technology, but that is starting to turn around. The corporate offices are adjacent to an unfortunate stretch of I-5 where heavy truck traffic slows things down during rush hours. It's important to know the surface-street shortcuts.

title: District Manager
pros: Stability, Structure and Growth Opportunity
cons: No cons, company is 100% transparent with their expectations.

title: Great company with endless growth!
pros: Public Storage is an extremely forward thinking company with opportunity to truly be a business owner. Compensation and company stability are huge benefits to working for Public Storage but in addition to that, I really appreciate the amount of time and commitment our leadership team pours into the team at every level. Leadership focuses on continuous development and will be there as a partner to help you achieve your goals.
cons: This job can be demanding but with the responsibility comes a lot of reward.

title: Opportunity to Make a Difference at a Top Company
pros: We are a relatively small team for such a large company, which can make it easier to make a meaningful difference. You do still have to be willing to be creative and to work a bit to stand out. Public Storage also has a family feel at team birthday parties and holiday events. Even the CEO and other execs attend when they are in town. Our smaller, more efficient team also makes for a stronger profit margin and more stable employer, which means a lot to me.
cons: Though I appreciate our structure and think it's efficient overall, sometimes having fewer peers can have drawbacks.

title: Property Manager
pros: Good benefits, decent pay, most coworkers are friendly, great training. Overall it is a great place to get a start on how things when working for a corporation, and a great way to put the title of "manager" on your resume.
cons: Constant upper management change, everything is based in California, no real thinking about what is going on in other parts of the US.

title: A lot of work for very little recognition or pay !
pros: This job offers full-time hours, which is a perk in this dwindling job market. You are never scheduled less than 38 hours a week. You get benefits and start accruing PTO and sick time from your first day of employment. Training was about 3-4 weeks and once you're out, you are placed with a set property to work at. After 6 months, you are eligible to put your bid in to become property manager. Property managers get paid more and have the option to live on-site if the property has an apartment (which not all of them do). On the job, you learn a lot of different trades and you increase your skill set. You can pick your own 2 off days.
cons: Where do I begin? The upper management is a mess. They are rarely on the same page, which creates so much tension in the district. A lot of broken promises and sweet nothings whispered in employees ears. No one knows where they stand with anyone. There is definitely favoritism something serious at this job and it can be a downer. The power that's given to the wrong person makes the turnover rate increase. The roster has changed so much over the years that the employees don't even know how soon they could be served their exit papers. You don't feel secure at all. The pay is laughable and not even livable and there is no room for negotiation in that regard. The pay isn't competitive so you get paid the same as someone with not even half of your experience. You wear many hats and do so many different things for honestly the bare minimum. The level of promotion doesn't reach as high as you think. You go from relief manager to property manager to KTP (key training professional). You would think that being here long-term would give you a shot at moving up the ranks to District Manager but that's not the case. There is no room for upward movement. The stress levels can reach dangerous levels so definitely have a hobby when you get off work. Also they don't tell you that only property managers can get Sundays off as one of their off days so you can only request the day off. That's really not an incentive to become a property manager but I guess who am I to judge? Overall, get the experience and after some time, move on to greener pastures. Longevity here is not worth it.

title: Terrible upper management!
pros: Most of the weekdays you can set your own pace, the job is easy to do most of the time.
cons: Upper management lie cheat abuse and steal to make sure they get their way after taking away from the property managers. The company turnover is very high and getting higher because of their power trips. They force very sick employees to work but give play time off to their favorites. Doing a good job is rewarded only with keeping a job. No raises!

title: Fantastic Opportunity
pros: The opportunity at Public Storage is excellent. Public Storage is the market leader in a stable industry and is poised for growth. For that reason those in leadership roles have tremendous room for advancement. The work load is challenging but not unmanageable. The work schedule has flexibility with enables work/life balance. The company leadership provides excellent direction without being overbearing. They allow leaders to lead. Upper management is approachable and provides support to the field. My entire experience at Public Storage has been positive.
cons: There are times when work is necessary at night or on weekends.

title: Would not recommend to anyone
pros: Good working hours and that is about all I can say about the company. I have met some very wonderful people that have become lifelong friends.
cons: Upper management has forgotten all about the employees. They are greedy, close minded and demanding. They put on a big front for those that do not know and pretend to care about everyone. They hire those that cannot do their jobs or just want a check. We have to lie to the customers with everything we say to them. I feel less human for we are told what to say, how to say it. One star is 10 stars too many on rating this company.

title: Micromanagement Capital of the World.
pros: The only pro is the pay is decent depending on your position.
cons: You are not given the opportunity to make decisions as a leader you are constantly micro-managed. You don't have any work life balance at all, you work 24-7. Whenever your off work on like a vacation you have to literally turn your phone off because of the amount of calls sometimes it may even be your supervisor. By far the worst job I ever had, can't wait to fine me something better.

title: More Stressful Then the Job is Worth
pros: I was able to learn much about how numbers and how ranking worked on a corporate level, something I will be able to use in all future jobs. I had much more customer interaction on this job then I did with prior employment, both in person and over the phone. I also liked that management wasn't constantly breathing over my shoulder at every second of the day and gave me a little freedom to make my own decisions with how I ran my property. If you are a self motivator then the job is good as you are often alone several times a week. Pay isn't great but you ca survive on it and the quaterly bonus can be pretty generous.
cons: The medical benefits are great if you rarely get sick. There is no room to advance as Public Storage does not promote from within past being a Property Manager. Upper management respect for their workers fluccates based on the kind of numbers your store is pulling in and many of the tactics used for raising numbers are dishonest to the customer. There is little to no employee loyalty. It is also very hard as a property manager to take care of any facility problems (gate malfunctions, potholes, leaks) as Public Storage fights tooth and nail to not allot much of a quaterly budget in property maintence. Most problems that occure can take up to months to resolve. Being that we are on the higher end of the spectrum as far as pricing is concerned, you think we would at least be able to fix problems more efficantly. This is also the only job I have had that did not pay overtime for Sundays and holidays.

title: Disappointing Big-Corporate Profits Mindset
pros: Stable company, financially profitable, good benefits, accrued time off.
cons: Extremely low 11$/hr pay for extensive duties expected, no time to use time off, flavor of the month type management with constantly changing expectations, extremely micromanaged and dictated on all levels. No real feedback or compromise allowed from employees. 40% employee turnover ratio for company. No room to grow within company if successful.

title: EASY OFFICE JOB THAT REQUIRES NO SPECIAL SKILLS OR EDUCATION
pros: Light work office job. Minimal paperwork and upkeep. If you have effective time management,this is an easy job.They cut the stock piling of PTO because too many PM/RF were making it impossible to schedule a district with all the four day weekends... I manage a very large property. My occupancy is always above 94%. All the goals are attainable. I have no problems staying above 90% on lock sales and insurance sales. They give you all the tools to complete those goals. The scripts work if you use them correctly. Doesnt matter what neighborhood your facility is in. Im in an extremely poor area.
cons: Constantly trying to match LY numbers plus 20% growth. Especially in poor economic times. Should go back last five years,drop higest,drop lowest and average the rest. Very few companies in the world see a 20% growth year after year, do not know why they expect properties to do it. Rental increases. They are ridiculous. Long term tenants pay almost 70% more for the same size a new customer off the street would pay. Long term tenants should not be punished for consumer loyalty. If a tenant rents more than one unit,they get all the increases at once. Had two different tenants have increases totaling combined at $179 and $220 more PER MONTH. Upkeep for the properties (atleast in my district) is poor. For all the late fees alone a typical property brings in,there shouldn't be any issues. Some properties so not even have restrooms. They have to drive to another property to use the facilities. Bonus structure is not personal,or even property performance based. Your lumped in as a district. You have have the best numbers in the world,but if other properties in your district are lacking. It drags up down with them on a lower tier.

title: Very unpredictable place to work
pros: DM's are supportive and there is some level of autonomy.
cons: Corporate changes bonus plans, salary increases, benefits and expectations frequently. It seems like every week, there is a major change (ie. a reduction in PTO, no raise, change in bonus plan, new expectations/quotas, back to the old expectations/quotas). It's really challenging to keep up with the changes.

title: Been happily working here full time for 2 years
pros: On site apartment at most of the properties, majority of the time DM's and above tell the customers the same thing regarding policy. in my 14 years of working, this is one of my favorite jobs because you aren't micro managed and you don't have to worry about telling the customers one thing and your boss telling them something else.
cons: The only con is that the call center and customer service tells the customers things that aren't accurate. Potential tenants are told to bring in the minimum to rent and then we have to inform them of the other security features.

title: I love my job with public storage!!!
pros: Hours of operation, customer interaction, working independently, great benefits & awards for job performance, paid mileage for traveling, great support from upper management. Paid time off as well as paid sick time. 3 paid holidays per year.
cons: The bonus program which was a great incentive was taken away. No anual raise in the past 3 years. No room for growth within the company for field management after being promoted to KTP.

title: Go work somewhere else.
pros: -In Tucson we had a really supportive district manager. -Depending on the property and how full it is, you can have pretty relaxed days. -Helping with storage auctions could be pretty fun.
cons: I want to start this off by saying I wasn't the best employee. I was going through a really dark time in my life and I didn't work my hardest a lot of the time. That said, I can still say today that this was one of the worst jobs I've ever had. Some of the cons were: -Insultingly low pay for the amount of responsibility and travel that is often required. -Pretty much only one opportunity for advancement if you can even call it that. Relief managers could become property managers with their very own property. From what I remember though, it was the same pay for more responsibilities. You COULD get your own on-site apartment offered if you become a property manager, though only 2 properties out of like 7 in Tucson had one. -Properties in high crime areas can be pretty scary. Threatened on multiple occasions. -Properties would be frequently broken in to leaving you to deal with customers and police in extremely stressful situations. -Given all that needs to be accomplished, two people minimum should be working the storage property. Usually though, you were scheduled to work by yourself. Juggling cleaning units, doing lock checks, calling delinquent customers, and leasing units to customers can be really challenging. Slow days at slow properties are nice, but you'll often be working on busy properties with a million things to do. -Properties in high crime areas often have people living in the units with you often tasked with kicking them out of the property. Pretty stressful and dangerous situations can ensue. -Pushed hard to sell merchandise and insurance to customers without any incentive. Overall, I do take some responsibility for my negative experience. That said, for a job that barely pays above minimum wage, it just isn't worth it. The job can be relaxed and fun, but it's more often stressful, dangerous, and headache-inducing. Work somewhere else.

pros: We now have promotions opportunities!!!! This is awesome because it gives seasoned employees the urge to want to do more. The benefits of being able to live on the properties is a blessing. Our healthcare coverage plans are also pretty affordable.
cons: Lack of INDIVIDUAL based insensitive bonuses Poor communication between District management and teams.

title: Good company
pros: Apartment with free rent, water and utilities included. Run your own property. Chances to move up in the company. Benefits. Pto and sick time off. Chance to when a monthly bonus and a yearly bonus.
cons: Doesn't have golf carts at all properties. Maintenance issues take forever to be fixed. Pay sucks and company never gives a raise. You can't bid on the auctions for public storage.

title: Going downhill!
pros: Steady hours (no more, no less)! No one breath under your neck! Definitely keep you physically and mentally strong with daily demands and routines. Gain customer service skill!
cons: Greedy corporation, moral and ethic are no longer exist in their dictionary. All they care about is the numbers. High expectations, but run your own show without help. Cut bonus & cut PTO, under pay for what you deserved. Become a robot, live on scripts!

title: An opportunity to grow with a successful company.
pros: I've only been with PS for a relatively short period of time but felt the company deserved a better report than what I've seen here in the past. In fact, the overall score and tone of reviews made me hesitate applying for this position. I'm glad I did. I knew from the interview and on-boarding process that this was the place for me. You'll meet and interview with every level of management from DM to COO before an offer can be extended. I was encouraged to continue at each step of the process, thanks to the honest dialog about the what the job entailed, and the honest feedback as I progressed through my 2nd, 3rd, and 4th interview. Even more than that, the Regional Manager (my current boss) could not have created a more warm and welcoming environment. The training program is 4 months long, during which you will be fully compensated (12 months). As a DM you'll work closely and face to face with your peers in the region. Tasks that support the group will be broken up and shared amongst the team. Your Regional Manager is close by and well connected to your business. Expectations are high, but based on attainable goals that are easily tracked. You'll be empowered to run your business and recognized for your success. I came from a Big Box retailer with a hectic and unpredictable work schedule. PS values your time and expects that you have a life outside the office. That being said, this is no different than any other email and phone connected management position. A timely response is expected to all inquiries, and emergencies do come up.
cons: I can think of one but there is a simple solution. We are lacking in real time performance updates at times. We simply manage the behaviors proven to lead to a positive result in the absence of reporting.

title: it's all right
pros: work hours are pretty good, 9:30-6 on weekdays and 9:30-5 on weekends. the work itself is pretty easy, and there's not much to do. good for anyone looking to just make easy money.
cons: they company pushes its employees to hustle customers into buying merchandise they really don't need, to the point where it's almost harassing. the simple fact that they expect every employer to be an automated message in order to sell items other than storage units really takes away from any sort of individuality that you would want.

title: Regional Vice President
pros: What i love it that the company is truly performance based at all positions of the organization. Each Month , each quarter you are ranked compared to your peers. This allows a individual to come in from the outside and get promoted based off of performance. The company is financially solid.As a fortune 500 company and to have the cash and the debt free balance sheet we are not in the same position of many companies out there that are going through restructures, and layoffs due to declining sells or in debt. I look at the retail companies out there that most of us came from and I see some closing , but most at a minimal are laying people off. Districts are expanding, and job responsibilities are increasing for same pay. Work Life balance for the being the retail world is night and day compared to where I am from. For the most part my phone doesn't ring after 6:00PM. All the property's are closed, all the employees have gone home for the day. There are those one off calls that I will get from a alarm company, and or customer service. If i compare that to the years in my previous career we didn't close until 11:00 and those calls didn't really stop till after 1:00AM This is a very thin organization. To have the ability to have the CEO in my market , or the President riding in my property's yearly is amazing. My divisional manager has been in my market at least 10 times this year. This by some may seem as a con. I see this as a pro. I get to be developed and influenced by the executives of the company often. In my previous career the CEO was never in my market even once. The president was there twice. This was over a 15 year period of time.
cons: Like most companies i think the insurance cost is out of control. The amount of money I spend to cover myself and my family has climbed each and every year. We all are at work for our family's and to have the burden of paying for the insurance that are above the cost that most of us cannot any longer afford is disappointing . I wish we celebrated more. We do a great job at our annual sales conference of celebrating out top performers. We do a great job of making that week incredible for all of our district managers and above. There needs to be more in our local markets to show our people how amazing they are. A yearly budget should be in place at the regional level to facilitate this

title: Regional Manager
pros: This is a company stacked with great people from the store managers up to the CEO. There is a great balance of support from peers, subordinates and supervisors. The company prides itself on leading with a high level of integrity which has contributed to the stability and success of Public Storage. And there unlimited career growth potential! The combination of these factors make Public Storage a great place to work, develop and succeed.
cons: There are ups and downs in every job but the difference here is that you have the support of many to guide you through .

title: Happily @ Public Storage
pros: The company - Great company, solid financials, quality product and portfolio, high-integrity execution of the business plan. The people – Hard working, tireless work ethic, relentless attention to detail; nobody “above” any specific task when it needs to get done. Longevity and loyalty to the company permeate all levels of staff and leadership. The facility (corporate office) – Well maintained and recently renovated interior/exterior, great parking, ease of access from the 5 Fwy. The work – Wildly diverse and on a scope and scale this is tough to complain about. You will not be bored..! The pace is fast and exciting, no 2 days alike… Bottom Line If you’re looking for a challenge in your career, this is a great place to work; if you’re looking to coast and hide among the crowd, don’t waste your (and their) time. This is a lean running, rock solid company with amazing people and a tireless drive to be the very best in the industry; so far, for me, it’s been great ride…!
cons: The company – Given the legacy and power of the brand, being at the top, there is little time to rest and enjoy the fruits of your labor. The next threat, urgent project, initiative or opportunity is always just around the corner. You always have to be on your toes and ready to go in a different direction if needed. The people – Like any company this well-established, new ideas can be harder to introduce than what might be observed at a younger upstart company; there can be growing pains when giving up the “old way” of doing something. The fortunate thing here is that in contrast, leadership does not fall into this category; there is a constant pressure to reinvent as needed to stay at the forefront. The facility (corporate office) – The location is freeway convenient, but isn’t immediately adjacent to any shops/restaurants. Pack a lunch or plan a short drive over into Burbank or Glendale. (note, the in-office lunch room, coffee and break areas are clean and functional; and don’t forget bagel Fridays!) The work – It’s not always predictable and it can be discouraging not being able to gain momentum when tides change. If you are the type that needs an ultra-stable plan and very predictable work, this may not be a fit for you.

title: On site KTP property manager
pros: I started here over 2 years ago. I worked my way up and was promoted to A key trainer. I enjoy living on site and being able to make a connection with my customers. The hours are great and it has a steady schedule with full time each week and sometimes overtime. I enjoy being able to work as a team and train new members. The District manager works closely with the properties to make sure we have everything we need to be successful.
cons: I don’t really have anything to say as a negative!

title: Workloads vs actual human ability
pros: Full time. Straight forward policies. Same hours every day. Chance to work multiple locations.
cons: No overtime. Not enough hours in a day. The 1st to the 7th are unbearable and you WILL have blisters on your feet from walking, because all golf carts on properties in the district were taken away if you don't meet budgets. Forced to work solo, without assistance for over one year at the largest location in the city. Does not promote from within, past Property Manager. (now known as customer service representative for some reason)

title: Very Toxic
pros: Not a lot just the experience, knowledge you gain from the position and good benefits
cons: You're basically doing 5 jobs for so little pay, you have to do reception work, heavy phone calling, security, sales and janitor work. Customers have literally threatened us and they don't care. No type of safety whatsoever, always pushing us to sale merch but don't provide commission or any kind of rewards and they don't give raises! There's no growth in that company besides becoming property manager but even then you stay at the same pay too, do not recommend!

title: Overworked but paid ok?
pros: Hours: Mostly full-time employment and off by 6pm most of the time. Benefits: Good bonus plan (when you qualify for it, they change it so frequently one can never be sure), good medical, great pto. Co-Workers: As always, they can make or break a job. Mine were 90% awesome :) Customers: Can be very great.
cons: 1. Micro-managed sometimes, undermanaged others. This made it very difficult to obtain a good balance. 2. Over-worked in some areas (always working alone and being expected to make all calls AND memorize 4 new scripts a week at times)...under-worked in others (there were at least 2 weeks a month where 4-6 hours of an 8 hour day I had nothing to do). 3. Management: I don't know where to begin. This is the ONLY job I ever had where managers felt the need to try and turn team members against each other. I have read other reviews from other areas, so I know it's not just my area, plus I worked for PS on both coasts in my 3 yrs with them. Sometimes I felt like they broke their backs to help us out, other times it felt like we were just an irritant when things like the security system breaking (in one case, the security system was down OVER A YEAR and we still had to sell the great security to new customers like it worked). My last 2 years my team was under a constant threat of firing...what our DM failed to understand was that we were all friends in and out of work and shared the interviews with one another--he was telling all of us the same thing.

title: Property manager and key district trainer.
pros: Great support from current and previous district managers, all upper management is very supportive and wants to see property managers and reliefs succeed. I like the hours very much we always have a start time of 9:30am. Saturdays and Sundays we go home 1 hour early. Team support within my district is fabulous. We all work very well with each other and strive to help each other as often as it's needed. I am a KTP ( key district trainer ) I thoroughly enjoy teaching and training new hires to work to a standard that is higher than whats expected and helping them to succeed. We work alone alot and are given the privilege of our own time management with periodic check-ins from our district manager. Bonus program in place for top performers with an average of 40% of team members benefiting from a yearly bonus. Top performers receive opportunities for special prizes like trips ( for 2 ) and extra bonus $. Better than decent medical and dental with eye care insurance available other benefit program in place is working advantage available to all employees with numerous discounts and coupons with email alerts when discounst in selected grouping is chosen.
cons: Yearly increases are not good, last year I received the same 4% raise that under performers and average performers received, I am a over achiever. Upward mobility is nonexistent and they will not promote within. 3 holidays a year off Christmas, Thanksgiving and New years day. PTO (paid time off) went from 17 days yearly to 10 days for a total of sick time and vacation time combined,

title: OK to get some baseline experience... and use it for that
pros: Training program was efficient and complements some customer service and sales. The opportunity to meet new people daily and hear different stories was cool also.
cons: Biggest dissatisfaction here was compensation. Two aspects need to be considered by management and really brought to attention of employees 1) *Underpayment on an industry basis*- regional competitors offer much higher wages. If I can get paid 20% more by a competitor, that devalues my view of the company and the results I want to achieve. 2) *Undervaluing of employees and their results*- at this position you will be doing a great variety of things to contribute for the operation of the store including but not limited too: sales (contacting new leads through walk-ins, internet reservations or referrals), customer service (some upset customers about promotion pricing and definitely about increased rates for repeat customers), operations (ensuring everything at that location in terms of supplies or maintenance issues is addressed timely and efficiently), vendor management (working with companies that contract with PS for maintenance issues) and last but not least labor (yes you will be putting the gloves on in this position!) *No promotion opportunities*- Also, ironically... this company does not really promote from within! Almost all middle management on a district and regional basis came from other companies and usually other industries. Inadept company policies- About every other month senior management tries to inact a new policy to boost sales, reservations or gauge on merch pricing. This is largely out of touch of the customer base and has negligent results.

title: New to Public Storage
pros: I have been with Public Storage for about six months - so far so good. Great training program, which is very important - this is a different industry, so there is a lot to learn. The hours of the properties help to promote a great work/home life balance. Public Storage is a very stable and growing company; which allows great opportunities for advancement. I have no doubt that I have made the right choice in joining the PS family!
cons: I believe that this is already in the works, but some computers systems/programs need to be upgraded.

title: Solid Company
pros: Stable and pleasant environment to work in. Plenty to do. Fun activities year round. Rose Parade float. Smart and approachable management. Fair salary.
cons: A bit conservative at times. Purchase approval process is a bit slow.

title: Incredibly stable and profitable company.
pros: During my 10 years at Public Storage I've had the opportunity to work with incredibly talented people in the both the field organization and the corporate office. I've had the opportunity to take on many roles that were well suited to my talents and skills. Work/life balance is great, and as a corporate employee I've rarely had to work weekends or holidays.
cons: I would love to see a profit sharing program. In years prior, employees had the option to purchase company stock in their 401K plan, this option no longer exists.

title: Excellent resume builder
pros: If you work hard, and have the right work ethic the compensation will certainly show for it. Coworkers are all very close knit and it feels very much like a family. Upper management DM's and higher are all great, very friendly and will push you to meet your expectations. If you don't want to work for your recognition, and be competitive in your sales then this is not the job for you; as a property manager and KTP there is a lot of responsibility and some stress involved but it takes the right mindset to handle and if you love helping people learn about a company you believe in then it is a piece of cake. There are yearly bonus incentives based on sales numbers which are generous if you are within the top percentile of sales within your region, as well as yearly raises also based on performance.
cons: Sometimes the customers are very difficult to deal with, even as a property manager and KTP (which is as high as you can go as a field associate) there is no power to make any decisions; everything must be escalated to DM for approval. There is room to move up through the field but after KTP you're at a dead end. There is no such thing as hiring from within, and you cannot advance after you make it to key training professional, which results in a somewhat high turnover rate for retaining valuable employees that the company should not want to lose.

title: Overall a good company to work for.
pros: As a current Property Manager for a little over 5 years and Key Training Professional for 2 years I have been satisfied with my job. If you like meeting and helping people but know the meaning of hard work then this is the place for you. Great hours for life after work. I have been under the direction of several DM'S while in my career with PS and have made many new friendships with coworkers that are now like family. It takes hard work and the right mindset to make this company and job work for you so therefore it is not for everyone. But if you give it your all and have a great work ethic then you will find a lasting place with PS. And the award pays off in the long run.
cons: The pay is not the greatest and yes it could be more for all that you do. You are pressured to make numbers which is overwhelming at times. And promoting from within is not done. Once you get to the Property Management or Key Training Professional level this is as far as you will go. And laziness of others is allowed which puts even more work on the individuals that really care about the company and our success.

title: The other shoe dropped
pros: People seem to really get along with each other. There is free food from time to time.
cons: It's a sales job where non-sales calls work hurt your numbers. You also have to compete with the website (which has lower prices), so you have to compete with the company itself for sales. The bonus structure constantly changes. Working holidays is mandatory, if you are scheduled for it, and there is no overtime or holiday pay. Either people have been there for a few months or almost 10 years, there doesn't seem to be an in-between, and it seems every day someone is quitting.

title: Public Storage has excellent promotional opportunities
pros: I have been with Public Storage and have really enjoy and thrive in the performance based environment. I have been able to move up in the organization after starting as a DM and have seen many others move up as well.
cons: Base pay is good but in some major metro markets base pay could be higher due to the cost of living

title: What a joke! They post tons of opening and virtually impossible to get hired
pros: Lots of job "opportunities" and the positions look to be good
cons: Way too many job postings, makes you wonder how many District Managers they turnover and why

title: Quit mid-shift because of my district manager
pros: All in all, not a bad company to work for! Bi-monthly pay results in big checks when you work the amount of hours I racked up in each pay period. I love the ability to self manage your time and work load. The independence of not having higher ups breathing over you. They allow you to make your own daily plan based on the work load on a given day.
cons: Some days the work load is literally unbearable. When tenants leave property behind the ONE relief/property manager working that day is responsible for disposing of it properly. There is an option to put in a maintenance request to have it removed but the list of requests is so long it takes weeks and sometimes MONTHS to get taken care of. Customers are either super cool, or TERRIBLE and rude. Depending on location, the lots can take a serious toll on your vehicle. There is only so much any one individual can get done in a shift, and a lot of customers have no sense of empathy towards the situation so they tend to talk to you like garbage. Rent increases also contribute to the attitudes received. Gates always seem to be broken and again, maintenance requests can sit for months at a time sometimes. It can get pretty rough. My personal experience was more negative than anything because of my unique experience with my direct district manager. He had no sense of empathy to peoples personal lives so when I got pregnant during employment he expected me to still preform every work function to my usual ability. I was still maintaining the most important daily functions and working more than my energy level approved of, but with a baby on the way I did it. HE alone is the reason for me quitting.

title: Flexible, but dead-end, moral is very low among teams, walk outs happen.
pros: Job has its relaxed moments. Beginning and end of the month are rushed, but the middle of the month is slow and allows for a slow paced day and tasks to be done at your own discretion.
cons: The company is very forward about never giving raises. Higher ups come off as unmotivated which creates a hopeless work environment where no one feels the need to do their job. Communication is lacking between higher ups and Management. Often I won’t get responses to emails.
