Schedule comes out with little to no advance warning, only 2 to 3 days before the work week starts, often I’ve found myself not knowing I work until the day before the shift.

title: It's a job where you are allowed to do anything
pros: Nice and constant work hours. Ability to live onsite, so you don't have to drive to work and home. Coworkers make this job fun.
cons: Customers tend to come in at the last minute so you have to stay late quite often. Pay sucks unless you get an apartment. Customers can be really rude and hard to deal with. Bonus pay has gotten worse and worse every year. Living onsite means customers can bug you at any time. Puic storage wants you to help the customers, but ties your hands, by not allowing you to waive late fees or get items fixed on property.

title: Cheap and Greedy Corporation.
pros: Worked with some great hard working people that make the best out of work.
cons: Another cheap and greedy corporation. Look up corporate greed in the dictionary and you will find Public Storage there. Keeps cost low for Wall Street investors. Low care about workers making a living wage. Insurance after 6 months of work. .25 cent raises. Low $10-$12 pay. Most places have no security cameras, or ways to combat many of the rude, and dangerous customers. Low budget work environment. Corp will push you to sell everything but do not reward you for the effort.

title: Property Manager, South Carolina
pros: The team of people that I work with in the district that I am in are great. We are team players, and when another property needs help there is always someone stepping up to the plate to help. And of course it helps that we have the greatest District Manager that there is. Working with the public you do meet lots of different people, so it is very important to be a people person.
cons: tantly being recognized for doing a good job.

title: Corporate Office Employee
pros: Public Storage hires talented staff with strong backgrounds in their specific field. Everyone comes from different industries and they bring in new and fresh ideas to create a more effective and efficient workplace. Work-life balance is great as long as you put in the hard work.
cons: Some employees have shared that there is lack of upward mobility. However, I still give the company 5 stars because I have not witnessed any cons myself.

title: Not too terrible.
pros: This job has decent hours and you do accrue paid time of based on hours worked. Love the customer interaction.
cons: No advancement opportunities. Beyond being a trainer, there are no advancement opportunities. They do not hire district managers from within. You work by yourself most of the time. They have traditional fixed hours, but days off change weekly. Yearly bonus that you cannot track to see if you will receive it.

title: Not to bad so far but I've only been here 4 months
pros: I personally like the fact that we get to work alone or with one other person. It can be a little lonely at times. There is about 4 hours of work in an 8 hour day , sometimes less so that gives you an option of going back to school because you have time to do homework at work. The hours are nice , 930 to 6 no overnight. Pretty good insurance benefits.
cons: No room for growth, I've been here 4 months and I'm already a property manager but unfortunately that's as high as there is to go because they don't hire within for the upper management jobs. Pay is pretty awful, I make 10.50 an hour and when I got hired it was made clear that the pay was non negotiable. If you live in an apartment at one of the properties you basically get paid 8 an hour because they charge you to live there and watch THEIR property, it's ridiculous. It's been very obvious that the people that make the wages and rules don't care about who they are making the wages and rules for. I don't make enough money to pay bills like car , phone insurance etc, AND live in a place of my own so I live with my parents at 28 years old. Which is why I put in the pros that there is time to do homework because if you ever want to make more than 10.50 an hr you are going to have to go to school. The thing is, is that the things we deal with and the kind of work , even if it's only 4 hours of work in an 8 hour day, deserves more than what they are willing to offer. There are lots of angry customers that upper management won't deal with and won't call back so we are the ones that get yelled at. Property and relief managers are on the front lines but don't get paid or treated like we are.

title: Working at Public Storage
pros: The Pros about working for public storage. 1. As a property manager, you don't have more than 2 bosses. Your main boss is your DM. (district manager) 2. You are able to work at your own pace, but with time limits, and that's were time management comes in. 3. If you need help, other PM's there always a phone call away.
cons: Haven't found a con yet!

title: Great company providing profitable and stable career
pros: I have been with Public Storage for little over 3 years and absolutely love the culture, stability and work life balance. Company has always treated me fairly and made me feel valuable. Public Storage continues to grow! I enjoy the timely feedback which is very important for the growth within the company. I worked in retail environment for over 12 years and finally made decision to join the company and absolutely love it!
cons: I cannot think of one at this time

title: Supervisor Corporate Office
pros: Overall the company is a good place to work. The people at Public Storage are very hard working both in the office and out in the field. They are a very ethical company and I appreciate and admire the high caliber of experienced executives who have been with PS for many years. The company is stable and growing strategically.
cons: Benefits are expensive and they could provide for more paid time off such as holidays and sick time.

title: Great company to work for with room to grow!
pros: Retail environment without the long retail hours Extensive training program for all employees from hourly associates to District Managers Competitive pay and bonus program for District managers Attractive Bonus program for hourly associates Great benefits available including 401k! Team environment with a great culture
cons: No real cons to speak of. Best decision I made, making the change from a "typical" retailer to the Storage industry.

title: Dont get Comfortable
pros: Not hard work for good pay. Easy to learn the pay is the best part overall
cons: Upper management, they lie to you and say there's room to grow with in but dont Promote within. If you dont keep track of your pay and mileage they will cheat you out your money. They use you but don't raise your pay with all the responsibility they give you.

title: Unfair payroll system
pros: The best reasons to work at Public Storage is, if you like to work unsupervised and have the responsibility to manage your own location.
cons: Some downsides of working Public Storage, is that you get paid only on the 7th and the 22nd of each month. Also you work as a security/IRS, where you have to make phone calls to DTM customers who don't make there monthly payments.

title: Not the worst but dont see myself working here long term .
pros: 38-39 hours a week 5 days a week 12 starting with 50 cent raise after 6 mo Health and dental n vision benefits
cons: No same days off per week Alot of work for 12 per hr Makes you sell insurance with no commision Corparation ran Communication with upper management Little to no Advancement

title: Not for long term
pros: Opportunity to gain different useful skills. If just starting out this is a good place. Gives some management qualities, as well as team building when available. No late nights/early morning...but EVERY weekend
cons: Scripted...scripted...scripted. Everything here is a script and if it is not done correctly it all effects "bonus" potential. The salary is ridiculous and the opportunity for growth is worse. There is not growth past property manager, which does not come with a pay increase...go figure.

title: Relief Manager
pros: Not a bad job...pretty easy to learn and do.
cons: Benefits are not very competitive, time off is awful. Health benefits are too expensive.

title: Horrible
pros: Possibly nice co-workers but most properties only have 1 person at a time and turnover is so bad you won't get to know most of them.
cons: Everything.. Bad pay, forced to work 6 days a week when short staffed. EXTREMELY MICRO-MANAGED! Some examples are if you don't sell a new rental a lock or insurance you have to call your district manager to explain why - after EACH TIME. If you don't meet your google review quota you have to attend a conference call EVERY DAY explaining why you haven't gotten your quota. Absolutely ridiculous.

title: Avoid
pros: No evenings. Decent Medical If Single. Chance to make a positive impact in some people's lives while they are in transition. Not micro-managed, except when numbers are poor.
cons: Driven to sell, sell, sell. If you don't sell, you are admonished and have to endure corrective action just because someone doesn't want your locks, insurance, or merchandise. The way storage insurance is sold borders on the unethical. Some properties scary and occasionally staffed by one person. Older properties have possibility of leaks and security lapses. Possibility of burnout and exhaustion real.

pros: Never a minute of boredom. Relaxed work clothing while working. Opportunity to advance and make $32,000 year bonus.
cons: Of course, for each pro, there is an equal con. Never a minute of boredom. Not on weekends, at nights, on your paid time off (when you are told to ensure your phone and computer are nearby to work) Contrary to what some of the other HR people have posted, there is ZERO work/life balance. Cannot be unavailable at any time on the weekends without having your regional manager OKing it. Including going to the movies. Seriously. Relaxed clothing. You'll need it. You will be cutting locks with grinders and drills. Roughly 150 per month. You also have 10 properties to auction off people's belongings. Walking each property, rain or shine. You will have to treat your best employees poorly. We have stopped giving raises to resident property managers. New ones will have to be at minimum wage, forever. Try using that to retain your best help. Opportunity to advance. Because everyone is replaceable. You, your boss. People come and go constantly. Nearly 50% turnover in the DM position. Don't let them fool you about work ethic and such. They know your shelf life is roughly 2 years and will work you to the bone until then. Lastly, company philosophy on almost everything. They refuse to spend money on ANYTHING, yet tenants get yearly rent increases, significant amounts, 15% or more. So many SCRIPTS, that I am surprised the hourly turnover isn't higher than the 75% it is. (Our region pushed past 110% this year)

title: DON'T APPLY HERE UNLESS YOU REALLY NEED A JOB
pros: You are able to run your own store. I like the hours of operation.
cons: Too much cleaning. Especially the location I work at. Always finding pee stains & pee bottles everywhere. If you apply here, PROCEED WITH CAUTION

title: Sturdy, expanding company that you can rely on
pros: Expanding and growing industry with the leading experts and leaders on your side. Job stability is hard to come by these days, but as long as you work hard and stay dedicated to doing your work better each day, you can expect this company to be here. It's a creative environment where you can put your knowledge and skills to the test.
cons: Few holidays off (but your PTO grows instead), seemingly-long days (which make them go by fast), and high expectations (which make you a better worker).

title: Ok job but too stressful
pros: Hours, working alone, property apartments
cons: Scripts, manipulating customers, have to do everything, no maintenance or cleaning crew, selling peoples stuff at auctions,too much pressure and not enough money, dishonest company

title: Overall good company
pros: Good pay starting. Ability to earn commission. Work from home.
cons: Too many mandatory overtime days in a row. 9 and ten hour days 5 days in a row is a bit much. It’s hard to plan a life around working 10 hour days.

title: Wonderful work place
pros: Great work hours, no night work you will be home with your family in time for dinner. Paid time off. Other employees in the company are like family we work as a team. Great work environment.
cons: Some days you are really busy with many people coming into the office.

title: Public Storage: All about money, could give 2 craps about their employees
pros: No nights... that's about it.
cons: Low pay for all the crap you have to deal with from customers, unclean work sites, dangerous work sites (not to scare anyone but I was robbed at gunpoint!), company puts you in compromising situations by not having locked cash drawers, security cameras, security, usable bathroom facilities (had to go to a grocery store on break to use the bathroom because the one on site had splattered feces everywhere)

title: No room for moving up
pros: Hours, pto, possibility of an apartment, relatively easy work (physically)
cons: There is no promotions from within the company. If you start as a relief manager the highest position you will ever climb to is a training property manager. They always higher district managers from outside the company who often do not know how storage works. They continuously change the bonus program to benefit company keeping more money in their pockets not their employees.

title: World Class Organization
pros: Public Storage is an excellent company to work for. As a whole they act with integrity and know how to drive business results year after year in a competitive self-storage industry. Public Storage has a commitment to providing career advancement to individuals who work hard and achieve results through determination.
cons: Public Storage is a structured company that gives you all the tools necessary to succeed. The most successful individuals are those that thrive in a structured environment.

title: Property Manager
pros: Worked alone managing property with no direct supervision. Checked in with District Managers but no constant micro managing.
cons: Working far from Management was not always good, sometimes it would take days for requests that went above my decission.

title: My Public Storage Experience
pros: I have been working for this company for about a year and four months and its really been a pleasure. Aside from great pay this company offers flexiable work shifts, and full time positions. Something that attracked me here is that they give everyone an equal chance. Since working for this company not only expand my experience with 1 on 1 customer service but it gave me an opportunity to grow with the company and become a Property Manger.
cons: nothing I can think of

title: Great job, so so company.
pros: Lots of freedom to do the job as you see fit, with little to no direct oversite. A position of trust that requires integrity and work ethic.
cons: The pay is mediocre. The company doesn't get maintenance done because if too much of the budget is spent, the regional manager won't get their bonus. And that includes work needed on the employee apartments. When maintenance IS done, its done by the lowest bidder with shoddy workmanship and patch jobs that dont last. PS is too concerned about the bottom line.

title: Public Storage is an AWESOME place to work.
pros: Steady work Great management Very easy to move up Promotes daily goals Allows you to evaluate your customer service skills I LOVE IT
cons: Being a relief manager is hard having to travel to different properties daily Being a property manager is a difficult task with a lot of responsibility Customer can be extremely rude but it challenges you to remain calm

title: Outstanding culture of leadership and integrity!!
pros: If you want a culture of integrity, passion, and outstanding leadership, Public Storage is for you! The development of each and every person in the organization is taken very seriously and is the foremost responsibility of all of our leadership teams.
cons: After almost 9 years here at Public Storage the only thing I would like to see change would be the streamlining of data access points, whether retrieval or entry. Other than that, I would not change a thing!

title: Property Manager
pros: No micro-management, you basically manage the property by yourself and have relief managers to help on the busiest days of the month.
cons: Salary is way too low for this type of job and everything you are required to do (etc. Leasing, sales, collections, cleaning rental units...) Employees come and go frequently. For instance, in the first year I saw 7 people leave and 6 get hired. No promotions to a higher level.

title: Run from this company!
pros: Pay is okay, decent benefits, bonus & stock if you can survive long enough to see it, not much travel
cons: AWFUL CULTURE, (and by the way, those gleaming 5* reviews are fake, once you work here, you'll see what I mean. Pool work / Life balance, never a break, managing underpaid, unmotivated employees with no incentive, you truly are a # here, upper management does not care & are just in it for the bonus, poorly maintained facilities, major turn over on DM and hourly employee level, you really are over worked here, plan on never getting quality time off, the hourly employees are miserable, you are a slum lord to the resident managers, mandatory Saturday & Sunday each month On Top of a full work week for 6-7 months out of the year, plan on a 65-70 hour work week, always threatened with losing your job, plan on being maxed out & stressed out, you really have to do everything here / most companies have other employees to do certain things like training & coaching, repairs & maintenance, basic customer service, accounts payable & receivable (this list goes on & on) but here at PS, EVERYTHING falls on the DM lap, and one mistake & you're fired. Nobody seems to be happy, everyone is miserable & bashes this company (I get that every company has this, but it's excessive here) hence the turnover! Don't fall for that "we're growing" BS, they are growing, but people quitting is the REAL problem here. Constantly told what's wrong, but nobody offers to help, there's no development here, it's an electric fence of performance with unrealistic goals. You get little or no support from management or corporate, they all just slam down on the field, and everyone just points fingers & looks for someone to blame, you have no voice here.

title: Great company to work for!
pros: Great opportunity for growth - the team is focused on people development. Spending time in the field, coaching employees, and improving the business on a daily basis - no company does it better.
cons: The expectations are very high - if you embrace the challenges and work hard, you will achieve the goals you have set for yourself

title: Fun organized environment
pros: Great environment great staff great customer relationships, management is great very homey environment . Very helpful and educational when it comes to learning the business.
cons: The pay should be at least 11:50 or 12.00 employers should be able to move up within the company if your employer is working very hard and understands the business

title: Avoid Public Storage!
pros: Continuous opportunity for OT, ability to work alone
cons: No advancement, terrible pay, worked like slaves, company has no interest in you. Public Storage has no real interest or care for their employees or their customers. People will need storage=>we'll keep increasing prices=>money goes to stockholders. The only investment back into the company is buying out smaller storage companies, hiring District Managers, who hire grunts to work them. Once they run a location into the ground they just bulldoze it and build a bigger one. You will never advance and you will never be more than a number.

title: Your happiness depends on your DM
pros: great hours decent pay to start PTO
cons: Lack of communication with DM Left to fend for yourselves practically if DM thinks a topic is unimportant Constant visits from higher ups, causing major stress No room for growth What they want you to do is not in your pay grade.

title: Terrible Pay
pros: The location I worked at was very nice
cons: Terrible pay for what is expected from each employee. You have to not only clean toilets, mop floors but you are constantly dealing with people that are not always the best of character. You are expected to be a janitor, plumber, maid,social worker, law enforcement and so many more things. Then if you are fortunate enough to become a Property Manager, well it does not come with a raise. I will Never understand this.

title: Don't work for Public Storage.
pros: You work alone most of the time.
cons: The bogus "medical plan" for hourly workers. Upper management are provided excellent medical benifits. Can't figure out why there's a difference between "us" and "them".... No room for growth. Most managers are forced to live on-site, taking a MAJOR paycut. The company does not care for their employee's safety. Nothing gets repaired on the properties in a timely manner. Customer complaints are basically ignored until the customer gets tired of complaining and goes away. Employees are required to make afterhours bank drops off the clock. We were offered stock options in company stock, but they quickly cut that out!

title: DO NOT TAKE A POSITION WITH THIS COMPANY!
pros: IF YOU ARE A SHAREHOLDER...SOLID STOCK PRICES.
cons: They pride themselves on overworking and underpaying employees. Any positive reviews have to be HR plants to mislead you. Toxic CEO manages by fear and intimidation and will fire anybody who disagrees with him. Management follows his lead. The meager benefits (3 paid holidays per year) are progressively downgraded to maximize shareholder profits and on principle. Last year employees were robbed of their sick days. It doesn't matter what position you are considering...your self respect will be destroyed....DON'T DO IT!

title: Do not ruin your resume being a District Manager for Public Storage
pros: The salary is very good. Bonuses are great if they don't fire you before you can collect.
cons: This is a temporary job. There is a 90% turn on the DM position. Public Storage constantly hires "Bench District Managers" to learn the job of a DM and then take over when one is fired. Within 2 years I watched over 20 District Managers get fired for no reason. You will sign an agreement that you agree you can be terminated for no reason at any time. Taking a job with PS will ruin your resume because it will show a short length of time and it is bottom barrel multi level management working for a storage company. Do not let the one year of a good salary tempt you. Public Storage has a "No references allowed" policy, so do not expect a reference upon your departure. Regional Vice Presidents do not want anyone good to stand out and possibly take their job, so they fire you. Even if you are one of the very top performers in consecutive quarters - you will be fired. #1 They don't want to give out raises and bonuses to those doing so well and there are 3 or 4 fully trained "Bench DM's" waiting for placement. #2 The Regionals do not want a DM to outshine them. #3 It's difficult to build a team of successful YOY Property Managers because Public Storage does not promote Property Managers. As a DM you will have to find and hire people that are ok with being paid $9.50 per hour with zero chance of advancement.

title: Very decent employment...
pros: We have a very supportive District Manager who works hard to help us with anything we need. Our district works well as a team and we have fun while working hard. They offer contests and other incentives on a regular basis for a little extra money in our pockets. They coach from a positive perspective. Nobody gets yelled at or embarrassed by management. We work independently and are not 'baby-sat'. We are trusted to run our stores and do the job. I always have plenty of PTO time to use and our DM does his very best to accommodate our needs. Not one person was 'let go' when the economy 'tanked' a few years ago. We all kept our 40 hours. If you don't like to work hard, this is not the job for you. Sometimes a lot is expected of us, but that works well for me. Some of the sites offer company apartments with paid utilities, which has saved me a great deal of money in living expenses over the years.
cons: I don't have too many complaints about the job, except for the extensive paper-trail we are required to keep; and getting 'called in' like in other typical retail environments when people don't show for their shifts. I have never been pressured or required to do this, though. There can be a heavy work-load at times, so if you are looking to 'ride the clock', this is not the job for you. All-in-all, very solid job. I am grateful to the company for the opportunities they have given me during my employment here.

title: It is great to be part of a solid and successful company.
pros: One of the most efficient, productive and economical company. Hires the best and brightest in the industry. I am very fortunate to be apart of this organization. This makes my job interesting and challenging. Plenty of learning opportunities. Great working environment were everyone is professional and courteous to one another. Very family oriented company. Many loyal employees who dedicated many years of service to the company.
cons: Health benefits could be better.

title: Great job thus far.
pros: Public storage offers Great benefits for employees, Nice work hours, Good pay, occasionally has apartments rent free for property managers, and an even layer of working independantly and as a team.
cons: Everything you do is scripted to a tee which can be hard and a bit overwhelming at times. They push for your numbers to look great which is also a struggle sometimes. Cannot advance through company.

title: Ok place to work
pros: Independent work most of the time, not too busy, great coworkers at other properties to help you out, good sales experience
cons: No bonuses/raises of any kind ever, its corporate job so its tough to get maintenace on property approved so you have to deal with customer complaints over simple things, hard to want to work hard when great work goes unnoticed, company does not promote internally

title: Customer Service
pros: The company has great benefits and great employees. I love the opportunity to work with customers from all over, a great family of coworkers and a great management support system. I get a chance to do administrative duties, outside work and working one on one with my team. I like that we get an opportunity to move around within district to see other stores and is a company that you can work for any where in the US no matter how family life changes.
cons: Work on Holidays and weekends

title: An organization that has it backwards
pros: You will be forced to improve your time management and prioritization skills. Those who do not focus on this will be left behind.
cons: Every publicly traded organization has three customers to prioritize: 1) the Wall Street customer (investors) 2) the external customer (those who purchase goods/services) and 3) the internal customer (the employee). Public storage has prioritized them in exactly that order. All questions, complaints, and concerns are looked at through a lens of "what will this do to the bottom line?" As a previous shareholder I can appreciate a focus on yielding returns and dividends, but as a former internal customer it was clear there was no balance in decision making. Front-line employees are paid minimum wage, or barely above, and asked to do unthinkable tasks due to the nature of the work. When asked why pay increases were so rare and unlikely, the response always referred back to Senior Leaderships approach that we can always "find more minimum wage people out there." As an internal employee that led front-line employees, you act as every department. You're required to lead R&M efforts, manage payroll, recruit vendors, handle customer escalations, manage IT issues, work with Legal department, manage operational projects, etc... There are NO SUPPORT PARTNERS to aid in any aspect of your job. Successful organizations have layers of support built in to support their most important customer: the internal one. Public Storage elects to remove those layers to reduce costs. There are no pay raises for any level of leadership. There is an annual offer of Restricted Stock Units that required 5 years minimum to vest and are consistently reducing in value due to the stock price falling. The work conditions are horrible and the environment is toxic for anyone with an executive maturity level seeking to grow their career. As a district manager your phone is never off. Minimum wage employees that realize they're not valued simply can't be reliable. District Managers are required to do the entry-level position at work as a Property Manager when the staffing model restricts payroll and resources. There were countless times where a peer or I had to work at a property and do our "day job" simultaneously. This is not a CAREER. This is a JOB that is designed to churn and burn when your best work is completed with promises of promotion that are not fulfilled.

title: Former employee
pros: Its a good job if you dont like working in large groups. Also theres always something to do. It definitely keeps you busy. Once your a property manager you can live on site rent and utility free.
cons: It can be very stressful at times. The relief managers only make 25 cents more an hour then the property managers but still have to do just as much work as the property managers.

title: Working at Public Storage
pros: Working for Public Storage is great honestly, pay is okay hours are good and you receive bonuses threw out the month so extra money is always a plus.
cons: I have not experienced anything bad so far working with the company so no cons on my end. I’m not saying this is the perfect job but I haven’t had any problems since I have been here. Everyone has been nice since I started working and I have made a lot of new friends

title: Our best days are ahead of us. A great place to work.
pros: I wanted to comment on Public Storage and provide some thoughts as my outlook is very positive. When I am interviewing prospective candidates, a question that I am regularly asked without fail is “What do I like most about the company?” My reply is always the people I work with. Full disclosure, I am in a management position, but whether it’s the property personnel I interact with, DMs, Regional Managers, Corporate Execs or Support, there is a common trait within our organization, and that is we pride ourselves on hard work. Public Storage fosters a strong culture of teamwork and a palpable desire to provide support to each other, at all levels within the organization. For those that are willing to learn, remain challenged and bring their best selves to work each day will do very well here. Furthermore, Public Storage is a company that is growing, and that makes this an incredibly dynamic place to work. With strong leadership, very little debt, a keen desire to grow intelligently coupled with the enviable position of the market leader – for all these reasons and more, it reinforces my decision to be here. The opportunities are present for hourly employees to take on more challenging roles as well; agreeable full-time hours allow for the opportunity to go to school and a high quality of life; and on-site apartments allow living accommodations in desirable markets. For District Managers, with our incredible growth, comes the opportunity to move into higher-level positions with increased responsibility. In short, Public Storage presents a very dynamic environment that will reward those who are willing to learn and put in the time and effort. Are we perfect? No. But few organizations are. Is it a place work making a living or building a career? Absolutely.
cons: We are growing and with change comes discomfort at times. But the fact that we are willing to look at how we operate and reassess our business, this I view as very positive. A stable, veteran CEO, a dynamic COO, excellent Executive Leaders, a thoughtful HR team, plus a workforce that is for the most part highly engaged, all help to keep our company pointed in the right direction.

title: The worst company ive ever been apart of
pros: Will hire with some customer service background , will allow you to gain entry level management experience
cons: The district management will treat you horribly, they talk to you( adults) as if you are less than human. They have unrealistic company metrics that are unattainable for majority of properties. The district managers dont and refuse to understand the full scope of the relief/ property mansger job. Worst of all the incite fear amongst employees with divide and conquer tactics.

title: My personal opinion
pros: You do not have to deal with any boss on top of you but in the end the one who works or has worked in a storage company knows that you are your own supervisor.
cons: honestly if you have the need to work in this company is still looking, but if you do not have another then nothing luck. They do not consider the employee and do not give the opportunity for growth and to talk about what they give you apartment or bonus.

title: District Manager
pros: + Successful company + Results driven environment. You are responsible for achieving results. + Work Life Balance + Great for people who love to work in a competitve environment and enjoy coaching employees on Sales and Customer Service
cons: Be aware that this position requires you to be competent with Facilities. As a District Manager, you are responsible for vendor management and securing competitive bids.

title: It's a job
pros: You get 39 hours a week and have job security, most of the time you are working alone or with one coworker as management does not stay in one location
cons: You wear many hats in this job for little pay. There's no upward growth even for being property manager you still make the same starting wage. You are front desk customer service, phone collections, janitor, merchandise salesman, and social media manager. I have been threatened by customers multiple times and management doesn't really have any plans for those situations. All District Managers and above are hired from outside the company.

title: KTP-Property Manager
pros: Employee recognition. PS provides opportunity to utilize your skills in the customer service field. I have grown with this company three times in the three years I’ve been employed PS is a GREAT place to work if you want opportunity for growth. they are dedicated to their employees and customers.
cons: CurrentlyI have no cons about PS

title: Administrative job - No Leadership
pros: Good compensation package when stock is granted. Properties are closed at 6 so few calls after closing.
cons: Everything is micromanaged. DMs and RMs don't have much decision making ability; they are administrators and just stamp things for approval that adhere to very narrow company guidelines. Property managers and DMs make less each year due to reduced bonuses and stock.

title: Corporate Office
pros: Been working for Public Storage since 1989 and I've known my co-workers in my department for about the same amount of years (25+) and we've enjoyed each other as a tight team. The ability to get along well with each other is key to a positive environment and the leadership fosters a spirit of camaraderie.
cons: I hate driving in traffic especially with the ongoing freeway construction along Interstate 5 but I learned to make use of my time while in the car.

title: Reviews are Misleading! But not the negative ones for this company.
pros: Pay for DM’s was good over the years. If you started in the early days and managed money well, you are in great shape. In addition, there were some great leaders to learn from....oh wait, they usually get fired once the CEO hears them say one thing he doesn’t agree with. This is NOT an opinion nor isolated to one instance. Anyways, thanks to those great leaders who provided a wealth of knowledge!
cons: As a previous DM and RVP with this company, please do not fall in to this trap. The stock grants were so good in the past that it used to make misery worth it, but now the measly 12 share per year vest is simply not worth the stress. Also, ethics and integrity are out the window here. If you are over 40 with tons of multi unit experience, you need not apply. Hiring managers are coached to label you as “ downside of career” which is their way of saying “too old.” Perhaps the EEOC should be alerted to these practices?Also, they realize that you are most likely too smart to put up with the craziness. Instead, they like to hire young, give them a life changing salary and wait for them to burn out. They will just get more when they need to. If you hate taking care of customers, this is the place for you because you don’t have the authority to do so. Try explaining to customers why PS (billion dollar company)has not replaced a 30 yr old roof that is supposed to protect their belongings. Or why a brand new building has mold because the company didn’t want to pay for dehumidifiers . Please pay close attention to the great reviews from the RVP’s and DM’s . Look at the dates when they come in. Funny that they come in around the same days??? It is a directive from above to try and increase ratings and they are simply not true. If you do come here, hope for a great leader that can filter the corp direction well. Also, don’t be fooled by a DM title. You are in control of very little. Think “high paid baby sitter.” Your turnover will be high unless you have the cash to incentivize your team out of your own pocket. Some great people along the way, but some really horrible people as well.

title: Amazing Company
pros: Public Storage has been an amazing fit for me personally. They truly care about you as an individual. They provide coaching and feedback that allows everyone on the team to get better on a daily basis. The work life balance is great. This allows you time to spend with your family. Moving to Public Storage was the best decision I made over four years ago. I recommend this to everyone.
cons: None that I can share currently

title: Access to customers' property
pros: - if you store it, we can take it - non-working video cameras - shady circle of friends and associates - no repercussions or accountability
cons: - the fear of retribution by angry customers

title: Large company that's always trying to reinvent itself
pros: Excellent benefits for senior employees, diversified workforce, strong company with large infrastructure, number one in it's industry.
cons: Priorities are always changing, lost sight of their core business, operations are run like a much smaller company with a lot of micromanagement, too much turnover in middle management really effects customer service and employee training.

title: Horrible compay to work for.
pros: There are no pros. There is nothing positive to say. Read all reviews. This is a company that had the HR Directors call new District Managers to ask them to write positive reviews on Glass Door because the reviews they had were horrible.
cons: Honestly...there are no pros to working here. There is no home/work balance. It's all work. They expect their district managers to work 24/7, and have even made statements that this job "is not 8 to 6 anymore...you must do work before 8 and after 6". You really do have to work long days--the expectation is high and so is the workload. Unfortunately the pay is not. There is a base commute that they take out of your mileage so this leaves you driving all over and receiving pennies for your travel. The expectations on the property managers are great, but their pay borders on the poverty level. Public Storage is very well run and is extremely profitable, but this comes at the cost of the employees. There is little to no recognition. The CEO stated at an annual conference that the company is "puking cash". What a fantastic statement to make in front of managers brought to the meeting making minimum wage or slightly above. One property manager commented to us that if the company is puking cash how come none of the lights work outside on her property and nothing ever gets repaired. They promote heavily from the DM level and above, but you need to be a favorite of the Regional VP--you don't necessarily have to be the smartest, or best at your job, but you sure need to be liked by the Regional. They have hired many new district managers all over the country and this is really the direction they are moving in. New blood--in with the new and out with the old. If you are great at driving results by beating your team down this is the job for you! Just keep asking them to get you those results by giving them nothing in return. Think twice before you accept the position. They will sell you on the company and how they run the business, but once you're in you will regret your choice. I work in an area where most of the DMs are overwhelmed and very unhappy. Health benefits are horrible--of course because they just don't care.

title: Great opportunity, and nice work environment
pros: Following guidelines to lease storage units and sell merchandise. Mostly have to be self-driven and building strong relationships with our customers to give them five star experience. However, if you take pride of taking care your storage facility as manager is very enjoyable and satisfying.
cons: Public storage is leading industry in this category and the pay could be better compared the competitor.

title: Greedy company
pros: Set schedule and that’s it.
cons: Public storage is a company ran on greed. They do not care about their store level employees at all. Even with the current covid-19 situation they refuse to close their doors, adjust hours, or do anything to limit exposure to their employees. The bottom line with this company is make all the money at all costs. Even if it means putting their employees health at risk. No way of moving up in the company. No real growth.

title: Easy work, steady hours, below average compensation, and no loyalty to employees.
pros: You work steady hours and I found it enjoyable to have both office and outdoor work.
cons: Low wages, dead-end job. Generally speaking, I have noticed that in the storage industry you need to bounce around between companies in order to acquire new titles. Otherwise, I did not notice any in-house promotions. The property manager and relief manager positions are generally the same minus some direct responsibility by the latter.

title: Relief Manager
pros: Full Benefits Full-Time Bonuses Decent pay ($2/hr more than minimum wage)
cons: Close-knit (1 or two people per office) Versatile job duties (You do everything--the sales, the janitor jobs, the maintenance, the cleaning of units, etc.) Boring at times--real slow--and high paced other times. No in between. From personal experience, I was dealt with a terrible Regional Manager, who is the boos of the office. Some of the managers are the same. The managers constantly change districts. We had two managers in 1 year. No over-time.

title: Under paid
pros: There are no real pros about this job other then the hours
cons: To many to list, but worst is pay, then pay again, too much work, district manager is over paid and not helpful,

title: Beware of "staged" reviews!
pros: You are at least allowed to go home at 6pm. But I wouldn't say you're done working. The only positive thing I can think of is They pay you on time.
cons: Ok- notice how most of the recent reviews from October are from Regional Managers, claiming how "upper management" is so personable? That's because you won't find any other employees giving them that credit. That's false. They are so far out of reality. They never visit a property unless they are being visited from their bosses, then it's all a dog-and-pony show, and will flat out lie about being in the field with the employees. I literally have a Regional Manager that doesn't know half my team and has never been to 30% of my properties. Pay is very low compared to other District Managers at other storage companies. I know this because most of PS Managers leave for that very reason. For about 4 days each month, you're cutting locks all day. Other storage companies do not require DMs to cut locks. Look- turnover with Property Managers is so high, all you do as a DM is recruit and hire, and scramble to fill your schedules with a warm body to hopefully get your property open on time. This is causing the District Managers to start jumping ship because the work sucks. There are so many DMs leaving, or in the process of leaving, that I feel bad for the current DMs that will be having to run their own districts, plus keep others afloat since there will be open districts. Because of the high DM turnover, you are now seeing Regional Managers posting 5-star reviews on Glass Door hoping they can fool you into thinking this is a great company. There is no personal development here- nobody has the time.

title: Retired, but not Retired.
pros: Interaction with customers. Time goes fast as there is always plenty to do. Office work and physical labor, but not too demanding as to be burdensome. Work alone most of the time, great for self starters. No nights. Provide a need. Teamwork in district is good.
cons: Collections can be tiresome. Emotional customers can take out frustrations on you. Some employees do not have as high of standards as you. Can get stuck with bulk of cleaning chores.

title: Very low pay and no advancement
pros: Job security. It is very difficult to get fired here. No direct supervising.
cons: Low pay with no raises and bonuses get cut more each year. No advancement after a becoming a Property Manager making $13. Annual PTO accrual was also just cut, and health insurance switched to a plan with horrible coverage. Company is too large and cannot keep up with their 2,200 locations, so repairs never get done and customers are never happy. Company increases costs to customer constantly (merchandise, rent raises, late fees, ins. etc etc etc)

title: Currently employed for over 7 years now...
pros: This company offers great training programs and on the job experience in management, retail, and sales. All members of management and corporate level employees really care about each other's safety and overall job satisfaction throughout the company by offering great benefits, bonus programs, incentives, and opportunities to advance within the company.
cons: Challenges that can arise during a work day involve customer service issues or complaints. This company is all about customer happiness and satisfaction that upper management is always available to assist if help is needed in resolving issues.

title: Good for getting on your feet til you can do better
pros: Great shift, free apartment, easy simple job.
cons: Management puts too much unrealistic expectancies on you. They have no idea what's going on in the office until they run the office themselves. Half of the upper management staff can't even process a lease...

title: Property Manager
pros: I have some really amazing customers,the pay is good and the insurance benefits are even better!
cons: The only thing I would have negative to say it working at the same location can get a bit boring but there is always work to be done for sure!

title: Just like all storage companies!
pros: Benefits are good, ability to work by yourself, easy to keep busy.
cons: Pay, mileage reimbursement for employees that live far from properties, micromanaging, company is cheap with repairs and they take forever to get done, high rent raises and hardly any help available for customers, days off are inconsistent especially if you have a child. Good luck ever getting a weekend day off unless you're a favorite manager.

title: Not the best not the worst
pros: Flexible with time off and location
cons: Pay and management suck big time

title: District Manager
pros: Public Storage is a great Company to work for. The people are great! The training program is very thorough and the Company focuses on setting up all of their employees for success. I am proud to be on the Public Storage team.
cons: I do not have any cons for the Company. You will enjoy the job if you are competitive and you want to strive to be the best employee out there.

title: 8 years and still not bored.
pros: This is the best Retail has to offer. I truly enjoy my job. I have been able to make my store my own. I follow the company guidelines, I know my scripts. Yes you do have to learn scripts but I have found at every turn they help. They are just a way to know policy. I have had several DM's and they have all been very kind and understanding especially when it comes to family. Scheduling is very flexible and days off are primarily together. The company is stable and I know I will have my job for awhile. I have respect for upper management including the CEO. I have enjoyed great success because I like to take care of customers. The customers are always interesting. The success has been rewarded and I have been recognized as a leader within my group by both my peers and management. I have been both an onsite and offsite manager. The great part about being onsite is the commute, the bad part is that you are always at work, however, you are never required to work on your off time. The great part about being an offsite manager is you get to go home when the day is done. I am lucky because I have seen the effect I have had within my work groups. I have been around long enough to see a fair amount of change and it has all been good. When I first met Ron Havner I said "welcome to my store" and then I said "wait your store" He corrected me by saying it was "our store." That just about says it all.
cons: Like all large companies the processes to get things done can be slow.

title: Life at PS
pros: PS is a very stable company. It offers job security. This is the longest I've stayed in one company. The people are wonderful and welcoming. It's the right place for me.
cons: Working for PS requires you to work harder because of its numerous properties. If you are not willing to work hard, then this is not the place for you.

title: Terrible company
pros: Independent work environment . The job you don't deal with many customer . You don't see the supervisors as much . You're basically running the store alone .
cons: You're not about to grow I the company. Once you become a property manger that's it . The management here sucks . It's a big turnover rate . The pay sucks . You have many job titles .

title: Relief Manager
pros: It's a great environment to work, and to gain management skills. You do have your own independence to work, that's when you are capable of handling a property on your own. You learned a lot, if you fresh out of high school or in college. This will work for you, set hours but you have to be available to work any days of the week.
cons: There is no pros about working for this company, you just have to apply what you learned on training

title: 2+ Years Property Manager
pros: Independence, light workload, guaranteed hours
cons: Low pay, excessive downtime (gets old), corporate is pretty obvious about caring more about money than customers or employees, zero opportunity for advancement

title: Great company, Great culture, Great employees, Great career choice...
pros: Working for Public Storage as a District Manager was one of the best professional choices I have made. You are truly a business owner and have all the tools necessary to succeed and well as the autonomy to run your business uniquely. The culture is driven around development, training and learning on all levels. Great place to work.
cons: None. I enjoy my day to day.

title: Terrible Corporate Culture
pros: Your check. That's it. Though, when you add up the hours you put in, you'll find out that you're making a lot less per hour than you could at other organizations.
cons: The company culture is terrible. The executives couldn't care less about any of it's employees. To them, you are but a cog in the money making machine. Regional Managers (you're not VPs) think they're important, but really they are just losers that have become complacent in life and bought into the whole PS BS. They're good at taking orders from the Divisional Managers, who are the first level of management with any amount of authority. My Regional obsessed over the most trivial points, such as stickers on the front door, or the number of rolls of tape on the counter. Thinking outside the box to solve issues wasn't a possibility, because he didn't even realize he was in a box. I could detail all sorts of examples of why this company is terrible, but at the end of the day, I'd be just wasting my time. Frankly, this review is to counter one of the many FAKE reviews that are on here. Public Storage's HR department routinely asks employees being promoted to post positive reviews, as a condition of promotion. Clever. Know this, while you'll be tempted by the decent base salary, you're going to be working long, hard hours for it...doing mindless tasks....which repeat every month. Don't even for a second count on the bonus, it's tiered and capped, and easily manipulated by the executive team. Training is OTJ, and lackluster. You'll walk (more like run) away from this position with no additional skills, save for maybe cutting locks off doors, and you'll hate yourself for wasting your most precious resource with a thankless company, your time.

title: A dead end job.
pros: Hours (no nights), full time (38-39 hours), decent PTO accrual, benefits, set days off (depending on your DM), on-site apartment at some properties (if you're a property manager). The people you work with are, on average, the nicest people you'll know. I made some great friends. There is LOTS of down time in the office on slow days since we're not supposed to leave it closed for more than 15 minutes, so if you're a student you'll have time to study (though you'll get in trouble if you get caught.) Rainy days are best.
cons: Hooo boy. First off, the company used to be better. Go back 5 or 6 years and the bonuses and PTO payouts were MUCH better. Old time employees who'd been there a decade or more told stories of how there used to be company parties and trips to baseball games. No more. Over time, the company has shed practically every benefit. Bonuses used to be a major perk every quarter. Now they're a joke. Not even everyone gets one, and those who do generally get the lowest tier. Since it's based on DM preference rather than your numbers, if the DM doesn't like you, you aren't getting a bonus. PTO benefits have also been cut, and health costs have risen. All the while they ask more and more of the property level staff while telling them about how the company is puking money. It's great coming home to your little apartment broke, tired, and dirty knowing that you just made your company thousands of dollars that you'll never see. The job is a thankless, dirty one. You will usually work alone. This means you have to close the office to do anything outside (and you will be doing things outside), which will generally lead to angry customers. I was cursed out on several occasions by people who had to wait for me to return from a bank run or lunch. Speaking of lunch, many properties don't have break rooms. Since we wear uniforms, eating in your car is out (unless you like people knocking on your window!), so you have to eat in the office with people trying to peer through the door at you. I often ate sitting on the floor or in the bathroom to avoid this, as if customers catch sight of you, they'll start banging on the door. One of my coworkers actually got in trouble for ignoring a customer while on his state-mandated lunch break because the customer saw him and called customer service to complain. Explain that! There's no security. I dealt with transients, people with mental problems, and tweakers. As a rather petite woman, I was afraid to do lock checks on dark evenings, and I have no idea how people in the northern parts of the country do this job during the winter because of how early it gets dark. The properties are poorly lit so there are ample opportunities for something bad to happen. I carried mace. The properties are falling apart because the DMs aren't given money to order repairs. Doors were broken and difficult to open, parking lots were pitted, there were plumbing issues (three times this resulted in us having no bathroom), lighting issues, tripping hazards... You name it. We had elevators break, doors to buildings break... It was just unsafe. The equipment we're given are not designed for the heavy amount of work we do (sweeping out a 10x30 space with an office broom is awful). Most properties in my district had their golf carts taken away because the properties were "too small". I was often logging 3 miles plus on my pedometer, so I have no idea where they got this idea. Customers would show up in the rain and then complain that they had to walk to the space they wanted to rent. I had customers whine about having to walk in the heat of summer too. Good luck if you get someone who has a hurt leg or is old. We're not supposed to use our cars (though I often did). Customers are slobs and will leave cigarette butts and discarded furniture everywhere. I have dragged more dirty, gross mattresses to the dumpster than I care to remember. You will also come in contact with animal and human urine and feces. "Pee bottles" are a common occurrence. Without a golf cart, you'll be walking around with a garbage bag and broom during your lock check. If you find an empty space, congratulations! You get to trek back to the company space to get your kit to clean it. The company only wants you out of the office for 15 minutes at a time, by the way, so have fun doing this on days when you're alone. What ended up happening was that a lot of us just stopped cleaning the spaces on weekdays. If I had to rent it, I'd offer to clean it for the customer, but we generally would clean on Saturdays, when we had double coverage (if we were lucky enough to get it) Customers did the stupidest things, and then would get angry at you for it. They would move out without telling you and leave their lock on their space, expecting us to magically know they're done. They'd dump garbage and food on the property. They'd break into the restroom after hours and make a mess. Then they would complain about the property looking messy. They'll show up to rent a space with 5 minutes until the end of the day after you called them a hundred times throughout the day to schedule them an appointment. They'd wait until the last second to pay their bill and then would get mad at us if we were out to lunch or at the bank. Field staff have loads of metrics they're supposed to meet, as I hinted at above. Most are now clustered around sales of overpriced merchandise. Meeting them can be very easy or very hard depending on what property you're at and how busy you are. Slow property in a good area? Piece of cake. Busy property in the ghetto? Good luck. The company thinks that every property is the same regardless of location or clientele, so expect no sympathy from your bosses. You also have to sell locks and insurance, and both are overpriced. The locks are cheap Chinese steel with keys that often get stuck. We would open all of the locks up when we received them and test the keys just to make sure the locks weren't broken. The insurance is absolute junk. It barely covers anything and the limitations are ridiculous (if someone breaks into your space and steals your lock, guess what? Your insurance won't cover it because the lock is missing.) The worst thing in the world that can happen to you is getting stuck with a "dud", a person who wants to just move in and brings their own lock and refuses insurance or merchandise. Since there are no incentives for actually renting units, these people count against you. It pits you against your customer and makes you get angry with people just for being money smart. Left a bad taste in my mouth. GOOGLE REVIEWS. First it was 1 a month, then 2, then 4. They will harass you to no end if you don't meet your quotas. This especially sucks if you work multiple properties. You may work hard to meet the quota at one property just to rotate into one that has 0 reviews the next day. Guess what? You're going to get accusatory emails asking why you aren't doing your job right. Oh, AND you get to do calls! You will be on the phone almost as much as you're outside. You have prorate calls, auction calls, collection calls, confirmation calls, follow up calls... So many calls. Depending on your property, you may be doing 100+ calls a week. It's mind numbing, incredibly boring work, and you'll get sick of talking to the same people week after week. If you end up with lots of people who can't pay? That's your fault. One of our scripts for delinquency literally had us suggesting they borrow money from a friend or family member to pay their storage bill. You can guess how most people reacted to that. Since the job is miserable and pays near minimum wage, a lot of people don't actually do their jobs. Since the temptation to be lazy is strong, if you're not lazy you're going to be picking up the slack. Think that all sounds bad? Well, you get to do all of the above with scripts. That's right, PS has written scripts for practically every interaction you have with a customer. You'll rarely use them with real customers (oftentimes the customer would derail the script within two lines. It's hard to stick to a script when the other party isn't), but you'd better know them because the DMs will quiz you. This can happen at any time. They show up monthly to tour the property, but you can also get called out on conference calls. PLUS, they send out secret shoppers. Don't screw up a script on a secret shop, or you can be written up. This whole situation makes the job much more stressful than it needs to be. We on the ground knew how to do our jobs, but the company insisted we do it THEIR way, which was nearly impossible for some people. My numbers went down when using the scripts. Having a system that works that you're afraid to use makes the job nervewracking. The icing on the cake is that there's no room to advance. They don't hire from within, even if you have a degree. They also won't allow you to list your DM as a reference on a job application, and if you do, you will immediately have a target on your back. The moment PS knows you want out, they'll try to hack you off like a diseased limb. It is the literal definition of a dead end job.

title: Perks
pros: Great peers and coworkers. The Glendale building is clean, but dated. Plenty of outdoor parking.
cons: Public Storage seems to appreciate their employees with donuts and bagels. However, other perks have been slowly taken away. This would be from the period I was there of 2011 to 2013. I've heard it may be worse as employees I know there are finally jumping ship. No places to eat within walking distance (short), but you can walk like a mile to get some Del Taco.

title: Great place to work!
pros: Been working for Corporate for almost 30 years and I love working with the people and the company. Work time is flexible and management works with its people. Flat organization structure, great opportunity to interact with the senior management team. The company is in a strong financial position with many resources to use. Great people to work with. Enjoy coming to work every day. People are recognized for outstanding performance. Management leads by example.
cons: Not any to speak of

title: My experience with Public Storage has been wonderful.
pros: Great Management, Excellent Benefits, Work Life Balance, Residential Apartments, Starting salary above Minimum Wage, Referral Bonus Program.
cons: Shortage of Staff. Its difficult to be utilized elsewhere and for longer then 30 min when you normally work alone.

title: good compensation but not very satisfying
pros: You can make a decent paycheck and have flexible hours. This is a great job for college students of anyone looking to start in sales.
cons: Your time is extremely micromanaged because of call forecasting. Some management plays favorites. Pay structure changed often, one day you were making $25/ hr and the next you could make $12.

title: Key Training Professional
pros: Great hours, Great co workers.
cons: There is no room for growth. Once I got to the position I had I could not be promoted. I was told this company doesn't promote district managers within, they hire from other companies. After I have trained more than a handful of district managers.

title: Great work environment and Strong Company
pros: The people are great. Atmosphere is easy going. I'm able to balance work and personal life with ease. My commute is great. The company is solid. I'm happy and comfortable here.
cons: Nothing major, but do notice when little things here and there are no longer offered. It just gets the mind wondering about reasons why or might make one feel a little less valued?

title: Starting from the top, everyone wants you to be successful. They definitely lead by example.
pros: The teamwork is extraordinary. Everyone is really encouraging, and they want you to win! They not only show you how to be successful, they lead by example. The Executive Management team is approachable and they are a group of excellent listeners.
cons: At times the job can be pretty physical. Having said that, everyone is willing to roll up their sleeves and assist you.

title: District Manager
pros: The training is great and PS takes the time to ensure you are set up for success. The PM/RS are great. They have a lot of responsibility but the rewards are fantastic!
cons: No cons. Be prepared to connect with customers. Utilize your customer service skills to take care of the customer. The job has its demands but the rewards are beneficial.

title: Manager
pros: Your on your own.
cons: I dont know which is hard seeing the employees tuen over or the DM as much as they do. It seems like customer service is not on their agenda at all its all about profit.

title: Worst company ever
pros: No real pros here, when i first started in 2006 the company was great, good bonus structure, really good upper management, but that did not last long
cons: No respect for store level employes, does not promote from within was told flat out that store manager was as high as i would ever get, as a live on site manager i was only paid minimum wage which was a $2.00 a hour pay cut from what i was making before taking a PM job, high turn over at upper management level we had 7 district managers in the 6 years i with company, nothing was ever good enuff

title: Terrible company to work for.
pros: The job itself is easy. Some of the customers are fantastic people.
cons: Name it. Everything is wrong with this company. I was there for 4 years. When I started with the company I received a monthly bonus. Then it was a quarterly bonus. Then they changed it to a yearly bonus that was impossible to get. I made less money every year I worked there. We didn't even get a cost of living raise in 2013. We were driven like donkeys to meet upper managements goals so they would bonus. Management was constantly in our faces about Google reviews. People were writing fake reviews to get them off their backs which was grounds for termination. Management had non customers write reviews so they would bonus. Nothing got fixed. Security cameras were out and wouldn't be fixed. The gate would allow anyone to enter using any number at any time. They wouldn't fix it. I had to lie to customers about everything. We were forced to harass non paying customers with repeated phone calls. There was a gas leak from one of the heaters, They wouldn't call for repair service. There was black mold in the office and utility closet that was making me sick. I was told to purchase bleach with my own money (we were not allowed to order it),and scrub it off the wall. I was told to never mention it again. We were forced to falsify the monthly checklist (grounds for termination) only to have the auditor call us out on it. This company doesn't care about employees or customers. It's all about upper management making their bonuses. Bonuses most of them do not deserve.

title: Corporate Employee of 10 Years
pros: Public Storage has grown so much in the 10 years I have been here. It is great to a company thrive and do so much to promote within its own ranks.
cons: Its a reality that the cost of healthcare continues to climb and hence the cost of benefits is getting high but its a sign of the times.

title: Low cost operator
pros: If you like to have your boss approve any expenditure over $5, this company is for you. Also, you will hit max salary of $68k and will not be eligible for a raise moving forward. The max may be $75k now
cons: Bonuses are pay out like so. 8k top 10%. 6k next 20% 4K next 25% 2k next 25% and then $0k. Stock options at minimal and if u like working Saturdays during the rental season and only receive Sunday's off, have fun.

title: Decent job
pros: Pros: Hours are great, work with little to no supervision, pretty easy job.
cons: Cons: Pay is not competitive, no room for growth, days can be slow during the middle of the month because you see little to no customers, scripts change VERY frequently leaving you unsure of what to say, not a good job to stay at long term.

title: Warning
pros: Hours were good No rent if u were able to get a on site apartment Supply shirts Can think of any others pros
cons: Pay was awful Dealing with homeless trying not to live in their unit Cleaning up after homeless people Constantly being shopped by management to ensure you were spitting out the scripts Getting a day off was a constant problem do to blackout mouths and weeks Revamping the commission program every year to ensure 60% of employees didn't qualify Forced to sale over priced merchandise Forced to sale insurance that was worthless if you needed to use it Took a act of God to get any thing fixed on the property

title: Customer Service
pros: Awesome work environment, there's opportunity to grow within the company if you do your job well. There's a lot of opportunities to pick up extra hours as well as to leave early if the workload permits. Management is very helpful and always willing to help out. Coworkers are kind of your second family and it makes the job easier.
cons: A very high call volume in the summer (busy season, calls back to back) nothing that can't be handled though.

title: Great company
pros: Amazing benefits, paid time off, sick time, good coaching plan, good hours NO nights which works perfect for working parents , you can work by yourself or with a co worker, Stability company keeps growing, opportunity to transfer to other states, I been working for company many years and I'm proud of being part of the team, It feels like working with family,
cons: We Only get 3 holidays off

title: relief manager
pros: Its a ok job for students or moms looking for a little extra income. The other property managers are great. The District mangers really try to do the best that they can but in alot of things their hands are tied.
cons: The thing is that this company does not pay enough for someone to survive paying their bills.

title: Property Manager
pros: The employees in the field level watch each other’s backs.
cons: pay is Terrible, use and abuse employees, district managers don’t do anything. property managers are the money drivers for the company. work weekends, treats long term employees like there peasants. don’t waste your time with this company they will drain you and just hire some other peon. do not recommend ever to anyone. terrible culture and no respect.

title: The Place to Work & Grow!!
pros: Working as a DM for Public storage is a great career delivering great flexibility! I have the responsibility to positively impact employees and customers all across my district while driving key business metrics!
cons: Only opportunity in this role that I would lift up is that this role requires a lot of thorough follow up and relation ship building with vendors that you will always be in a partnership with rather than directly in charge of.

title: Not a job for single parents
pros: I have no Pros to give.
cons: They take over your life entirely. No time for your kids no time for yourself. They are short staffed and is over working the good employees they do have. And do not care. It’s not enough pay for the mental disturbance it put on you daily. Buildings are falling apart they take their time to fix. Apartments are not up to code to live in let alone with kids. Overall they talk a good game until you’re apart of the team then you are ignored.

title: good job great property team
pros: good place to work, great hours, great local team to work with, understanding of family issues when time off is needed,
cons: Benifits can change from location (districts) sometimes you can realy work with lazy people who push there job on others but make more money than the hard workers

title: A great opportunity with an outstanding company.
pros: There are numerous reasons to work for Public Storage. Some of the best reasons include, but are not limited to, the hours, the experiences, the benefits, the personal growth and training, and much more. It's not your normal 9 to 5, but very close. You work 9:30 am to 6 pm during the week and 9:30 to 5 on the weekends. Even with a busy home life the hours fit great into your schedule. Secondly, nothing can beat the experiences you have working for this company. Every customer who walks through your door is going through something in life that has brought them to you. You have the opportunity to put a smile on there face and send them home with a piece of mind knowing you are there to help them in any way you can. Benefits that come along with working for public storage, of course at your choosing, range from medical insurance, dental insurance, life insurance, and the list goes on. Enough about the nuts and bolts, my favorite thing about working for this company is the personal growth and training. Whether you come into this company with customer service skills or not, I guarantee you will leave with them. On top of the elaborate training you receive as a new hire, the District Manager and Senior DM will also take the time to help you grow by doing regular training with you. They do critic you, as any boss would, but not in a way that demeans you. They help you learn how to be even better and by doing so you grow into a better customer service professional.
cons: I wouldn't say there are challenges to working for public storage. You do tend to work on your own a lot. However, if you need help with anything someone is always a phone call away.

title: No growth
pros: Etime is the only good thing about PS. Its hard to service customers with the type of system in place.
cons: Mid management is not good at all some people are overall good people but the "clicks" run management. Not a good thing.

title: Public Storage
pros: Best part about working for this company is little to no supervision while working.
cons: The hourly pay doesn't balance the actual work you do. Sales performance is a big factor and you do get a commission. They don't promote from within the company.

title: Property Manager
pros: I have worked for this company full time for 10 years. There is no worry about the company's longevity.
cons: There is no promoting within unless you are District Manager or higher, lack of communication with field employees, no bonus structure unless you can sell over priced merchandise and required use of unrealistic scripts.

title: property manager
pros: working by yourself and great benefits.
cons: company does not value employees. feels like the call center/customer service is working against you. the company does not have realistic expectation to sales. constantly changing protocol. if you've been there too long they'll find a reason to fire you. does not promote within. upper management reaps all the benefits for what field employees work hard for. not paid enough for the work they expect.

title: Great company and culture
pros: Company invests in its district managers and their careers Company is changing with the times and implementing new strategies and technology to keep us relevant Great work life balance Great team and district culture Ton of training and knowledge to keep our teams successful
cons: Some older facilities in the market but I know we are working to remodel and rebrand which will make a huge impact

title: It was okay.
pros: 40 hours a week guaranteed. 30 minute lunch breaks A lot of down time. A lot of cleaning and organization.
cons: Too much freedom- allows people to slack off. People don’t do their jobs when DMs aren’t around. Get paid minimum wage to do more than what is said in job description. Trained to getting customers to purchase lock, insurance and merchandise. Everything is scripted- you have to follow everything by the script.

title: Dead end job.
pros: Mandatory full-time hours for all property level employees
cons: There is no opportunity to advance in this company beyond becoming a trainer or running an "A" property (1000+ unit properties) and your odds of either are slim unless you have seniority in your district. They do not promote within the company, regardless of your qualifications. They expect a tremendous amount of work both on the property and in the office, for a barely livable wage.

title: Great Company to work for.
pros: This is an amazing company to work for. The training program for a District Manager is top notch. This company truly believes that it is about hiring the right people and investing the time necessary to make them the best they can be. Upper management is extremely professional and is always ready to give a helping hand when necessary. A career change to this company was well worth it. Two big thumbs up!
cons: No cons to submit as I am extremely happy thus far.

title: Great place to work, and a humble CEO!!
pros: 1. Close to where I live, like 10mins away :) 2. Great people, wonderful working environment, especially in my department!! 3. Free bagels every Friday, and donuts every first Friday of the month!
cons: Medical benefits is a little bit high for an average hourly employee, especially when you have a family plan.

pros: Salary and bonus are a plus. On top of that, they have a good benefits package.
cons: The culture here is rough. Little to no recognition, I just constantly am made to feel like I suck at my job or I have a poor performing district when in actuality I've had significant turnover and I'm working with my new folks on meeting the standard. Leaders don't care, they often manage from reports.

title: Great Resume Builder
pros: Relaxed Environment No Micro-Management Great Sales Experience Potential become a live on Property Manager with a 2 bedroom apartment that is discounted.
