cons: they lie about housing, pay raise, they do not pay you right your paycheck is always wrong, then they do not fix it. they wonder why they can not keep employees, their new expectations of what they want you to do and clean now is not worth the little tiny pay they give you every 2 weeks.

title: Literally better off anywhere else.
pros: Good co workers that’s it.
cons: You have to lie to customers and say that they basically have to buy their $20 lock, you work holidays, weekends, you get terrible pay. No growth. And it’s so scriptured, you start to feel so robotic and unauthentic. If you don’t sell merchandise and meet your quota, then you get scolded. You get 30 min for lunch. It’s just not worth the pay. Period.

title: “Moving goalpost” bonus structure
pros: Pay WAS great. One, maybe 2, supervisors are incredible leaders and great support
cons: Mandatory 10hr OT shifts. Majority of supervisors are not supportive. Bonus plan abrupt change cuts pay

title: Run!
pros: They offer a reasonable 401k program and decent benefits.
cons: I worked for this company as a resident property manager. I was provided an apartment that was never maintained by facilities and I along with other employees, constantly had the apartment thrown in my face if sales numbers didn't meet their outlandish quota. My apartment never had carpets or floors replaced prior to moving in and were disgusting. I was promised they would replace them shortly after moving in, they never did.. they do not feel they should follow simple housing codes. Management loves to take advantage of people who are unknowledgable of their rights as a tenant or an employee. The pay is not competitive to other storage locations within the area. You are expected to wear too many hats and manage multiple stores due to short staffing. Management belittled you and used scare tactics to push sales numbers. They hired unlicensed companies to complete maintenance work. While living onsite they did a "property of tomorrow" upgrade in the office that was connected to my apartment and put me in a temporary box with the door facing the gate. I was told this was only to last a week, maybe 2. Everytime I stepped outside of the office I risked getting hit by a car. They did not hire a contractor that was properly licensed to be completing the work required and did not pull permits. When I voiced my fear of the office catching fire due to the overloaded and outdated electrical panel, facilities told me "you're there to rent storage units". I then realized they did not care about my safety, my family's or my customer's safety.. I was left in the temp office for over 6 months due to a complaint being filed with the city because no permits were pulled. Mind you, I was pregnant through the entire experience. I quit 2 weeks after returning from maternity leave. They do not care about safety or security for their employees, let alone their customers. I had threats made against me my customers because of immoral business practices that we were forced to enforce! I never felt safe the entire time I worked there. You give up all of your privacy when you live on site. The training sucks. You are sent out knowing very little and they hire irresponsible kids. When you go to management about other employees you are told to just deal with it and expected to clean up after the relief managers' mistakes. There is a lot of favoritism. Through the years I witnessed other employees steal, come to work under the influence, verbally assault others and management does nothing about it.. even when it's been reported to HR it all gets swept under the rug and you are labeled as "trouble" for doing your dudiligence to report the issues as you are told to do through the code of conduct you sign every year. Do not work for this company unless you want to be treated like scum every day. The pay is not worth any of the crap situations you will have to endure. I promise the "free apartment" they will dangle over your head is never worth the mental anguish you will endure every day and the lack of privacy. You will have people banging on your kid's bedroom window in the middle of the night because they're above following simple rules like access hours and feel entitled to being served at every dying moment. You'll miss out on time with your kids and family because you're forced to work most major holidays. You will not be provided with the bare necessities to complete your day to day job then asked why a, b or c is not completed. You'll be treated like you're stupid every day you clock in.

title: Deplorable management, working and living conditions
pros: The only good thing about Public Storage is the 3 days a year that they willingly give for (1 day) Christmas Day, (1 day) Thanksgiving Day and (1 day) New Year's Day
cons: The company is only worried about putting money the the owners pocket and their own. They do not care about their employees or the employees time! They hire you and lie and tell you that you can move up in the company!! (Ball faced lie) The highest you can go is a KTP and you only get $1 more an hour to have to be a babysitter! You will never be a Disrict manager or corporate because they only outsource for them! They bring in new District Managers that have never rented a unit to a customer and got all their training from a video but yet they "seem" to know how to tell you how to talk and deal with customers that you deal everyday! The Managers bend the rules and show favoritism! The managers will tell you one thing one day and then come back the next day and get onto you for doing it the way they told you and threaten to wright you up. Please do not move into the apartments on property unless you have no choice!!! They think they are doing you a favor but will have you living in unsanitary conditions! They take forever to fix anything or you have to threaten to call the code enforcement people to get anything done! The apartment that i was in on Veterans Memorial Dr had plumbing issues, roach infestation, rats in the roof and mold! The plumbing (sewage) would back up in the laundry room in the same room as the air for the apartment! So we were breathing it in throught the air vents! When it would flood it would flood the hallway and it went through the walls and went all the way into the kitchen! The roaches were not bad at first but there at the end they were so bad that they had started to crawl on us in our sleep! Most of the apartments all have the same issues! The apartments are super old and need to be completely gutted and renovated!! Oh and dont expect to get a raise or anything if you live on property! You will only get paid $10 an hour because they take the rest you make per hour for the rent! The only extra that you might be able to get it the incentive of $150 if your property can keep their numbers in the green for 30 days! It's not worth it when you get your check! I went through 3 different district managers while I was there for 3 years. Not by choice! They redirect the areas every year and when COVID happened they moved me to the property that i lived at! I was cool with that other than they took me from The Absolute Best Manager I have ever had at any job and just heard that they just fired her a few days ago! The other 2 Dm's were Pure Hell!! One was a Child and talked to people like they are dumb or "beneath" her. We had to show her how to do a rental! The other one has been with PS so long that she gets away with not following the rules or bending them to sut her! She wrights up employees that really do their job but let the slackers get away with everything. She wrote me up for my money being short $17 (only happened 1 time in 3 years of me working there) but she knowingly allowed a guy to keep working for the company even though she was sent videos of the guy taking money out of the safe and then coming back to the office at 1am in the morning and putting money back! This happened more then one time!!! She said at least he brought it back!! All the DM's or the higher ups believe she is the "Great"! If Publice what's to know why District 209 people are leaving like they are they need to talk to the people in the district and they will let them know it's the DM!! When I first started with the company I thought and told my Dm that I was going to be with the company until I retired BUT my family's health and my sanity are more important!

title: My experience at public storage has been consistantly full of change!
pros: Bonus structure has been revised to a bonus payout every month . Schedules are fairly consistent and hours of operation do not change.
cons: Revised bonus structure lessens the payout amount.Management would rather retain a tenant that physically harms a field manager than to evict them. The properties do not protect staffing with security personnel our surveillance equipment. Scripts change with the wind if you'd like to rehearse and recite lines this its the job for you!

title: Complete BS!!
pros: Good work hours - apart from working sundays, which is a complete waste of time, as nobody ever comes in - some customers are awesome! They get rid of good employess and DMs and keep the ones that dont work or give a rats a***
cons: Crap health insurance - had to have surgery last year as a heart condition was diagnosed and it was have surgery or possibly die, back in work 19 days after surgery, couldnt afford to have time off as thte short term disability that I was paying for, suddenly wouldnt cover me after they said it would (6 weeks off could NEVER be done) - had a small stroke the month before, and was back at work within 3 days - Now looking at being sued by what the insurance wouldnt cover, and come to find out, they seem to have not covered what they said they were! Scripts scripts scripts!!! all of them a waste of time, customers want service not a robot! Pay SUCKS, as a KTP (with the whole 58 cents extra) I was making $2 an hour LESS than a RF thats been here a year...tell me how does that figure? 10 times the workload and making a whole lot less than someone who did absolutely NOTHING but play angry birds on her phone and play on facebook? You tell the DM and nothing gets done, customers complain, and nothing gets done, other managers complain and nothing gets done.....its not what you know...its who you b**w... Bonuses are unatainable now, they keep pushing goals to places there are no way that you can hit all 5 parts....you may hit 2, 3 or 4 and still get NOTHING...I sold almost 3 grands worth of merchandise....and get this...I got just over $5 in merchandise incentive! INCENTIVE? REALLY???? I think not. I finished my 2 weeks notice today, and I am SOOOOOO glad I am out of there, starting with another company that actually pays bonus, and you make bonus on what you do...not unrealistic goals and NO outside work, no landscaping, no trying to fix doors and dealing with falling sheetrock, and not having to deal with crappy looking units and charging premium prices, that have roaches and mice and brown recluses...GOOD RIDDENCE!

title: Worst Job I've had, ever.
pros: Co-workers are great to work with.
cons: There's so much I'm not sure where to start. :( First scripts, there are WAY too many of them. No matter what you do the customers know its a script and just don't like it. It makes you seem robotic when dealing with customers. I'm a property manager.... yet I can't do anything to help a customer. I can't waive a late fee, or make any decisions without first contacting the District manager. The sales technique used is so close to lying. I've been called a "shark" by customers and it's just the way the company wants you to do your job. Customers will constantly accuse you of lying because they come in expecting to pay $16 to move in and then suddenly you're trying to get $44.07 or more out of them. Micromanagement. Upper management doesn't listen to their property managers/relief managers at all. If we suggest anything at all its ignored or we are making excuses about things. It's all about numbers and how much you can sell. If you don't get your goals you're given a hard time by upper management. Theres no advancement at all. If you hire in as a property manager you will never move up in the company. Ever. Period. Bonus program was cut and no real details on how to get it now. Used to be monthly and is now yearly and the company even says that only 40% of managers are expected to get it. So most likely even less will get a bonus at the end of the year. There's a $.50 raise after 6 months but don't count on another one. I just got my yearly review and did very well but won't be getting a raise because they did a base pay raise to all employees..... not the same thing as a performance raise. Raises were also not given last year.

title: "We Care"....... About Lining Our Pockets!
pros: The option of a company apartment is a nice pro but good luck getting one.... the waitlist on them is very long! Most of the coworkers are very nice as well.
cons: Ahh..... Where do I start?! Scripts, scripts, scripts and sell, sell, sell. That's all upper management ever says. There are literally 10-15 scripts to memorize.... and yes you will be tested on it and your bonus will depend on it... good luck being one of the 40% that even get a bonus though! Employees are also evaluated monthly on how many customers we can sucker in to buying a ridiculously overpriced lock and boxes. Any local hardware or home improvement store sells the same lock and boxes at a small fraction of the cost. But if we don't sell them, we are disciplined and it goes down in the record so they can ding your bonus. Oh and good luck taking vacation or personal time. Te company has restricted it so that in the summer months it's next to impossible to take a paid vacation with your family. They've "blacked out" several weeks where employees cannot use personal time. The company's we care slogan is totally bogus. Customers are deceived and tricked. Employees are instructed to quote you a low price over the phone and then tack all the extras (lock, insurance, merchandise) on when you get there which brings your move in total to nearly double what we quote you. Long time customers receive rent increases almost every 6 months. It is not uncommon to find a customer paying double or triple the going rate for a unit. It's a total bait and switch operation they have going. And if the manager tells you that break ins and flooding are not a common issue, it is a flat out lie. I've been with the company less than a year and I don't plan on making my one year review! Awful company to work for!

title: Worse job I have ever had
pros: Some of the customers I have gotten to know.
cons: As a property manager I make a whole $.05 cents more than my relief managers but have double the work load and accountability. My DM refuses to call customers back which leads the customers to call us or come into the office screaming at us when we cannot do anything at the property.. We are not given what we need to do the job including enough coverage, a working golf cart and a broom that is actually made for industrial cleaning and not to sweep out my kitchen. We are told that safety in the work place is most important but are then told we need to fix broken doors putting us at risk for injury. And you know if you get hurt they will tell you you are not covered because we should not have been fixing it in the first place. At least when we were able to get a bonus it was incentive to increase our numbers. I don't consider the yearly bonus they have now a bonus because only 40 percent of us will get it. Our DM is such a condescending witch that everyone she hires wants to leave after the first day. She tells us to follow company policy but she doesn't. Like giving units that don't sell at auction to her friends. Funny I thought we were suppose to throw everything in the dumpster. I could go on and on about how horrible this company is. Everyone in my area except for 1 person is looking for another job and we all fantasize about how we are going to quit.

title: Very happy working at Public Storage.
pros: Public Storage is a very successful company and with that comes a certain amount of job security. Their business model is one of the strongest I've ever seen and they continue to plan on extensive growth every year. With this, they are very supportive and understanding of work life balance.
cons: I don't have any Cons at this time. This company is a perfect fit for me.

title: The Best Company I
pros: It’s a great work environment and we work with people from different department who are supportive and knowledgeable in their area. You become good friends with peers with amazing sense of belonging and community. The company provides necessary tools and guidance for career growth. Salary and compensation are totally based on work and accomplishments which is great.
cons: Sometimes overwhelming amount of work.

title: Wasn't a bad job but the pay was bologna
pros: - Indoor/ Outdoor - Never have to sit for too long - Management is amazing - Sign up for benefits right away
cons: - PAY IS JUST NOT GREAT ENOUGH TO STICK WITH THE JOB

title: good experience
pros: Company provides employees a wide variety of experience in the work place. Great health benefits. Job allows one to help and meet a variety of people.
cons: No advancement. Low pay. No incentive program. Maintenance done at all or on a timely basis is substandard and at times nonexistent.

title: Terrible management policies
pros: You generally work alone or with 1-2 co-workers Decent work life balance Medical benefits and 401k
cons: I can really only speak about my experience as a field employee with Public Storage but after working here for over 2 years and seeing the way the upper management runs things, I can only assume it just as bad in other departments. To anyone looking at becoming either a relief or property manager for Public Storage please be wary. First off, there is no room for advancement as a field employee. You could become a property manager and possibly get an on site apartment but that is as high as you will ever go. Public Storage DOES NOT promote higher than the property manager position but they will attempt to give you extra work with no pay raise once you become more experienced. Because field employees are not promoted to the corporate side of this business, the managers are MASSIVELY DISCONNECTED with the employees they are managing. As a field employee you report directly to a DM(District Manager) who has never actually done your job full time. The DMs are told by the RMs(Regional Manager) how to manage us field employees. Well the RMs have never done this job either and are rarely out in the field so they are even more disconnected. Now this wouldn't be so bad except that Public Storage upper management evaluates your performance based almost solely on numbers and metrics. We are told to follow these absolutely robotic and inhuman scripts for just about every interaction we could have with a customer. These scripts are written by someone in corporate who has also never done this job. The point of the scripts is to streamline the service to help us meet certain numbers each month in several different categories such as move-ins, lock sales, insurance sign ups, and merchandise sales to name only a few. But the scripts really just make us sound like the robots and makes the entire interaction terribly awkward. Then, if you don't meet the numbers they expect, you just get told that you must not be following the scripts well enough. Plus most of these categories are not even within our control and trying to influence customers to buy packing supplies or locks can only get even the best salesman so far. But you'll still reprimanded for not meeting your numbers anyway! On top of having to manage reservations, maintain the cleanliness of the property and do collections, this can become a bit of a stressful job. In the end Public Storage is asking A LOT more from us field employees than what we are paid for and all incentive to work as hard as upper managements wants to get the job done is completely removed. Why would I keep working my butt off when I have no other room for advancement and I'm barely getting paid over minimum wage? I would highly advise anyone thinking of working for this company to only use it as a place holder job until you find something better.

title: Great company/culture
pros: Great work/life balance , able to apply leadership skills to drive to results and develop amazing team culture throughout your district.
cons: You manage every aspect of your team and business, you have to be self motivated and passionate to get results you need.

title: Basically an under paid janitor
pros: N.O.N.E at all what so ever
cons: Stores have been understaffed for over a year. Properties with 800 - 1200 units are single staffed constantly. Other stores only half day with one person splitting their time running between stores or stores not opened at all. The supervisor has you punch in at the 1st store then go to the 2nd store so it looks like all the stores are open. The amount of work needed to be done is never going to be completed with only one person there all day. Try putting in for PTO, HAH! You're told you need to be a team player and shorten the requested time. PTO is time that the company gives you in accordance with your length of time on the job. More time in, means more PTO. We are allowed and encouraged by Corporate to take that time off. Only to be denied or asked to shorten it because we are short staffed. Solution is HIRE PEOPLE ! Someone was not allowed time off for a family wedding and the bride and groom had family coming in from several states. They only had the day of the wedding off and had to be in the next day. Another property had to work while they had COVID!! The supervisor said we don't have enough people to cover so they had to work and just tell reservations to do the E Rental. The door signage is confusing to the customers. It says "We're Open" BUT WE AREN'T !! They want the customer to scan the QRC and do it online. We are not in the office because it's either closed or we are outside on the property washing doors and mopping hallways. The customer doesn't know if we will be back in 10 minutes or not at all. The customers would prefer to have us in the store. Not everyone does everything online and fewer people don't have a clue what a QRC is! The company would rather have us be janitors than someone taking care of the customers. Store level employees cannot plan anything outside of work because the supervisors can't get a schedule out in a timely manner. They are constantly changing peoples days off after they have had the same days off for years. Supervisors play favorites and it's very obvious. They have other employees that roll their eyes when they ask them to do something and they don't do it. The supervisor will ask someone else. They have no clue how this business works. They keep saying "Well when I was at XYZ Big box store we did this. I'm sorry, we are no longer at XYZ Big box store, this is a totally different business, Another manager reported that a sliding glass door was off track and needed repair. The supervisor told the manager that they should be able to nudge and knock the door back into place. No one is knocking any doors back into place. Not any 300lb glass door! If they did, and got hurt and or broke the door, They would have been fired. No one wants to get hurt because the supervisor thinks it can be done. They try to do repairs themselves to avoid paying vendors, only having to call a vendor because they are not a handy man and botched it up.

title: Really enjoy working for public Storage
cons: istent hours with set schedule, great bonus structure, PTO packages are great, great health insurance and 401k packages.

title: Overworked Underpaid
pros: Offers full and part-time schedule Lunch break Benefits Hiring bonus
cons: Low wage for everything we do Not all managers live on property but we are paid as if we are all live on property Upper managers make great money while Relief and on site Managers do the hard work We pay 50% of our benefits

title: Wouldn't recommend this to my worse enemy
pros: - The pay is good - Work independently - Meet great people such as customers or/employees - Can be active around the work place - Gain experience in customer service and retail work. - Offers a bonus for over meeting company expectations
cons: - "Company expectations" (what ever it may be) is unrealistic - Their pay dates are on specific days of the month, so the pay is never the same every month - Upper management couldn't give a rats behind about you or what they are inflicting in your personal life. (Expects you to eliminate your personal life for the company) - Expects you to drive to numerous locations with out compensating for mileage no matter the distance. - Changes the bonus system when suitable for them, also it is unattainable. - Does not have an anonymous compliance department even though they say it is anonymous . - makes you work overtime but no overtime pay (asks you to work extra hours but tells you to eliminate hours from a different day so there isn't over 40 hours on you time by the end of the week or pushes your days off to the end of the week and make you work a 7 day stretch) - the over turn rate between relief and property manages are ridiculous which ends up hurting the rest of the district when it boils down to coverage (which the lack of coverage is already existing) - single coverage is majority of the work week (normally) and could even be the entire work week (expects you to do the work of 2 people by yourself). - getting an approval to get something fixed in THEIR facility is like pulling teeth and even if it is approved, the job is less then inadequate so the object breaks down in less than a week. - ridiculously micro-managed but can't provide us with updated technology. I'm sure there is a lot more but I can't sit here and say it all, ill just get myself enraged.

title: Worst job I have had.
pros: Great co-workers and you learn how to organize rooms.
cons: So many downsides I don't know where to start. SCRIPTS. They give new scripts every month and they all sound like something that was randomly put together by someone with less social skills then a newly made robot. Promotions are nonexistent in this company. They would rather bring a person from another company or another state to be the DM or RM. The only care they have is to the stockbrokers. They tell you that when the performance reviews come out no one is going to get a 5. So why do they even have it on the review sheet to begin with. They combined sick and vacation days together and black out days to keep people stuck at work. You have put to vacation time in the system by a month or longer or you will not get the time off. Birthdays or sickness they do not care you are stuck at work. The properties are falling apart. They charge people premium prices but if something breaks at the facility it will stay broken for at least 6 months because they put a freeze on all repairs without their consent. When the customers call the DM, RM, or corporate about the broken doors, insulation, or gates, corporate blames you for them calling. That right, Corporate blames the relief and property managers for the customers calling about their unit and goods damage, instead of calling the vendors to fix the problems and expects you to try and fix the issue knowing that that they will not pay workman comp if you get hurt. The wildlife that is at the properties is another problem. Spiders, Roaches, and rats are as regular as the customers. I lost out on a rental once because a rat ran out of the unit when I opened the door. The biggest step on their on the PM and RM is the waste that they call the bonus program. Every year it gets worse and worse. They rose the best rewards to 95% and when stores began to reach those goals. The bonus amount reduced and it went from a monthly to an annually program. The DM's and RM's keep nothing to themselves. If they know something everyone knows. It doesn't matter if the information is personal all of the company knows. No advancement, no loyalty, no bonuses. PS was a decent place to work before the sin of GREED took over. Senior management knows people will always need storage so they will only get worse from here.

title: Its a job......that's it!
pros: Working alone, interacting with customers/ new people.
cons: There are so many....first of all the company does not care about you as a person they only care about their numbers......I got written up because I called into work twice in a month for being sick and having a sick child that I could not send to school or daycare let alone try and get myself up and moving. They want us to sell merchandise which is way overpriced and the customers know this and have stated that they will buy boxes down the street. The pay for what we do on a daily basis is not worth it. We are the front line of the company and basically we are treated like scum from upper management. I would like to see them do what we do everyday at the pay we make and see how they would feel. Bonuses when I started were ok they went from monthly to every three months now to yearly if you are the lucky 40% that will actually get bonuses. The DM should get to know the employees working under him and know a little about them instead of just downing the employees all the time maybe say something on the positive. Spend time with employees at every property to see what their strengths and weaknesses are. The scripts are horrible and sound rediculous when you actually use them with a customer. There are only three holidays the store is not open other than that you are required to work. Hope you don't want a big personal life working here you will not have one as you will work EVERY weekend and just about every holiday with the exception of the three that the store is closed. Nothing is ever repaired and if it is then it is literally not done correctly and needs to be repaired again about a week later. Many properties in my district do not have a working golf cart which is fine for small properties but there are quite a few large ones and asking a potential rental who may be handicapped to walk to a space a far distance away seems inappropriate and using your car and having people follow you is not much better. Property managers are asked to fix things that are broken to which may not be safe. Lack of communication between property and higher ups as well as call center. Treated poorly if you do not sell lock or insurance with every single rental....even if it is a return customer. If you are a guy do not plan on getting hired. Do not plan on having certain days off as they are never approved even if it's a medical thing. They took away PTO pretty much. "Black out dates" are rediculous we should be able to have a vacation in the summer with our families we are not much busier during these dates than any other time period. DM has been trained same as us but not willing to do the job we do if someone calls in or quits we are scheduled over time with out being asked. I could go on and on....

title: An okay job if you're looking for something very short term
pros: I enjoyed the autonomy more than anything. Being able to dictate when to do tasks when you wanted to, when to go to lunch, etc. Got along fairly well with co-employees and District Manager. Okay if you're between jobs and need a full time position quickly and temporarily. But having worked there for two years, I cannot recommend anything beyond about six months.
cons: No room for advancement for the boots on the ground. Shrinking benefits despite growing profits. Ron Havner. Needless stress from higher ups re: sales, maintaining scripts (never used their scripts and sold just fine, thank you very much). Most properties had some pretty big maintenance issues that didn't get resolved for months, many properties lack proper security precautions. The feeling of constantly harassing customers with calls; either reservation, delinquency, or welcome calls. Not evicting problem customers (customers dangerous to employees or other customers, conducting illegal operations on site, customers who frequently go in to lien or auction). Feeling like you could be held up and shot at any time at certain properties and no real precautions to alleviate that threat at those properties. Forcing customers in to purchasing a lock and insurance. Always unsure if person working property the day before actually did anything. Poor work/life balance for property managers as they're required to work where they live and if they quit or get terminated, they have an extremely short amount of time (about 48 hours) to find a new place and move out. Sadly, despite all these cons, I don't see this company changing anything and since we're getting in to the company's busy season, things will continue to go down this same path.

title: Property Manager
pros: hours aren't bad, not too early nor to late (9:30a-6pm on weekdays) (weekends 9:30a-5pm)
cons: everything!! you start getting paid at $10hr but do everything at the property....from cleaning units, picking leaves, picking up abandon goods, doing rentals, selling over priced merchandise, forcing the customer to buy insurance when most of the time insurance doesn't cover anything. have reports ready for DM, prepare auction paper work, deal with customer that our extremely stress due to a foreclosure, divorce,death in family, moving, etc...your also a collections agency calling every single customer through the month......and mind you everything that i have mentioned is ok, i dont mind it, but get ready it gets even better.....dont you dare not sell an over priced lock to a new customer, or you will hear about it until the next month. a public storage lock cost $20 you can buy one at home depot for $7 walmart for $10 etc.....same with insurance, they want all customer to have insurance so they kinda force us shove it down the customers throat....saying its "required" but yes its not mandatory...and the sad part is that when an incident does happen the insurance will never come thorugh for what the customer really lost. sorry am not money hungry i do have a heart for my customers!! they expect you to memorize around 20 scripts and they want it word for word!!! and will make you do it over ad over again....make sure you get along with your boss if not he will call you on the spot to role play the useless scripts....scripts to do a rental, scripts to sell merchandise, scrit to take payment, script to make calls and leave message...and i can go on and on...in all honesty AVOID this place....and let me add i was also and onsite manager DO NOT take the apartment...they wil own you and expect everything from you and if you do something wrong they will threat you right away.....once again...stay away from this company..they dont take care of the employee when we make all the money. bonuses get smaller and smaller..when you apply (i pray you dont) bonuses probably wont exist..with all the unrealistic goals, we are set up for failure......do yourself a favor and look elsewhere.....

title: High Turnover leads to poor performance
pros: Multiple locations that are cookie cutter, meaning you can work at many different locations that can often benefit you.
cons: Due to the high turnover rate, the management does very little to keep employee satisfaction high.

title: Nice Company
pros: I've worked at Public Storage for many years now, I like it here, people are nice and I like my job. Sure, I'd recommend this workplace to a friend. I will continue to work here as long as my boss will have me.
cons: I just wish the vacation hours and holiday hours are the same as before, sick and vacation hours keep getting smaller and smaller.

title: Great company to work for
pros: Co-workers are very friendly. Comfortable, good working atmosphere and great company culture. If you ask for a challenge, you will get one!
cons: Must have a great working mindset to reveal and discover your true potential. Might occassionally work long days to meet deadlines, rewarding in the end.

title: Relief Manager
pros: Full time work, hold the manager title, raise after the first 6 months and PTO
cons: Required to work every weekend and after normal daycare hours during the week.

title: Relief Manager
pros: The best reasons to work at public storage is the customer friendly environment, the workers, the managers are very helpful and respectful. The pay is pretty good.
cons: Some of the downfalls of working at public storage is the scheduling, the change of hours of operation. Also the maintenance is all done by relief managers and some of the work is too excessive for just us relief managers.

title: Ok for early 20 year olds
pros: Can't really think of anything. This job is seriously the worst job I ever had. I feel tricked. These people cant hold employees for 2 months yet I was loyal and stayed 1 1/2 years.
cons: Too many to name. I came from a VERY strong sales background, and was told I was being hired as a salesman, with a little "light sweeping" involved. Yeah, not that. This company is super excited when you sell ONE box. Yep, that is the sales part. All of the sales part. The higher ups make money on your sales, but you personally do not. They will also hound you for reviews, occupancy, and delinquency because they make money off that as well, based on your hard work. They will not supply you with the tools needed for the job. They expect you to hand carry a 10x15 unit to a small trash dumpster over a 2 acres property. By hand. They build more and more properties, and let the rest go to rust. The grass will be 2' foot tall in the storefront, yet they will tell you that you have to pick weeds. Every morning you will receive a delightful letter from your DM that the district as a whole just sucks. Ok! Way to start the morning! They hire people constantly, but can't keep employees because for the work you are expected to do is way beyond the $10 an hour they pay you. They expect you to use your own car to get rid of trash. They make you use these STUPID scripts to get evicted and homeless people to buy stuff. And then they send hateful emails when you can't get evicted and homeless people to buy this overpriced crap. They raise the rent constantly, hoping people will just take it. They do take it. After yelling at us, and not the real people responsible for the outrageous rate hikes. These people have a party when they sell a box for $3. Not kidding. This is seriously the worst place I've ever worked. I am not a Property Manager, I am a janitor, a gardener, a collection agency, and ALL the money is going into other people's wallet.

title: Employees beware, run run run!!
pros: Property managers don't have to move around to other properties. Set schedule, no nights
cons: I worked for Public Storage for 8 1/2 years. It was fun when I first started there. We received quarterly bonus if you met the goals of the company, which I did and received decent bonuses. Then about 4 years into working there it just got worse and worse. They went to a bonus once a year and made it cheaper and tougher to achieve and then if you made bonus, the regional mgr. along with the DM'S would sit around a table and cheapen up your bonus and steal from you and give the portion that you were supposed to get to a favorite, they play favorites alot. They started implementing that you sell merchandise with a new lease and take the customers all around the store and tell them they need these items for your move and keep telling them what they need for three no's and by that time you've become obnoxious and by the way you put the merchandise in their hands while your doing all of this. The company will harass you if you don't get a certain % of merchandise with your leases for the month, they expect you to get a certain number of Google reviews and ask every customer except the unsatisfied customers. Customers don't put in review and if you don't get your reviews the company harassed you and puts you on conference calls everyday until you get them and employees end up putting in their own fake reviews just so you won't be harassed. You work by yourself all the time and they don't care about your safety at all. You take care of everything even all the cleaning including bathroom cleaning and customers are disgusting in there. The list is just too long as to why you should look elsewhere. 8 1/2 years was too long to spend with this company. Run don't walk

title: Disappointed
pros: You get a pay check, potential for lots of wealth accumulation if you can put up with the job. Does not require skills or intelligence
cons: Lots of micro management, weak mid level leadership who does not know how to manage managers, dealing with highly ignorant customers and staff, lack of prioritizing strategic goals and objectives,

title: Property Manager / KTP
pros: Benefits and set schedule. They do accommodate if you have school and need to leave for a reason related to that.
cons: This company does not take care of their employees. You are single staffed every day but expected to literally run everything in the store alone, from heaters, cleaning , bathrooms, trash outside. Aside from the cleaning they take really long to fix items. I had a roof leaks in my property for the past 4 plus years because they refuse to fix the roof nor do they care if customer items are damaged. You have no room to move up so once you're a property manager that's it for you !! They never see nah good that you do .. everytime the bosses come around it's way to tell how "what you could improve" not the amazing things you do for them daily. You get one raise a year if that and they now removed the bonuses so you have no room to make extra money. ALSO YOU DO HAVE TO WORK HOLIDAYS AND WILL NOT GET PAID TIME AND HALF.

title: If I knew then what I know now! Not disgruntled just truthful
pros: Late morning start time allows for better commute & time to send kids off to school. On-site residences are convenient.
cons: Some of these properties are run down & neglected. All responsibility falls onto the on-site managers who barely have enough supplies, equipment or safety items to keep the places comfortably operational, so they spend out of their own pockets for office & cleaning supplies. At some locations there are missing or broken carts & elevator & bathroom problems, poor lighting in hallways which could become hazardous situations for customers and staff. The corporation leverages the on-site staff to add extra duties, custodial, janitorial & maintence because of their on-site residences plus sometimes dispatching those property managers to other locations specifically to clean & fix ‘as needed. It seems to me that those on-site PMs are at a disadvantage to complain or decline the management orders. This corporation is very profitable yet pays barely minimum wage, the benefits are expensive compared to the wages. There have been property managers that had to seek public services for their medical needs. Raises are not given to property managers (there were in past but no longer exist) & there are no additional compensation incentives. Some PMs who have worked 5-10 years are making 50 cents more than a new hire. I have been told that some onsite residences are also neglected & many property managers make household repairs themselves. Customer storage rental fees are increased on average every 6 mo & customers are told the increases are for upkeep costs...the increases are not reinvested into the properties...those profits are kept at executive level bonuses. When I asked, I was told there is a compliance hotline but altho’ it’s supposed to be anonymous, specific questions can reveal the source of the complaint with subsequent consequences. I feel that this company can leverage the on-site residences against the property managers (many of which are female with children). Think seriously about working for this company

title: The pit of hell...
pros: Nothing!!! Not one thing. Zero. Nada. Zilch.
cons: Poverty level salary, demanding and unreasonable management, dangerous work place, disease ridden office and bathrooms, used condoms and human filth and defamation on the property and renters sleeping in the storage units.

title: I Enjoy what I do! I love my job!
pros: Benefits are great, the ability to work alone and not have to work under micromanagement, building a great connection with your tenants, connecting one on one with your teammates, everything is based on scripts to keep everyone on the same tune, there’s always something to do.
cons: Unable to advance to upper management from KTP , resident manager pay scale.

title: Good Work Life Balance
pros: Good work life balance. Good peers and leadership. They promote from within so you have a good change to move up if you work hard and perform. No real weekend work except for a few times a year in the peak season. Much better hours than retail with most locations closed at 6:00pm so no late calls.
cons: Staffing model can make things difficult at times.

title: Wonderful company
pros: Great Boss's they care about their employees and understand that life out side of work happens Great benefits
cons: Property Managers should be paid more for the amount of work and Travel they have to do pays not horrible $14 per hour

title: I now see why their turn over rate is so high!!!!!!!
pros: Off by 6pm is the only thing great about this company
cons: Only Property Manager are off on Sundays. Working @ more than one location Changing schedule at last minute

title: Dead end job...
pros: There isn't someone looking over your shoulder constantly.
cons: Your District Managers make up for the time they weren't there to look over your shoulder constantly when they visit your. COMPLETE MICRO-MANAGEMENT at every level. They put into effect a "recertification program" which they implement whenever they decide it's time to rehearse scripts again after you've already passed your probationary period. Recertification, implying that you could lose your job if you don't remember their constantly changing scripts word for word. And there are at least 10 scripts and growing. Say the scripts verbatim, and I guarantee they'll still find fault. It's how you said it, it wasn't said in your own words, ...etc..etc.. Then you do it they way they suggested you tweak the scripts, and next time they ask you, you do it their way, and they contradict ever having told you to say it that way. So guess what, you're wrong again! There goes your performance review! Yes, I said rehearse. They love SCIPTS. They have one for just about every human interaction you have with any customer and love to change the scripts or add new ones all the time. The district managers are on complete power trips and it's all about who they like. If they don't like you, they use "at will employment" and a casual grey matter excuse to get rid of you. That's how they did me. I was written up several times for things I thought would benefit the properties I was working at. Why? Because I didn't ask permission from my manager first. Yes, that's why I no longer work there. I was written up for doing something my district manager told me to do, then I was written up for not asking permission to do something positive for the property that actually SAVED the company money and time! Also, sexism reigned supreme in my district and management favored females specifically!

title: WORST COMPANY EVER.
pros: The only pro's is that there are set hours.
cons: very LOW pay for all the hard work that we do. We get treated as if we are stupid by management when they're the ones who need help from us constantly .... You sucker in customers saying that the first month is only a dollar BUT they have to pay a $22 admin fee we have to say insurance is required but it's NOT ! and we have to try to sell them a lock that is $20 dollars ... I was told I only had to work two stores that were close to me but after I took the job they started making me do 80 mile commutes EVERY DAY. You cant drive that far off of the very low money that you make ...You'll be a slave to this company. The bonus scale changed from weekly, to monthly, to quarterly now to YEARLY ! They have this because of such a high turn-over rate because no-one wants to stay when they get suckered into this job. On top of that when you're ready for your bonus management try to cut it down as low as possible so that THEY can get a bigger bonus. Literally all the hard work that property managers and relief managers do the higher ups ( district manager, regional manager etc.) are the ones who get the bonus for it ! All of our hard work and they rack in the money? That isn't right. Do yourself a favor stay as FAR away from this job as possible ...

title: Headache with Lies used for Asprin
pros: Free apartment with electricity included, you get to work alone
cons: I worked for PS from 2009-2011, and I quickly became a manager at the Red Bank location just outside of Chattanooga. At first, I enjoyed the job until the DM changed. They brought in a guy who cared more about respect than the job being done right. He demanded respect, but did nothing at all to earn it. But, he gave you none in return. The scripts were ridiculous. They made you look like an idiot, and worse, they come off as talking down to the customer and insulting their intelligence. Personally, if someone talked to me like in those scripts, I would turn around and walk away. I remember one time, they were trying to increase the sales of their overpriced locks, so they made it a requirement to buy TWO locks. This is part of the script basically...Cust: I brought a lock. PS: Good! You only need one more. Cust: Why do I need 2? PS: To maximize security. Cust: Do you have alot of break ins? (this next part is amazing) PS: I'm glad you asked that. It seems like security is important to you. It is to us too. We do our part by having coded gate entry and security cameras. We ask that you do your part by purchasing these 2 locks. Talk about condescension. The script didn't even answer the customer's question! The scripts constantly changed too. It seems like they hired a bunch of college kids who had never set on a property to write the scripts. I see alot of people here mentioning the bonuses being taken. Did you ever notice that each time the bonuses were reduced or made even harder to obtain, a week or to before it happened, there would be an email from corporate telling us to welcome so in so, the head of some new department of whatever? How do you think those people get paid? Not to mention the so called 'safety manager.' This guy travels from city to city investigating the properties. He spends 10-15 minutes at each property, asking the property managers how to raise a door, and other common sense things like that. He then asks you what the 'safety topic' is for that month, and looks over your 'safety binder,' which never changes year to year. All they do is send you another flyer with the topic on it, with the current year's date on it. Now, I want THAT job. Getting paid to travel the country, complete with hotel and meals paid too, and all you have to do is annoy people for a few minutes a day? Sign me up!! And, I imagine its a pretty lucrative salary too! I'm going to go back to the upper management here. I mentioned the new guy I worked for. But his boss thought he was a drill instructor. This next segment illustrated the lack of communication and the low regard that upper management has for the property managers...One time, the regional manager came in, and I had locks in 2 different places behind the counter. He told me to get rid of one of the locations. I did, and the next time he came in, he told me that I disobeyed him, saying that he told me to get rid of BOTH of them. I politely reminded him that he told me to get rid of one of them. The next day, the DM who was there for both conversations reamed me for being disrespectful to the RM. The DM also lied to keep me there. I requested a transfer to Augusta, GA. It was (supposedly) approved. We were just waiting for the property manager there to work out his notice and vacate the apartment there. But then, I made the mistake of giving a second dollar move in special to a family who already had a unit there...even though the person moving in had a different last name than the other tenant. The DM rushed to write me up, then told me that in order to transfer, you had to be writeup free for a year. I finally relocated on my own, but I found out later from a different DM that there was no such rule. He made the whole thing up just so I couldn't leave. Do yourself a favor, and look into a different storage company if you want to go that route. There are others who treat their employees much better and pay more.

title: No security, false promise and no accountability
pros: I like management. I enjoy the fast paced days and reaching goals. This job has taught me what I need to be successful regarding speaking with people, describing transactions and policy procedures a s well as my personal enrichment.
cons: Unfortunately this outweighs the pros. I called my boss and told them I felt unsafe here. There are men - possibly without a home who walk around and get too close to property office front door. I work alone - no cameras, bad lighting at night and 90% off the highway where anyone can walk up and shoot you, rape or rob basically do whatever they want to you. Anyway I told him about this and he said "call the police if they come in I can't really do anything about homeless men walking around your areas of work." He said nothing also didn't ask about how they could improve on security. Basically meant well ya know I can't do anything and nothing will change to improve your workplace. Also the bathrooms are filthy at some locations, causing me to use my gas to drive 5 miles and find a bathroom. They know these places are unsafe and dangerous with no lighting and dark hallways. Oh and they have job fairs 247, knowing were short handed and not hiring a single person. They want you to be over qualified for poverty wages and won't hire good honest people. My current manager wouldn't have hired me. I got in a couple of yrs before he did. You get 30 minutes for lunch. Enough time to drive across the interstate and grab some lunch and drive right back hopijg you get enough time to eat. If you are seen eating lunch while on the clock you will be looked down on. Don't work here unless you're willing to suffer while doing it.

title: Relief Manager
pros: Independent work environment, reimbursed for mileage, planning your time for the day and no micromanagement
cons: Hours conflict with your life if you are a single parent with children active in school functions, hardly any weekends off, convincing people to purchase locks, insurance and merchandise

title: Fantastic place to work!
pros: Growing company with a lot of opportunities to advance. Great work life balance. Stock incentives are awesome! Senior leadership acts quickly to the feedback provided by employees!
cons: Keeping up with the repair and maintenance of the facilities could be a challenge if you do not have great organizational skills

title: No respect, no form of promotion.
pros: - Working alone with minimal supervision is great for introverts. - Laid back and easy work on slow days
cons: - Expected to do practically 4 jobs, every day, by yourself, which include leasing/administration, sales of merchandise, collections, and janitorial work of the entire property. - After 3 years working there, the only time I got a raise was when they raised the new employee rate, so the new and long time managers got paid the same. - Very little to no support form supervising managers and higher-ups. - Expected to always do extra, no matter how much extra you do, its not enough. - Expected to solve customer issues that property managers don't have the authority to solve, then when trying to escalate, supervising managers hardly ever call customers back. - Company calls consist of sitting on the phone and listening to whining about the company not making enough money from the sales of property managers. - Expected to sell merchandise with no incentive, in fact, most supervising managers get bonuses if their district does well, but the people who actually do the selling get nothing. - Property managers are treated like they are stupid, with no respect, and given no authority. - Break ins happen constantly and 9/10 times nothing is done about it. Property managers are expected to explain the situation to the customer who lost their stuff, tell the customer to call the police and then tell them to call the insurance, who won't help them most of the time either. Storage facilities are a huge target for homeless, who know that the security is lacking and never gets fixed/updated. I was told one time that as cameras break on the property, that they would not be replaced, by the time I left the company, my property had 4 cameras, one on the entrance gate, one on the exit gate, one in the office and one on the dumpster. These camera's purposes were to see who came in, see who came out, see if an employee stole money/got robbed, and fine people for getting in the dumpster. Not a single storage unit was on camera. There were no burglar alarms, broken exterior lights for over 2 years, and gates that stay stuck open for weeks before being fixed, practically inviting people to come in and steal.

title: Good from far, far from good
pros: Guaranteed bonus first year Stay 5 years and first round stocks are fully vested
cons: No work life balance Very limited holiday time off, 3 days entire year On call during weekends Wear every hat, responsible for everything Lack of support Every problem is yours to deal with Worst communication among any company I have worked for Staffing issues year round. Scheduling issues year round. All of it the responsibility of DMs. No in between levels. All issues, big or small come directly to you.

title: Great place to work
pros: Very stable company, Plenty of room to advance, Work life balance is great,
cons: Slow to change when needed, the field has very little influence on any aspect of the business plan looking forward.

title: District Manager Position Review
pros: Work Life Balance/Focused Purpose/Supportive leaders
cons: Some customer decisions require further collaboration

title: Mundane, not paid well enough, stressful
pros: Job Stability+Benefits+Bonuses (competition) Room for (fast) growth. "Trusted" company brand name. The job started at $10/hr.
cons: Mundane Stressful/super slow! You do EVERY job: Customer Service, Billing, Administration, Complaints, Janitor, Maintenance, etc. Run into occasional break ins!

title: District Manager
pros: Decent pay, though not so much when you factor in hours worked.
cons: On-call 24/7 even on weekends and when on vacation. HIGH turn-over, property level employees have no authority so you babysit, everything changes each month or quarter, impossible to meet metrics, not enough money budgeted for constant repairs needed so you're forced to fudge the numbers then someone gets fired when it's discovered. Unethical company, run fast if you're even thinking of working here at any level.

title: never never land
pros: apartment on property, 40 hour work week, enjoy working with tenants from all over the United States and from other countries.
cons: no input from property managers. over priced locks. boxes and other merchandise, scripts that make you sound like a robot. DM that expect you to make there bonus for them and you get nothing no matter how hard you work. people at corp that have never worked at a property and have no idea what we do or put up with.

title: District manager
pros: The position is well defined and you know what is expected in order to succeed. You have the freedom to manage your business but have the support of a large company.
cons: Several of the policies are outdated and no longer apply to the current business.

title: Decent job
pros: Independent work environment. You get to drive a golf cart.
cons: 9/10 of your customer interactions are negative. High turn over rate. Pay is mediocre. Weekends are mandatory. No room for advancement. The attitude from upper management is "reach your goal any way that you can" even if it is unethical.

title: Relief Manager
pros: Daytime work hours Christmas bonus Vacation pay Pays mileage
cons: Mystery shoppers Unrealistic expectations Taxable bonus Low pay No support from upper management

title: Short but sweet
pros: I worked with smart friendly people who liked their jobs and their bosses.
cons: Tightly controlled company can change focus or direction quickly at the whim of upper management. In my case the board eliminated our department. Typical inter-department competition was present, but not in any way unpleasant. This is a good company to work for.

title: Not bad but not good.
pros: Meeting new people, a lot of down time, working on a computer which tells you everything you need to know,having scripts so you’ll never have to “freestyle” when speaking to a customer.
cons: Minimum wage, having excessive amount of hats that you have to wear such as: grounds keeper, landscaper,pest control,cashier,customer service.

title: Great Culture/Great Leadership
pros: Public Storage has been a FANTASTIC company to work for ever since the beginning. Here are some of the numerous pros of working as a District Manager at Public Storage: Work-Life Balance, Company Culture, Opportunity for Career Growth and Development, Amazing Leadership, and Peer Relationship.
cons: No cons that I can think of currently.

title: Abusive company, understaffed, underpaid
pros: They offer 40 hrs a week plus overtime. Offer 401k and insurance.
cons: Management is corrupt. The turnover rate is ridiculous. District managers quit like property managers do due to the treatment of their employees. Overworked in unsafe conditions the majority of the time. They do not value their employees even a bit. And if you call OSHA or the compliance line, they will retaliate and you will lose your job for some off the wall reason that they look over a billions times before when they use you. Forced to work in rat infested offices or storage units without proper attire. Only what they think complies and counts as safe for them. In my district that I worked over the span of 5 yrs, we went through 4 district managers. They coerce you to take positions you don't want and lie to get you there. This company and their management better be ashamed of themselves. If budget doesn't permit, you will be forced to live in their apartments with pests such as rats roaches or ants. God forbid you some how get bedbugs. Their budget also makes you walk huge properties without a golf cart in 100 degrees heat during the summer and to protect the customers put their employees in danger by putting them in situations, risking your literal lives in the winter snow. When you get robbed they don't press charges on the person and offer you to go and pay 10 for therapy on teladoc which is offered to everyone and not a benefits specifically from them whatsoever. This place is immoral and underpays their workers who take abuse from the company and the customers. Oh and when you do have a district manager don't expect support and help. Or even a response. They mainly hire women. Not much diversity. They limit you from advancing past a disgustingly underpaid DTM manager. Dms put half their work into the ktps, who abuse their power. Dts does the same. If you live on property you are constantly bother by customers banging on your door in the am during the day and at night. Then the company adds to all of that by making Kiosk properties. Those properties get broken into without any repercussions. Are disgusting because they're so understaffed that they make 1 manager go to 3 or more properties in the day regardless of health issues, restrictions or age. Just downright horrible. There needs to be an investigation.

title: Public Storage - A great career
pros: Public Storage is a great place to have a career and is competitive with other companies I have worked for. The salary is competitive and the company provides great work life balance.
cons: Some upgrades could be made with some of the technology utilized. This is an issue that has been in the works over time and will be rectified.

title: Good Company
pros: A very solid company with good people. Well run and steady.
cons: Some profit sharing for all and a boost in the 401k contribution would be good for all. Our middle class is going away - this would help.

title: Relief Manager
pros: Easy and straight forward job. Simple 9-5 schedule.
cons: Underpaid and the responbilities and expectations are always growing, without the pay growing along with it. Some employees do not get fully trained if they are short on people and get sent into work without proper training.

title: District manager
pros: Autonomy, in the job training, support from peers, owning your own business, hiring your own team, development daily, processes and policies are structured for you to stay focused and understand the bigger picture. Opportunity to assist throughout the company with acquisitions, natural disasters and other situations.
cons: Ask questions and lean in to learning and your own development to stay focused and challenged

title: Great Company to Work for
pros: Great company, work life balance is amazing, compensation package is extremely good. You will succeed if you can time manage properly.
cons: I haven’t come across any yet. All I would say is that company needs a better process for the facility side of the business. It can take a while to get something very simple fixed.

title: Great People & Opportunity!
cons: istent leadership and unafraid to make a change when it's best for the business. A culture of supporting your team without removing accountability.

title: Second worst company I’ve ever worked for.
pros: The pros for working here is if you becOme an on-site property manager, you get to live rent free.
cons: The cons are they ask you to do a ridiculous amount of work and do t pay very well. The regional manager is very shady and the expectations are ridiculous. If your an on-site property manager your basically on call because if something happens on the property your the one that has to attend to it. P matter what time it is, and you don’t even get paid to be on call.

title: Bad district managers Good company
pros: Great training provided, gives you great tools to complete your job effectively and efficiently. Good pay many locations.
cons: Only three days off a year when they are closed. They have a huge difference from District to District management.

title: OVER-WORKED & UNDER-PAID
pros: A diverse work environment, differentiated customer demographic's based on property location, and a strong work-life balance orientation for employees.
cons: Public Storage ROBS its customers and takes advantage of its employees. From one stranger to another, SAVE YOURSELF THE HEADACHE AND WORK ANYWHERE ELSE. First and foremost, if you recognize the difference between a Franchise (like your local McDonald’s or Pizza Hut) and a Corporation (like Apple or Public Storage) - you know how terrible it can be for both the customer and the employee with very limited power. Public Storage’s California Headquarters mandates every move of ALL PS locations across the country - all the way down to how merchandise is displayed on-site to the rental rates of units to the digital time listing on office telephones (no matter the timezone it’s actually located in). Just imagine trying to find out the details of your auctioned-off unit or negotiating your storage bill with a person whose cost-of-living is 38% higher, receiving 40% more in annual income than those living in the rest of the United States… you better have the legal claim ready for filing otherwise you won't achieve much. When applying for a “Property Manager” (PM) position, as posted online - individuals are hired in as “Relief Managers” (RFM) traveling from location to location (within an assigned district) to manage a property on the regularly scheduled “PM’s” day off. This position entails running the property as if you were in the same role, with the same base knowledge of customer accounts/property details, and play the acting role of PM while the other individual is away. The description of duties in the online position posting is FAR FROM the actual day-to-day responsibilities of individuals in the role. Both RFM’s and PM’s are paid the same, barely livable wage ($10/hr) - sold with the “bountiful benefit programs” that PS swoons about, but is awarded to the rare and few that most will never see the benefits from. Each day employees are expected to clean empty units, manage up-keep on the property (including bugs, vermin, and other facility requirements), clean on-site facilities (bathrooms, hallways, office spaces, elevators, etc.). All the while, placing recorded phone calls following a specific scripting to 15-50 customers, sell merchandise, seek new tenants/provide in-person customer service, and meet required margins in various categories monitored by the District Manager and Regional Manager. Save yourself the headache and work somewhere, ANYWHERE, else.

title: A lot of not enought pay....

cons: You do a lot of work but they dont pay you enough for the work that you do.... Its sanitation, call center, lifting, working in all types of weather, data entry, and leasing just to name a few. All that for almost nothing.

Yesterday, I came in with multiple problems and he found ways to resolve and continue to help me out. Public Storage couldn't do better with this employee!!!

They make sure that the hard workers do not receive a raise but that the district managers favorites do get one. All in all it is the WORST company I have EVER worked for in my life. Benefits suck as well. Upper management are so greedy!
