title: Great work/life balance
pros: Schedule, promotion opportunities, teammates, ability to develop team with actual time for coaching, stock options, job stability (industry is always needed, in good and bad economic environments).
cons: Not a tech savvy company, need to empower DMs more to improve customer service. Better base rate compensation instead of solely focusing on stocks.

title: Great Millennial Employment
pros: Short training, great managers and trainers. Great job relocation opportunity. The daily grind changes daily. Diverse work environment. 9 to 5 hours I can have life and live it. 401 k and good vacation benes
cons: Scheduled days off. no mandatory overtime (I like to work) sometimes u must travel

title: If you are ready to leave retail, go to PS
pros: Autonomy, off weekends, you get to see your results make a direct impact, competitive, great bonus structure, transparent feedback, sense of “job security”
cons: Not glamorous in anyway, can take a long time before you feel like an “expert”

title: Low pay. Stressful and aggravating.
pros: Employee apartments. Health benefits, pto, no nights. Nice if you like working outside
cons: Shady line of work, crazy, rude customers. Can be strenuous, having to clear storage spaces not just sweep, but actually having to move items abandoned by customers and dead rats to the dumpster. High turnover.

title: Great employer bad for single mothers with kids
pros: Everything was great especially pay
cons: Pto process is ridiculous you can’t use any They add mandatory overtime to your shift regardless if you have kids to take to daycare or not Your first week determines the shift you get and it’s more than difficult to get that changed.

title: starter job
pros: my DM was understanding and extremely kind. My other property manager did the job properly.
cons: communication, Relief managers just sit in the office and don't clean or stage. let alone make any calls and never gets held accountable for their actions or lack there of

title: Great Company that is run by an outstanding group of leaders. PS is a world leader in the Storage Industry!
pros: Public Storage's DM training program is top notch and helps its newer DM's learn the nuts and bolts of the business and prepares them to succeed.
cons: None - I am very optimistic about the outlook and competitive strategy of our company.

title: My experience was neutral.
pros: My experience at Public Storage can be described as neutral. There were both good and bad aspects to the company. The work is fairly easy.
cons: I wouldn't really recommend this for personal growth. The company is okay but career is not fulfilling. The corporation has some sketchy aspects.

title: Horrible
pros: You meet people coming from all walks of life. There's really nothing else good to say about public storage. they just don't care and I learn that by working here for over 5 years.
cons: Unappreciative, upper management doesn't care about their managers, underpaid.When things break they don't get fixed. Corporation really doesn't care. And they wonder why their turnover is so high.

title: Great balance between work and life.
pros: Great atmosphere, I enjoy the customer interaction. The work schedule is awesome; bankers hours, you can actually have a life.
cons: There are occasions where you will work alone, not necessarily bad. Every so often you may have to dispose of customer's abandonef property.

title: Great Place to Work
pros: The People - Truly thoughtful and friendly co-workers. Opportunity - The company continues to grow and develop, offering multiple paths for advancement. Work/Life Flexibility - Hard work is rewarded, but life outside of work is also very much valued.
cons: Not a lot of options for lunch within walking distance.

title: Too many expectations
pros: Fulltime, steady paycheck, mileage reimbursement, ok co workers
cons: Poor management, Higher ups gossip about you with other managers, embarrass you in front of coworkers, coworkers act like your boss, safety, customers threaten you, no advancement

title: Hate it.
pros: SOME customers are great and give you free stuff. And you are always guaranteed at least 38 hours. And benefits are okay.
cons: Too many cons to list. Main one is pay is not enough! And raise is 15cents a year! Slap in the face. When you go from relief manager to property manager there is no raise. You just run the property by yourself most of the time. Dms do not care at all.

title: Stay away from D0125
pros: Having the same hours to work every week is a nice perk
cons: Management doesn't know what they're doing or what the policies are, any repairs or work orders you need to fix your property or any units take at very least three weeks and upwards of a few months to get repaired, then management gets upset when nothing is fixed on your property.

title: Solid Company to work for
pros: i'm happy with this company because of the flexibility of work hours and also the people I work with at our department and our manager are great. It's not a stressful job.
cons: the salary and the benefits are not competitive.

title: Stay far away!!!
pros: None that I can think of
cons: They are discriminatory towards certain protected class employees (ie they don’t care for naked employees). They modify the hours to pay you less and avoid paying over-time. They are sneaky and very juvenile whenever they have a person on the chopping block. Management lies and are not trustworthy

title: Company overall
pros: You get set start times and end of day times. There are benefits And bonuses
cons: You have to build up your vacation time and you don't seem like you get very much free time.

title: Does not value employees
pros: I enjoyed everything about my job.
cons: The company would rather let a good employee go rather than support or offer any help when they are the target for harassment, blackmail, etc.

title: Bogus Reviews from Glendale
pros: All these unknown employees that work at corp. They all come from HR or at their behest. Just like FAKE Google reviews that are required for locations, that the DMs threaten managers with firing.
cons: Poor pay, no bonuses (there's a chance for a small one). NO chance for advancement.

title: Don't.
pros: Easy work. The people you work with are usually wonderful.
cons: Lots of pressure for sales. Often work alone at properties that should be double covered. Many of the locations I worked made me feel unsafe.

title: Easy
pros: Great co-workers, easy job, 3 weeks paid training, most locations you work alone, great for college students who needs the down time to work on school work.
cons: Not any cons in my opinion

title: Relief Property Manager
pros: The work is easy with plenty of opportunity to exercise and not be stuck in an office all day.
cons: The company is always right.

title: Manager
pros: None about this company at all
cons: For what they want you to do the pay definitely isn’t worth it and they treat you like peasants

title: Great Co-Workers
pros: Excellent Training program KTP Manager is the BEST! The Westside KTP Manager trains new employees. Overall...Public Storage is a great company to work for.
cons: The hourly pay is not the best.

title: Are you ready for a change?
pros: Our company continues to open doors for career driven individuals and there are so many opportunities available.
cons: Every employer has cons and everyone is different as far as opinions.

title: Good job.
pros: You work alone, Flexible schedule, good benefits, and cool team members.
cons: Angry customers can be hard to deal with, sometimes there can be a lot of work to do in the day, and sometimes you need to drive a bit of a distance to get to the property you’re working at.

title: Would not recommend
pros: You work on your own most of the time
cons: You never get a pay increase or commission but they want you to sell sell sell! No real recognition for people who work their butts off.

title: No Way
pros: Flexible schedule. I can't think of any other pros.
cons: Micro managing boss, cheap company who brags about cash on hand constantly.

title: District Manager
pros: Excellent compensation. Good company structure. Zero worries about layoffs
cons: No work life balance. Demanding pace.

title: Senior Regional Manager
pros: Public Storage is a great place to work. I enjoy the autonomy of the position and the people and supervisors I work with are supportive.
cons: Stock grants have been generous making me feel like a business owner. Base salary could be more competitive especially in major metropolitan markets.

title: Not so much
pros: It gives you the freedom to work on other things
cons: They are contradicting and make it a sales job but the pay is only good if you have no family and in college

title: Stay away
pros: Time off if you find a boss that allows you to take it
cons: Under staffed unreasonable expectations money game you can get the best numbers but have one bad day and your treated like crap for it .. no advancement you will never make more than $14.5 even as a trainee

title: Great Entry into customer service.
pros: The work hours are great and Pretty flexible schedule wise.
cons: No real Possibility to grow and the ceiling is easy reachable with in a couple of years.

title: It was ok
pros: The place rarely closed for holidays so if you were new you’d be working holidays. Usually no one looking over your shoulder. If you got your stuff done you’re good.
cons: A little creepy being alone most of the time. Dealing with angry customers because you’re the only one on site.

title: corp. greed
pros: co-workers are cool. very cool.
cons: The company has changed the employees get a bonus. It went from every 3 months to every month. (everyone was getting a bonus) In 2012 the company changed it so that ONLY 40% of the field employees get a !! Not fair. Especially after pushing them hard for numbers, so that the DM's can get their bonus either way...

title: Great company to work for.
pros: Business generates lots of cash for growth and justifies high stock price. Management team always seeking to improve
cons: Not in a flashy business of renting storage units Sometimes not thought of as a leading edge company but it is the leader in the industry.

title: Decent place
pros: Hours, Starting pay,Paid training,Coworkers,Office environment
cons: Fight for raise 3 paid holidays and there is a catch as to who gets paid Open 7 days a week Selling peoples belongings

title: Great place to work
pros: I appreciate the Flexible Work Schedules since I commute a long distance. They also offer Lots of opportunity for advancement. All of the employees are friendly and Helpful. They seem to genuinely care about the employees and their families.
cons: Long Commute and no rideshare

title: The expect way too much and pay too little.
pros: I enjoyed the work. No one looking over your shoulder every day. I also loved the customers.
cons: It you are a property manager they expect perfection, but if you are a relief manager they hardly expect you to even do your job, yet bothpositions make the same amount of money per hour. Do not work here this is a predatory company that acts morally bankrupt.

title: Home away from home
pros: Day one everyone at PS made me feel welcomed. It feels like a family, you are treated as an individual and not as a number. Great opportunities for those that are willing to work for it.
cons: No cons, only wish I found PS sooner.

title: Horrible company to work for!!!
pros: Some downtime. One shift only, no night shifts.
cons: No bonuses, no pay raises and yet they are on your back constantly micro managing and lying to customers with bait and switch tactics.

title: Alot work little pay
pros: Not many incestives gone except GO TEAM GO!
cons: Know your training by da 3 their STAR MOMENTS WITH OR WITHOUT TRAINING.YOU WILL ROLE PLAY THESE DAILY!THROUGH 9 DAYS TRAINING!KNOW HOW TO SELL THE PRODUCTS RIGHT AWAY!Make sure your 9 day training happens on schedule and you learn manager and relief manager job for all the sites and how its run ALL DIFFERENT.Have codes rules ect before you go& know tennant problems ahead of time.9 days training not enough!

title: Poor place to work
pros: There’s no one there micromanaging you.
cons: You work alone a lot which could kind of be a good thing but it’s a bad thing because the company and forces rules that caused the employees to get a lot of backlash. you spend part of your day cleaning and part of your day and an office and then a majority of your day getting cussed out by customers. The pay sucks they are one of the lowest paying storage company.

title: Lots of down time!
pros: More or less be your own boss. Insane scripts they paid a consultancy too much money for that don’t work. District Managers do nothing except explain sales numbers they have no affect on to upper management and make quintuple your salary.
cons: It’s a bad, greedy company that inflates its prices and removes promotions during natural disasters.

title: A good job to start out with if you’re looking for full time.
pros: The people. The hours. The money. My DIstrict Managers were excellent.
cons: Corporate, if you’ve ever felt like corporate didn’t care you’ll see that here.

title: Bait and switch
pros: Well established and organized corporate ran company that provides an awesome training program to allow you to advance to property manager.
cons: They do not promote from within. High turn over rate due to lack of communication and compassion from upper management

title: Great people, great potential...
pros: Reasonable hours, acceptable benefits and, in my case, exceptional leadership and associates.
cons: The $ leader in the industry and yet, the worst pay at $13/hr. They do not pay commensurate with their expectations. Also, zero advancement opportunity.

title: Overall this job is good.
pros: The pros of the job are that they compensate pretty good in my opinion for what they ask you to do on the job.
cons: The cons of the job are that they are very micro managed. Coming from a retailer that gave more freedom to impact the business this has been a negative.

title: My career with Public Storage
pros: One of the best things working for Public Storage is they care in customer service. They provide the best training to make you the storage expert, between product knowledge, customer service, policy and safety.
cons: One of the down sides is holiday office hours

title: Love at storage
pros: Co workers and on site living are pretty amazing add awe some benefits and they are perfect.
cons: Clients are mean and trashy, cleaning up after them is gross, and sometimes unsanitary.

title: Property manager
pros: Great job you know the hours are always the same.
cons: They don't hire within the company, the highest you could become is property manager. The pay rate should be higher given all the things you do.

pros: You work alone and plan your own day
cons: No assistance from anyone when needed. Expected to do a lot on your own. No raises, no bonuses, no advancement, and a lot of drama.

title: Great place to work
pros: Flexible schedules, great work/life balance, very supportive management. Full benefits with many options.
cons: Some days can be kind of boring.

title: FANTASTIC!
pros: My Company may take pride in what they stand for...but the employees make it happen..WE ARE.. BY FAR.. THE BEST TEAM TO BE A PART OF!!
cons: Only down side is having to fight traffic to and from work.

title: It’s alright
pros: Scheduling flexibility, generous time off package
cons: The work is not intellectually stimulating, you have to cut locks every month, and you are directly managing low level hourly employees

title: Dead end
pros: Set schedule paid sick leave accrued vacation.... slowly...
cons: No holidays off or paid. No raise. Milage reimbursement gets lower as gas prices go up. Randomly started to close properties. Can't cut the grass when the landscapers dont show up for 2 years and the city complains.

title: This company is focused only on achieving numbers and does not care about customers or employees.
pros: Apartments for property managers and no nights.
cons: benefits, politics, incompetent leaders, making people learn scripts

title: Review
pros: Great work environment and senior management is open to learning and suggestions to make the work environment better
cons: Benefits seem to be in constant decline. Less time off and holiday/sick pay. Use of sick days is very restrictive and really puts a strain on working parents

title: dont recommend
pros: great hours , a good student job or retired folks, great employees
cons: not a good pay , don't treat there employees good , they expect more out of you for less money

title: Relief manager
pros: Hours were good, bonus Christmas money, 401k and healthcare benefits, raise after 3 months, good training. Good environment, you are your own boss
cons: Cleaning dusty storage spaces, temperature in the buildings and office were almost below freezing. Typical work day was very slow. Mandatory weekends

title: Manager
pros: There is good training fo entry level customer service and management. Variety of work to do, not in an office all day.
cons: Low pay and upper management always wanting you to do more. Constant turn over in personnel.

title: Store Manager
pros: There are no pros to working at this company, The pay, management, and employees in the woodbridge area are awful.
cons: The pay is low compared to the amount of work you do Management is terrible

title: Company is great, the people in my district acted like children and my district manager played favorites
pros: Company's policies were clear and to the point.
cons: If your not a property manager you get treated like crap in one of the district's

title: Upper Mgmt Truth
pros: This company will probably never go out of business.
cons: The truth * On call 24/7. * 99% of customer interactions are negative * Property repair process is archaic at best * positive reviews on Glassdoor are internally solicited due to poor real reviews * compensation doesn’t equal expectations * no diversity in upper management * micro management at all levels * you can do better. Apply somewhere else

title: Low pay High stress
pros: Friendly co-workers that bond through horror stories of bad customers and terrible CSR issues.
cons: Abusive customers. High stress levels. Not compensated for stressful calls. Forced overtime. Broken CSR that crashes daily.

title: Needs work
pros: Get alot of overtime and consecutive days off
cons: Company makes you do everything for minimum wage they dont care about their employees ,they say you will do light cleaning but you are the janitor,manager,security, and maintenance workers

title: A Great Place to Work
pros: The job allows for a lot of customer service experience, entry-level sales experience, and you get to meet a variety of different people.
cons: It can be tense to interact with certain customers and it's required to work at least one day of the weekend.

title: A Fast Paced Environment
pros: Autonomy, great pay, few people between worker and executives as opposed to other large firms, good benefits, good work environment, work and life balance
cons: Rapid growth, rapidly changing direction, lack of process and procedures, lack of training, lack of technology tools, isolation, no growth opportunity.

title: It was OK
pros: You don't have a manager breathing down your neck all day.
cons: You have to memorize scripts and they expected you to use them for all interactions. They expected you to persuade customers to keep renting storage units when they were moving out.

title: Great place to work
pros: - Positive business outlook - Leadership development - Continuous improvement - Data driven - Supportive team environment
cons: - Heavy task workload at times. I appreciate that we complete time studies to continually evaluate workload.

title: Hard work sometimes pays off
pros: Hard work and effort is rewarded. After tenure is established it becomes much easier and flexible job.
cons: Low morale and poor communication between management levels and departments

title: Very slow, very micro managed,. ..
pros: Not bad money for very easy work. Benefits are okay. If you don't mind sitting most of the day, it's probably the job for you. Maybe great for a retired person.
cons: You have to memorize these crazy scripts. Working alone. Very boring. You have to leave the building on your break. Which just seems odd. The uniforms are awful.

title: Complete Joke
pros: Working Alone, Balance of Outside and Office Work, Decent rapport with most co-workers,
cons: No Chance of Internal Promotion, Lack of empathy and respect from most of the Direct Supervisors, Lack of salary competition against rivals, Lack of Customer Service abilities from other managers.

title: Never a dull moment!
pros: Same job daily, but interaction with different people from walks of life daily, which I enjoyed.
cons: I didn't like cleaning the restrooms. :{

title: Dead end job
pros: Money, however little you actually see...
cons: Same low life delinquent clients to deal with every month, always cussing at you and fighting with you about having to pay their bill. Being forced by the company to push worthless storage insurance which half the time will not pay out to the customers for legit claims. Low pay. And quite literally no way to advance.

title: Great Company!
pros: Never a dull moment. Very challenging and fast paced environment. Allways doing something new and interesting. Yes, we work hard but are able to participate in the growth of the company.
cons: No cons to speak of.

title: Great place to work
pros: Good atmosphere and helpful colleagues. Well-run company that has grown a great deal in recent years and still has a bright future.
cons: While some mid-level managers have "favorite" employees without sufficient reason, there is nothing earth-shattering that doesn't occur at other companies.

title: Not to shabby
pros: Knowing what you need to do day to day its easy work once you get the hang of it pretty relaxed.
cons: It can get extremely slow. You need to be able to keep your self busy or else you will get so board.

title: Relief manager
pros: Full time hours 9:30-6:30, downtime
cons: Running a large facility basically by yourself. Being a janitor and office manager all at the same time.

title: Great place to work! Its like working with a family. District managers and hire are easy to work with.
pros: Not just the same old job every day. Variety of daily tasks to be completed. Work indoors and outdoors. Flexible schedule.
cons: No cons, Im happy with my job.

title: My experience with public storage is amazing. They help you succeed at your job. You are never alone
pros: The professional people I work with
cons: One challenge is learning while you work. However I love learning

title: Can't get in touch to get W2
pros: Ioved working there, unfortunately the commute was killing me in gas. Had to suddenly quit because had local job offer to start immediately. DM blocked my number. Can't reach him to give new address. Email, and number. . Can't file taxes without the W2 VERY FRUSTRATING!!!!! HOPE CEO SEES THIS AND RESOLVES IT ASAP!!!!!!!
cons: No communication 😨 and I can't file taxes!!!!!!!!!!

title: Great place to work!
pros: A great environment, lots of collaboration, team efforts. . In general, a good balance of work to life is supported
cons: Employer needs to contribute more on employees benefits and their dependents. Premiums keeps increasing every year

title: A friendly work environment
pros: I enjoy working at the Public Storage Corporate offices because there's a friendly work environment. It a place where you can be established and grow. Management is great and very approachable.
cons: I don't have any cons

title: Loved Public Storage, I only left because they do not promote to District Manager from wothin.
pros: Loved the support from upper management. Great hours, no nights! I was awarded trips and bonuses for exceeding standards.
cons: Unable to advance to upper management from a Property Manager Status.

title: Unappreciated Manager
pros: Free housing for Resident Manager, day shift no late nights, works independently
cons: Low pay, job description constantly changes, work holidays with no holiday pay

title: It was good.
pros: Helping people with their moving needs. Nice customers and plenty of resources. Easy location. Big facility. Wonderfull workers. Good general managment.
cons: It was difficult getting time off when needed. District meetings every month. A lot of travel. Always changing how to speak to customers.

title: Relief Manager
pros: Gives you the skill set to work with a diverse clientele as well as bettering yourself with customer service techniques.
cons: Not alot of room for advancement. Benefits and rewards for performance are slim to none. High stress environment.

title: Great starter position
pros: The job is easy but it’s only hard when having to deal with rodent infested properties the pay is only 10.50 and semi monthly pay period
cons: The rodents and the rain and cold weather be prepared to be handy man

title: Great place to work at!
pros: Excellent work-life balance with top-notch benefits. The company really cares about their employees.
cons: None that I can’t think of! Every company has its pros and cons, but with PS it’s all about the cons

title: Good thing I'm not married
pros: Work from home full time
cons: Mandatory OT daily. Back to back 10 hr shifts equalling over 100 calls with angry customers Most of the time you cant request PTO. Get used to taking sick time when you just need a break.

title: PMs & Relief Mgrs are treated like they’re disposable
pros: So many locations you’re lucky if you’re able to work close to your residence
cons: Most field ops (PMs & Relief Mgrs) do not make a liveable wage which forces them to require public assistance for healthcare, subsidized food stamps & housing

title: Great company
pros: I love the great teamwork with my fellow coworkers and management. The great opportunities for advancement such as Property Managers and KTP ( Knowledge Training Personal) etc.
cons: That the job market is such that we don’t get enough people that apply for positions.

title: Not so bad
pros: Good hours and good days off if your property manager.
cons: I'm sorry but annoying customers due to the area.

title: Relief Managee
pros: Creating bonds with regular customers and gaining that customer service experience all at once.
cons: Having to work outside is unbearable weather at times.

title: • Assist reservation and walk-in customers in renting storage units
pros: Company provides all the training to be successful in the position. Not physically demanding.
cons: Fixed pay. Non-negotiable. Limits growth inside the company.

title: Public Storage is not a good company to work for.
pros: You get to leave at 6pm, sometimes.
cons: No days off. Harrassed by customers daily. Poor accommodations. Poor compensation. Policies are convoluted. No stability. District managers are unbearable.

title: Best company i have ever worked for..
pros: The people are great and the company is even better. If you work hard you will get great rewards!!
cons: Nothing. I enjoy working for this company.

title: Okay place to work
pros: Alot of training, no one over your shoulder daily
cons: Pay doesn't match other storage companies. Open Sundays. Open holidays.

title: There is lots of favoritism and management creates chaotic work environment.
pros: Great learning opportunities. Teamwork atmosphere can be great with a good leader to follow.
cons: Lack of honesty and integrity. Lack of leadership

title: It was ok only parttime
pros: the hours was good had a great boss that was willing to work with my schedule.
cons: cleaning out the storage rooms was the worst parts and customers that got upset at me when they didn't their storage bill

title: Great for short term, don't get stuck
pros: Pros: you are full time and if you're a property manager you stay at one location.
cons: The opportunity to get a bonus becomes more difficult every year. A lot of pressure coming from corp, my work load is double what it use to be but I have not received a pay increase

title: Don't Do It!
pros: You don't have the late nights that are the retail norm.
cons: Awful working conditions, District Managers ask you to lie to customers, no on-site safety for employees or customers...and the list goes on.

title: life at public storage
pros: work is easy Great job with no supervision. The only perk is an apartment rent and utilities included
cons: low pay and unrealistic bonus metrics.

title: Great until new DM took over
pros: On site apartment, the benefits were great, learned quite on how the storage business works, the co workers were great as well as the customers
cons: The new DM did not know what he was doing, fired me over a lousy promo, that pretty much sums it up

title: Great Company, Stable Employment
pros: Great working environment. Lots of room for professional growth. Great Benefits and compensation. Remodeled Facilities, always clean, security on-site at all times and plenty of parking.
cons: Open all major holidays (except Thanksgiving, Christmas, New Year)

title: Public Storage Review
pros: Some good, knowledgeable people. Easy location to get to.
cons: Antiquated IT technologies and ideaology. Too many older white men in management positions. Strict facilities management, limited parking, small eating areas.

title: Huge gap between upper management and employees
pros: If you are applying for a DM position or higher, then you will get all of the benefits of this organization. High pay, flexible hours, job security.
cons: The pay gap between DM and other employees is enormous, it is disheartening to see a company doing so well paying their employees minimum wage. It is difficult to see the cycle of wealth disparity right in front of your eyes.

title: Not my favorite job
pros: Cool co-workers and supervisors. Willing to give time off. Decent hourly wage.
cons: Call center is not "Corporate" so we do not get the same benefits. There are no raises and they have horrible bonus structure.

title: Corporate Accounting/Auditing
pros: A pleasing and family-like environment for everyday office works. Management staffs are nice and supportive. Company is financially sound and keep growing.
cons: Cons? It's all on you. If you don't perform as expected or required, you could easily be offshored.

title: Sales rep
pros: Flexible with your schedule Great environment everyone is super nice!!!
cons: Bonus structure sucks Expectations for your reservation rate and production is way too high since all of our facilities are about 98% full

title: It's an OK Job
pros: Good hours, work outside, not micro managed, good starter
cons: No room for advancement after Property Manger, raises are not equal to work performed

title: Property manager
pros: Freedom to work unsupervised, got to drive a golf cart. Meet interesting people and the auction days are fun.
cons: Lots of cleaning and hauling junk, cleaning public restroom, angry clients hold you responsible

title: Great Company to Work For
pros: Great visibility to Management and Leadership Ability to make and implement change quickly Great stable company Company continues to want to lead the industry Many positions are only promoted from within instead of externally hired
cons: None currently at this time

pros: Benefits, able to live on site
cons: There is no growth after KTP

title: avoid if you want a work life balance.
pros: If you like to be a landlord and auctioneer this is the job for you.
cons: Having to deal with break-in on a weekly basis and then dealing with the customers that had their person items stolen.

title: Control your destiny
pros: Ability to be seen and recognized by all levels of Leadership, you get back what you put in, great working hours and the Leaders work to put you in the best position to succeed.
cons: Tough to hire during the Pandemic

title: Store manager
pros: Easy and relaxed environment Meet new people On site apartment 2 off days Benefits Paid time off Sick time off
cons: Does not pay enough Lots of traveling Dangerous interactions Favoritism No room of advancement Non livable wage Rude managers Older properties

title: Breeding a culture of disrespect and focused only on the bottom line.
pros: Locations everywhere. Successful business model.
cons: Concerned only with profitability, not creating a great place to work or facilitating a positive work-life balance.

title: Time spent at Public Storage
pros: Working at night was not required.
cons: On site managers are bothered at home. The pay is very low and the benefits are not good.

title: relief property manager
pros: Good hrs. Good benefits. Self paced
cons: Working multiple properties. Select lazy employees. SCRIPTED CONVERSATIONS

title: Great company!!
pros: I've been with the company for 18 years...needless to say, job security. It's a great company to work for. Everyone is so friendly it makes coming to work enjoyable.
cons: It would be nice to get more Corporate holidays.

title: Pay could be better. Hours are good though.
pros: Set days off are awesome, vacation is good and hours.
cons: Pay is not enough and moving around to different locations can become stressful

title: they don't care!
pros: Set hours, some properties are pleasant.
cons: Disgraceful pay, micromanagement by district managers, unsafe environment, repairs are not made quickly, constant threat of job security, property managers and relief managers do all the work and the district managers and above receive the bonuses.

title: It's Okay...
pros: You have a job... some live on properties... medical benefits
cons: As a manager you are micro management and merely a customer service representative

title: No room for advancement
pros: Awesome DM and freedom to make decisions
cons: low pay, tons of work, no room for advancement and they do not promoted from within unless you are a DM or higher

title: Corporate IT - Software Development
pros: Knowledgeable workforce team Great environment, vision and most importantly - team! Low turn over rate - corporate HQ Compensation is fair Flexible work schedule
cons: Benefit package Not many paid holidays - only 3

title: Public Storage Review
pros: The position is flexible with great work life balance. The people I work for and with have a great relationship with one another and it makes it fun.
cons: Very happy at this point. Nothing negative to report.

title: Public Storage is a great place to work.
pros: Public Storage offers a wide range of positions that challenge your skill set. You work in a friendly, safe environment.
cons: No immediate downsides that I have seen with my position.

title: A Stepping Stone
pros: Great Hours and Benefits. Provided Housing in select markets and at the time of employment had annual bonus incentives. Self dependent.
cons: Lack of Growth and advancement. Low wages for the amount of work they ask.

title: Horrible place to work
pros: There honestly were no pros to the job but a paycheck
cons: EVERYTHING. They want you to be security, a janitor, administrative assistant, a mover, all for $11.50 . You have no steady store , you literally have to drive to at least 8 locations . The insurance sucks so bad. I could go on and on .

title: Treating your stuff like our stuff since 1972
pros: Excellent work life balance, flexible scheduling. diversity, inclusion, team-oriented.
cons: Limited managerial and leadership positions.

title: Better than fast food, but not by much.
pros: Hours, recession-resistant business, very little manual labor, on-site apartment
cons: Low pay, no opportunities for advancement, management rules by intimidation not motivation.

title: Exhausting
pros: Was a good place to work until managment changes took place.
cons: Went down hill once new management took over Dm and Above.

title: The 900 lb Gorilla
pros: Good place to train in the self storage business. You learn about deceptive practices and how this company will con their customers.
cons: Low pay, poor benefits, bad ethics on how to treat customers and employees. Overbearing managers who really don't care about anything except their own selves.

title: Sales
pros: Good environment, not a lot of over time expected but available when you want it. Pay is reliable & commissions are good.
cons: Not easy to move up, they rarely hire Management from within the company & that is bad for moral.

pros: gain manager skill set, good stepping stone and resume builder
cons: no work life balance or consideration, coworkers are not supportive, creates for a tense and micromanaged environment unnecessarily

title: Dont waste your time AT ALL
pros: Full time okay hours during week
cons: Low pay and rude district manger lazy and sloppy

title: Relief Manager
pros: Start work 9:00am, able to work indoors and outside
cons: No advancements in company, long time to get raises and very small if you do. Expected to be a robot and salesman but with no incentive

title: Property manager
pros: There is no reason I can think of to work for public storage. I really don't know why I stuck around for 8 years.
cons: The pay wage is not comparable never get raises no cost of living raise. New recognition a lot of hard work top management changes thoughts and ideas constantly. Treated with no respect.

title: Relief Manager
pros: A lot of downtime. No Daily Supervision. Paid time off.
cons: Sales are shoved down your throat, and you don't get jack for it. No promotions & bonuses. Constant customer complaints, because upper management never wants to fix anything. Insurance is a SCAM! I've seen it first hand. Start treating your customers & employees better! Maybe, you won't have such a high turnover.

title: District Manager
pros: Work/Life Balance, Career Advancement, Stock Ownership, Company Culture, Job Autonomy, Manage FT Employees
cons: Removing Delinquent Customer Locks, Limited Positive Customer Interaction (in comparison to Big Box Retail)

title: Property Manager
pros: Independent work evironment. Some storage facilities offer apartments.
cons: Awful company. Does not give you the tools necessary to do your job. We are told to sell off of scripts. We are also told to push insurance which does nothing for the customers. Awful business practices and extremely unethical. Also, they do not promote from within. If you are a property manager, that is the highest you can go.

title: Join Our Team!
pros: Great hours, engaging management team, relaxed workplace, onsite living accommodations available, advancement opportunities, different experiences daily!
cons: Weekends required; open on some holidays

title: Profits are All that Matter to Public Storage
pros: Decent pay for DMs and above.
cons: They do not pay hourly employees enough for the amount of work they ask. Bonus targets are very difficult to hit. Benefits are just OK and you only get Thanksgiving and Christmas off for holidays.

title: Great Place to Work!
cons: istent hours/Flexible schedule. Reliable teammates that are happy to help you. Empowered to work independently. Transparency with job expectations.

title: Very underpaid for what you do.
pros: lots of down time where your basically just sitting there listening to customer issues.
cons: There’s always 1000 things to do and never anytime to get it done, customers tend to get on your case for anything.

title: The company is very well structured. Great place to work if you care about people and your team

title: Good company for long term employment

cons: Health Benefits change often. Extreme micro-management with constantly changing tasks. As a property manager you have no weekends off unless negotiated upon hiring.

title: Great job
pros: Helping customers makes this job worth it

title: Public Storage
pros: Job security, stock, 401k match, PTO
cons: Workload and amount of admin, large districts, staffing for front line, hard to retain, not all markets are created equal but pay is the same

title: Worst place to work
pros: Pay is decent and hours are decent

title: Horrible company

cons: Management doesn’t care about you they only care about how much money they can make they pay you the bare minimum and if you do well they put a bunch of rules to lose the pay you deserve I don’t recommend working for this company.

title: decent work/life balance

title: Love this company! Great upper management and staff.

title: Bare Minimum

No room for advancement after reaching property management because the company doesn't hire within for the higher level positions regardless of an employee's knowledge and experience. Relief/Property Management includes customer service, janitorial, light maintenance, security, administrative duties, and light banking all for a whopping $10/hr and $10.50/hr after six months.

title: Public Storage
pros: Work independently. Other Property managers are very helpful and easy to worth with. There is a lot of variety of work.

cons: The pay is terrible, they don’t give raises, and there’s no upward mobility. And that’s just the start.

title: Good job

title: I came, I saw, I regret...
pros: Truly interesting customers. Occasionally getting the feeling that you've helped make a life a little less stressful in some small way.
cons: Work environment almost celebrates the very things one would avoid (from an HR standing). HR/open door/compliance reporting is a JOKE on a good day. The grapevine is the preferred method of information gathering for important decision making. Favoritism runs rampant and is reflected in relief manager movement (or lack thereof), as well as response time to calls for assistance. I've met both great and mediocre managers. The ability is there, but given the environment, the going belief is that you need to be this terrible, abusive wretch to be successful. Some of the bullying, lying and out right mistreatment of customers (simply because) leaves me disgusted. I can go on, and on, and on, but I think you get the idea. It takes Herculean efforts to force action against the "Preferred Few" or the hopelessly stuck that feel they can't find work elsewhere. I would advise folks to sell, donate or throw away whatever cannot fit where you are. The sadness of ridding yourself of those items is far less than the financial and emotional cost of the treatment that I've witnessed and the cost of having them go up for sale at auction anyway.

title: Easy, decent pay, heavy service oriented
pros: Being a Relief Manager for Public Storage is way easier than I ever thought it would be. I'd worked in retail for about 5 years prior to moving to this company and I thought that with the title "Manager", I was really going to be moving up in skills and pay. Reality is, everyone that works there has a "Manager" title. Relief Manager is the bottom tier, followed by Assistant Manager (making approximately $15/hour) and then Property Manager, (making about $16/hour). You typically work with 1-2 other people during the day. It's an easy job especially if you're decent at talking with people, cleaning and being able to fulfill basic duties. This job is also great if you like to sit in an office for the majority of your day. Most days, it feels like I get paid to sit around and wait for people to come by which isn't terrible (but boring). Overall, laid back and easy environment. All shifts are 9:30-6pm on weekdays and 9:30-5 on weekends.
cons: I find because this business deals with people's money, customers love to verbally abuse me when they're angry (I'm used to it though. Worked 5 years in retail and customer service already!). The District Managers are REALLY focused on getting reviews for their properties which can get annoying and frustrating. I find I'm bored a lot at this job and it just doesn't stimulate me enough most days.

title: Playing Favorites
pros: Easy to get time off when needed accrue PTO hours quickly
cons: DM has his FAVORITES he favors certain properties and does nothing for others....try to get issues fixed and he does not want to hear about it most of the time. He has very litle patience for dealing with people if you call him about an issue be ready to be talked to like an idiot he talks to us like we are less than him. When he is having a bad day then everyone knows about it. He is more concerned with HIS bonus and HIS review not ours. He tells is he wants us to succeed but we all feel like its a never ending battle. We used to get a bonus for merchandise sales, occupancy and delinquency now all they are giving bonus for is occupancy in this economy fer few got a bonus. So they basically took away part of our pay that many of us depended on. When I was hired on I really liked this job, now I just stay there since there are no other jobs to go to in Las Vegas right now.

title: Public Storage, Profits First
cons: istent and regular hours, decent rate of pay, and good initial training.

title: Unless you are in Upper Management you don 't have a full week-end off and salaries are very low..
pros: If you need a job without any degree and willing to accept minimum wage it's OK.They do offer some good benefits
cons: My son has been with Public Storage for many years and have yet to get a week-end off. Only managements get the goodies.The other little peons have to work their butts off, so that Management can have their Bonuses and Holidays and week-ends off. There is little chance for advancement.Even with a Degree.Management does not care that you have a family and that you would like to spend the week-end with them. Before on Sundays,we would be open until 2pm now we have to work until 5 pm. The greed is everywhere.

title: It's Toxic
pros: Set hours. I met some great people in my customers. If you like working on your own without direct supervision it may be for you.
cons: Pay is enough to survive on, barely. Upper management is out of touch with the front line. No room for advancement. They hire upper management from outside the company only. Every few months there is a new gimmick on how to make the company more money. Employees on the front line are treated as inferiors instead of the assets. They will bend over backwards for customers but will not take care of their employees or properly maintain the facilities because of budgetary constraints. They are more likely to answer to stock holders than those who are running the business on the front line. The employees can become catty gossips without proper direction. It can be like working in a small town where everyone is nice to your face. The environment breeds resentment toward fellow employees instead of teamwork. This is a very toxic place to work.

title: It's a good job, better than some I've had.
pros: I like my boss, and some co-workers, who are great people to work for. We all help each other out, when needed, which is great.
cons: There are some co-workers who are just "warm bodies" and I think it's sad that they are still around, when there are hard working and honest people out there that need a job, and who would do their job.

title: Great pay, no life
pros: pay is decent, hours can be very flexible, if you don't have a senior dm then you can run your district as you see fit
cons: no time off, never a day off, you can't even get away when you're on vacation, no auto allowance or reimbursement, no company provided cell phone, none of the normal allowances most companies offer for using your own equipment, zero ability to reward PMs who deserve it, forced to turn in shitty evaluations for employees who break their necks, never enough money in the budget to pay the bills

title: Use only as a possible stepping stone
pros: a good place to learn the hard, cruel world of Retail. You'll learn quickly to how to do the best job you can for the customer in spite of required scripts and robotics. The customers and co-workers are your only support system. However, if you see PS as a stepping stone to "somewhere-else" then it can be useful for a small time, but keep a safety net handy and plenty of ear plugs for the incessant whip cracking.
cons: emails, memos, and meetings are heavily riddled with threats regarding performance; management style is extreme micro-managing; stress levels and pressure are enormously out of proportion for the product. Storage has a built-in customer base; but PS browbeats it's employees for that one extra sale.

title: Stay far away from this place unless you are a retiree or someone with no future!
pros: The hours are great!! You will never get more than 40 hrs because they would rather die then to pay overtime! Never work nights you work no later than 6 pm! Got to meet a lot of nice people who were the customers and a few nice coworkers.
cons: Pay is terrible, THEY NEVER PROMOTE WITHIN!!! what kind of company would rather hire a district manager who managed several video stores than to promote a property manager who knows about storage???? Upper management tries there best to work with employees but corporate is always on their case to save money and cut costs. Employees are suppose to be a companies number 1 asset. at Public Storage they are known as their number one EXPENSE.

title: Robotic daily routine,no flexibility for days off,high expectations of performance even if calls are out of your control
pros: Decent pay but if you don't like strict structure, then do something else.
cons: I worked there many years so my schedule was 7am-3pm so my calls were good. If you're new, your hours are late and the calls are not good. Very hard to get a good schedule and to get time off. Very difficult to get promoted. In order to bonus, you must take time off work because taking less calls will get you to the bonus level. Sounds weird but the less you're on the phone, your bonus chances increase. But now you must work less meaning you get paid less all in the hopes of getting a bonus which is still not guaranteed. Your schedule is lottery so no days and times are guaranteed.

title: District Manager
pros: Decent pay after stock starts to kick in. Benefits are ok for a single person. Lots of autonomy. Great multi-unit experience. Great facilities, security, safety management experience. Very liquid company.
cons: Goals and expectations are very unrealistic. Corporate office is very disconnected from the field and have no idea what we do. Zero work/life balance and it gets worse the longer you are there. Regional Managers (your boss) do nothing except approve expense reports and have no purpose in the organization. The company has no idea what they want. Everything is pass/fail, with DMs set up for failure constantly. The audit process is the biggest farce I have ever seen that lacks credibility, relevance, and objectivity. The Property Managers are the most incompetant people with no skill-set, however the company expects results you would see from college graduates.

title: Run Forest, Run...
pros: The job is simple and there are no late nights.
cons: Field employees are treated like idiots. There is no promotional opportunity at the Property Manager level. Most of the time, District Managers are sent to "train" with Property Managers who earn 1/3 the salary. Employee safety is a joke - the company spends more time "worrying" about your use of leather gloves to pick up a sharp object, but does nothing when a customer comes into your office and threatens you.

title: Decent Job with no room for improvement
pros: -Hours. Off by 6 at the latest -Work at own pace -Gain vacation time quickly -You can work outside -Meet some interesting people
cons: -No room for advancement -Merchandise is somewhat over priced -Have to follow scripts that never go with what the customer wants -Pay -Hard to get a sick day. Ive tried to call off before but the DM couldn't get anyone to come in so I still had to work. - Property managers get paid the same as relief managers, yet are still held responsible for everything that goes wrong in their store.

title: Generally speaking, it's good experience but there's no opportunity to grow vertically.
pros: Good People to work with in our District, Good HR and Good Customers.
cons: A DEAD-END JOB for PROPERTY LEVEL MANAGEMENT.

title: Great Place to Work
pros: Public Storage is a great place to work! The company really cares about their employees and is always looking ahead to continue to provide their employees with a great experience. The CEO and Senior Leaders not only listen to the feedback provided by every employee in the company, but they act on this feedback. The culture is a very collaborative one where everyone works together to accomplish their goals.
cons: Public Storage is very innovative and competitive, ensuring that we provide the best for our customers and team. Because of this, as an employee, it is important to be open to change which can be tough for some.

title: PS needs improvement
pros: Shift is from 9:30am to 6:00pm on weekdays and closes early on weekends by 5:00pm. You will learn how to become independent
cons: Company's structure needs to improve. The job requires a lot of skills but employees are not well compensated. Most employees are aging that's why its hardtop implement some changes that can benefit mostly the company and the employees as well.

title: Not a job I would recomend
pros: Was once a great company to work for, but now the only thing left is the hours. I do have a good bunch of people I work with.
cons: If you want to work for little money, no chance of a raise because you've reached as high as you can go, learn new scripts every week, push locks, merchandise, an insurance on people, live in fear you will lose your job if your numbers aren't good every month then this is your place to work.

title: It's a job !!!!
pros: It's a stress free job ,with flexible hours and very friendly Co worker.
cons: The pay rate is low for a relief/property manager position and this company do not give any incentives to their employees. Every co-worker I met at this company complains about the pay and not getting any of incentives for sales.

title: Here's some info for RFs, PMs, and DMs
pros: You're in charge of your own day-to-day tasks. Given mileage reimbursement for travel. Uniforms are paid for by the company. 401K eligible quickly. PTO accrues pretty fast. You get a manager title (it doesn't mean much, but you still have the title). The are quarterly bonuses. I liked the people I worked with and for. I had a good DM and pretty good PMs. Notes for DMs: You are the lifeline for your PMs. They need you. They work by themselves and they need good support. they pay is good for a DM (from what I know). You will definitely work for it though.
cons: Pay isn't much. You aren't bonus eligible for six months. The company will change policies very fast and don't give the field adequate time to react. Often, they change things not just in theory but will even have time to get programers to change the system before they give their people a head's up about what's going on. Most properties do not have a location for you to eat lunch. You work alone most of the time. It doesn't feel very safe. There's no room for growth. You start as a PM and when you leave you'll be a PM. You will not be promoted any higher than that. It's all about the bottom line from the corporate side of things. What are you numbers? The "We Care" slogan applies more to the lower levels of the company, but they aren't given any power to do anything. There's a lot of turn over for property/relief managers. For DMs: Your PMs work 7 days a week. they need you 7 days a week. Tenants don't typically get to your level unless they are complaining. You will be dealing with the problems and the crazies.... Sorry, that's just how it is.

title: Great job for HS Graduate, dead end for people who went to college
pros: Regular hours Every day brings something new. Often left alone Not very hard work. Bonus can be great if you wok at the right property.
cons: Low pay. No opportunity to advance. You have to make delinquency calls. Merchandise is overpriced. Company sets rates to avoid paying bonus. Unrealistic sales demands.

title: Upper Management is KEY to retention of Good employees.
pros: * Hours of opperation * Ability to help customers with their problems * Enjoyable Co-workers * Bonus Program (if you undestand it and they don't change it) * Available Residence if you agree (pay is reduced to minimum wage with no chance of a raise)
cons: * Upper management does not answer their phone or return calls in a timely manner. * Ability to resolve customer issues thru District Manager not held in a timely manner. * Fear of loosing employment and/or houseing if you stand up for yourself. * Changing of policies and proceedures with no or short notice. * Bringing up issues with upper management about your direct management will make you a target for being fired. * Complaints reguarding co-workers/management is overlooked and are "swept under the rug." * Schedules are not available until the day before the upcoming week. * District Manager does not perform duties to company expectations. * Request for PTO is not accepted or rejected in a timely manner. * No promotion potential * Required to hold meetings on personal phone on your day off with no compensation. * If a death occurs, District Manager does not want to have overtime and finds way to not pay bereavement. * The list could go on...

title: Big responsibilities, itty bitty pay
pros: No need for a degree to get in. Broad corporate/administrative/customer service experience to be gained, with a hard lean on retail. Bonuses, and slightly better-than-McDonald’s pay.
cons: You need to have a broad range of skills - managerial, administration, customer service, janitorial, and retail - which you will need to juggle, sometimes simultaneously. You are the company’s first line of defence, so make sure you don’t drop the ball, because you will be the clients #1, and often, only target for complaints and confrontations (ranging from whining to full-on Academy Award nominee-contending meltdowns). Usually short-staffed, employees come and go, through a veritable revolving-door. Because of that, don’t expect them to love you if you need a couple of sick days. Schedules change frequently, and dramatically. You may have to work multiple locations, and adjust your working style to mesh with the local teams. As with any job, every location has a different set of personalities, so once you have one set figured out, and are able to feel comfortable, don’t get comfortable…you’ll be dropped-in with another team. The job also has heavy demand on employees to reach certain quotas every quarter, so prepare for a cold, ‘corporate panache’-laced, passive-aggressive talking-to, either through a surprise phone call, or within the 3-4+ hour monthly meetings. Sure there are bonuses and some perks including limited health and dental. But, including the bonuses, you’ll still have a hard time putting any money away. The income will allow you to just get by on a very humble lifestyle. Certainly not worth the level of stress you must endure on. Regular basis.

title: Under Paid For Job Requirements
pros: Excellent hours. Fun environment. Good People. Good training.
cons: Property Managers and Relief Managers are not paid what they are worth for the job they are expected to do. There are not enough employees to run locations when someone calls in sick or wants vacation. There is no "management" at the stores, District Managers are expected to manage everyone. There is no advancement for Property Managers so there is no company buy in.

title: "This business pukes cash"
pros: This company is stable and is doing well financially. To quote the CEO with one of his famous inappropriate quotes: "This business pukes cash". Unfortunately, you won't see any of it.
cons: Any positive review written on this company is either enforced by the management or written by them. Public Storage is not a people business, the leadership doesn't care about the people and will do anything to cut back on pay, PTO, benefits, etc. Pay is very low and possibilities to grow only to the level of property manager. You will have to work based on scripts and will be micromanaged. Very little respect for the people that actually do the work.

title: Assistant Manager
pros: This is a great place to work. You voice is heard and they teat you fairly. The job is not too difficult, and most of the employees are nice.
cons: The only thing I did not like was it is up to the employees to remove dead animals and rodents, I did not like this. Thankfully it is not a daily thing.

title: Ask a "Mile" of you, but policy only allows you to give an "Inch"
pros: Work with little supervision and living expenses are generally paid for (rent, utilities, etc -- as most properties supply a two bedroom apt).
cons: Thefts on the property and comforting a disappointed customer who feels violated.

title: Good but not career at the bottom level.
pros: Lots of space from the boss, they are not behind you telling you what to do. It gives you some freedom to be a self starter.
cons: Getting stuck with a poor DM, they can make you love or hate this job. Company changes policies every few months.

title: BS not PS
pros: Minimal supervison by upper management and paid time off accrues quickly. Customers were, for the most part, the best aspect of the job.
cons: Working for this company for 5 yrs ( only because I had a family to support ) was a huge eye-opener. To sum it up: low wages, zero advancement, disrespectful, backstabbing, manipulative and immoral group. Not a fun place to work ( or store ). They only care about their bonuses not their people.

title: Not the best or worst job
pros: apartment onsite for property managers cheap with utilities included and never work nights
cons: It Takes forever for anything to get fixed and everything has to be approved by upper management. Role plays are expected for all communication with customers

title: Micro-Managed
pros: The benefits are not the greatest but at least you get the option.
cons: Working for Public Storage for over 2 years now and have received 2 annual bonuses...both under $.20ph. I have yet to make over $10 an hour with this employer. A few months ago the bonus system was a good contributor to make the low wages seem not as bad, unfortunately they (Corp) have since changed the structure of the bonus system to where if you get a bonus you really don't notice it. I am a property manager at a facility with over 450 storage units and work alone more times than not. I have a golf cart tire that has been flat for over a month and the company refuses to fix it. I have units that have abandoned goods but the company refuses to pay to get them cleaned out so i have to drag all the furniture across the property...these are just smaller inconveniences whilst our new COO makes over half a million annually...As a property manager I have no power, that has been stripped from us. What the owners of this company wants is robots not individuals. Not only does this company treat its employees like garbage they also treat the customers extremely bad. The longer you rent a unit the more money you have to pay (it increases every year).

title: Great job for new managers
pros: Great job to improve your management and communication skills with customers, employees, and management. Heavy interaction with customers as well as competitors.
cons: Unless you live in area of corporate office, no room for advancement unless District Manager leaves.

title: Company treats you well
pros: They offer great bonus opportunity. It is a also the type of company that appreciates their people and awards hard work.
cons: There are a lot of hours involved even though they say that you will be done by 6pm each day.But I guess that is something that comes along with a management role.

title: Bad Company Decent Job
pros: If you enjoy working with the public this is a good place, if you enjoy giving great customer service this is a place where the customers will respond warmly to you, the hours are consistent.
cons: Low pay, bad benefits, we are actively encouraged to lie to customers, no advancement beyond the store, dysfunctional corporate culture etc....

title: two years experiance.
pros: Good schedule. Off at 6pm during the week and 5 on the weekend. Managers normally will work to make sure you get the requested days off.
cons: Never enough coverage. If you are sick or have an emergency its like pulling teeth to get the time off needed because "there is nobody to cover"

title: Poor place to work
pros: None None None None None
cons: Worked at Public Storage for 8 yrs and several months. Upper management talks down to the property managers. Public Storage needs to realize that the property managers are the key to this companies success. Horrible pay not all employees have access to running water or a place to use the restroom. Can't believe I was all these yrs on this company.
